1: ¶Of Mans First Disobedience, and the Fruit
2: Of that Forbidden Tree, whose mortal tast
3: Brought Death into the World, and all our woe,
4: With loss of *Eden*, till one greater Man
5: Restore us, and regain the blissful Seat,
6: Sing Heav'nly Muse, that on the secret top
8: That Shepherd, who first taught the chosen Seed,
9: In the Beginning how the Heav'ns and Earth
10: Rose out of *Chaos*: Or if *Sion* Hill
11: Delight thee more, and *Siloa's* Brook that flow'd
12: Fast by the Oracle of God; I thence
13: Invoke thy aid to my adventrous Song,
14: That with no middle flight intends to soar
15: Above th' *Aonian* Mount, while it pursues
16: Things unattempted yet in Prose or Rhime.
17: And chiefly Thou O Spirit, that dost prefer
18: Before all Temples th' upright heart and pure,
19: Instruct me, for Thou know'st; Thou from the first
20: Wast present, and with mighty wings outspread
21: Dove-like satst brooding on the vast Abyss
22: And mad'st it pregnant: What in me is dark
23: Illumine, what is low raise and support;
24: That to the highth of this great Argument
25: I may assert th' Eternal Providence,
26: And justifie the wayes of God to men.
27: ¶Say first, for Heav'n hides nothing from thy view
28: Nor the deep Tract of Hell, say first what cause
29: Mov'd our Grand Parents in that happy State,
30: Favour'd of Heav'n so highly, to fall off
31: From their Creator, and transgress his Will
32: For one restraint, Lords of the World besides?
33: Who first seduc'd them to that fowl revolt?
34: Th' infernal Serpent; he it was, whose guile
35: Stird up with Envy and Revenge, deceiv'd
36: The Mother of Mankinde, what time his Pride
37: Had cast him out from Heav'n, with all his Host
38: Of Rebel Angels, by whose aid aspiring
39: To set himself in Glory above his Peers,
40: He trusted to have equal'd the most High,
41: If he oppos'd; and with ambitious aim
42: Against the Throne and Monarchy of God
43: Rais'd impious War in Heav'n and Battel proud
44: With vain attempt.  Him the Almighty Power
45: Hurld headlong flaming from th' Ethereal Skie
46: With hideous ruine and combustion down
47: To bottomless perdition, there to dwell
48: In Adamantine Chains and penal Fire,
49: Who durst defie th' Omnipotent to Arms.
50: Nine times the Space that measures Day and Night
51: To mortal men, he with his horrid crew
52: Lay vanquisht, rowling in the fiery Gulfe
53: Confounded though immortal: But his doom
54: Reserv'd him to more wrath; for now the thought
55: Both of lost happiness and lasting pain
56: Torments him; round he throws his baleful eyes
57: That witness'd huge affliction and dismay
58: Mixt with obdurate pride and stedfast hate:
59: At once as far as Angels kenn he views
60: The dismal Situation waste and wilde,
61: A Dungeon horrible, on all sides round
62: As one great Furnace flam'd, yet from those flames
63: No light, but rather darkness visible
64: Serv'd only to discover sights of woe,
65: Regions of sorrow, doleful shades, where peace
66: And rest can never dwell, hope never comes
67: That comes to all; but torture without end
68: Still urges, and a fiery Deluge, fed
70: Such place Eternal Justice had prepar'd
71: For those rebellious, here their Prison ordain'd
72: In utter darkness, and their portion set
73: As far remov'd from God and light of Heav'n
74: As from the Center thrice to th' utmost Pole.
75: O how unlike the place from whence they fell!
76: There the companions of his fall, o'rewhelm'd
77: With Floods and Whirlwinds of tempestuous fire,
78: He soon discerns, and weltring by his side
79: One next himself in power, and next in crime,
80: Long after known in *Palestine*, and nam'd
82: And thence in Heav'n call'd Satan, with bold words
83: Breaking the horrid silence thus began.
84: ¶If thou beest he; But O how fall'n! how chang'd
85: From him, who in the happy Realms of Light
86: Cloth'd with transcendent brightnes didst outshine
87: Myriads though bright: If he whom mutual league,
88: United thoughts and counsels, equal hope,
89: And hazard in the Glorious Enterprize,
90: Joynd with me once, now misery hath joynd
91: In equal ruin: into what Pit thou seest
92: From what highth fal'n, so much the stronger provd
93: He with his Thunder: and till then who knew
94: The force of those dire Arms? yet not for those
95: Nor what the Potent Victor in his rage
96: Can else inflict do I repent or change,
97: Though chang'd in outward lustre; that fixt mind
98: And high disdain, from sence of injur'd merit,
99: That with the mightiest rais'd me to contend,
100: And to the fierce contention brought along
102: That durst dislike his reign, and me preferring,
103: His utmost power with adverse power oppos'd
104: In dubious Battel on the Plains of Heav'n,
105: And shook his throne.  What though the field be lost?
106: All is not lost; the unconquerable Will,
107: And study of revenge, immortal hate,
108: And courage never to submit or yield:
109: And what is else not to be overcome?
110: That Glory never shall his wrath or might
111: Extort from me.  To bow and sue for grace
112: With suppliant knee, and deifie his power
113: Who from the terrour of this Arm so late
114: Doubted his Empire, that were low indeed,
115: That were an ignominy and shame beneath
116: This downfall; since by Fate the strength of Gods
117: And this Empyreal substance cannot fail,
118: Since through experience of this great event
119: In Arms not worse, in foresight much advanc't,
120: We may with more successful hope resolve
121: To wage by force or guile eternal Warr
123: Who now triumphs, and in th' excess of joy
124: Sole reigning holds the Tyranny of Heav'n.
125: ¶So spake th' Apostate Angel, though in pain,
126: Vaunting aloud, but rackt with deep despare:
127: And him thus answer'd soon his bold Compeer.
128: ¶O Prince, O Chief of many Throned Powers,
129: That led th' imbattelld Seraphim to Warr
130: Under thy conduct, and in dreadful deeds
132: And put to proof his high Supremacy,
133: Whether upheld by strength, or Chance, or Fate,
134: Too well I see and rue the dire event,
135: That with sad overthrow and foul defeat
136: Hath lost us Heav'n, and all this mighty Host
137: In horrible destruction laid thus low,
138: As far as Gods and Heav'nly Essences
139: Can Perish: for the mind and spirit remains
141: Though all our Glory extinct, and happy state
142: Here swallow'd up in endless misery.
143: But what if he our Conquerour, (whom I now
144: Of force believe Almighty, since no less
145: Then such could hav orepow'rd such force as ours)
146: Have left us this our spirit and strength intire
147: Strongly to suffer and support our pains,
148: That we may so suffice his vengeful ire,
149: Or do him mightier service as his thralls
150: By right of Warr, what e're his business be
151: Here in the heart of Hell to work in Fire,
152: Or do his Errands in the gloomy Deep;
153: What can it then avail though yet we feel
156: Whereto with speedy words th' Arch-fiend reply'd.
157: ¶Fall'n Cherube, to be weak is miserable
158: Doing or Suffering: but of this be sure,
159: To do ought good never will be our task,
160: But ever to do ill our sole delight,
161: As being the contrary to his high will
162: Whom we resist.  If then his Providence
163: Out of our evil seek to bring forth good,
164: Our labour must be to pervert that end,
165: And out of good still to find means of evil;
166: Which oft times may succeed, so as perhaps
167: Shall grieve him, if I fail not, and disturb
168: His inmost counsels from their destind aim.
169: But see the angry Victor hath recall'd
170: His Ministers of vengeance and pursuit
171: Back to the Gates of Heav'n: The Sulphurous Hail
172: Shot after us in storm, oreblown hath laid
173: The fiery Surge, that from the Precipice
174: Of Heav'n receiv'd us falling, and the Thunder,
175: Wing'd with red Lightning and impetuous rage,
176: Perhaps hath spent his shafts, and ceases now
177: To bellow through the vast and boundless Deep.
178: Let us not slip th' occasion, whether scorn,
179: Or satiate fury yield it from our Foe.
180: Seest thou yon dreary Plain, forlorn and wilde,
181: The seat of desolation, voyd of light,
182: Save what the glimmering of these livid flames
183: Casts pale and dreadful?  Thither let us tend
184: From off the tossing of these fiery waves,
185: There rest, if any rest can harbour there,
187: Consult how we may henceforth most offend
188: Our Enemy, our own loss how repair,
190: What reinforcement we may gain from Hope,
191: If not what resolution from despare.
192: ¶Thus Satan talking to his neerest Mate
193: With Head up-lift above the wave, and Eyes
194: That sparkling blaz'd, his other Parts besides
195: Prone on the Flood, extended long and large
196: Lay floating many a rood, in bulk as huge
197: As whom the Fables name of monstrous size,
200: By ancient *Tarsus* held, or that Sea-beast
201: *Leviathan*, which God of all his works
202: Created hugest that swim th' Ocean stream:
203: Him haply slumbring on the *Norway* foam
204: The Pilot of some small night-founder'd Skiff,
205: Deeming some Island, oft, as Sea-men tell,
206: With fixed Anchor in his skaly rind
207: Moors by his side under the Lee, while Night
208: Invests the Sea, and wished Morn delayes:
209: So stretcht out huge in length the Arch-fiend lay
210: Chain'd on the burning Lake, nor ever thence
211: Had ris'n or heav'd his head, but that the will
212: And high permission of all-ruling Heaven
213: Left him at large to his own dark designs,
214: That with reiterated crimes he might
215: Heap on himself damnation, while he sought
216: Evil to others, and enrag'd might see
217: How all his malice serv'd but to bring forth
218: Infinite goodness, grace and mercy shewn
219: On Man by him seduc't, but on himself
220: Treble confusion, wrath and vengeance pour'd.
221: Forthwith upright he rears from off the Pool
222: His mighty Stature; on each hand the flames
223: Drivn backward slope their pointing spires, & rowld
224: In billows, leave i'th' midst a horrid Vale.
225: Then with expanded wings he stears his flight
226: Aloft, incumbent on the dusky Air
227: That felt unusual weight, till on dry Land
228: He lights, if it were Land that ever burn'd
229: With solid, as the Lake with liquid fire;
230: And such appear'd in hue, as when the force
231: Of subterranean wind transports a Hill
232: Torn from *Pelorus*, or the shatter'd side
234: And fewel'd entrals thence conceiving Fire,
235: Sublim'd with Mineral fury, aid the Winds,
236: And leave a singed bottom all involv'd
237: With stench and smoak: Such resting found the sole
238: Of unblest feet.  Him followed his next Mate,
239: Both glorying to have scap't the *Stygian* flood
240: As Gods, and by their own recover'd strength,
241: Not by the sufferance of supernal Power.
242: ¶Is this the Region, this the Soil, the Clime,
243: Said then the lost Arch Angel, this the seat
244: That we must change for Heav'n, this mournful gloom
245: For that celestial light?  Be it so, since hee
246: Who now is Sovran can dispose and bid
247: What shall be right: fardest from him is best
248: Whom reason hath equald, force hath made supream
249: Above his equals.  Farewel happy Fields
250: Where Joy for ever dwells: Hail horrours, hail
251: Infernal world, and thou profoundest Hell
252: Receive thy new Possessor: One who brings
253: A mind not to be chang'd by Place or Time.
254: The mind is its own place, and in it self
255: Can make a Heav'n of Hell, a Hell of Heav'n.
256: What matter where, if I be still the same,
257: And what I should be, all but less then hee
258: Whom Thunder hath made greater?  Here at least
259: We shall be free; th' Almighty hath not built
260: Here for his envy, will not drive us hence:
261: Here we may reign secure, and in my choyce
262: To reign is worth ambition though in Hell:
263: Better to reign in Hell, then serve in Heav'n.
264: But wherefore let we then our faithful friends,
265: Th' associates and copartners of our loss
266: Lye thus astonisht on th' oblivious Pool,
267: And call them not to share with us their part
268: In this unhappy Mansion, or once more
269: With rallied Arms to try what may be yet
270: Regaind in Heav'n, or what more lost in Hell?
272: Thus answer'd.  Leader of those Armies bright,
273: Which but th' Omnipotent none could have foyld,
274: If once they hear that voyce, their liveliest pledge
275: Of hope in fears and dangers, heard so oft
276: In worst extreams, and on the perilous edge
277: Of battel when it rag'd, in all assaults
278: Their surest signal, they will soon resume
279: New courage and revive, though now they lye
280: Groveling and prostrate on yon Lake of Fire,
281: As we erewhile, astounded and amaz'd,
282: No wonder, fall'n such a pernicious highth.
283: ¶He scarce had ceas't when the superiour Fiend
284: Was moving toward the shore; his ponderous shield
285: Ethereal temper, massy, large and round,
286: Behind him cast; the broad circumference
287: Hung on his shoulders like the Moon, whose Orb
288: Through Optic Glass the *Tuscan* Artist views
289: At Ev'ning from the top of *Fesole*,
290: Or in *Valdarno*, to descry new Lands,
291: Rivers or Mountains in her spotty Globe.
292: His Spear, to equal which the tallest Pine
293: Hewn on *Norwegian* hills, to be the Mast
294: Of some great Ammiral, were but a wand,
295: He walkt with to support uneasie steps
296: Over the burning Marle, not like those steps
297: On Heavens Azure, and the torrid Clime
298: Smote on him sore besides, vaulted with Fire;
299: Nathless he so endur'd, till on the Beach
300: Of that inflamed Sea, he stood and call'd
301: His Legions, Angel Forms, who lay intrans't
302: Thick as Autumnal Leaves that strow the Brooks
304: High overarch't imbowr; or scatterd sedge
305: Afloat, when with fierce Winds *Orion* arm'd
306: Hath vext the Red-Sea Coast, whose waves orethrew
308: While with perfidious hatred they pursu'd
310: From the safe shore their floating Carkases
311: And broken Chariot Wheels, so thick bestrown
312: Abject and lost lay these, covering the Flood,
313: Under amazement of their hideous change.
314: He call'd so loud, that all the hollow Deep
316: Warriers, the Flowr of Heav'n, once yours, now lost,
317: If such astonishment as this can sieze
318: Eternal spirits; or have ye chos'n this place
319: After the toyl of Battel to repose
320: Your wearied vertue, for the ease you find
321: To slumber here, as in the Vales of Heav'n?
322: Or in this abject posture have ye sworn
323: To adore the Conquerour? who now beholds
324: Cherube and Seraph rowling in the Flood
325: With scatter'd Arms and Ensigns, till anon
326: His swift pursuers from Heav'n Gates discern
327: Th' advantage, and descending tread us down
328: Thus drooping, or with linked Thunderbolts
329: Transfix us to the bottom of this Gulfe.
330: Awake, arise, or be for ever fall'n.
331: ¶They heard, and were abasht, and up they sprung
332: Upon the wing, as when men wont to watch
333: On duty, sleeping found by whom they dread,
334: Rouse and bestir themselves ere well awake.
335: Nor did they not perceave the evil plight
336: In which they were, or the fierce pains not feel;
337: Yet to their Generals Voyce they soon obeyd
338: Innumerable.  As when the potent Rod
340: Wav'd round the Coast, up call'd a pitchy cloud
341: Of *Locusts*, warping on the Eastern Wind,
342: That ore the Realm of impious *Pharoah* hung
343: Like Night, and darken'd all the Land of *Nile*:
344: So numberless were those bad Angels seen
345: Hovering on wing under the Cope of Hell
347: Till, as a signal giv'n, th' uplifted Spear
348: Of their great Sultan waving to direct
349: Thir course, in even ballance down they light
350: On the firm brimstone, and fill all the Plain;
351: A multitude, like which the populous North
352: Pour'd never from her frozen loyns, to pass
353: *Rhene* or the *Danaw*, when her barbarous Sons
354: Came like a Deluge on the South, and spread
356: Forthwith from every Squadron and each Band
357: The Heads and Leaders thither hast where stood
358: Their great Commander; Godlike shapes and forms
360: And Powers that earst in Heaven sat on Thrones;
361: Though of their Names in heav'nly Records now
362: Be no memorial, blotted out and ras'd
363: By thir Rebellion, from the Books of Life.
364: Nor had they yet among the Sons of *Eve*
365: Got them new Names, till wandring ore the Earth,
366: Through Gods high sufferance for the tryal of man,
367: By falsities and lyes the greatest part
368: Of Mankind they corrupted to forsake
369: God their Creator, and th' invisible
370: Glory of him, that made them, to transform
371: Oft to the Image of a Brute, adorn'd
372: With gay Religions full of Pomp and Gold,
373: And Devils to adore for Deities:
374: Then were they known to men by various Names,
375: And various Idols through the Heathen World.
376: Say, Muse, their Names then known, who first, who last,
377: Rous'd from the slumber, on that fiery Couch,
378: At thir great Emperors call, as next in worth
379: Came singly where he stood on the bare strand,
380: While the promiscuous croud stood yet aloof?
381: The chief were those who from the Pit of Hell
382: Roaming to seek their prey on earth, durst fix
383: Their Seats long after next the Seat of God,
384: Their Altars by his Altar, Gods ador'd
385: Among the Nations round, and durst abide
387: Between the Cherubim; yea, often plac'd
388: Within his Sanctuary it self their Shrines,
390: His holy Rites, and solemn Feasts profan'd,
391: And with their darkness durst affront his light.
392: First *Moloch*, horrid King besmear'd with blood
393: Of human sacrifice, and parents tears,
394: Though for the noyse of Drums and Timbrels loud
395: Their childrens cries unheard, that past through fire
396: To his grim Idol.  Him the *Ammonite*
397: Worshipt in *Rabba* and her watry Plain,
398: In *Argob* and in *Basan*, to the stream
399: Of utmost *Arnon*.  Nor content with such
401: Of *Solomon* he led by fraud to build
402: His Temple right against the Temple of God
403: On that opprobrious Hill, and made his Grove
405: And black *Gehenna* call'd, the Type of Hell.
406: Next *Chemos*, th' obscene dread of *Moabs* Sons,
410: The flowry Dale of *Sibma* clad with Vines,
412: *Peor* his other Name, when he entic'd
414: To do him wanton rites, which cost them woe.
415: Yet thence his lustful Orgies he enlarg'd
416: Even to that Hill of scandal, by the Grove
417: Of *Moloch* homicide, lust hard by hate;
418: Till good *Josiah* drove them thence to Hell.
419: With these came they, who from the bordring flood
420: Of old *Euphrates* to the Brook that parts
423: These Feminine.  For Spirits when they please
424: Can either Sex assume, or both; so soft
425: And uncompounded is their Essence pure,
426: Not ti'd or manacl'd with joynt or limb,
427: Nor founded on the brittle strength of bones,
428: Like cumbrous flesh; but in what shape they choose
429: Dilated or condens't, bright or obscure,
431: And works of love or enmity fulfill.
432: For those the Race of *Israel* oft forsook
433: Their living strength, and unfrequented left
434: His righteous Altar, bowing lowly down
435: To bestial Gods; for which their heads as low
436: Bow'd down in Battel, sunk before the Spear
437: Of despicable foes.  With these in troop
439: *Astarte*, Queen of Heav'n, with crescent Horns;
440: To whose bright Image nightly by the Moon
441: *Sidonian* Virgins paid their Vows and Songs,
442: In *Sion* also not unsung, where stood
443: Her Temple on th' offensive Mountain, built
444: By that uxorious King, whose heart though large,
446: To Idols foul. *Thammuz* came next behind,
448: The *Syrian* Damsels to lament his fate
449: In amorous dittyes all a Summers day,
450: While smooth *Adonis* from his native Rock
451: Ran purple to the Sea, suppos'd with blood
454: Whose wanton passions in the sacred Porch
455: *Ezekiel* saw, when by the Vision led
456: His eye survay'd the dark Idolatries
458: Who mourn'd in earnest, when the Captive Ark
459: Maim'd his brute Image, head and hands lopt off
460: In his own Temple, on the grunsel edge,
461: Where he fell flat, and sham'd his Worshipers:
462: *Dagon* his Name, Sea Monster, upward Man
463: And downward Fish: yet had his Temple high
464: Rear'd in *Azotus*, dreaded through the Coast
468: Was fair *Damscus*, on the fertil Banks
470: He also against the house of God was bold:
471: A Leper once he lost and gain'd a King,
472: *Ahaz* his sottish Conquerour, whom he drew
473: Gods Altar to disparage and displace
474: For one of *Syrian* mode, whereon to burn
475: His odious offrings, and adore the Gods
476: Whom he had vanquisht. After these appear'd
477: A crew who under Names of old Renown,
479: With monstrous shapes and sorceries abus'd
480: Fanatic *Egypt* and her Priests, to seek
481: Thir wandring Gods disguis'd in brutish forms
482: Rather then human.  Nor did *Israel* scape
483: Th' infection when their borrow'd Gold compos'd
484: The Calf in *Oreb*: and the Rebel King
485: Doubl'd that sin in *Bethel* and in *Dan*,
486: Lik'ning his Maker to the Grazed Ox,
487: *Jehovah*, who in one Night when he pass'd
488: From *Egypt* marching, equal'd with one stroke
489: Both her first born and all her bleating Gods.
490: *Belial* came last, then whom a Spirit more lewd
491: Fell not from Heaven, or more gross to love
492: Vice for it self: To him no Temple stood
493: Or Altar smoak'd; yet who more oft then hee
494: In Temples and at Altars, when the Priest
495: Turns Atheist, as did *Ely's* Sons, who fill'd
496: With lust and violence the house of God.
497: In Courts and Palaces he also Reigns
498: And in luxurious Cities, where the noyse
499: Of riot ascends above thir loftiest Towrs,
500: And injury and outrage: And when Night
501: Darkens the Streets, then wander forth the Sons
502: Of *Belial*, flown with insolence and wine.
503: Witness the Streets of *Sodom*, and that night
505: Yielded thir Matrons to prevent worse rape.
506: These were the prime in order and in might;
507: The rest were long to tell, though far renown'd,
509: Gods, yet confest later then Heav'n and Earth
510: Thir boasted Parents; *Titian* Heav'ns first born
511: With his enormous brood, and birthright seis'd
513: His own and *Rhea's* Son like measure found;
514: So *Jove* usurping reign'd: these first in *Creet*
515: And *Ida* known, thence on the Snowy top
516: Of cold *Olympus* rul'd the middle Air
517: Thir highest Heav'n; or on the *Delphian* Cliff,
518: Or in *Dodona*, and through all the bounds
519: Of *Doric* Land; or who with *Saturn* old
521: And ore the *Celtic* roam'd the utmost Isles.
522: All these and more came flocking; but with looks
523: Down cast and damp, yet such wherein appear'd
524: Obscure som glimps of joy, to have found thir chief
525: Not in despair, to have found themselves not lost
526: In loss it self; which on his count'nance cast
527: Like doubtful hue: but he his wonted pride
528: Soon recollecting, with high words, that bore
529: Semblance of worth not substance, gently rais'd
530: Their fainted courage, and dispel'd their fears.
531: Then strait commands that at the warlike sound
532: Of Trumpets loud and Clarions be upreard
533: His mighty Standard; that proud honour claim'd
534: *Azazel* as his right, a Cherube tall:
535: Who forthwith from the glittering Staff unfurld
536: Th' Imperial Ensign, which full high advanc't
537: Shon like a Meteor streaming to the Wind
538: With Gemms and Golden lustre rich imblaz'd,
539: Seraphic arms and Trophies: all the while
541: At which the universal Host upsent
542: A shout that tore Hells Concave, and beyond
543: Frighted the Reign of *Chaos* and old Night.
544: All in a moment through the gloom were seen
545: Ten thousand Banners rise into the Air
546: With Orient Colours waving: with them rose
547: A Forrest huge of Spears: and thronging Helms
548: Appear'd, and serried Shields in thick array
549: Of depth immeasurable: Anon they move
550: In perfect *Phalanx* to the Dorian mood
551: Of Flutes and soft Recorders; such as rais'd
552: To highth of noblest temper Hero's old
553: Arming to Battel, and in stead of rage
554: Deliberate valour breath'd, firm and unmov'd
555: With dread of death to flight or foul retreat,
556: Nor wanting power to mitigate and swage
557: With solemn touches, troubl'd thoughts, and chase
558: Anguish and doubt and fear and sorrow and pain
559: From mortal or immortal minds.  Thus they
560: Breathing united force with fixed thought
561: Mov'd on in silence to soft Pipes that charm'd
562: Thir painful steps o're the burnt soyle; and now
563: Advanc't in view they stand, a horrid Front
564: Of dreadful length and dazling Arms, in guise
565: Of Warriers old with order'd Spear and Shield,
566: Awaiting what command thir mighty Chief
567: Had to impose: He through the armed Files
568: Darts his experienc't eye, and soon traverse
569: The whole Battalion views, thir order due,
570: Thir visages and stature as of Gods,
571: Thir number last he summs.  And now his heart
572: Distends with pride, and hardning in his strength
573: Glories: For never since created man,
574: Met such imbodied force, as nam'd with these
575: Could merit more then that small infantry
576: Warr'd on by Cranes: though all the Giant brood
577: Of *Phlegra* with th' Heroic Race were joyn'd
578: That fought at *Theb's* and *Ilium*, on each side
579: Mixt with auxiliar Gods; and what resounds
582: And all who since, Baptiz'd or Infidel
586: When *Charlemain* with all his Peerage fell
588: Compare of mortal prowess, yet observ'd
589: Thir dread Commander: he above the rest
590: In shape and gesture proudly eminent
591: Stood like a Towr; his form had yet not lost
592: All her Original brightness, nor appear'd
593: Less then Arch Angel ruind, and th' excess
594: Of Glory obscur'd: As when the Sun new ris'n
595: Looks through the Horizontal misty Air
596: Shorn of his Beams, or from behind the Moon
597: In dim Eclips disastrous twilight sheds
598: On half the Nations, and with fear of change
599: Perplexes Monarchs.  Dark'n'd so, yet shon
600: Above them all th' Arch Angel: but his face
601: Deep scars of Thunder had intrencht, and care
602: Sat on his faded cheek, but under Browes
603: Of dauntless courage, and considerate Pride
604: Waiting revenge: cruel his eye, but cast
605: Signs of remorse and passion to behold
606: The fellows of his crime, the followers rather
607: (Far other once beheld in bliss) condemn'd
608: For ever now to have their lot in pain,
609: Millions of Spirits for his fault amerc't
610: Of Heav'n, and from Eternal Splendors flung
611: For his revolt, yet faithfull how they stood,
612: Thir Glory witherd.  As when Heavens Fire
613: Hath scath'd the Forrest Oaks, or Mountain Pines,
614: With singed top their stately growth though bare
615: Stands on the blasted Heath.  He now prepar'd
616: To speak; whereat their doubl'd Ranks they bend
617: From Wing to Wing, and half enclose him round
618: With all his Peers: attention held them mute.
619: Thrice he assayd, and thrice in spite of scorn,
620: Tears such as Angels weep, burst forth: at last
621: Words interwove with sighs found out their way.
622: ¶O Myriads of immortal Spirits, O Powers
623: Matchless, but with th' Almighty, and that strife
624: Was not inglorious, though th' event was dire,
625: As this place testifies, and this dire change
626: Hateful to utter: but what power of mind
627: Foreseeing or presaging, from the Depth
628: Of knowledge past or present, could have fear'd,
629: How such united force of Gods, how such
630: As stood like these, could ever know repulse?
631: For who can yet beleeve, though after loss,
632: That all these puissant Legions, whose exile
633: Hath emptied Heav'n, shall faile to re-ascend
634: Self-rais'd, and repossess their native seat.
635: For me, be witness all the Host of Heav'n,
636: If counsels different, or danger shun'd
637: By me, have lost our hopes.  But he who reigns
638: Monarch in Heav'n, till then as one secure
639: Sat on his Throne, upheld by old repute,
640: Consent or custome, and his Regal State
641: Put forth at full, but still his strength conceal'd,
642: Which tempted our attempt, and wrought our fall.
643: Henceforth his might we know, and know our own
644: So as not either to provoke, or dread
645: New warr, provok't; our better part remains
646: To work in close design, by fraud or guile
647: What force effected not: that he no less
648: At length from us may find, who overcomes
649: By force, hath overcome but half his foe.
650: Space may produce new Worlds; whereof so rife
651: There went a fame in Heav'n that he ere long
652: Intended to create, and therein plant
653: A generation, whom his choice regard
654: Should favour equal to the Sons of Heaven:
655: Thither, if but to prie, shall be perhaps
656: Our first eruption, thither or elsewhere:
657: For this Infernal Pit shall never hold
658: Caelestial Spirits in Bondage, nor th' Abysse
659: Long under darkness cover.  But these thoughts
660: Full Counsel must mature: Peace is despaird,
661: For who can think Submission?  Warr then, Warr
662: Open or understood must be resolv'd.
663: ¶He spake: and to confirm his words, out-flew
664: Millions of flaming swords, drawn from the thighs
665: Of mighty Cherubim; the sudden blaze
666: Far round illumin'd hell: highly they rag'd
667: Against the Highest, and fierce with grasped arm's
668: Clash'd on their sounding shields the din of war,
669: Hurling defiance toward the vault of Heav'n.
670: ¶There stood a Hill not far whose griesly top
671: Belch'd fire and rowling smoak; the rest entire
672: Shon with a glossie scurff, undoubted sign
673: That in his womb was hid metallic Ore,
674: The work of Sulphur.  Thither wing'd with speed
675: A numerous Brigad hasten'd.  As when bands
676: Of Pioners with Spade and Pickaxe arm'd
677: Forerun the Royal Camp, to trench a Field,
678: Or cast a Rampart.  *Mammon* led them on,
679: *Mammon*, the least erected Spirit that fell
680: From heav'n, for ev'n in heav'n his looks & thoughts
681: Were always downward bent, admiring more
682: The riches of Heav'ns pavement, trod'n Gold,
683: Then aught divine or holy else enjoy'd
684: In vision beatific: by him first
685: Men also, and by his suggestion taught,
686: Ransack'd the Center, and with impious hands
687: Rifl'd the bowels of thir mother Earth
688: For Treasures better hid.  Soon had his crew
689: Op'nd into the Hill a spacious wound
690: And dig'd out ribs of Gold.  Let none admire
691: That riches grow in Hell; that soyle may best
692: Deserve the pretious bane.  And here let those
693: Who boast in mortal things, and wondring tell
694: Of *Babel*, and the works of *Memphian* Kings,
695: Learn how thir greatest Monuments of Fame,
696: And Strength and Art are easily outdone
697: By Spirits reprobate, and in an hour
698: What in an age they with incessant toyle
700: Nigh on the Plain in many cells prepar'd,
701: That underneath had veins of liquid fire
702: Sluc'd from the Lake, a second multitude
703: With wondrous Art founded the massie Ore,
704: Severing each kinde, and scum'd the Bullion dross:
705: A third as soon had form'd within the ground
706: A various mould, and from the boyling cells
707: By strange conveyance fill'd each hollow nook,
708: As in an Organ from one blast of wind
709: To many a row of Pipes the sound-board breaths.
710: Anon out of the earth a Fabrick huge
711: Rose like an Exhalation, with the sound
712: Of Dulcet Symphonies and voices sweet,
713: Built like a Temple, where *Pilasters* round
714: Were set, and Doric pillars overlaid
715: With Golden Architrave; nor did there want
716: Cornice or Freeze, with bossy Sculptures grav'n,
717: The Roof was fretted Gold.  Not *Babilon*,
719: Equal'd in all thir glories, to inshrine
722: In wealth and luxurie.  Th' ascending pile
723: Stood fixt her stately highth, and strait the dores
724: Op'ning thir brazen foulds discover wide
725: Within, her ample spaces, o're the smooth
726: And level pavement: from the arched roof
727: Pendant by suttle Magic many a row
728: Of Starry Lamps and blazing Cressets fed
730: As from a sky.  The hasty multitude
731: Admiring enter'd, and the work some praise
732: And some the Architect: his hand was known
733: In Heav'n by many a Towred structure high,
734: Where Scepter'd Angels held thir residence,
735: And sat as Princes, whom the supreme King
736: Exalted to such power, and gave to rule,
737: Each in his Herarchie, the Orders bright.
738: Nor was his name unheard or unador'd
739: In ancient Greece; and in *Ausonian* land
740: Men call'd him *Mulciber*; and how he fell
741: From Heav'n, they fabl'd, thrown by angry *Jove*
742: Sheer o're the Chrystal Battlements: from Morn
743: To Noon he fell, from Noon to dewy Eve,
744: A Summers day; and with the setting Sun
745: Dropt from the Zenith like a falling Star,
746: On *Lemnos* th' *Aegaean* Ile: thus they relate,
747: Erring; for he with this rebellious rout
748: Fell long before; nor aught avail'd him now
749: To have built in Heav'n high Towrs; nor did he scape
750: By all his Engins, but was headlong sent
751: With his industrious crew to build in hell.
752: Mean while the winged Haralds by command
753: Of Sovran power, with awful Ceremony
754: And Trumpets sound throughout the Host proclaim
755: A solemn Councel forthwith to be held
757: Of Satan and his Peers: thir summons call'd
758: From every and Band squared Regiment
759: By place or choice the worthiest; they anon
760: With hundreds and with thousands trooping came
761: Attended: all access was throng'd, the Gates
762: And Porches wide, but chief the spacious Hall
763: (Though like a cover'd field, where Champions bold
764: Wont ride in arm'd, and at the Soldans chair
765: Defi'd the best of Panim chivalry
766: To mortal combat or carreer with Lance)
767: Thick swarm'd, both on the ground and in the air,
768: Brusht with the hiss of russling wings.  As Bees
769: In spring time, when the Sun with Taurus rides,
770: Poure forth thir populous youth about the Hive
771: In clusters; they among fresh dews and flowers
772: Flie to and fro, or on the smoothed Plank,
773: The suburb of thir Straw-built Cittadel,
774: New rub'd with Baume, expatiate and confer
775: Thir State affairs.  So thick the aerie crowd
776: Swarm'd and were straitn'd; till the Signal giv'n,
777: Behold a wonder! they but now who seemd
778: In bigness to surpass Earths Giant Sons
779: Now less then smallest Dwarfs, in narrow room
780: Throng numberless, like that Pigmean Race
781: Beyond the *Indian* Mount, or Faerie Elves,
782: Whose midnight Revels, by a Forrest side
783: Or Fountain fome belated Peasant sees,
784: Or dreams he sees, while over head the Moon
785: Sits Arbitress, and neerer to the Earth
786: Wheels her pale course, they on thir mirth & dance
787: Intent, with jocond Music charm his ear;
788: At once with joy and fear his heart rebounds.
789: Thus incorporeal Spirits to smallest forms
790: Reduc'd thir shapes immense, and were at large,
791: Though without number still amidst the Hall
792: Of that infernal Court.  But far within
793: And in thir own dimensions like themselves
794: The great Seraphic Lords and Cherubim
795: In close recess and secret conclave sat
796: A thousand Demy-Gods on golden seat's,
797: Frequent and full.  After short silence then
798: And summons read, the great consult began.
800: ¶High on a Throne of Royal State, which far
801: Outshon the wealth of *Ormus* and of *Ind*,
802: Or where the gorgeous East with richest hand
803: Showrs on her Kings *Barbaric* Pearl & Gold,
804: Satan exalted sat, by merit rais'd
805: To that bad eminence; and from despair
806: Thus high uplifted beyond hope, aspires
807: Beyond thus high, insatiate to pursue
808: Vain Warr with Heav'n, and by success untaught
811: For since no deep within her gulf can hold
812: Immortal vigor, though opprest and fall'n,
813: I give not Heav'n for lost.  From this descent
815: More glorious and more dread then from no fall,
816: And trust themselves to fear no second fate:
817: Mee though just right, and the fixt Laws of Heav'n
818: Did first create your Leader, next, free choice,
819: With what besides, in Counsel or in Fight,
820: Hath bin achievd of merit, yet this loss
821: Thus farr at least recover'd, hath much more
822: Establisht in a safe unenvied Throne
823: Yeilded with full consent.  The happier state
824: In Heav'n, which follows dignity, might draw
825: Envy from each inferior; but who here
826: Will envy whom the highest place exposes
827: Formost to stand against the Thunderers aime
828: Your bulwark, and condemns to greatest share
829: Of endless pain? where there is then no good
830: For which to strive, no strife can grow up there
831: From Faction; for none sure will claim in hell
832: Precedence, none, whose portion is so small
833: Of present pain, that with ambitious mind
834: Will covet more.  With this advantage then
835: To union, and firm Faith, and firm accord,
836: More then can be in Heav'n, we now return
837: To claim our just inheritance of old,
839: Could have assur'd us; and by what best way,
840: Whether of open Warr or covert guile,
841: We now debate; who can advise, may speak.
842: ¶He ceas'd, and next him *Moloc*, Scepter'd King
843: Stood up, the strongest and the fiercest Spirit
844: That fought in Heav'n; now fiercer by despair:
845: His trust was with th' Eternal to be deem'd
846: Equal in strength, and rather then be less
847: Car'd not to be at all; with that care lost
848: Went all his fear: of God, or Hell, or worse
849: He reckd not, and these words thereafter spake.
850: ¶My sentence is for open Warr: Of Wiles,
851: More unexpert, I boast not: them let those
852: Contrive who need, or when they need, not now.
853: For while they sit contriving, shall the rest,
854: Millions that stand in Arms, and longing wait
855: The Signal to ascend, sit lingring here
856: Heav'ns fugitives, and for thir dwelling place
857: Accept this dark opprobrious Den of shame,
858: The Prison of his Tyranny who Reigns
859: By our delay? no, let us rather choose
860: Arm'd with Hell flames and fury all at once
861: O're Heav'ns high Towrs to force resistless way,
862: Turning our Tortures into horrid Arms
863: Against the Torturer; when to meet the noise
864: Of his Almighty Engin he shall hear
865: Infernal Thunder, and for Lightning see
866: Black fire and horror shot with equal rage
867: Among his Angels; and his Throne it self
868: Mixt with *Tartarean* Sulphur, and strange fire,
869: His own invented Torments.  But perhaps
870: The way seems difficult and steep to scale
871: With upright wing against a higher foe.
872: Let such bethink them, if the sleepy drench
873: Of that forgetful Lake benumme not still,
874: That in our proper motion we ascend
875: Up to our native seat: descent and fall
876: To us is adverse.  Who but felt of late
877: When the fierce Foe hung on our brok'n Rear
878: Insulting, and pursu'd us through the Deep,
879: With what compulsion and laborious flight
880: We sunk thus low?  Th' ascent is easie then;
881: Th' event is fear'd; should we again provoke
882: Our stronger, some worse way his wrath may find
883: To our destruction: if there be in Hell
884: Fear to be worse destroy'd: what can be worse
885: Then to dwell here, driv'n out from bliss, condemn'd
886: In this abhorred deep to utter woe;
888: Must exercise us without hope of end
889: The Vassals of his anger, when the Scourge
891: Calls us to Penance?  More destroy'd then thus
892: We should be quite abolisht and expire.
893: What fear we then? what doubt we to incense
894: His utmost ire? which to the highth enrag'd,
895: Will either quite consume us, and reduce
896: To nothing this essential, happier farr
897: Then miserable to have eternal being:
898: Or if our substance be indeed Divine,
899: And cannot cease to be, we are at worst
900: On this side nothing; and by proof we feel
901: Our power sufficient to disturb his Heav'n,
902: And with perpetual inrodes to Allarme,
904: Which if not Victory is yet Revenge.
905: ¶He ended frowning, and his look denounc'd
907: To less then Gods.  On th' other side up rose
908: *Belial*, in act more graceful and humane;
909: A fairer person lost not Heav'n; he seemd
910: For dignity compos'd and high exploit:
911: But all was false and hollow; though his Tongue
912: Dropt Manna, and could make the worse appear
913: The better reason, to perplex and dash
914: Maturest Counsels: for his thoughts were low;
915: To vice industrious, but to Nobler deeds
916: Timorous and slothful: yet he pleas'd the eare,
917: And with perswasive accent thus began.
918: ¶I should be much for open Warr, O Peers,
919: As not behind in hate; if what was urg'd
920: Main reason to perswade immediate Warr,
921: Did not disswade me most, and seem to cast
922: Ominous conjecture on the whole success:
923: When he who most excels in fact of Arms,
924: In what he counsels and in what excels
925: Mistrustful, grounds his courage on despair
926: And utter dissolution, as the scope
927: Of all his aim, after some dire revenge.
928: First, what Revenge? the Towrs of Heav'n are fill'd
929: With Armed watch, that render all access
930: Impregnable; oft on the bordering Deep
931: Encamp thir Legions, or with obscure wing
932: Scout farr and wide into the Realm of night,
933: Scorning surprize.  Or could we break our way
934: By force, and at our heels all Hell should rise
936: Heav'ns purest Light, yet our great Enemie
937: All incorruptible would on his Throne
938: Sit unpolluted, and th' Ethereal mould
939: Incapable of stain would soon expel
940: Her mischief, and purge off the baser fire
941: Victorious.  Thus repuls'd, our final hope
942: Is flat despair: we must exasperate
943: Th' Almighty Victor to spend all his rage,
944: And that must end us, that must be our cure,
945: To be no more; sad cure; for who would loose,
946: Though full of pain, this intellectual being,
947: Those thoughts that wander through Eternity,
948: To perish rather, swallowd up and lost
949: In the wide womb of uncreated night,
950: Devoid of sense and motion? and who knows,
951: Let this be good, whether our angry Foe
952: Can give it, or will ever? how he can
953: Is doubtful; that he never will is sure.
954: Will he, so wise, let loose at once his ire,
956: To give his Enemies thir wish, and end
957: Them in his anger, whom his anger saves
958: To punish endless? wherefore cease we then?
959: Say they who counsel Warr, we are decreed,
960: Reserv'd and destin'd to Eternal woe;
961: Whatever doing, what can we suffer more,
962: What can we suffer worse? is this then worst,
963: Thus sitting, thus consulting, thus in Arms?
964: What when we fled amain, pursu'd and strook
965: With Heav'ns afflicting Thunder, and besought
966: The Deep to shelter us? this Hell then seem'd
967: A refuge from those wounds: or when we lay
968: Chain'd on the burning Lake? that sure was worse.
969: What if the breath that kindl'd those grim fires
970: Awak'd should blow them into sevenfold rage
971: And plunge us in the Flames? or from above
973: His red right hand to plague us? what if all
974: Her stores were op'n'd, and this Firmament
975: Of Hell should spout her Cataracts of Fire,
977: One day upon our heads; while we perhaps
979: Caught in a fierie Tempest shall be hurl'd
980: Each on his rock transfixt, the sport and prey
981: Of racking whirlwinds, or for ever sunk
982: Under yon boyling Ocean, wrapt in Chains;
983: There to converse with everlasting groans,
985: Ages of hopeless end; this would be worse.
986: Warr therefore, open or conceal'd, alike
987: My voice disswades; for what can force or guile
988: With him, or who deceive his mind, whose eye
989: Views all things at one view? he from heav'ns highth
990: All these our motions vain, sees and derides;
991: Not more Almighty to resist our might
992: Then wise to frustrate all our plots and wiles.
993: Shall we then live thus vile, the race of Heav'n
994: Thus trampl'd, thus expell'd to suffer here
995: Chains & these Torments? better these then worse
996: By my advice; since fate inevitable
998: The Victors will.  To suffer, as to doe,
999: Our strength is equal, nor the Law unjust
1000: That so ordains: this was at first resolv'd,
1001: If we were wise, against so great a foe
1002: Contending, and so doubtful what might fall.
1003: I laugh, when those who at the Spear are bold
1004: And vent'rous, if that fail them, shrink and fear
1005: What yet they know must follow, to endure
1006: Exile, or ignominy, or bonds, or pain,
1007: The sentence of thir Conquerour: This is now
1008: Our doom; which if we can sustain and bear,
1009: Our Supream Foe in time may much remit
1010: His anger, and perhaps thus farr remov'd
1011: Not mind us not offending, satisfi'd
1012: With what is punish't; whence these raging fires
1013: Will slack'n, if his breath stir not thir flames.
1014: Our purer essence then will overcome
1015: Thir noxious vapour, or enur'd not feel,
1016: Or chang'd at length, and to the place conformd
1017: In temper and in nature, will receive
1018: Familiar the fierce heat, and void of pain;
1019: This horror will grow milde, this darkness light,
1020: Besides what hope the never-ending flight
1021: Of future days may bring, what chance, what change
1022: Worth waiting, since our present lot appeers
1023: For happy though but ill, for ill not worst,
1024: If we procure not to our selves more woe.
1025: ¶Thus *Belial* with words cloath'd in reasons garb
1026: Counsel'd ignoble ease, and peaceful sloath,
1027: Not peace: and after him thus *Mammon* spake.
1028: ¶Either to disinthrone the King of Heav'n
1029: We warr, if warr be best, or to regain
1030: Our own right lost: him to unthrone we then
1031: May hope, when everlasting Fate shall yeild
1032: To fickle Chance, and *Chaos* judge the strife:
1033: The former vain to hope argues as vain
1034: The latter: for what place can be for us
1035: Within Heav'ns bound, unless Heav'ns Lord supream
1036: We overpower?  Suppose he should relent
1037: And publish Grace to all, on promise made
1038: Of new Subjection; with what eyes could we
1039: Stand in his presence humble, and receive
1040: Strict Laws impos'd, to celebrate his Throne
1041: With warbl'd Hymns, and to his Godhead sing
1042: Forc't Halleluiah's; while he Lordly sits
1043: Our envied Sovran, and his Altar breathes
1045: Our servile offerings.  This must be our task
1046: In Heav'n, this our delight; how wearisom
1047: Eternity so spent in worship paid
1048: To whom we hate.  Let us not then pursue
1049: By force impossible, by leave obtain'd
1050: Unacceptable, though in Heav'n, our state
1051: Of splendid vassalage, but rather seek
1052: Our own good from our selves, and from our own
1053: Live to our selves, though in this vast recess,
1054: Free, and to none accountable, preferring
1055: Hard liberty before the easie yoke
1056: Of servile Pomp.  Our greatness will appear
1057: Then most conspicuous, when great things of small,
1058: Useful of hurtful, prosperous of adverse
1059: We can create, and in what place so e're
1060: Thrive under evil, and work ease out of pain
1061: Through labour and endurance.  This deep world
1062: Of darkness do we dread?  How oft amidst
1063: Thick clouds and dark doth Heav'ns all-ruling Sire
1064: Choose to reside, his Glory unobscur'd,
1065: And with the Majesty of darkness round
1066: Covers his Throne; from whence deep thunders roar
1067: Must'ring thir rage, and Heav'n resembles Hell?
1068: As he our Darkness, cannot we his Light
1069: Imitate when we please?  This Desart soile
1070: Wants not her hidden lustre, Gemms and Gold;
1071: Nor want we skill or art, from whence to raise
1072: Magnificence; and what can Heav'n shew more?
1073: Our torments also may in length of time
1074: Become our Elements, these piercing Fires
1075: As soft as now severe, our temper chang'd
1076: Into their temper; which must needs remove
1077: The sensible of pain.  All things invite
1078: To peaceful Counsels, and the settl'd State
1079: Of order, how in safety best we may
1080: Compose our present evils, with regard
1081: Of what we are and where, dismissing quite
1082: All thoughts of Warr: ye have what I advise.
1083: ¶He scarce had finisht, when such murmur filld
1084: Th' Assembly, as when hollow Rocks retain
1085: The sound of blustring winds, which all night long
1086: Had rous'd the Sea, now with hoarse cadence lull
1087: Sea-faring men orewatcht, whose Bark by chance
1088: Or Pinnace anchors in a craggy Bay
1089: After the Tempest: Such applause was heard
1090: As *Mammon* ended, and his Sentence pleas'd,
1091: Advising peace: for such another Field
1092: They dreaded worse then Hell: so much the fear
1093: Of Thunder and the Sword of *Michael*
1094: Wrought still within them; and no less desire
1095: To found this nether Empire, which might rise
1096: By pollicy, and long process of time,
1099: *Satan* except, none higher sat, with grave
1100: Aspect he rose, and in his rising seem'd
1101: A Pillar of State; deep on his Front engraven
1103: And Princely counsel in his face yet shon,
1104: Majestick though in ruin: sage he stood
1106: The weight of mightiest Monarchies; his look
1107: Drew audience and attention still as Night
1108: Or Summers Noon-tide air, while thus he spake.
1109: ¶Thrones and imperial Powers, off-spring of heav'n,
1110: Ethereal Vertues; or these Titles now
1111: Must we renounce, and changing stile be call'd
1112: Princes of Hell? for so the popular vote
1113: Inclines, here to continue, and build up here
1114: A growing Empire; doubtless; while we dream,
1115: And know not that the King of Heav'n hath doom'd
1116: This place our dungeon, not our safe retreat
1117: Beyond his Potent arm, to live exempt
1118: From Heav'ns high jurisdiction, in new League
1119: Banded against his Throne, but to remaine
1120: In strictest bondage, though thus far remov'd,
1122: His captive multitude: For he, be sure,
1123: In highth or depth, still first and last will Reign
1124: Sole King, and of his Kingdom loose no part
1125: By our revolt, but over Hell extend
1126: His Empire, and with Iron Scepter rule
1127: Us here, as with his Golden those in Heav'n.
1128: What sit we then projecting Peace and Warr?
1129: Warr hath determin'd us, and foild with loss
1130: Irreparable; tearms of peace yet none
1131: Voutsaf't or sought; for what peace will be giv'n
1132: To us enslav'd, but custody severe,
1134: Inflicted? and what peace can we return,
1135: But to our power hostility and hate,
1136: Untam'd reluctance, and revenge though slow,
1137: Yet ever plotting how the Conquerour least
1138: May reap his conquest, and may least rejoyce
1139: In doing what we most in suffering feel?
1140: Nor will occasion want, nor shall we need
1142: Heav'n, whose high walls fear no assault or Siege,
1143: Or ambush from the Deep.  What if we find
1144: Some easier enterprize?  There is a place
1145: (If ancient and prophetic fame in Heav'n
1146: Err not) another World, the happy seat
1147: Of som new Race call'd *Man*, about this time
1148: To be created like to us, though less
1149: In power and excellence, but favour'd more
1150: Of him who rules above; so was his will
1151: Pronounc'd among the Gods, and by an Oath,
1152: That shook Heav'ns whol circumference, confirm'd.
1153: Thither let us bend all our thoughts, to learn
1154: What creatures there inhabit, of what mould,
1155: Or substance, how endu'd, and what thir Power,
1156: And where thir weakness, how attempted best,
1157: By force or suttlety: Though Heav'n be shut,
1158: And Heav'ns high Arbitrator sit secure
1159: In his own strength, this place may lye expos'd
1160: The utmost border of his Kingdom, left
1161: To their defence who hold it: here perhaps
1162: Som advantagious act may be achiev'd
1163: By sudden onset, either with Hell fire
1164: To waste his whole Creation, or possess
1165: All as our own, and drive as we were driven,
1166: The punie habitants, or if not drive,
1167: Seduce them to our Party, that thir God
1168: May prove thir foe, and with repenting hand
1169: Abolish his own works.  This would surpass
1170: Common revenge, and interrupt his joy
1171: In our Confusion, and our Joy upraise
1172: In his disturbance; when his darling Sons
1173: Hurl'd headlong to partake with us, shall curse
1174: Thir frail Originals, and faded bliss,
1175: Faded so soon.  Advise if this be worth
1176: Attempting, or to sit in darkness here
1178: Pleaded his devilish Counsel, first devis'd
1179: By *Satan*, and in part propos'd: for whence,
1180: But from the Author of all ill could Spring
1181: So deep a malice, to confound the race
1182: Of mankind in one root, and Earth with Hell
1183: To mingle and involve, done all to spite
1184: The great Creatour?  But thir spite still serves
1185: His glory to augment.  The bold design
1186: Pleas'd highly those infernal States, and joy
1187: Sparkl'd in all thir eyes; with full assent
1188: They vote: whereat his speech he thus renews.
1189: ¶Well have ye judg'd, well ended long debate,
1190: Synod of Gods, and like to what ye are,
1191: Great things resolv'd; which from the lowest deep
1192: Will once more lift us up, in spight of Fate,
1193: Neerer our ancient Seat; perhaps in view
1194: Of those bright confines, whence with neighbouring Arms
1195: And opportune excursion we may chance
1196: Re-enter Heav'n; or else in some milde Zone
1197: Dwell not unvisited of Heav'ns fair Light
1198: Secure, and at the brightning Orient beam
1199: Purge off this gloom; the soft delicious Air,
1200: To heal the scarr of these corrosive Fires
1201: Shall breath her balme.  But first whom shall we send
1202: In search of this new world, whom shall we find
1203: Sufficient? who shall tempt with wandring feet
1205: And through the palpable obscure find out
1206: His uncouth way, or spread his aerie flight
1208: Over the vast abrupt, ere he arrive
1209: The happy Ile; what strength, what art can then
1210: Suffice, or what evasion bear him safe
1211: Through the strict Senteries and Stations thick
1212: Of Angels watching round?  Here he had need
1213: All circumspection, and we now no less
1214: Choice in our suffrage; for on whom we send,
1215: The weight of all and our last hope relies.
1216: ¶This said, he sat; and expectation held
1217: His look suspence, awaiting who appeer'd
1218: To second, or oppose, or undertake
1219: The perilous attempt: but all sat mute,
1220: Pondering the danger with deep thoughts; & each
1221: In others count'nance red his own dismay
1222: Astonisht: none among the choice and prime
1223: Of those Heav'n-warring Champions could be found
1224: So hardie as to proffer or accept
1225: Alone the dreadful voyage; till at last
1227: Above his fellows, with Monarchal pride
1228: Conscious of highest worth, unmov'd thus spake.
1230: With reason hath deep silence and demurr
1231: Seis'd us, though undismaid: long is the way
1232: And hard, that out of Hell leads up to Light;
1233: Our prison strong, this huge convex of Fire,
1234: Outrageous to devour, immures us round
1235: Ninefold, and gates of burning Adamant
1236: Barr'd over us prohibit all egress.
1237: These past, if any pass, the void profound
1238: Of unessential Night receives him next
1239: Wide gaping, and with utter loss of being
1240: Threatens him, plung'd in that abortive gulf.
1241: If thence he scape into what ever world,
1242: Or unknown Region, what remains him less
1243: Then unknown dangers and as hard escape.
1244: But I should ill become this Throne, O Peers,
1246: With splendor, arm'd with power, if aught propos'd
1247: And judg'd of public moment, in the shape
1248: Of difficulty or danger could deterre
1249: Me from attempting.  Wherefore do I assume
1250: These Royalties, and not refuse to Reign,
1251: Refusing to accept as great a share
1252: Of hazard as of honour, due alike
1253: To him who Reigns, and so much to him due
1254: Of hazard more, as he above the rest
1255: High honourd sits?  Go therfore mighty powers,
1256: Terror of Heav'n, though fall'n; intend at home,
1257: While here shall be our home, what best may ease
1258: The present misery, and render Hell
1259: More tollerable; if there be cure or charm
1260: To respite or deceive, or slack the pain
1261: Of this ill Mansion: intermit no watch
1262: Against a wakeful Foe, while I abroad
1263: Through all the coasts of dark destruction seek
1264: Deliverance for us all: this enterprize
1265: None shall partake with me.  Thus saying rose
1266: The Monarch, and prevented all reply,
1267: Prudent, least from his resolution rais'd
1268: Others among the chief might offer now
1269: (Certain to be refus'd) what erst they feard;
1270: And so refus'd might in opinion stand
1271: His rivals, winning cheap the high repute
1272: Which he through hazard huge must earn.  But they
1273: Dreaded not more th' adventure then his voice
1274: Forbidding; and at once with him they rose;
1275: Thir rising all at once was as the sound
1276: Of Thunder heard remote.  Towards him they bend
1277: With awful reverence prone; and as a God
1278: Extoll him equal to the highest in Heav'n:
1279: Nor fail'd they to express how much they prais'd,
1280: That for the general safety he despis'd
1281: His own: for neither do the Spirits damn'd
1282: Loose all thir vertue; least bad men should boast
1283: Thir specious deeds on earth, which glory excites,
1284: Or close ambition varnisht o're with zeal.
1285: Thus they thir doubtful consultations dark
1286: Ended rejoycing in thir matchless Chief:
1287: As when from mountain tops the dusky clouds
1288: Ascending, while the North wind sleeps, o'respread
1289: Heav'ns chearful face, the lowring Element
1290: Scowls ore the dark'nd lantskip Snow, or showre;
1291: If chance the radiant Sun with farewell sweet
1292: Extend his ev'ning beam, the fields revive,
1293: The birds thir notes renew, and bleating herds
1294: Attest thir joy, that hill and valley rings.
1295: O shame to men!  Devil with Devil damn'd
1296: Firm concord holds, men onely disagree
1297: Of Creatures rational, though under hope
1298: Of heavenly Grace: and God proclaiming peace,
1299: Yet live in hatred, enmitie, and strife
1300: Among themselves, and levie cruel warres,
1301: Wasting the Earth, each other to destroy:
1302: As if (which might induce us to accord)
1303: Man had not hellish foes anow besides,
1304: That day and night for his destruction waite.
1306: In order came the grand infernal Peers,
1307: Midst came thir mighty Paramount, and seemd
1308: Alone th' Antagonist of Heav'n, nor less
1309: Then Hells dread Emperour with pomp Supream,
1310: And God-like imitated State; him round
1311: A Globe of fierie Seraphim inclos'd
1312: With bright imblazonrie, and horrent Arms.
1313: Then of thir Session ended they bid cry
1314: With Trumpets regal sound the great result:
1315: Toward the four winds four speedy Cherubim
1316: Put to thir mouths the sounding Alchymie
1317: By Haralds voice explain'd: the hollow Abyss
1318: Heard farr and wide, and all the host of Hell
1319: With deafning shout, return'd them loud acclaim.
1320: Thence more at ease thir minds and somwhat rais'd
1321: By false presumptuous hope, the ranged powers
1322: Disband, and wandring, each his several way
1323: Pursues, as inclination or sad choice
1324: Leads him perplext, where he may likeliest find
1325: Truce to his restless thoughts, and entertain
1326: The irksome hours, till his great Chief return.
1327: Part on the Plain, or in the Air sublime
1328: Upon the wing, or in swift race contend,
1329: As at th' Olympian Games or *Pythian* fields;
1330: Part curb thir fierie Steeds, or shun the Goal
1331: With rapid wheels, or fronted Brigads form.
1332: As when to warn proud Cities warr appears
1333: Wag'd in the troubl'd Skie, and Armies rush
1334: To Battel in the Clouds, before each Van
1335: Pric forth the Aerie Knights, and couch thir spears
1336: Till thickest Legions close; with feats of Arms
1337: From either end of Heav'n the welkin burns.
1338: Others with vast *Typhoean* rage more fell
1339: Rend up both Rocks and Hills, and ride the Air
1340: In whirlwind; Hell scarce holds the wilde uproar.
1342: With conquest, felt th' envenom'd robe, and tore
1343: Through pain up by the roots *Thessalian* Pines,
1344: And *Lichas* from the top of *Oeta* threw
1345: Into th' *Euboic* Sea.  Others more milde,
1346: Retreated in a silent valley, sing
1347: With notes Angelical to many a Harp
1348: Thir own Heroic deeds and hapless fall
1349: By doom of Battel; and complain that Fate
1350: Free Vertue should enthrall to Force or Chance.
1351: Thir song was partial, but the harmony
1352: (What could it less when Spirits immortal sing?)
1353: Suspended Hell, and took with ravishment
1354: The thronging audience.  In discourse more sweet
1355: (For Eloquence the Soul, Song charms the Sense,)
1356: Others apart sat on a Hill retir'd,
1357: In thoughts more elevate, and reason'd high
1358: Of Providence, Foreknowledge, Will, and Fate,
1359: Fixt Fate, free will, foreknowledge absolute,
1360: And found no end, in wandring mazes lost.
1361: Of good and evil much they argu'd then,
1363: Passion and Apathie, and glory and shame,
1364: Vain wisdom all, and false Philosophie:
1365: Yet with a pleasing sorcerie could charm
1366: Pain for a while or anguish, and excite
1367: Fallacious hope, or arm th' obdured brest
1368: With stubborn patience as with triple steel.
1369: Another part in Squadrons and gross Bands,
1370: On bold adventure to discover wide
1371: That dismal world, if any Clime perhaps
1372: Might yeild them easier habitation, bend
1373: Four ways thir flying March, along the Banks
1374: Of four infernal Rivers that disgorge
1375: Into the burning Lake thir baleful streams;
1376: Abhorred *Styx* the flood of deadly hate,
1377: Sad *Acheron* of sorrow, black and deep;
1379: Heard on the ruful stream; fierce *Phlegeton*
1380: Whose waves of torrent fire inflame with rage.
1381: Farr off from these a slow and silent stream,
1383: Her watrie Labyrinth, whereof who drinks,
1384: Forthwith his former state and being forgets,
1385: Forgets both joy and grief, pleasure and pain.
1386: Beyond this flood a frozen Continent
1387: Lies dark and wilde, beat with perpetual storms
1388: Of Whirlwind and dire Hail, which on firm land
1389: Thaws not, but gathers heap, and ruin seems
1390: Of ancient pile; all else deep snow and ice,
1391: A gulf profound as that *Serbonian* Bog
1393: Where Armies whole have sunk: the parching Air
1394: Burns frore, and cold performs th' effect of Fire.
1396: At certain revolutions all the damn'd
1397: Are brought: and feel by turns the bitter change
1398: Of fierce extreams, extreams by change more fierce,
1399: From Beds of raging Fire to starve in Ice
1400: Thir soft Ethereal warmth, and there to pine
1402: Periods of time, thence hurried back to fire.
1404: Both to and fro, thir sorrow to augment,
1405: And wish and struggle, as they pass, to reach
1406: The tempting stream, with one small drop to loose
1407: In sweet forgetfulness all pain and woe,
1408: All in one moment, and so neer the brink;
1409: But fate withstands, and to oppose th' attempt
1411: The Ford, and of it self the water flies
1412: All taste of living wight, as once it fled
1413: The lip of *Tantalus*.  Thus roving on
1414: In confus'd march forlorn, th' adventrous Bands
1415: With shuddring horror pale, and eyes agast
1416: View'd first thir lamentable lot, and found
1417: No rest: through many a dark and drearie Vaile
1418: They pass'd, and many a Region dolorous,
1419: O're many a Frozen, many a Fierie Alpe,
1420: Rocks, Caves, Lakes, Fens, Bogs, Dens, and shades of death,
1421: A Universe of death, which God by curse
1422: Created evil, for evil only good,
1423: Where all life dies, death lives, and nature breeds,
1424: Perverse, all monstrous, all prodigious things,
1426: Then Fables yet have feign'd, or fear conceiv'd,
1428: ¶Mean while the Adversary of God and Man,
1429: *Satan* with thoughts inflam'd of highest design,
1430: Puts on swift wings, and toward the Gates of Hell
1431: Explores his solitary flight; som times
1432: He scours the right hand coast, som times the left,
1433: Now shaves with level wing the Deep, then soares
1434: Up to the fiery concave touring high.
1435: As when farr off at Sea a Fleet descri'd
1436: Hangs in the Clouds, by *Aequinoctial* Winds
1437: Close sailing from *Bengala*, or the Iles
1439: Thir spicie Drugs: they on the trading Flood
1440: Through the wide *Ethiopian* to the Cape
1441: Ply stemming nightly toward the Pole.  So seem'd
1442: Farr off the flying Fiend: at last appeer
1443: Hell bounds high reaching to the horrid Roof,
1444: And thrice threefold the Gates; three folds were Brass
1445: Three Iron, three of Adamantine Rock,
1447: Yet unconsum'd.  Before the Gates there sat
1448: On either side a formidable shape;
1449: The one seem'd Woman to the waste, and fair,
1450: But ended foul in many a scaly fould
1451: Voluminous and vast, a Serpent arm'd
1452: With mortal sting: about her middle round
1453: A cry of Hell Hounds never ceasing bark'd
1454: With wide *Cerberean* mouths full loud, and rung
1455: A hideous Peal: yet, when they list, would creep,
1456: If aught disturb'd thir noyse, into her woomb,
1457: And kennel there, yet there still bark'd and howl'd
1458: Within unseen.  Farr less abhorrd then these
1459: Vex'd *Scylla* bathing in the Sea that parts
1461: Nor uglier follow the Night-Hag, when call'd
1462: In secret, riding through the Air she comes
1463: Lur'd with the smell of infant blood, to dance
1464: With *Lapland* Witches, while the labouring Moon
1465: Eclipses at thir charms.  The other shape,
1466: If shape it might be call'd that shape had none
1467: Distinguishable in member, joynt, or limb,
1468: Or substance might be call'd that shadow seem'd,
1469: For each seem'd either; black it stood as Night,
1470: Fierce as ten Furies, terrible as Hell,
1471: And shook a dreadful Dart; what seem'd his head
1472: The likeness of a Kingly Crown had on.
1473: *Satan* was now at hand, and from his seat
1474: The Monster moving onward came as fast,
1475: With horrid strides, Hell trembled as he strode.
1476: Th' undaunted Fiend what this might be admir'd,
1477: Admir'd, not fear'd; God and his Son except,
1478: Created thing naught vallu'd he nor shun'd;
1479: And with disdainful look thus first began.
1480: ¶Whence and what art thou, execrable shape,
1481: That dar'st, though grim and terrible, advance
1482: Thy miscreated Front athwart my way
1483: To yonder Gates? through them I mean to pass,
1484: That be assur'd, without leave askt of thee:
1485: Retire, or taste thy folly, and learn by proof,
1486: Hell-born, not to contend with Spirits of Heav'n.
1487: ¶To whom the Goblin full of wrauth reply'd,
1488: Art thou that Traitor Angel, art thou hee,
1489: Who first broke peace in Heav'n and Faith, till then
1490: Unbrok'n, and in proud rebellious Arms
1491: Drew after him the third part of Heav'ns Sons
1492: Conjur'd against the highest, for which both Thou
1493: And they outcast from God, are here condemn'd
1494: To waste Eternal daies in woe and pain?
1495: And reck'n'st thou thy self with Spirits of Heav'n,
1496: Hell-doomd, and breath'st defiance here and scorn,
1497: Where I reign King, and to enrage thee more,
1498: Thy King and Lord?  Back to thy punishment,
1499: False fugitive, and to thy speed add wings,
1500: Least with a whip of Scorpions I pursue
1501: Thy lingring, or with one stroke of this Dart
1502: Strange horror seise thee, and pangs unfelt before.
1503: ¶So spake the grieslie terrour, and in shape,
1504: So speaking and so threatning, grew ten fold
1505: More dreadful and deform: on th' other side
1507: Unterrifi'd, and like a Comet burn'd,
1508: That fires the length of *Ophiucus* huge
1509: In th' Artick Sky, and from his horrid hair
1510: Shakes Pestilence and Warr.  Each at the Head
1511: Level'd his deadly aime; thir fatall hands
1512: No second stroke intend, and such a frown
1513: Each cast at th' other, as when two black Clouds
1514: With Heav'ns Artillery fraught, come rattling on
1515: Over the *Caspian*, then stand front to front
1516: Hov'ring a space, till Winds the signal blow
1517: To joyn thir dark Encounter in mid air:
1518: So frownd the mighty Combatants, that Hell
1519: Grew darker at thir frown, so matcht they stood;
1520: For never but once more was either like
1521: To meet so great a foe: and now great deeds
1522: Had been achiev'd, whereof all Hell had rung,
1523: Had not the Snakie Sorceress that sat
1524: Fast by Hell Gate, and kept the fatal Key,
1525: Ris'n, and with hideous outcry rush'd between.
1526: ¶O Father, what intends thy hand, she cry'd,
1527: Against thy only Son?  What fury O Son,
1528: Possesses thee to bend that mortal Dart
1529: Against thy Fathers head? and know'st for whom;
1530: For him who sits above and laughs the while
1531: At thee ordain'd his drudge, to execute
1532: What e're his wrath, which he calls Justice, bids,
1533: His wrath which one day will destroy ye both.
1534: ¶She spake, and at her words the hellish Pest
1535: Forbore, then these to her *Satan* return'd:
1536: ¶So strange thy outcry, and thy words so strange
1537: Thou interposest, that my sudden hand
1538: Prevented spares to tell thee yet by deeds
1539: What it intends; till first I know of thee,
1540: What thing thou art, thus double-form'd, and why
1541: In this infernal Vaile first met thou call'st
1542: Me Father, and that Fantasm call'st my Son?
1543: I know thee not, nor ever saw till now
1544: Sight more detestable then him and thee.
1545: ¶T' whom thus the Portress of Hell Gate reply'd;
1546: Hast thou forgot me then, and do I seem
1547: Now in thine eye so foul, once deemd so fair
1548: In Heav'n, when at th' Assembly, and in sight
1549: Of all the Seraphim with thee combin'd
1550: In bold conspiracy against Heav'ns King,
1551: All on a sudden miserable pain
1552: Surpris'd thee, dim thine eyes, and dizzie swumm
1553: In darkness, while thy head flames thick and fast
1554: Threw forth, till on the left side op'ning wide,
1555: Likest to thee in shape and count'nance bright,
1556: Then shining heav'nly fair, a Goddess arm'd
1557: Out of thy head I sprung: amazement seis'd
1558: All th' Host of Heav'n; back they recoild affraid
1559: At first, and call'd me *Sin*, and for a Sign
1560: Portentous held me; but familiar grown,
1561: I pleas'd, and with attractive graces won
1562: The most averse, thee chiefly, who full oft
1563: Thy self in me thy perfect image viewing
1564: Becam'st enamour'd, and such joy thou took'st
1565: With me in secret, that my womb conceiv'd
1566: A growing burden.  Mean while Warr arose,
1567: And fields were fought in Heav'n; wherein remaind
1568: (For what could else) to our Almighty Foe
1569: Cleer Victory, to our part loss and rout
1570: Through all the Empyrean: down they fell
1571: Driv'n headlong from the Pitch of Heaven, down
1572: Into this Deep, and in the general fall
1573: I also; at which time this powerful Key
1574: Into my hand was giv'n, with charge to keep
1575: These Gates for ever shut, which none can pass
1576: Without my op'ning.  Pensive here I sat
1577: Alone, but long I sat not, till my womb
1578: Pregnant by thee, and now excessive grown
1579: Prodigious motion felt and rueful throes.
1580: At last this odious offspring whom thou seest
1581: Thine own begotten, breaking violent way
1582: Tore through my entrails, that with fear and pain
1583: Distorted, all my nether shape thus grew
1584: Transform'd: but he my inbred enemie
1585: Forth issu'd, brandishing his fatal Dart
1586: Made to destroy: I fled, and cry'd out *Death*;
1587: Hell trembl'd at the hideous Name, and sigh'd
1588: From all her Caves, and back resounded *Death*.
1589: I fled, but he pursu'd (though more, it seems,
1590: Inflam'd with lust then rage) and swifter far,
1591: Me overtook his mother all dismaid,
1592: And in embraces forcible and foule
1593: Ingendring with me, of that rape begot
1594: These yelling Monsters that with ceasless cry
1595: Surround me, as thou sawst, hourly conceiv'd
1596: And hourly born, with sorrow infinite
1597: To me, for when they list into the womb
1598: That bred them they return, and howle and gnaw
1599: My Bowels, their repast; then bursting forth
1600: Afresh with conscious terrours vex me round,
1601: That rest or intermission none I find.
1602: Before mine eyes in opposition sits
1603: Grim *Death* my Son and foe, who sets them on,
1604: And me his Parent would full soon devour
1605: For want of other prey, but that he knows
1606: His end with mine involvd; and knows that I
1607: Should prove a bitter Morsel, and his bane,
1608: When ever that shall be; so Fate pronounc'd.
1609: But thou O Father, I forewarn thee, shun
1610: His deadly arrow; neither vainly hope
1611: To be invulnerable in those bright Arms,
1612: Though temper'd heav'nly, for that mortal dint,
1613: Save he who reigns above, none can resist.
1614: ¶She finish'd, and the suttle Fiend his lore
1615: Soon learnd, now milder, and thus answerd smooth.
1616: Dear Daughter, since thou claim'st me for thy Sire,
1617: And my fair Son here showst me, the dear pledge
1618: Of dalliance had with thee in Heav'n, and joys
1619: Then sweet, now sad to mention, through dire change
1620: Befalln us unforeseen, unthought of, know
1621: I come no enemie, but to set free
1622: From out this dark and dismal house of pain,
1623: Both him and thee, and all the heav'nly Host
1624: Of Spirits that in our just pretenses arm'd
1625: Fell with us from on high: from them I go
1626: This uncouth errand sole, and one for all
1627: My self expose, with lonely steps to tread
1628: Th' unfounded deep, & through the void immense
1629: To search with wandring quest a place foretold
1630: Should be, and, by concurring signs, ere now
1631: Created vast and round, a place of bliss
1632: In the Pourlieues of Heav'n, and therein plac't
1633: A race of upstart Creatures, to supply
1634: Perhaps our vacant room, though more remov'd,
1635: Least Heav'n surcharg'd with potent multitude
1636: Might hap to move new broiles: Be this or aught
1637: Then this more secret now design'd, I haste
1638: To know, and this once known, shall soon return,
1639: And bring ye to the place where Thou and Death
1640: Shall dwell at ease, and up and down unseen
1641: Wing silently the buxom Air, imbalm'd
1642: With odours; there ye shall be fed and fill'd
1643: Immeasurably, all things shall be your prey.
1644: He ceas'd, for both seemd highly pleasd, and Death
1645: Grinnd horrible a gastly smile, to hear
1646: His famine should be fill'd, and blest his mawe
1647: Destin'd to that good hour: no less rejoyc'd
1648: His mother bad, and thus bespake her Sire.
1649: ¶The key of this infernal Pit by due,
1650: And by command of Heav'ns all-powerful King
1651: I keep, by him forbidden to unlock
1652: These Adamantine Gates; against all force
1653: Death ready stands to interpose his dart,
1654: Fearless to be o'rematcht by living might.
1655: But what ow I to his commands above
1656: Who hates me, and hath hither thrust me down
1658: To sit in hateful Office here confin'd,
1660: Here in perpetual agonie and pain,
1661: With terrors and with clamors compasst round
1662: Of mine own brood, that on my bowels feed:
1663: Thou art my Father, thou my Author, thou
1664: My being gav'st me; whom should I obey
1665: But thee, whom follow? thou wilt bring me soon
1666: To that new world of light and bliss, among
1667: The Gods who live at ease, where I shall Reign
1668: At thy right hand voluptuous, as beseems
1669: Thy daughter and thy darling, without end.
1670: ¶Thus saying, from her side the fatal Key,
1671: Sad instrument of all our woe, she took;
1672: And towards the Gate rouling her bestial train,
1673: Forthwith the huge Porcullis high up drew,
1674: Which but her self not all the *Stygian* powers
1675: Could once have mov'd; then in the key-hole turns
1676: Th' intricate wards, and every Bolt and Bar
1677: Of massie Iron or sollid Rock with ease
1678: Unfast'ns: on a sudden op'n flie
1679: With impetuous recoile and jarring sound
1680: Th' infernal dores, and on thir hinges great
1681: Harsh Thunder, that the lowest bottom shook
1682: Of *Erebus*.  She op'nd, but to shut
1683: Excel'd her power; the Gates wide op'n stood,
1684: That with extended wings a Bannerd Host
1685: Under spread Ensigns marching might pass through
1686: With Horse and Chariots rankt in loose array;
1687: So wide they stood, and like a Furnace mouth
1688: Cast forth redounding smoak and ruddy flame.
1689: Before thir eyes in sudden view appear
1690: The secrets of the hoarie deep, a dark
1692: Without dimension, where length, breadth, and highth,
1693: And time and place are lost; where eldest Night
1696: Of endless warrs and by confusion stand.
1697: For hot, cold, moist, and dry, four Champions fierce
1698: Strive here for Maistrie, and to Battel bring
1699: Thir embryon Atoms; they around the flag
1700: Of each his faction, in thir several Clanns,
1701: Light-arm'd or heavy, sharp, smooth, swift or slow,
1702: Swarm populous, unnumber'd as the Sands
1704: Levied to side with warring Winds, and poise
1705: Thir lighter wings.  To whom these most adhere,
1706: Hee rules a moment; *Chaos* Umpire sits,
1707: And by decision more imbroiles the fray
1708: By which he Reigns: next him high Arbiter
1709: *Chance* governs all.  Into this wilde Abyss,
1710: The Womb of nature and perhaps her Grave,
1711: Of neither Sea, nor Shore, nor Air, nor Fire,
1712: But all these in thir pregnant causes mixt
1713: Confus'dly, and which thus must ever fight,
1714: Unless th' Almighty Maker them ordain
1715: His dark materials to create more Worlds,
1716: Into this wilde Abyss the warie fiend
1717: Stood on the brink of Hell and look'd a while,
1718: Pondering his Voyage; for no narrow frith
1719: He had to cross.  Nor was his eare less peal'd
1720: With noises loud and ruinous (to compare
1721: Great things with small) then when *Bellona* storms,
1722: With all her battering Engines bent to rase
1723: Som Capital City, or less then if this frame
1724: Of Heav'n were falling, and these Elements
1725: In mutinie had from her Axle torn
1726: The stedfast Earth.  At last his Sail-broad Vannes
1727: He spreads for flight, and in the surging smoak
1728: Uplifted spurns the ground, thence many a League
1729: As in a cloudy Chair ascending rides
1730: Audacious, but that seat soon failing, meets
1732: Fluttring his pennons vain plumb down he drops
1733: Ten thousand fadom deep, and to this hour
1734: Down had been falling, had not by ill chance
1735: The strong rebuff of som tumultuous cloud
1736: Instinct with Fire and Nitre hurried him
1737: As many miles aloft: that furie stay'd,
1738: Quencht in a Boggie *Syrtris*, neither Sea,
1739: Nor good dry Land: nigh founderd on he fares,
1740: Treading the crude consistence, half on foot,
1741: Half flying; behoves him now both Oare and Saile.
1742: As when a Gryfon through the Wilderness
1743: With winged course ore Hill or moarie Dale,
1745: Had from his wakeful custody purloind
1746: The guarded Gold: So eagerly the fiend
1747: Ore bog or steep, through strait, rough, dense, or rare,
1748: With head, hands, wings, or feet pursues his way,
1749: And swims or sinks, or wades, or creeps, or flyes:
1750: At length a universal hubbub wilde
1751: Of stunning sounds and voices all confus'd
1752: Born through the hollow dark assaults his eare
1753: With loudest vehemence: thither he plyes,
