1754: Undaunted to meet there what ever power
1755: Or Spirit of the nethermost Abyss
1756: Might in that noise reside, of whom to ask
1757: Which way the neerest coast of darkness lyes
1758: Bordering on light; when strait behold the Throne
1759: Of *Chaos*, and his dark Pavilion spread
1760: Wide on the wasteful Deep; with him Enthron'd
1761: Sat Sable-vested Night, eldest of things,
1762: The consort of his Reign; and by them stood
1765: And Tumult and Confusion all imbroild,
1766: And Discord with a thousand various mouths.
1767: ¶T' whom *Satan* turning boldly, thus.  Ye Powers
1768: And Spirits of this nethermost Abyss,
1769: *Chaos* and *Ancient Night*, I come no Spie,
1770: With purpose to explore or to disturb
1771: The secrets of your Realm, but by constraint
1772: Wandring this darksome desart, as my way
1773: Lies through your spacious Empire up to light,
1774: Alone, and without guide, half lost, I seek
1775: What readiest path leads where your gloomie bounds
1776: Confine with Heav'n; or if som other place
1777: From your Dominion won, th' Ethereal King
1779: I travel this profound, direct my course;
1780: Directed, no mean recompence it brings
1781: To your behoof, if I that Region lost,
1783: To her original darkness and your sway
1784: (Which is my present journey) and once more
1785: Erect the Standerd there of *Ancient Night*;
1786: Yours be th' advantage all, mine the revenge.
1787: ¶Thus *Satan*; and him thus the Anarch old
1788: With faultring speech and visage incompos'd
1789: Answer'd.  I know thee, stranger, who thou art,
1790: That mighty leading Angel, who of late
1791: Made head against Heav'ns King, though overthrown.
1792: I saw and heard, for such a numerous host
1793: Fled not in silence through the frighted deep
1794: With ruin upon ruin, rout on rout,
1795: Confusion worse confounded; and Heav'n Gates
1796: Pourd out by millions her victorious Bands
1797: Pursuing.  I upon my Frontieres here
1798: Keep residence; if all I can will serve,
1799: That little which is left so to defend
1800: Encroacht on still through our intestine broiles
1801: Weakning the Scepter of old Night: first Hell
1802: Your dungeon stretching far and wide beneath;
1803: Now lately Heaven and Earth, another World
1804: Hung ore my Realm, link'd in a golden Chain
1805: To that side Heav'n from whence your Legions fell:
1806: If that way be your walk, you have not farr;
1807: So much the neerer danger; goe and speed;
1808: Havock and spoil and ruin are my gain.
1809: ¶He ceas'd; and *Satan* staid not to reply,
1810: But glad that now his Sea should find a shore,
1811: With fresh alacritie and force renew'd
1812: Springs upward like a Pyramid of fire
1813: Into the wilde expanse, and through the shock
1814: Of fighting Elements, on all sides round
1815: Environ'd wins his way; harder beset
1816: And more endanger'd, then when *Argo* pass'd
1818: Or when *Ulysses* on the Larbord shunnd
1819: *Charybdis*, and by th' other whirlpool steard.
1820: So he with difficulty and labour hard
1821: Mov'd on, with difficulty and labour hee;
1822: But hee once past, soon after when man fell,
1823: Strange alteration!  Sin and Death amain
1824: Following his track, such was the will of Heav'n,
1825: Pav'd after him a broad and beat'n way
1826: Over the dark Abyss, whose boiling Gulf
1827: Tamely endur'd a Bridge of wondrous length
1828: From Hell continu'd reaching th' utmost Orbe
1829: Of this frail World; by which the Spirits perverse
1830: With easie intercourse pass to and fro
1831: To tempt or punish mortals, except whom
1832: God and good Angels guard by special grace.
1833: But now at last the sacred influence
1834: Of light appears, and from the walls of Heav'n
1835: Shoots farr into the bosom of dim Night
1836: A glimmering dawn; here Nature first begins
1837: Her fardest verge, and *Chaos* to retire
1838: As from her outmost works a brok'n foe
1839: With tumult less and with less hostile din,
1840: That *Satan* with less toil, and now with ease
1841: Wafts on the calmer wave by dubious light
1842: And like a weather-beaten Vessel holds
1843: Gladly the Port, though Shrouds and Tackle torn;
1844: Or in the emptier waste, resembling Air,
1845: Weighs his spread wings, at leasure to behold
1846: Farr off th' Empyreal Heav'n, extended wide
1847: In circuit, undetermind square or round,
1848: With Opal Towrs and Battlements adorn'd
1849: Of living Saphire, once his native Seat;
1850: And fast by hanging in a golden Chain
1851: This pendant world, in bigness as a Starr
1852: Of smallest Magnitude close by the Moon.
1853: Thither full fraught with mischievous revenge,
1854: Accurst, and in a cursed hour he hies.
1856: ¶Hail holy light, ofspring of Heav'n first-born,
1857: Or of th' Eternal Coeternal beam
1858: May I express thee unblam'd? since God is light,
1859: And never but in unapproached light
1860: Dwelt from Eternitie, dwelt then in thee,
1861: Bright effluence of bright essence increate.
1862: Or hear'st thou rather pure Ethereal stream,
1863: Whose Fountain who shall tell? before the Sun,
1864: Before the Heavens thou wert, and at the voice
1865: Of God, as with a Mantle didst invest
1866: The rising world of waters dark and deep,
1867: Won from the void and formless infinite.
1868: Thee I re-visit now with bolder wing,
1869: Escap't the *Stygian* Pool, though long detain'd
1870: In that obscure sojourn, while in my flight
1871: Through utter and through middle darkness borne
1872: With other notes then to th' *Orphean* Lyre
1874: Taught by the heav'nly Muse to venture down
1875: The dark descent, and up to reascend,
1876: Though hard and rare: thee I revisit safe,
1877: And feel thy sovran vital Lamp; but thou
1878: Revisit'st not these eyes, that rowle in vain
1879: To find thy piercing ray, and find no dawn;
1880: So thick a drop serene hath quencht thir Orbs,
1881: Or dim suffusion veild.  Yet not the more
1882: Cease I to wander where the Muses haunt
1883: Cleer Spring, or shadie Grove, or Sunnie Hill,
1884: Smit with the love of sacred song; but chief
1885: Thee *Sion* and the flowrie Brooks beneath
1886: That wash thy hallowd feet, and warbling flow,
1887: Nightly I visit: nor somtimes forget
1888: Those other two equal'd with me in Fate,
1889: So were I equal'd with them in renown,
1892: Then feed on thoughts, that voluntarie move
1893: Harmonious numbers; as the wakeful Bird
1894: Sings darkling, and in shadiest Covert hid
1895: Tunes her nocturnal Note.  Thus with the Year
1896: Seasons return, but not to me returns
1897: Day, or the sweet approach of Ev'n or Morn,
1898: Or sight of vernal bloom, or Summers Rose,
1899: Or flocks, or herds, or human face divine;
1900: But cloud in stead, and ever-during dark
1901: Surrounds me, from the chearful waies of men
1902: Cut off, and for the book of knowledg fair
1904: Of Natures works to mee expung'd and ras'd,
1905: And wisdome at one entrance quite shut out.
1906: So much the rather thou Celestial light
1907: Shine inward, and the mind through all her powers
1908: Irradiate, there plant eyes, all mist from thence
1909: Purge and disperse, that I may see and tell
1910: Of things invisible to mortal sight.
1911: ¶Now had the Almighty Father from above,
1912: From the pure Empyrean where he sits
1913: High Thron'd above all highth, bent down his eye,
1914: His own works and their works at once to view:
1915: About him all the Sanctities of Heaven
1916: Stood thick as Starrs, and from his sight receiv'd
1917: Beatitude past utterance; on his right
1918: The radiant image of his Glory sat,
1919: His onely Son; On Earth he first beheld
1920: Our two first Parents, yet the onely two
1921: Of mankind, in the happie Garden plac't,
1922: Reaping immortal fruits of joy and love,
1924: In blissful solitude; he then survey'd
1925: Hell and the Gulf between, and *Satan* there
1926: Coasting the wall of Heav'n on this side Night
1927: In the dun Air sublime, and ready now
1928: To stoop with wearied wings, and willing feet
1929: On the bare outside of this World, that seem'd
1931: Uncertain which, in Ocean or in Air.
1932: Him God beholding from his prospect high,
1933: Wherein past, present, future he beholds,
1934: Thus to his onely Son foreseeing spake.
1935: ¶Onely begotten Son, seest thou what rage
1936: Transports our adversarie, whom no bounds
1937: Prescrib'd, no barrs of Hell, nor all the chains
1938: Heapt on him there, nor yet the main Abyss
1939: Wide interrupt can hold; so bent he seems
1940: On desperat revenge, that shall redound
1941: Upon his own rebellious head.  And now
1942: Through all restraint broke loose he wings his way
1943: Not farr off Heav'n, in the Precincts of light,
1944: Directly towards the new created World,
1945: And Man there plac't, with purpose to assay
1946: If him by force he can destroy, or worse,
1947: By som false guile pervert; and shall pervert;
1948: For man will heark'n to his glozing lyes,
1949: And easily transgress the sole Command,
1950: Sole pledge of his obedience: So will fall
1951: Hee and his faithless Progenie: whose fault?
1952: Whose but his own? ingrate, he had of mee
1953: All he could have; I made him just and right,
1954: Sufficient to have stood, though free to fall.
1955: Such I created all th' Ethereal Powers
1956: And Spirits, both them who stood & them who faild;
1957: Freely they stood who stood, and fell who fell.
1958: Not free, what proof could they have givn sincere
1959: Of true allegiance, constant Faith or Love,
1960: Where onely what they needs must do, appeard,
1961: Not what they would? what praise could they receive?
1962: What pleasure I from such obedience paid,
1963: When Will and Reason (Reason also is choice)
1964: Useless and vain, of freedom both despoild,
1965: Made passive both, had servd necessitie,
1966: Not mee.  They therefore as to right belongd,
1967: So were created, nor can justly accuse
1968: Thir maker, or thir making, or thir Fate;
1970: Thir will, dispos'd by absolute Decree
1971: Or high foreknowledge; they themselves decreed
1972: Thir own revolt, not I: if I foreknew,
1973: Foreknowledge had no influence on their fault,
1974: Which had no less prov'd certain unforeknown.
1975: So without least impulse or shadow of Fate,
1976: Or aught by me immutablie foreseen,
1977: They trespass, Authors to themselves in all
1978: Both what they judge and what they choose; for so
1979: I formd them free, and free they must remain,
1980: Till they enthrall themselves: I else must change
1981: Thir nature, and revoke the high Decree
1983: Thir freedom, they themselves ordain'd thir fall.
1984: The first sort by thir own suggestion fell,
1986: By the other first: Man therefore shall find grace,
1987: The other none: in Mercy and Justice both,
1988: Through Heav'n and Earth, so shall my glorie excel,
1989: But Mercy first and last shall brightest shine.
1990: ¶Thus while God spake, ambrosial fragrance fill'd
1991: All Heav'n, and in the blessed Spirits elect
1992: Sense of new joy ineffable diffus'd:
1993: Beyond compare the Son of God was seen
1994: Most glorious, in him all his Father shon
1995: Substantially express'd, and in his face
1997: Love without end, and without measure Grace,
1998: Which uttering thus he to his Father spake.
1999: ¶O Father, gracious was that word which clos'd
2000: Thy sovran sentence, that Man should find grace;
2001: For which both Heav'n and Earth shall high extoll
2002: Thy praises, with th' innumerable sound
2003: Of Hymns and sacred Songs, wherewith thy Throne
2004: Encompass'd shall resound thee ever blest.
2005: For should Man finally be lost, should Man
2006: Thy creature late so lov'd, thy youngest Son
2007: Fall circumvented thus by fraud, though joynd
2008: With his own folly? that be from thee farr,
2009: That farr be from thee, Father, who art Judge
2010: Of all things made, and judgest onely right.
2011: Or shall the Adversarie thus obtain
2012: His end, and frustrate thine, shall he fulfill
2013: His malice, and thy goodness bring to naught,
2014: Or proud return though to his heavier doom,
2015: Yet with revenge accomplish't and to Hell
2016: Draw after him the whole Race of mankind,
2017: By him corrupted? or wilt thou thy self
2019: For him, what for thy glorie thou hast made?
2020: So should thy goodness and thy greatness both
2021: Be questiond and blaspheam'd without defence.
2022: ¶To whom the great Creatour thus reply'd.
2023: O Son, in whom my Soul hath chief delight,
2024: Son of my bosom, Son who art alone
2025: My word, my wisdom, and effectual might,
2026: All hast thou spok'n as my thoughts are, all
2027: As my Eternal purpose hath decreed:
2028: Man shall not quite be lost, but sav'd who will,
2029: Yet not of will in him, but grace in me
2030: Freely voutsaft; once more I will renew
2031: His lapsed powers, though forfeit and enthrall'd
2032: By sin to foul exorbitant desires;
2033: Upheld by me, yet once more he shall stand
2034: On even ground against his mortal foe,
2035: By me upheld, that he may know how frail
2036: His fall'n condition is, and to me ow
2037: All his deliv'rance, and to none but me.
2038: Some I have chosen of peculiar grace
2039: Elect above the rest; so is my will:
2040: The rest shall hear me call, and oft be warnd
2041: Thir sinful state, and to appease betimes
2042: Th' incensed Deitie, while offerd grace
2043: Invites; for I will cleer thir senses dark,
2044: What may suffice, and soft'n stonie hearts
2045: To pray, repent, and bring obedience due.
2046: To prayer, repentance, and obedience due,
2047: Though but endevord with sincere intent,
2048: Mine eare shall not be slow, mine eye not shut.
2049: And I will place within them as a guide
2050: My Umpire *Conscience*, whom if they will hear,
2051: Light after light well us'd they shall attain,
2052: And to the end persisting, safe arrive.
2053: This my long sufferance and my day of grace
2054: They who neglect and scorn, shall never taste;
2055: But hard be hard'nd, blind be blinded more,
2056: That they may stumble on, and deeper fall;
2057: And none but such from mercy I exclude.
2058: But yet all is not don; Man disobeying,
2059: Disloyal breaks his fealtie, and sinns
2060: Against the high Supremacie of Heav'n,
2061: Affecting God-head, and so loosing all,
2062: To expiate his Treason hath naught left,
2063: But to destruction sacred and devote,
2064: He with his whole posteritie must die,
2065: Die hee or Justice must; unless for him
2066: Som other able, and as willing, pay
2067: The rigid satisfaction, death for death.
2068: Say Heav'nly Powers, where shall we find such love,
2069: Which of ye will be mortal to redeem
2070: Mans mortal crime, and just th' unjust to save,
2071: Dwels in all Heaven charitie so deare?
2072: ¶He ask'd, but all the Heav'nly Quire stood mute,
2073: And silence was in Heav'n: on mans behalf
2075: Much less that durst upon his own head draw
2076: The deadly forfeiture, and ransom set.
2077: And now without redemption all mankind
2078: Must have bin lost, adjudg'd to Death and Hell
2079: By doom severe, had not the Son of God,
2080: In whom the fulness dwels of love divine,
2082: ¶Father, thy word is past, man shall find grace;
2083: And shall grace not find means, that finds her way,
2084: The speediest of thy winged messengers,
2085: To visit all thy creatures, and to all
2087: Happie for man, so coming; he her aide
2088: Can never seek, once dead in sins and lost;
2089: Attonement for himself or offering meet,
2090: Indebted and undon, hath none to bring:
2091: Behold mee then, mee for him, life for life
2092: I offer, on mee let thine anger fall;
2093: Account mee man; I for his sake will leave
2094: Thy bosom, and this glorie next to thee
2095: Freely put off, and for him lastly die
2096: Well pleas'd, on me let Death wreck all his rage;
2097: Under his gloomie power I shall not long
2098: Lie vanquisht; thou hast givn me to possess
2099: Life in my self for ever, by thee I live,
2100: Though now to Death I yeild, and am his due
2101: All that of me can die, yet that debt paid,
2102: Thou wilt not leave me in the loathsom grave
2103: His prey, nor suffer my unspotted Soule
2104: For ever with corruption there to dwell;
2105: But I shall rise Victorious, and subdue
2106: My Vanquisher, spoild of his vanted spoile;
2107: Death his deaths wound shall then receive, & stoop
2108: Inglorious, of his mortall sting disarm'd.
2109: I through the ample Air in Triumph high
2110: Shall lead Hell Captive maugre Hell, and show
2111: The powers of darkness bound.  Thou at the sight
2112: Pleas'd, out of Heaven shalt look down and smile,
2113: While by thee rais'd I ruin all my Foes,
2114: Death last, and with his Carcass glut the Grave:
2115: Then with the multitude of my redeemd
2116: Shall enter Heaven long absent, and returne,
2117: Father, to see thy face, wherein no cloud
2118: Of anger shall remain, but peace assur'd,
2119: And reconcilement; wrauth shall be no more
2120: Thenceforth, but in thy presence Joy entire.
2121: ¶His words here ended, but his meek aspect
2122: Silent yet spake, and breath'd immortal love
2123: To mortal men, above which only shon
2125: Glad to be offer'd, he attends the will
2126: Of his great Father.  Admiration seis'd
2127: All Heav'n, what this might mean, & whither tend
2128: Wondring; but soon th' Almighty thus reply'd:
2129: ¶O thou in Heav'n and Earth the only peace
2130: Found out for mankind under wrauth, O thou
2131: My sole complacence! well thou know'st how dear,
2132: To me are all my works, nor Man the least
2133: Though last created, that for him I spare
2134: Thee from my bosom and right hand, to save,
2135: By loosing thee a while, the whole Race lost.
2136: Thou therefore whom thou only canst redeeme,
2137: Thir Nature also to thy Nature joyne;
2138: And be thy self Man among men on Earth,
2139: Made flesh, when time shall be, of Virgin seed,
2140: By wondrous birth: Be thou in *Adams* room
2141: The Head of all mankind, though *Adams* Son.
2142: As in him perish all men, so in thee
2143: As from a second root shall be restor'd,
2144: As many as are restor'd, without thee none.
2145: His crime makes guiltie all his Sons, thy merit
2146: Imputed shall absolve them who renounce
2147: Thir own both righteous and unrighteous deeds,
2148: And live in thee transplanted, and from thee
2149: Receive new life.  So Man, as is most just,
2150: Shall satisfie for Man, be judg'd and die,
2151: And dying rise, and rising with him raise
2152: His Brethren, ransomd with his own dear life.
2153: So Heav'nly love shal outdoo Hellish hate,
2154: Giving to death, and dying to redeeme,
2155: So dearly to redeem what Hellish hate
2156: So easily destroy'd, and still destroyes
2157: In those who, when they may, accept not grace.
2158: Nor shalt thou by descending to assume
2159: Mans Nature, less'n or degrade thine owne.
2160: Because thou hast, though Thron'd in highest bliss
2161: Equal to God, and equally enjoying
2162: God-like fruition, quitted all to save
2163: A World from utter loss, and hast been found
2164: By Merit more then Birthright Son of God,
2165: Found worthiest to be so by being Good,
2166: Farr more then Great or High; because in thee
2167: Love hath abounded more then Glory abounds,
2169: With thee thy Manhood also to this Throne;
2170: Here shalt thou sit incarnate, here shalt Reigne
2171: Both God and Man, Son both of God and Man,
2173: I give thee, reign for ever, and assume
2174: Thy Merits; under thee as Head Supream
2175: Thrones, Princedoms, Powers, Dominions I reduce:
2176: All knees to thee shall bow, of them that bide
2177: In Heaven, or Earth, or under Earth in Hell;
2178: When thou attended gloriously from Heav'n
2179: Shalt in the Skie appeer, and from thee send
2181: Thy dread Tribunal: forthwith from all Windes
2182: The living, and forthwith the cited dead
2183: Of all past Ages to the general Doom
2184: Shall hast'n, such a peal shall rouse thir sleep.
2185: Then all thy Saints assembl'd, thou shalt judge
2186: Bad men and Angels, they arraignd shall sink
2187: Beneath thy Sentence; Hell, her numbers full,
2188: Thenceforth shall be for ever shut.  Mean while
2189: The World shall burn, and from her ashes spring
2190: New Heav'n and Earth, wherein the just shall dwell
2191: And after all thir tribulations long
2192: See golden days, fruitful of golden deeds,
2193: With Joy and Love triumphing, and fair Truth.
2194: Then thou thy regal Scepter shalt lay by,
2195: For regal Scepter then no more shall need,
2196: God shall be All in All.  But all ye Gods,
2197: Adore him, who to compass all this dies,
2198: Adore the Son, and honour him as mee.
2199: ¶No sooner had th' Almighty ceas't, but all
2200: The multitude of Angels with a shout
2201: Loud as from numbers without number, sweet
2202: As from blest voices, uttering joy, Heav'n rung
2203: With Jubilee, and loud Hosanna's fill'd
2205: Towards either Throne they bow, & to the ground
2206: With solemn adoration down they cast
2207: Thir Crowns inwove with Amarant and Gold,
2208: Immortal Amarant, a Flour which once
2209: In Paradise, fast by the Tree of Life
2210: Began to bloom, but soon for mans offence
2211: To Heav'n remov'd where first it grew, there grows,
2212: And flours aloft shading the Fount of Life,
2213: And where the river of Bliss through midst of Heavn
2214: Rowls o're *Elisian* Flours her Amber stream;
2215: With these that never fade the Spirits Elect
2216: Bind thir resplendent locks inwreath'd with beams,
2217: Now in loose Garlands thick thrown off, the bright
2218: Pavement that like a Sea of Jasper shon
2220: Then Crown'd again thir gold'n Harps they took,
2221: Harps ever tun'd, that glittering by their side
2222: Like Quivers hung, and with Praeamble sweet
2224: Thir sacred Song, and waken raptures high;
2225: No voice exempt, no voice but well could joine
2226: Melodious part, such concord is in Heav'n.
2229: Eternal King; thee Author of all being,
2230: Fountain of Light, thy self invisible
2231: Amidst the glorious brightness where thou sit'st
2232: Thron'd inaccessible, but when thou shad'st
2233: The full blaze of thy beams, and through a cloud
2234: Drawn round about thee like a radiant Shrine,
2235: Dark with excessive bright thy skirts appeer,
2236: Yet dazle Heav'n, that brightest Seraphim
2237: Approach not, but with both wings veil thir eyes.
2238: Thee next they sang of all Creation first,
2240: In whose conspicuous count'nance, without cloud
2241: Made visible, th' Almighty Father shines,
2242: Whom else no Creature can behold; on thee
2243: Impresst the effulgence of his Glorie abides,
2244: Transfus'd on thee his ample Spirit rests.
2245: Hee Heav'n of Heavens and all the Powers therein
2246: By thee created, and by thee threw down
2247: Th' aspiring Dominations: thou that day
2248: Thy Fathers dreadful Thunder didst not spare,
2249: Nor stop thy flaming Chariot wheels, that shook
2250: Heav'ns everlasting Frame, while o're the necks
2251: Thou drov'st of warring Angels disarraid.
2252: Back from pursuit thy Powers with loud acclaime
2253: Thee only extold, Son of thy Fathers might,
2254: To execute fierce vengeance on his foes,
2255: Not so on Man; him through their malice fall'n,
2256: Father of Mercie and Grace, thou didst not doome
2257: So strictly, but much more to pitie encline:
2258: No sooner did thy dear and onely Son
2259: Perceive thee purpos'd not to doom frail Man
2260: So strictly, but much more to pitie enclin'd,
2261: He to appease thy wrauth, and end the strife
2262: Of Mercy and Justice in thy face discern'd,
2263: Regardless of the Bliss wherein hee sat
2264: Second to thee, offerd himself to die
2265: For mans offence.  O unexampl'd love,
2266: Love no where to be found less then Divine!
2267: Hail Son of God, Saviour of Men, thy Name
2268: Shall be the copious matter of my Song
2269: Henceforth, and never shall my Harp thy praise
2270: Forget, nor from thy Fathers praise disjoine.
2271: ¶Thus they in Heav'n, above the starry Sphear,
2272: Thir happie hours in joy and hymning spent.
2273: Mean while upon the firm opacous Globe
2274: Of this round World, whose first convex divides
2276: From *Chaos* and th' inroad of Darkness old,
2277: *Satan* alighted walks: a Globe farr off
2278: It seem'd, now seems a boundless Continent
2279: Dark, waste, and wild, under the frown of Night
2282: Save on that side which from the wall of Heav'n
2283: Though distant farr som small reflection gaines
2284: Of glimmering air less vext with tempest loud:
2285: Here walk'd the Fiend at large in spacious field.
2286: As when a Vultur on *Imaus* bred,
2287: Whose snowie ridge the roving *Tartar* bounds,
2288: Dislodging from a Region scarce of prey
2289: To gorge the flesh of Lambs or yeanling Kids
2290: On Hills where Flocks are fed, flies toward the Springs
2292: But in his way lights on the barren plaines
2294: With Sails and Wind thir canie Waggons light:
2295: So on this windie Sea of Land, the Fiend
2296: Walk'd up and down alone bent on his prey,
2297: Alone, for other Creature in this place
2298: Living or liveless to be found was none,
2299: None yet, but store hereafter from the earth
2300: Up hither like Aereal vapours flew
2301: Of all things transitorie and vain, when Sin
2302: With vanity had filld the works of men:
2303: Both all things vain, and all who in vain things
2304: Built thir fond hopes of Glorie or lasting fame,
2305: Or happiness in this or th' other life;
2306: All who have thir reward on Earth, the fruits
2307: Of painful Superstition and blind Zeal,
2308: Naught seeking but the praise of men, here find
2309: Fit retribution, emptie as thir deeds;
2310: All th' unaccomplisht works of Natures hand,
2312: Dissolvd on earth, fleet hither, and in vain,
2314: Not in the neighbouring Moon, as some have dreamd;
2315: Those argent Fields more likely habitants,
2316: Translated Saints, or middle Spirits hold
2317: Betwixt th' Angelical and Human kinde:
2318: Hither of ill-joynd Sons and Daughters born
2319: First from the ancient World those Giants came
2320: With many a vain exploit, though then renownd:
2321: The builders next of *Babel* on the Plain
2322: Of *Sennaar*, and still with vain designe
2323: New *Babels*, had they wherewithall, would build:
2324: Others came single; hee who to be deemd
2325: A God, leap'd fondly into *Aetna* flames,
2329: Embryo's and Idiots, Eremits and Friers
2330: White, Black and Grey, with all thir trumperie.
2331: Here Pilgrims roam, that stray'd so farr to seek
2332: In *Golgotha* him dead, who lives in Heav'n;
2333: And they who to be sure of Paradise
2334: Dying put on the weeds of *Dominic*,
2335: Or in *Franciscan* think to pass disguis'd;
2336: They pass the Planets seven, and pass the fixt,
2337: And that Crystalline Sphear whose ballance weighs
2338: The Trepidation talkt, and that first mov'd;
2339: And now Saint *Peter* at Heav'ns Wicket seems
2340: To wait them with his Keys, and now at foot
2341: Of Heav'ns ascent they lift thir Feet, when loe
2342: A violent cross wind from either Coast
2343: Blows them transverse ten thousand Leagues awry
2344: Into the devious Air; then might ye see
2345: Cowles, Hoods and Habits with thir wearers tost
2346: And flutterd into Raggs, then Reliques, Beads,
2348: The sport of Winds: all these upwhirld aloft
2349: Fly o're the backside of the World farr off
2350: Into a *Limbo* large and broad, since calld
2351: The Paradise of Fools, to few unknown
2352: Long after, now unpeopl'd, and untrod;
2353: All this dark Globe the Fiend found as he pass'd,
2354: And long he wanderd, till at last a gleame
2355: Of dawning light turnd thither-ward in haste
2356: His travell'd steps; farr distant hee descries
2358: Up to the wall of Heaven a Structure high,
2359: At top whereof, but farr more rich appeerd
2360: The work as of a Kingly Palace Gate
2361: With Frontispice of Diamond and Gold
2362: Imbellisht, thick with sparkling orient Gemmes
2363: The Portal shon, inimitable on Earth
2364: By Model, or by shading Pencil drawn.
2365: The Stairs were such as whereon *Jacob* saw
2367: Of Guardians bright, when he from *Esau* fled
2369: Dreaming by night under the open Skie,
2370: And waking cri'd, This is the Gate of Heav'n.
2371: Each Stair mysteriously was meant, nor stood
2372: There alwaies, but drawn up to Heav'n somtimes
2373: Viewless, and underneath a bright Sea flow'd
2374: Of Jasper, or of liquid Pearle, whereon
2375: Who after came from Earth, sayling arriv'd,
2376: Wafted by Angels, or flew o're the Lake
2377: Rapt in a Chariot drawn by fiery Steeds.
2378: The Stairs were then let down, whether to dare
2379: The Fiend by easie ascent, or aggravate
2380: His sad exclusion from the dores of Bliss.
2381: Direct against which op'nd from beneath,
2382: Just o're the blissful seat of Paradise,
2383: A passage down to th' Earth, a passage wide,
2384: Wider by farr then that of after-times
2385: Over Mount *Sion*, and, though that were large,
2386: Over the *Promis'd Land* to God so dear,
2387: By which, to visit oft those happy Tribes,
2388: On high behests his Angels to and fro
2389: Pass'd frequent, and his eye with choice regard
2393: So wide the op'ning seemd, where bounds were set
2394: To darkness, such as bound the Ocean wave.
2395: *Satan* from hence now on the lower stair
2396: That scal'd by steps of Gold to Heav'n Gate
2397: Looks down with wonder at the sudden view
2398: Of all this World at once.  As when a Scout
2399: Through dark and desart wayes with peril gone
2400: All night; at last by break of chearful dawne
2401: Obtains the brow of some high-climbing Hill,
2402: Which to his eye discovers unaware
2403: The goodly prospect of some forein land
2405: With glistering Spires and Pinnacles adornd,
2406: Which now the Rising Sun guilds with his beams.
2407: Such wonder seis'd, though after Heaven seen,
2408: The Spirit maligne, but much more envy seis'd
2409: At sight of all this World beheld so faire.
2410: Round he surveys, and well might, where he stood
2411: So high above the circling Canopie
2412: Of Nights extended shade; from Eastern Point
2413: Of *Libra* to the fleecie Starr that bears
2415: Beyond th' *Horizon*; then from Pole to Pole
2416: He views in bredth, and without longer pause
2417: Down right into the Worlds first Region throws
2418: His flight precipitant, and windes with ease
2419: Through the pure marble Air his oblique way
2421: Stars distant, but nigh hand seemd other Worlds,
2422: Or other Worlds they seemd, or happy Iles,
2423: Like those *Hesperian* Gardens fam'd of old,
2424: Fortunate Fields, and Groves and flourie Vales,
2425: Thrice happy Iles, but who dwelt happy there
2426: He stayd not to enquire: above them all
2427: The golden Sun in splendor likest Heaven
2428: Allur'd his eye: Thither his course he bends
2429: Through the calm Firmament; but up or downe
2430: By center, or eccentric, hard to tell,
2431: Or Longitude, where the great Luminarie
2433: That from his Lordly eye keep distance due,
2434: Dispenses Light from farr; they as they move
2435: Thir Starry dance in numbers that compute
2436: Days, months, and years, towards his all-chearing Lamp
2437: Turn swift their various motions, or are turnd
2438: By his Magnetic beam, that gently warms
2439: The Univers, and to each inward part
2441: Shoots invisible vertue even to the deep:
2442: So wondrously was set his Station bright.
2443: There lands the Fiend, a spot like which perhaps
2444: Astronomer in the Sun's lucent Orbe
2445: Through his glaz'd Optic Tube yet never saw.
2446: The place he found beyond expression bright,
2447: Compar'd with aught on Earth, Medal or Stone;
2448: Not all parts like, but all alike informd
2449: With radiant light, as glowing Iron with fire;
2450: If mettal, part seemd Gold, part Silver cleer;
2451: If stone, Carbuncle most or Chrysolite,
2452: Rubie or Topaz, to the Twelve that shon
2453: In *Aarons* Brest-plate, and a stone besides
2454: Imagind rather oft then elsewhere seen,
2455: That stone, or like to that which here below
2456: Philosophers in vain so long have sought,
2457: In vain, though by thir powerful Art they binde
2459: In various shapes old *Proteus* from the Sea,
2460: Draind through a Limbec to his Native forme.
2461: What wonder then if fields and regions here
2462: Breathe forth *Elixir* pure, and Rivers run
2463: Potable Gold, when with one vertuous touch
2464: Th' Arch-chimic Sun so farr from us remote
2466: Here in the dark so many precious things
2467: Of colour glorious and effect so rare?
2468: Here matter new to gaze the Devil met
2469: Undazl'd, farr and wide his eye commands,
2470: For sight no obstacle found here, nor shade,
2471: But all Sun-shine, as when his Beams at Noon
2472: Culminate from th' *Aequator*, as they now
2473: Shot upward still direct, whence no way round
2474: Shadow from body opaque can fall, and the Aire,
2475: No where so cleer, sharp'nd his visual ray
2476: To objects distant farr, whereby he soon
2477: Saw within kenn a glorious Angel stand,
2478: The same whom *John* saw also in the Sun:
2479: His back was turnd, but not his brightness hid;
2480: Of beaming sunnie Raies, a golden tiar
2481: Circl'd his Head, nor less his Locks behind
2482: Illustrious on his Shoulders fledge with wings
2483: Lay waving round; on som great charge imploy'd
2484: Hee seemd, or fixt in cogitation deep.
2485: Glad was the Spirit impure as now in hope
2486: To find who might direct his wandring flight
2487: To Paradise the happie seat of Man,
2488: His journies end and our beginning woe.
2489: But first he casts to change his proper shape,
2490: Which else might work him danger or delay:
2491: And now a stripling Cherube he appeers,
2492: Not of the prime, yet such as in his face
2493: Youth smil'd Celestial, and to every Limb
2494: Sutable grace diffus'd, so well he feignd;
2495: Under a Coronet his flowing haire
2496: In curles on either cheek plaid, wings he wore
2497: Of many a colourd plume sprinkl'd with Gold,
2498: His habit fit for speed succinct, and held
2499: Before his decent steps a Silver wand.
2500: He drew not nigh unheard, the Angel bright,
2501: Ere he drew nigh, his radiant visage turnd,
2502: Admonisht by his eare, and strait was known
2503: Th' Arch-Angel *Uriel*, one of the seav'n
2504: Who in Gods presence, neerest to his Throne
2505: Stand ready at command, and are his Eyes
2506: That run through all the Heav'ns, or down to th' Earth
2507: Bear his swift errands over moist and dry,
2508: O're Sea and Land: him *Satan* thus accostes;
2509: ¶*Uriel*, for thou of those seav'n Spirits that stand
2510: In sight of God's high Throne, gloriously bright,
2511: The first art wont his great authentic will
2512: Interpreter through highest Heav'n to bring,
2513: Where all his Sons thy Embassie attend;
2514: And here art likeliest by supream decree
2515: Like honour to obtain, and as his Eye
2516: To visit oft this new Creation round;
2517: Unspeakable desire to see, and know
2518: All these his wondrous works, but chiefly Man,
2519: His chief delight and favour, him for whom
2520: All these his works so wondrous he ordaind,
2521: Hath brought me from the Quires of Cherubim
2522: Alone thus wandring.  Brightest Seraph tell
2523: In which of all these shining Orbes hath Man
2524: His fixed seat, or fixed seat hath none,
2525: But all these shining Orbes his choice to dwell;
2526: That I may find him, and with secret gaze,
2528: On whom the great Creator hath bestowd
2529: Worlds, and on whom hath all these graces powrd;
2530: That both in him and all things, as is meet,
2531: The Universal Maker we may praise;
2532: Who justly hath drivn out his Rebell Foes
2533: To deepest Hell, and to repair that loss
2534: Created this new happie Race of Men
2535: To serve him better: wise are all his wayes.
2537: For neither Man nor Angel can discern
2538: Hypocrisie, the only evil that walks
2540: By his permissive will, through Heav'n and Earth:
2541: And oft though wisdom wake, suspicion sleeps
2542: At wisdoms Gate, and to simplicitie
2543: Resigns her charge, while goodness thinks no ill
2544: Where no ill seems: Which now for once beguil'd
2545: *Uriel*, though Regent of the Sun, and held
2546: The sharpest sighted Spirit of all in Heav'n;
2547: Who to the fraudulent Impostor foule
2548: In his uprightness answer thus returnd.
2549: Faire Angel, thy desire which tends to know
2550: The works of God, thereby to glorifie
2551: The great Work-Maister, leads to no excess
2552: That reaches blame, but rather merits praise
2553: The more it seems excess, that led thee hither
2554: From thy Empyreal Mansion thus alone,
2555: To witness with thine eyes what some perhaps
2556: Contented with report heare onely in heav'n:
2557: For wonderful indeed are all his works,
2558: Pleasant to know, and worthiest to be all
2559: Had in remembrance alwayes with delight;
2560: But what created mind can comprehend
2561: Thir number, or the wisdom infinite
2562: That brought them forth, but hid thir causes deep.
2563: I saw when at his Word the formless Mass,
2564: This worlds material mould, came to a heap:
2565: Confusion heard his voice, and wilde uproar
2566: Stood rul'd, stood vast infinitude confin'd;
2567: Till at his second bidding darkness fled,
2568: Light shon, and order from disorder sprung:
2569: Swift to thir several Quarters hasted then
2570: The cumbrous Elements, Earth, Flood, Aire, Fire,
2571: And this Ethereal quintessence of Heav'n
2572: Flew upward, spirited with various forms,
2573: That rowld orbicular, and turnd to Starrs
2574: Numberless, as thou seest, and how they move;
2575: Each had his place appointed, each his course,
2576: The rest in circuit walles this Universe.
2577: Look downward on that Globe whose hither side
2578: With light from hence, though but reflected, shines;
2579: That place is Earth the seat of Man, that light
2580: His day, which else as th' other Hemisphere
2581: Night would invade, but there the neighbouring Moon
2582: (So call that opposite fair Starr) her aide
2583: Timely interposes, and her monthly round
2584: Still ending, still renewing, through mid Heav'n;
2585: With borrowd light her countenance triform
2586: Hence fills and empties to enlighten th' Earth,
2587: And in her pale dominion checks the night.
2588: That spot to which I point is *Paradise*,
2589: *Adams* abode, those loftie shades his Bowre.
2590: Thy way thou canst not miss, me mine requires.
2591: ¶Thus said, he turnd, and *Satan* bowing low,
2592: As to superior Spirits is wont in Heaven,
2593: Where honour due and reverence none neglects,
2594: Took leave, and toward the coast of Earth beneath,
2595: Down from th' Ecliptic, sped with hop'd success,
2596: Throws his steep flight with many an Aerie wheele,
2597: Nor staid, till on *Niphates* top he lights.
2599: ¶O For that warning voice, which he who saw
2600: Th' *Apocalyps*, heard cry in Heaven aloud,
2601: Then when the Dragon, put to second rout,
2602: Came furious down to be reveng'd on men,
2603: *Wo to the Inhabitants on Earth!* that now,
2604: While time was, our first Parents had bin warnd
2605: The coming of thir secret foe, and scap'd
2606: Haply so scap'd his mortal snare; for now
2607: *Satan*, now first inflam'd with rage, came down,
2608: The Tempter ere th' Accuser of man-kind,
2609: To wreck on innocent frail man his loss
2610: Of that first Battel, and his flight to Hell:
2611: Yet not rejoycing in his speed, though bold,
2612: Far off and fearless, nor with cause to boast,
2613: Begins his dire attempt, which nigh the birth
2614: Now rowling, boiles in his tumultuous brest,
2615: And like a devillish Engine back recoiles
2616: Upon himself; horror and doubt distract
2617: His troubl'd thoughts, and from the bottom stirr
2618: The Hell within him, for within him Hell
2619: He brings, and round about him, nor from Hell
2620: One step no more then from himself can fly
2621: By change of place: Now conscience wakes despair
2622: That slumberd, wakes the bitter memorie
2623: Of what he was, what is, and what must be
2624: Worse; of worse deeds worse sufferings must ensue.
2625: Sometimes towards *Eden* which now in his view
2626: Lay pleasant, his grievd look he fixes sad,
2627: Sometimes towards Heav'n and the full-blazing Sun,
2628: Which now sat high in his Meridian Towre:
2629: Then much revolving, thus in sighs began.
2630: ¶O thou that with surpassing Glory crownd,
2631: Look'st from thy sole Dominion like the God
2632: Of this new World; at whose sight all the Starrs
2633: Hide thir diminisht heads; to thee I call,
2634: But with no friendly voice, and add thy name
2635: O Sun, to tell thee how I hate thy beams
2636: That bring to my remembrance from what state
2637: I fell, how glorious once above thy Spheare;
2638: Till Pride and worse Ambition threw me down
2639: Warring in Heav'n against Heav'ns matchless King:
2640: Ah wherefore! he deservd no such return
2641: From me, whom he created what I was
2642: In that bright eminence, and with his good
2643: Upbraided none; nor was his service hard.
2644: What could be less then to afford him praise,
2645: The easiest recompence, and pay him thanks,
2646: How due! yet all his good prov'd ill in me,
2647: And wrought but malice; lifted up so high
2648: I sdeind subjection, and thought one step higher
2649: Would set me highest, and in a moment quit
2650: The debt immense of endless gratitude,
2651: So burthensome, still paying, still to ow;
2652: Forgetful what from him I still receivd,
2653: And understood not that a grateful mind
2654: By owing owes not, but still pays, at once
2655: Indebted and dischargd; what burden then?
2656: O had his powerful Destiny ordaind
2657: Me some inferiour Angel, I had stood
2658: Then happie; no unbounded hope had rais'd
2659: Ambition.  Yet why not? som other Power
2660: As great might have aspir'd, and me though mean
2661: Drawn to his part; but other Powers as great
2662: Fell not, but stand unshak'n, from within
2663: Or from without, to all temptations arm'd.
2664: Hadst thou the same free Will and Power to stand?
2665: Thou hadst: whom hast thou then or what to accuse,
2666: But Heav'ns free Love dealt equally to all?
2667: Be then his Love accurst, since love or hate,
2668: To me alike, it deals eternal woe.
2669: Nay curs'd be thou; since against his thy will
2670: Chose freely what it now so justly rues.
2671: Me miserable! which way shall I flie
2673: Which way I flie is Hell; my self am Hell;
2674: And in the lowest deep a lower deep
2675: Still threatning to devour me opens wide,
2676: To which the Hell I suffer seems a Heav'n.
2677: O then at last relent: is there no place
2678: Left for Repentance, none for Pardon left?
2679: None left but by submission; and that word
2680: *Disdain* forbids me, and my dread of shame
2681: Among the spirits beneath, whom I seduc'd
2682: With other promises and other vaunts
2683: Then to submit, boasting I could subdue
2684: Th' Omnipotent.  Ay me, they little know
2685: How dearly I abide that boast so vaine,
2686: Under what torments inwardly I groane;
2687: While they adore me on the Throne of Hell,
2688: With Diadem and Scepter high advanc'd
2689: The lower still I fall, onely Supream
2690: In miserie; such joy Ambition findes.
2691: But say I could repent and could obtaine
2692: By Act of Grace my former state; how soon
2693: Would highth recal high thoughts, how soon unsay
2694: What feign'd submission swore: ease would recant
2695: Vows made in pain, as violent and void.
2696: For never can true reconcilement grow
2697: Where wounds of deadly hate have peirc'd so deep:
2698: Which would but lead me to a worse relapse
2699: And heavier fall: so should I purchase deare
2700: Short intermission bought with double smart.
2701: This knows my punisher; therefore as farr
2702: From granting hee, as I from begging peace:
2703: All hope excluded thus, behold in stead
2704: Of us out-cast, exil'd, his new delight,
2705: Mankind created, and for him this World.
2706: So farwel Hope, and with Hope farwel Fear,
2707: Farwel Remorse: all Good to me is lost;
2708: Evil be thou my Good; by thee at least
2709: Divided Empire with Heav'ns King I hold
2710: By thee, and more then half perhaps will reigne;
2711: As Man ere long, and this new World shall know.
2712: ¶Thus while he spake, each passion dimm'd his face
2713: Thrice chang'd with pale, ire, envie and despair,
2714: Which marrd his borrow'd visage, and betraid
2715: Him counterfet, if any eye beheld.
2716: For heav'nly mindes from such distempers foule
2717: Are ever cleer.  Whereof hee soon aware,
2718: Each perturbation smooth'd with outward calme,
2719: Artificer of fraud; and was the first
2720: That practisd falshood under saintly shew,
2721: Deep malice to conceale, couch't with revenge:
2722: Yet not anough had practisd to deceive
2723: *Uriel* once warnd; whose eye pursu'd him down
2724: The way he went, and on th' *Assyrian* mount
2725: Saw him disfigur'd, more then could befall
2726: Spirit of happie sort: his gestures fierce
2727: He markd and mad demeanour, then alone,
2728: As he suppos'd, all unobserv'd, unseen.
2729: So on he fares, and to the border comes
2731: Now nearer, Crowns with her enclosure green,
2732: As with a rural mound the champain head
2733: Of a steep wilderness, whose hairie sides
2734: With thicket overgrown, grottesque and wilde,
2735: Access deni'd; and over head up grew
2737: Cedar, and Pine, and Firr, and branching Palm,
2738: A Silvan Scene, and as the ranks ascend
2739: Shade above shade, a woodie Theatre
2740: Of stateliest view.  Yet higher then thir tops
2741: The verdurous wall of Paradise up sprung:
2742: Which to our general Sire gave prospect large
2743: Into his neather Empire neighbouring round.
2744: And higher then that Wall a circling row
2745: Of goodliest Trees loaden with fairest Fruit,
2746: Blossoms and Fruits at once of golden hue
2747: Appeerd, with gay enameld colours mixt:
2748: On which the Sun more glad impress'd his beams
2749: Then in fair Evening Cloud, or humid Bow,
2750: When God hath showrd the earth; so lovely seemd
2751: That Lantskip: And of pure now purer aire
2752: Meets his approach, and to the heart inspires
2753: Vernal delight and joy, able to drive
2754: All sadness but despair: now gentle gales
2756: Native perfumes, and whisper whence they stole
2757: Those balmie spoiles.  As when to them who saile
2758: Beyond the *Cape of Hope*, and now are past
2759: *Mozambic*, off at Sea North-East windes blow
2761: Of *Arabie* the blest, with such delay
2762: Well pleas'd they slack thir course, and many a League
2763: Cheard with the grateful smell old Ocean smiles.
2764: So entertaind those odorous sweets the Fiend
2765: Who came thir bane, though with them better pleas'd
2767: That drove him, though enamourd, from the Spouse
2768: Of *Tobits* Son, and with a vengeance sent
2769: From *Media* post to *Aegypt*, there fast bound.
2770: ¶Now to th' ascent of that steep savage Hill
2771: *Satan* had journied on, pensive and slow;
2772: But further way found none, so thick entwin'd,
2773: As one continu'd brake, the undergrowth
2774: Of shrubs and tangling bushes had perplext
2775: All path of Man or Beast that past that way:
2776: One Gate there onely was, and that look'd East
2777: On th' other side: which when th' arch-fellon saw
2778: Due entrance he disdaind, and in contempt,
2779: At one slight bound high overleap'd all bound
2780: Of Hill or highest Wall, and sheer within
2781: Lights on his feet.  As when a prowling Wolfe,
2782: Whom hunger drives to seek new haunt for prey,
2783: Watching where Shepherds pen thir Flocks at eeve
2784: In hurdl'd Cotes amid the field secure,
2785: Leaps o're the fence with ease into the Fould:
2786: Or as a Thief bent to unhoord the cash
2787: Of some rich Burgher, whose substantial dores,
2788: Cross-barrd and bolted fast, fear no assault,
2789: In at the window climbes, or o're the tiles;
2790: So clomb this first grand Thief into Gods Fould:
2791: So since into his Church lewd Hirelings climbe.
2792: Thence up he flew, and on the Tree of Life,
2793: The middle Tree and highest there that grew,
2794: Sat like a Cormorant; yet not true Life
2795: Thereby regaind, but sat devising Death
2796: To them who liv'd; nor on the vertue thought
2797: Of that life-giving Plant, but only us'd
2798: For prospect, what well us'd had bin the pledge
2800: Any, but God alone, to value right
2801: The good before him, but perverts best things
2802: To worst abuse, or to thir meanest use.
2803: Beneath him with new wonder now he views
2804: To all delight of human sense expos'd
2805: In narrow room Natures whole wealth, yea more,
2806: A Heaven on Earth, for blissful Paradise
2807: Of God the Garden was, by him in the East
2809: From *Auran* Eastward to the Royal Towrs
2811: Or where the Sons of *Eden* long before
2812: Dwelt in *Telassar:* in this pleasant soile
2813: His farr more pleasant Garden God ordaind;
2814: Out of the fertil ground he caus'd to grow
2815: All Trees of noblest kind for sight, smell, taste;
2816: And all amid them stood the Tree of Life,
2818: Of vegetable Gold; and next to Life
2819: Our Death the Tree of Knowledge grew fast by,
2820: Knowledge of Good bought dear by knowing ill.
2821: Southward through *Eden* went a River large,
2822: Nor chang'd his course, but through the shaggie hill
2823: Pass'd underneath ingulft, for God had thrown
2824: That Mountain as his Garden mould high rais'd
2825: Upon the rapid current, which through veins
2826: Of porous Earth with kindly thirst up drawn,
2827: Rose a fresh Fountain, and with many a rill
2828: Waterd the Garden; thence united fell
2829: Down the steep glade, and met the neather Flood,
2830: Which from his darksom passage now appeers,
2831: And now divided into four main Streams,
2832: Runs divers, wandring many a famous Realme
2833: And Country whereof here needs no account,
2834: But rather to tell how, if Art could tell,
2835: How from that Saphire Fount the crisped Brooks,
2836: Rowling on Orient Pearl and sands of Gold,
2837: With mazie error under pendant shades
2838: Ran Nectar, visiting each plant, and fed
2839: Flours worthy of Paradise which not nice Art
2840: In Beds and curious Knots, but Nature boon
2841: Powrd forth profuse on Hill and Dale and Plaine,
2842: Both where the morning Sun first warmly smote
2843: The open field, and where the unpierc't shade
2844: Imbround the noontide Bowrs: Thus was this place,
2845: A happy rural seat of various view;
2846: Groves whose rich Trees wept odorous Gumms and Balme,
2847: Others whose fruit burnisht with Golden Rinde
2849: If true, here onely, and of delicious taste:
2850: Betwixt them Lawns, or level Downs, and Flocks
2851: Grasing the tender herb, were interpos'd,
2852: Or palmie hilloc, or the flourie lap
2853: Of som irriguous Valley spread her store,
2854: Flours of all hue, and without Thorn the Rose:
2855: Another side, umbrageous Grots and Caves
2856: Of coole recess, o're which the mantling Vine
2857: Layes forth her purple Grape, and gently creeps
2858: Luxuriant; mean while murmuring waters fall
2859: Down the slope hills, disperst, or in a Lake,
2860: That to the fringed Bank with Myrtle crownd,
2861: Her chrystall mirror holds, unite thir streams.
2862: The Birds thir quire apply; aires, vernal aires,
2863: Breathing the smell of field and grove, attune
2865: Knit with the *Graces* and the *Hours* in dance
2866: Led on th' Eternal Spring.  Not that faire field
2868: Her self a fairer Floure by gloomie *Dis*
2869: Was gatherd, which cost *Ceres* all that pain
2870: To seek her through the world; nor that sweet Grove
2874: Girt with the River *Triton*, where old *Cham*,
2878: Nor where *Abassin* Kings thir issue Guard,
2879: Mount *Amara*, though this by som suppos'd
2881: By *Nilus* head, enclos'd with shining Rock,
2882: A whole dayes journey high, but wide remote
2883: From this *Assyrian* Garden, where the Fiend
2884: Saw undelighted all delight, all kind
2885: Of living Creatures new to sight and strange:
2886: Two of far nobler shape erect and tall,
2887: Godlike erect, with native Honour clad
2888: In naked Majestie seemd Lords of all,
2889: And worthie seemd, for in thir looks Divine
2890: The image of thir glorious Maker shon,
2891: Truth, Wisdome, Sanctitude severe and pure,
2892: Severe, but in true filial freedom plac't;
2893: Whence true autoritie in men; though both
2894: Not equal, as thir sex not equal seemd;
2895: For contemplation hee and valour formd,
2896: For softness shee and sweet attractive Grace,
2897: Hee for God only, shee for God in him:
2898: His fair large Front and Eye sublime declar'd
2900: Round from his parted forelock manly hung
2901: Clustring, but not beneath his shoulders broad:
2902: Shee as a vail down to the slender waste
2904: Dissheveld, but in wanton ringlets wav'd
2905: As the Vine curles her tendrils, which impli'd
2906: Subjection, but requir'd with gentle sway,
2907: And by her yeilded, by him best receivd,
2908: Yeilded with coy submission, modest pride,
2910: Nor those mysterious parts were then conceald,
2911: Then was not guiltie shame, dishonest shame
2913: Sin-bred, how have ye troubl'd all mankind
2914: With shews instead, meer shews of seeming pure,
2915: And banisht from mans life his happiest life,
2917: So passd they naked on, nor shund the sight
2918: Of God or Angel, for they thought no ill:
2919: So hand in hand they passd, the lovliest pair
2920: That ever since in loves imbraces met,
2921: *Adam* the goodliest man of men since borne
2922: His Sons, the fairest of her Daughters *Eve*.
2923: Under a tuft of shade that on a green
2924: Stood whispering soft, by a fresh Fountain side
2925: They sat them down, and after no more toil
2926: Of thir sweet Gardning labour then suffic'd
2927: To recommend coole *Zephyr*, and made ease
2928: More easie, wholsom thirst and appetite
2929: More grateful, to thir Supper Fruits they fell,
2930: Nectarine Fruits which the compliant boughes
2931: Yeilded them, side-long as they sat recline
2932: On the soft downie Bank damaskt with flours:
2933: The savourie pulp they chew, and in the rinde
2934: Still as they thirsted scoop the brimming stream;
2935: Nor gentle purpose, nor endearing smiles
2936: Wanted, nor youthful dalliance as beseems
2937: Fair couple, linkt in happie nuptial League,
2938: Alone as they.  About them frisking playd
2939: All Beasts of th' Earth, since wilde, and of all chase
2940: In Wood or Wilderness, Forrest or Den;
2941: Sporting the Lion rampd, and in his paw
2942: Dandl'd the Kid; Bears, Tygers, Ounces, Pards
2943: Gambold before them, th' unwieldy Elephant
2944: To make them mirth us'd all his might, & wreathd
2945: His Lithe Proboscis; close the Serpent sly
2947: His breaded train, and of his fatal guile
2948: Gave proof unheeded; others on the grass
2949: Coucht, and now fild with pasture gazing sat,
2950: Or Bedward ruminating: for the Sun
2951: Declin'd was hasting now with prone carreer
2952: To th' Ocean Iles, and in th' ascending Scale
2953: Of Heav'n the Starrs that usher Evening rose:
2954: When *Satan* still in gaze, as first he stood,
2955: Scarce thus at length faild speech recoverd sad.
2956: ¶O Hell! what doe mine eyes with grief behold,
2957: Into our room of bliss thus high advanc't
2958: Creatures of other mould, earth-born perhaps,
2959: Not Spirits, yet to heav'nly Spirits bright
2960: Little inferior; whom my thoughts pursue
2961: With wonder, and could love, so lively shines
2962: In them Divine resemblance, and such grace
2963: The hand that formd them on thir shape hath pourd.
2964: Ah gentle pair, yee little think how nigh
2965: Your change approaches, when all these delights
2966: Will vanish and deliver ye to woe,
2967: More woe, the more your taste is now of joy;
2968: Happie, but for so happie ill secur'd
2969: Long to continue, and this high seat your Heav'n
2970: Ill fenc't for Heav'n to keep out such a foe
2971: As now is enterd; yet no purpos'd foe
2972: To you whom I could pittie thus forlorne
2973: Though I unpittied: League with you I seek,
2974: And mutual amitie so streight, so close,
2975: That I with you must dwell, or you with me
2976: Henceforth; my dwelling haply may not please
2977: Like this fair Paradise, your sense, yet such
2978: Accept your Makers work; he gave it me,
2979: Which I as freely give; Hell shall unfould,
2980: To entertain you two, her widest Gates,
2981: And send forth all her Kings; there will be room,
2982: Not like these narrow limits, to receive
2983: Your numerous ofspring; if no better place,
2984: Thank him who puts me loath to this revenge
2985: On you who wrong me not for him who wrongd.
2986: And should I at your harmless innocence
2987: Melt, as I doe, yet public reason just,
2988: Honour and Empire with revenge enlarg'd,
2989: By conquering this new World, compels me now
2990: To do what else though damnd I should abhorre.
2991: ¶So spake the Fiend, and with necessitie,
2992: The Tyrants plea, excus'd his devilish deeds.
2993: Then from his loftie stand on that high Tree
2994: Down he alights among the sportful Herd
2995: Of those fourfooted kindes, himself now one,
2996: Now other, as thir shape servd best his end
2997: Neerer to view his prey, and unespi'd
2998: To mark what of thir state he more might learn
2999: By word or action markt: about them round
3000: A Lion now he stalkes with fierie glare,
3001: Then as a Tiger, who by chance hath spi'd
3002: In some Purlieu two gentle Fawnes at play,
3003: Strait couches close, then rising changes oft
3004: His couchant watch, as one who chose his ground
3005: Whence rushing he might surest seise them both
3006: Grip't in each paw: when *Adam* first of men
3007: To first of women *Eve* thus moving speech,
3008: Turnd him all eare to heare new utterance flow.
3009: ¶Sole partner and sole part of all these joyes,
3010: Dearer thy self then all; needs must the Power
3011: That made us, and for us this ample World
3012: Be infinitly good, and of his good
3013: As liberal and free as infinite,
3014: That rais'd us from the dust and plac't us here
3015: In all this happiness, who at his hand
3016: Have nothing merited, nor can performe
3017: Aught whereof hee hath need, hee who requires
3018: From us no other service then to keep
3019: This one, this easie charge, of all the Trees
3020: In Paradise that beare delicious fruit
3021: So various, not to taste that onely Tree
3022: Of knowledge, planted by the Tree of Life,
3023: So neer grows Death to Life, what ere Death is,
3024: Som dreadful thing no doubt; for well thou knowst
3025: God hath pronounc't it death to taste that Tree,
3026: The only sign of our obedience left
3027: Among so many signes of power and rule
3028: Conferrd upon us, and Dominion giv'n
3029: Over all other Creatures that possesse
3030: Earth, Aire, and Sea.  Then let us not think hard
3032: Free leave so large to all things else, and choice
3034: But let us ever praise him, and extoll
3035: His bountie, following our delightful task
3036: To prune these growing Plants, & tend these Flours,
3037: Which were it toilsom, yet with thee were sweet.
3038: ¶To whom thus Eve repli'd.  O thou for whom
3039: And from whom I was formd flesh of thy flesh,
3040: And without whom am to no end, my Guide
3041: And Head, what thou hast said is just and right.
3042: For wee to him indeed all praises owe,
3043: And daily thanks, I chiefly who enjoy
3044: So farr the happier Lot, enjoying thee
3045: Preeminent by so much odds, while thou
3046: Like consort to thy self canst no where find.
3047: That day I oft remember, when from sleep
3048: I first awak't, and found my self repos'd
3049: Under a shade on flours, much wondring where
3050: And what I was, whence thither brought, and how.
3051: Not distant far from thence a murmuring sound
3052: Of waters issu'd from a Cave and spread
3053: Into a liquid Plain, then stood unmov'd
3054: Pure as th' expanse of Heav'n; I thither went
3055: With unexperienc't thought, and laid me downe
3056: On the green bank, to look into the cleer
3057: Smooth Lake, that to me seemd another Skie.
3058: As I bent down to look, just opposite,
3059: A Shape within the watry gleam appeerd
3060: Bending to look on me, I started back,
3061: It started back, but pleasd I soon returnd,
3062: Pleas'd it returnd as soon with answering looks
3063: Of sympathie and love, there I had fixt
3064: Mine eyes till now, and pin'd with vain desire,
3065: Had not a voice thus warnd me, What thou seest,
3066: What there thou seest fair Creature is thy self,
3067: With thee it came and goes: but follow me,
3068: And I will bring thee where no shadow staies
3069: Thy coming, and thy soft imbraces, hee
3070: Whose image thou art, him thou shall enjoy
3071: Inseparablie thine, to him shalt beare
3072: Multitudes like thy self, and thence be call'd
3073: Mother of human Race: what could I doe,
3074: But follow strait, invisibly thus led?
3075: Till I espi'd thee, fair indeed and tall,
3076: Under a Platan, yet methought less faire,
3077: Less winning soft, less amiablie milde,
3078: Then that smooth watry image; back I turnd,
3079: Thou following cryd'st aloud, Return fair *Eve*,
3080: Whom fli'st thou? whom thou fli'st, of him thou art,
3081: His flesh, his bone; to give thee being I lent
3082: Out of my side to thee, neerest my heart
3083: Substantial Life, to have thee by my side
3085: Part of my Soul I seek thee, and thee claim
3086: My other half: with that thy gentle hand
3087: Seisd mine, I yeilded, and from that time see
3088: How beauty is excelld by manly grace
3089: And wisdom, which alone is truly fair.
3090: ¶So spake our general Mother, and with eyes
3092: And meek surrender, half imbracing leand
3093: On our first Father, half her swelling Breast
3094: Naked met his under the flowing Gold
3095: Of her loose tresses hid: he in delight
3096: Both of her Beauty and submissive Charms
3098: On *Juno* smiles, when he impregns the Clouds
3099: That shed *May* Flowers; and press'd her Matron lip
3100: With kisses pure: aside the Devil turnd
3101: For envie, yet with jealous leer maligne
3102: Ey'd them askance, and to himself thus plaind.
3103: ¶Sight hateful, sight tormenting! thus these two
3105: The happier *Eden*, shall enjoy thir fill
3106: Of bliss on bliss, while I to Hell am thrust,
3107: Where neither joy nor love, but fierce desire,
3108: Among our other torments not the least,
3109: Still unfulfill'd with pain of longing pines;
3110: Yet let me not forget what I have gain'd
3111: From thir own mouths; all is not theirs it seems:
3112: One fatal Tree there stands of Knowledge call'd,
3113: Forbidden them to taste: Knowledge forbidd'n?
3114: Suspicious, reasonless.  Why should thir Lord
3115: Envie them that? can it be sin to know,
3116: Can it be death? and do they onely stand
3117: By Ignorance, is that thir happie state,
3118: The proof of thir obedience and thir faith?
3119: O fair foundation laid whereon to build
3120: Thir ruine!  Hence I will excite thir minds
3121: With more desire to know, and to reject
3123: To keep them low whom knowledge might exalt
3124: Equal with Gods; aspiring to be such,
3125: They taste and die: what likelier can ensue?
3126: But first with narrow search I must walk round
3127: This Garden, and no corner leave unspi'd;
3128: A chance but chance may lead where I may meet
3129: Some wandring Spirit of Heav'n, by Fountain side,
3130: Or in thick shade retir'd, from him to draw
3131: What further would be learnt.  Live while ye may,
3132: Yet happie pair; enjoy, till I return,
3133: Short pleasures, for long woes are to succeed.
3134: ¶So saying, his proud step he scornful turn'd,
3135: But with sly circumspection, and began
3136: Through wood, through waste, o're hil, o're dale his roam.
3137: Mean while in utmost Longitude, where Heav'n
3138: With Earth and Ocean meets, the setting Sun
3139: Slowly descended, and with right aspect
3140: Against the eastern Gate of Paradise
3141: Leveld his eevning Rayes: it was a Rock
3142: Of Alablaster, pil'd up to the Clouds,
3143: Conspicuous farr, winding with one ascent
3144: Accessible from Earth, one entrance high;
3145: The rest was craggie cliff, that overhung
3146: Still as it rose, impossible to climbe.
3148: Chief of th' Angelic Guards, awaiting night;
3150: Th' unarmed Youth of Heav'n, but nigh at hand
3151: Celestial Armourie, Shields, Helmes, and Speares
3152: Hung high with Diamond flaming, and with Gold.
3153: Thither came *Uriel*, gliding through the Eeven
3154: On a Sun beam, swift as a shooting Starr
3155: In *Autumn* thwarts the night, when vapors fir'd
3156: Impress the Air, and shews the Mariner
3157: From what point of his Compass to beware
3158: Impetuous winds: he thus began in haste.
3159: ¶*Gabriel*, to thee thy cours by Lot hath giv'n
3160: Charge and strict watch that to this happie place
3161: No evil thing approach or enter in;
3162: This day at highth of Noon came to my Spheare
3163: A Spirit, zealous, as he seem'd, to know
3164: More of th' Almighties works, and chiefly Man
3165: Gods latest Image: I describ'd his way
3166: Bent all on speed, and markt his Aerie Gate;
3167: But in the Mount that lies from *Eden* North,
3168: Where he first lighted, soon discernd his looks
3169: Alien from Heav'n, with passions foul obscur'd:
3170: Mine eye pursu'd him still, but under shade
3171: Lost sight of him; one of the banisht crew
3172: I fear, hath ventur'd from the deep, to raise
3173: New troubles; him thy care must be to find.
3174: ¶To whom the winged Warriour thus returnd:
3175: *Uriel*, no wonder if thy perfet sight,
3176: Amid the Suns bright circle where thou sitst,
3177: See farr and wide: in at this Gate none pass
3178: The vigilance here plac't, but such as come
3179: Well known from Heav'n; and since Meridian hour
3180: No Creature thence: if Spirit of other sort,
3181: So minded, have oreleapt these earthie bounds
3182: On purpose, hard thou knowst it to exclude
3184: But if within the circuit of these walks
3185: In whatsoever shape he lurk, of whom
3186: Thou telst, by morrow dawning I shall know.
3187: ¶So promis'd hee, and *Uriel* to his charge
3188: Returnd on that bright beam, whose point now raisd
3189: Bore him slope downward to the Sun now fall'n
3190: Beneath th' *Azores*; whither the prime Orb,
3191: Incredible how swift, had thither rowl'd
3192: Diurnal, or this less volubil Earth
3193: By shorter flight to th' East, had left him there
3194: Arraying with reflected Purple and Gold
3195: The Clouds that on his Western Throne attend:
3196: Now came still Eevning on, and Twilight gray
3197: Had in her sober Liverie all things clad;
3198: Silence accompanied, for Beast and Bird,
3199: They to thir grassie Couch, these to thir Nests
3200: Were slunk, all but the wakeful Nightingale;
3201: She all night long her amorous descant sung;
3202: Silence was pleas'd: now glow'd the Firmament
3204: The starrie Host, rode brightest, till the Moon
3205: Rising in clouded Majestie, at length
3206: Apparent Queen unvaild her peerless light,
3207: And o're the dark her Silver Mantle threw.
3208: ¶When *Adam* thus to *Eve*: Fair Consort, th' hour
3209: Of night, and all things now retir'd to rest
3210: Mind us of like repose, since God hath set
3211: Labour and rest, as day and night to men
3212: Successive, and the timely dew of sleep
3213: Now falling with soft slumbrous weight inclines
3214: Our eye-lids; other Creatures all day long
3215: Rove idle unimploid, and less need rest;
3216: Man hath his daily work of body or mind
3218: And the regard of Heav'n on all his waies;
3220: And of thir doings God takes no account.
3221: Tomorrow ere fresh Morning streak the East
3222: With first approach of light, we must be ris'n,
3223: And at our pleasant labour, to reform
3224: Yon flourie Arbors, yonder Allies green,
3225: Our walks at noon, with branches overgrown,
3226: That mock our scant manuring, and require
3227: More hands then ours to lop thir wanton growth:
3228: Those Blossoms also, and those dropping Gumms,
3229: That lie bestrowne unsightly and unsmooth,
3230: Ask riddance, if we mean to tread with ease;
3231: Mean while, as Nature wills, Night bids us rest.
3232: ¶To whom thus *Eve* with perfet beauty adornd.
3233: My Author and Disposer, what thou bidst
3234: Unargu'd I obey; so God ordains,
3235: God is thy Law, thou mine: to know no more
3236: Is womans happiest knowledge and her praise.
3237: With thee conversing I forget all time,
3238: All seasons and thir change, all please alike.
3239: Sweet is the breath of morn, her rising sweet,
3240: With charm of earliest Birds; pleasant the Sun
3241: When first on this delightful Land he spreads
3242: His orient Beams, on herb, tree, fruit, and flour,
3243: Glistring with dew; fragrant the fertil earth
3244: After soft showers; and sweet the coming on
3245: Of grateful Eevning milde, then silent Night
3246: With this her solemn Bird and this fair Moon,
3247: And these the Gemms of Heav'n, her starrie train:
3248: But neither breath of Morn when she ascends
3249: With charm of earliest Birds, nor rising Sun
3250: On this delightful land, nor herb, fruit, floure,
3251: Glistring with dew, nor fragrance after showers,
3252: Nor grateful Evening mild, nor silent Night
3253: With this her solemn Bird, nor walk by Moon,
3254: Or glittering Starr-light without thee is sweet.
3255: But wherfore all night long shine these, for whom
3256: This glorious sight, when sleep hath shut all eyes?
3258: Daughter of God and Man, accomplisht *Eve*,
3259: Those have thir course to finish, round the Earth,
3260: By morrow Eevning, and from Land to Land
3261: In order, though to Nations yet unborn,
3262: Ministring light prepar'd, they set and rise;
3263: Least total darkness should by Night regaine
3264: Her old possession, and extinguish life
3265: In Nature and all things, which these soft fires
3266: Not only enlighten, but with kindly heate
3267: Of various influence foment and warme,
3268: Temper or nourish, or in part shed down
3269: Thir stellar vertue on all kinds that grow
3270: On Earth, made hereby apter to receive
3271: Perfection from the Suns more potent Ray.
3272: These then, though unbeheld in deep of night,
3273: Shine not in vain, nor think, though men were none,
3274: That heav'n would want spectators, God want praise;
3275: Millions of spiritual Creatures walk the Earth
3276: Unseen, both when we wake, and when we sleep:
3277: All these with ceasless praise his works behold
3278: Both day and night: how often from the steep
3279: Of echoing Hill or Thicket have we heard
3280: Celestial voices to the midnight air,
3281: Sole, or responsive each to others note
3282: Singing thir great Creator: oft in bands
3283: While they keep watch, or nightly rounding walk
3284: With Heav'nly touch of instrumental sounds
3285: In full harmonic number joind, thir songs
3286: Divide the night, and lift our thoughts to Heaven.
3287: ¶Thus talking hand in hand alone they pass'd
3288: On to thir blissful Bower; it was a place
3289: Chos'n by the sovran Planter, when he fram'd
3290: All things to mans delightful use; the roofe
3291: Of thickest covert was inwoven shade
3292: Laurel and Mirtle, and what higher grew
3293: Of firm and fragrant leaf; on either side
3295: Fenc'd up the verdant wall; each beauteous flour,
3297: Rear'd high thir flourisht heads between, and wrought
3299: Crocus, and Hyacinth with rich inlay
3300: Broiderd the ground, more colour'd then with stone
3301: Of costliest Emblem: other Creature here
3302: Beast, Bird, Insect, or Worm durst enter none;
3303: Such was thir awe of man.  In shadier Bower
3304: More sacred and sequesterd, though but feignd,
3306: Nor *Faunus* haunted.  Here in close recess
3307: With Flowers, Garlands, and sweet-smelling Herbs
3308: Espoused *Eve* deckt first her Nuptial Bed,
3309: And heav'nly Quires the Hymenaean sung,
3310: What day the genial Angel to our Sire
3311: Brought her in naked beauty more adorn'd,
3312: More lovely then *Pandora*, whom the Gods
3313: Endowd with all thir gifts, and O too like
3314: In sad event, when to the unwiser Son
3316: Mankind with her faire looks, to be aveng'd
3317: On him who had stole *Joves* authentic fire.
3318: ¶Thus at thir shadie Lodge arriv'd, both stood,
3319: Both turnd, and under op'n Skie ador'd
3320: The God that made both Skie, Air, Earth & Heav'n
3321: Which they beheld, the Moons resplendent Globe
3322: And starrie Pole: Thou also mad'st the Night,
3323: Maker Omnipotent, and thou the Day,
3324: Which we in our appointed work imployd
3325: Have finisht happie in our mutual help
3326: And mutual love, the Crown of all our bliss
3327: Ordain'd by thee, and this delicious place
3328: For us too large, where thy abundance wants
3329: Partakers, and uncropt falls to the ground.
3330: But thou hast promis'd from us two a Race
3331: To fill the Earth, who shall with us extoll
3332: Thy goodness infinite, both when we wake,
3333: And when we seek, as now, thy gift of sleep.
3336: Which God likes best, into thir inmost bower
3337: Handed they went; and eas'd the putting off
3338: These troublesom disguises which wee wear,
3339: Strait side by side were laid, nor turnd I weene
3340: *Adam* from his fair Spouse, nor *Eve* the Rites
3343: Of puritie and place and innocence,
3344: Defaming as impure what God declares
3345: Pure, and commands to som, leaves free to all.
3346: Our Maker bids increase, who bids abstain
3347: But our Destroyer, foe to God and Man?
3348: Haile wedded Love, mysterious Law, true source
3350: In Paradise of all things common else.
3351: By thee adulterous lust was driv'n from men
3352: Among the bestial herds to raunge, by thee
3353: Founded in Reason, Loyal, Just, and Pure,
3354: Relations dear, and all the Charities
3355: Of Father, Son, and Brother first were known.
3356: Farr be it, that I should write thee sin or blame,
3357: Or think thee unbefitting holiest place,
3359: Whose Bed is undefil'd and chast pronounc't,
3360: Present, or past, as Saints and Patriarchs us'd.
3361: Here Love his golden shafts imploies, here lights
3362: His constant Lamp, and waves his purple wings,
3363: Reigns here and revels; not in the bought smile
3365: Casual fruition, nor in Court Amours
3366: Mixt Dance, or wanton Mask, or Midnight Bal,
3367: Or Serenate, which the starv'd Lover sings
3368: To his proud fair, best quitted with disdain.
3369: These lulld by Nightingales imbraceing slept,
3370: And on thir naked limbs the flourie roof
3371: Showrd Roses, which the Morn repair'd.  Sleep on,
3372: Blest pair; and O yet happiest if ye seek
3373: No happier state, and know to know no more.
3374: ¶Now had night measur'd with her shaddowie Cone
3375: Half way up Hill this vast Sublunar Vault,
3376: And from thir Ivorie Port the Cherubim
3377: Forth issuing at th' accustomd hour stood armd
3378: To thir night watches in warlike Parade,
3379: When *Gabriel* to his next in power thus spake.
3380: ¶*Uzziel*, half these draw off, and coast the South
3381: With strictest watch; these other wheel the North,
3382: Our circuit meets full West.  As flame they part
3383: Half wheeling to the Shield, half to the Spear.
3384: From these, two strong and suttle Spirits he calld
3385: That neer him stood, and gave them thus in charge.
3387: Search through this Garden, leav unsearcht no nook,
3388: But chiefly where those two fair Creatures Lodge,
3389: Now laid perhaps asleep secure of harme.
3390: This Eevning from the Sun's decline arriv'd
3391: Who tells of som infernal Spirit seen
3392: Hitherward bent (who could have thought?) escap'd
3393: The barrs of Hell, on errand bad no doubt:
3394: Such where ye find, seise fast, and hither bring.
3395: ¶So saying, on he led his radiant Files,
3396: Daz'ling the Moon; these to the Bower direct
3397: In search of whom they sought: him there they found
3398: Squat like a Toad, close at the eare of *Eve*;
3399: Assaying by his Devilish art to reach
3400: The Organs of her Fancie, and with them forge
3401: Illusions as he list, Phantasms and Dreams,
3402: Or if, inspiring venom, he might taint
3403: Th' animal Spirits that from pure blood arise
3404: Like gentle breaths from Rivers pure, thence raise
3406: Vain hopes, vain aimes, inordinate desires
3407: Blown up with high conceits ingendring pride.
3408: Him thus intent *Ithuriel* with his Spear
3409: Touch'd lightly; for no falshood can endure
3410: Touch of Celestial temper, but returns
3411: Of force to its own likeness: up he starts
3412: Discoverd and surpriz'd.  As when a spark
3413: Lights on a heap of nitrous Powder, laid
3414: Fit for the Tun som Magazin to store
3415: Against a rumord Warr, the Smuttie graine
3416: With sudden blaze diffus'd, inflames the Aire:
3417: So started up in his own shape the Fiend.
3418: Back stept those two fair Angels half amaz'd
3419: So sudden to behold the grieslie King;
3420: Yet thus, unmovd with fear, accost him soon.
3421: ¶Which of those rebell Spirits adjudg'd to Hell
3422: Com'st thou, escap'd thy prison, and transform'd,
3423: Why satst thou like an enemie in waite
3424: Here watching at the head of these that sleep?
3425: ¶Know ye not then said *Satan*, filld with scorn,
3426: Know ye not me? ye knew me once no mate
3427: For you, there sitting where ye durst not soare;
3428: Not to know mee argues your selves unknown,
3429: The lowest of your throng; or if ye know,
3430: Why ask ye, and superfluous begin
3431: Your message, like to end as much in vain?
3432: To whom thus *Zephon*, answering scorn with scorn.
3433: Think not, revolted Spirit, thy shape the same,
3434: Or undiminisht brightness, to be known
3435: As when thou stoodst in Heav'n upright and pure;
3436: That Glorie then, when thou no more wast good,
3437: Departed from thee, and thou resembl'st now
3438: Thy sin and place of doom obscure and foule.
3439: But come, for thou, be sure, shalt give account
3440: To him who sent us, whose charge is to keep
3441: This place inviolable, and these from harm.
3442: ¶So spake the Cherube, and his grave rebuke
3443: Severe in youthful beautie, added grace
3445: And felt how awful goodness is, and saw
3446: Vertue in her shape how lovly, saw, and pin'd
3447: His loss; but chiefly to find here observd
3448: His lustre visibly impar'd; yet seemd
3449: Undaunted.  If I must contend, said he,
3450: Best with the best, the Sender not the sent,
3451: Or all at once; more glorie will be wonn,
3452: Or less be lost.  Thy fear, said *Zephon* bold,
3453: Will save us trial what the least can doe
3454: Single against thee wicked, and thence weak.
3455: ¶The Fiend repli'd not, overcome with rage;
3456: But like a proud Steed reind, went hautie on,
3457: Chaumping his iron curb: to strive or flie
3458: He held it vain; awe from above had quelld
3459: His heart, not else dismai'd.  Now drew they nigh
3460: The western point, where those half-rounding guards
3461: Just met, & closing stood in squadron joind
3462: Awaiting next command.  To whom thir Chief
3463: *Gabriel* from the Front thus calld aloud.
3464: ¶O friends, I hear the tread of nimble feet
3465: Hasting this way, and now by glimps discerne
3467: And with them comes a third of Regal port,
3468: But faded splendor wan; who by his gate
3469: And fierce demeanour seems the Prince of Hell,
3470: Not likely to part hence without contest;
3471: Stand firm, for in his look defiance lours.
3472: ¶He scarce had ended, when those two approachd
3473: And brief related whom they brought, wher found,
3474: How busied, in what form and posture coucht.
3475: ¶To whom with stern regard thus *Gabriel* spake.
3476: Why hast thou, *Satan*, broke the bounds prescrib'd
3477: To thy transgressions, and disturbd the charge
