3478: Of others, who approve not to transgress
3479: By thy example, but have power and right
3480: To question thy bold entrance on this place;
3481: Imploi'd it seems to violate sleep, and those
3482: Whose dwelling God hath planted here in bliss?
3484: *Gabriel*, thou hadst in Heav'n th' esteem of wise,
3485: And such I held thee; but this question askt
3486: Puts me in doubt.  Lives ther who loves his pain?
3487: Who would not, finding way, break loose from Hell,
3488: Though thither doomd?  Thou wouldst thy self, no doubt,
3489: And boldly venture to whatever place
3490: Farthest from pain, where thou mightst hope to change
3492: Dole with delight, which in this place I sought;
3493: To thee no reason; who knowst only good,
3494: But evil hast not tri'd: and wilt object
3495: His will who bound us? let him surer barr
3496: His Iron Gates, if he intends our stay
3497: In that dark durance: thus much what was askt.
3498: The rest is true, they found me where they say;
3499: But that implies not violence or harme.
3500: ¶Thus hee in scorn.  The warlike Angel mov'd,
3502: O loss of one in Heav'n to judge of wise,
3504: And now returns him from his prison scap't,
3505: Gravely in doubt whether to hold them wise
3506: Or not, who ask what boldness brought him hither
3507: Unlicenc't from his bounds in Hell prescrib'd;
3508: So wise he judges it to fly from pain
3509: However, and to scape his punishment.
3510: So judge thou still, presumptuous, till the wrauth,
3511: Which thou incurr'st by flying, meet thy flight
3512: Seavenfold, and scourge that wisdom back to Hell,
3513: Which taught thee yet no better, that no pain
3515: But wherefore thou alone? wherefore with thee
3516: Came not all Hell broke loose? is pain to them
3517: Less pain, less to be fled, or thou then they
3518: Less hardie to endure? courageous Chief,
3519: The first in flight from pain, had'st thou alleg'd
3520: To thy deserted host this cause of flight,
3521: Thou surely hadst not come sole fugitive.
3522: ¶To which the Fiend thus answerd frowning stern.
3523: Not that I less endure, or shrink from pain,
3524: Insulting Angel, well thou knowst I stood
3525: Thy fiercest, when in Battel to thy aide
3526: The blasting volied Thunder made all speed
3527: And seconded thy else not dreaded Spear.
3528: But still thy words at random, as before,
3530: From hard assaies and ill successes past
3531: A faithful Leader, not to hazard all
3532: Through wayes of danger by himself untri'd.
3533: I therefore, I alone first undertook
3534: To wing the desolate Abyss, and spie
3535: This new created World, whereof in Hell
3536: Fame is not silent, here in hope to find
3537: Better abode, and my afflicted Powers
3538: To settle here on Earth, or in mid Aire;
3539: Though for possession put to try once more
3540: What thou and thy gay Legions dare against;
3541: Whose easier business were to serve thir Lord
3542: High up in Heav'n, with songs to hymne his Throne,
3543: And practis'd distances to cringe, not fight.
3544: ¶To whom the warriour Angel soon repli'd.
3545: To say and strait unsay, pretending first
3546: Wise to flie pain, professing next the Spie,
3547: Argues no Leader, but a lyar trac't,
3548: *Satan*, and couldst thou faithful add?  O name,
3549: O sacred name of faithfulness profan'd!
3550: Faithful to whom? to thy rebellious crew?
3551: Armie of Fiends, fit body to fit head;
3552: Was this your discipline and faith ingag'd,
3554: Allegeance to th' acknowledg'd Power supream?
3555: And thou sly hypocrite, who now wouldst seem
3556: Patron of liberty, who more then thou
3557: Once fawn'd, and cring'd, and servilly ador'd
3558: Heav'ns awful Monarch? wherefore but in hope
3559: To dispossess him, and thy self to reigne?
3560: But mark what I arreede thee now, avant;
3561: Flie thither whence thou fledst: if from this houre
3562: Within these hallowd limits thou appeer,
3563: Back to th' infernal pit I drag thee chaind,
3564: And Seale thee so, as henceforth not to scorne
3565: The facil gates of hell too slightly barrd.
3566: ¶So threatn'd hee, but *Satan* to no threats
3567: Gave heed, but waxing more in rage repli'd.
3568: ¶Then when I am thy captive talk of chaines,
3569: Proud limitarie Cherube, but ere then
3570: Farr heavier load thy self expect to feel
3571: From my prevailing arme, though Heavens King
3572: Ride on thy wings, and thou with thy Compeers,
3573: Us'd to the yoak, draw'st his triumphant wheels
3574: In progress through the rode of Heav'n Star-pav'd.
3575: ¶While thus he spake, th' Angelic Squadron bright
3576: Turnd fierie red, sharpning in mooned hornes
3577: Thir Phalanx, and began to hemm him round
3578: With ported Spears, as thick as when a field
3579: Of *Ceres* ripe for harvest waving bends
3580: Her bearded Grove of ears, which way the wind
3581: Swayes them; the careful Plowman doubting stands
3582: Least on the threshing floore his hopeful sheaves
3583: Prove chaff.  On th' other side *Satan* allarm'd
3584: Collecting all his might dilated stood,
3586: His stature reacht the Skie, and on his Crest
3587: Sat horror Plum'd; nor wanted in his graspe
3588: What seemd both Spear and Shield: now dreadful deeds
3589: Might have ensu'd, nor onely Paradise
3590: In this commotion, but the Starrie Cope
3591: Of Heav'n perhaps, or all the Elements
3592: At least had gon to rack, disturbd and torne
3593: With violence of this conflict, had not soon
3594: Th' Eternal to prevent such horrid fray
3595: Hung forth in Heav'n his golden Scales, yet seen
3597: Wherein all things created first he weighd,
3598: The pendulous round Earth with ballanc't Aire
3599: In counterpoise, now ponders all events,
3600: Battels and Realms: in these he put two weights
3601: The sequel each of parting and of fight;
3602: The latter quick up flew, and kickt the beam;
3603: Which *Gabriel* spying, thus bespake the Fiend.
3604: ¶*Satan*, I know thy strength, and thou knowst mine,
3605: Neither our own but giv'n; what follie then
3606: To boast what Arms can doe, since thine no more
3607: Then Heav'n permits, nor mine, though doubld now
3608: To trample thee as mire: for proof look up,
3609: And read thy Lot in yon celestial Sign
3610: Where thou art weigh'd, & shown how light, how weak,
3611: If thou resist.  The Fiend lookt up and knew
3612: His mounted scale aloft: nor more; but fled
3613: Murmuring, and with him fled the shades of night.
3615: ¶Now Morn her rosie steps in th' Eastern Clime
3616: Advancing, sow'd the Earth with Orient Pearle,
3617: When *Adam* wak't, so customd, for his sleep
3618: Was Aerie light, from pure digestion bred,
3619: And temperat vapors bland, which th' only sound
3620: Of leaves and fuming rills, *Aurora's* fan,
3621: Lightly dispers'd, and the shrill Matin Song
3622: Of Birds on every bough; so much the more
3623: His wonder was to find unwak'nd *Eve*
3624: With Tresses discompos'd, and glowing Cheek,
3625: As through unquiet rest: he on his side
3626: Leaning half-rais'd, with looks of cordial Love
3627: Hung over her enamour'd, and beheld
3628: Beautie, which whether waking or asleep,
3629: Shot forth peculiar Graces; then with voice
3631: Her hand soft touching, whisperd thus.  Awake
3632: My fairest, my espous'd, my latest found,
3633: Heav'ns last best gift, my ever new delight,
3634: Awake, the morning shines, and the fresh field
3635: Calls us, we lose the prime, to mark how spring
3636: Our tended Plants, how blows the Citron Grove,
3637: What drops the Myrrhe, & what the balmie Reed,
3638: How Nature paints her colours, how the Bee
3639: Sits on the Bloom extracting liquid sweet.
3640: ¶Such whispering wak'd her, but with startl'd eye
3641: On *Adam*, whom imbracing, thus she spake.
3642: ¶O Sole in whom my thoughts find all repose,
3643: My Glorie, my Perfection, glad I see
3644: Thy face, and Morn return'd, for I this Night,
3645: Such night till this I never pass'd, have dream'd,
3646: If dream'd, not as I oft am wont, of thee,
3647: Works of day pass't, or morrows next designe,
3648: But of offence and trouble, which my mind
3649: Knew never till this irksom night; methought
3650: Close at mine ear one call'd me forth to walk
3651: With gentle voice, I thought it thine; it said,
3652: Why sleepst thou *Eve*? now is the pleasant time,
3653: The cool, the silent, save where silence yields
3654: To the night-warbling Bird, that now awake
3655: Tunes sweetest his love-labor'd song; now reignes
3656: Full Orb'd the Moon, and with more pleasing light
3657: Shadowie sets off the face of things; in vain,
3658: If none regard; Heav'n wakes with all his eyes,
3659: Whom to behold but thee, Natures desire,
3660: In whose sight all things joy, with ravishment
3661: Attracted by thy beauty still to gaze.
3662: I rose as at thy call, but found thee not;
3663: To find thee I directed then my walk;
3664: And on, methought, alone I pass'd through ways
3665: That brought me on a sudden to the Tree
3666: Of interdicted Knowledge: fair it seem'd,
3667: Much fairer to my Fancie then by day:
3668: And as I wondring lookt, beside it stood
3669: One shap'd & wing'd like one of those from Heav'n
3670: By us oft seen; his dewie locks distill'd
3671: Ambrosia; on that Tree he also gaz'd;
3672: And O fair Plant, said he, with fruit surcharg'd,
3673: Deigns none to ease thy load and taste thy sweet,
3674: Nor God, nor Man; is Knowledge so despis'd?
3675: Or envie, or what reserve forbids to taste?
3676: Forbid who will, none shall from me withhold
3677: Longer thy offerd good, why else set here?
3678: This said he paus'd not, but with ventrous Arme
3679: He pluckt, he tasted; mee damp horror chil'd
3680: At such bold words voucht with a deed so bold:
3681: But he thus overjoy'd, O Fruit Divine,
3682: Sweet of thy self, but much more sweet thus cropt,
3683: Forbidd'n here, it seems, as onely fit
3684: For Gods, yet able to make Gods of Men:
3685: And why not Gods of Men, since good, the more
3687: The Author not impair'd, but honourd more?
3689: Partake thou also; happie though thou art,
3690: Happier thou mayst be, worthier canst not be:
3691: Taste this, and be henceforth among the Gods
3692: Thy self a Goddess, not to Earth confind,
3693: But somtimes in the Air, as wee, somtimes
3694: Ascend to Heav'n, by merit thine, and see
3695: What life the Gods live there, and such live thou.
3696: So saying, he drew nigh, and to me held,
3697: Even to my mouth of that same fruit held part
3698: Which he had pluckt; the pleasant savourie smell
3699: So quick'nd appetite, that I, methought,
3700: Could not but taste.  Forthwith up to the Clouds
3701: With him I flew, and underneath beheld
3702: The Earth outstretcht immense, a prospect wide
3703: And various: wondring at my flight and change
3705: My Guide was gon, and I, me thought, sunk down,
3706: And fell asleep; but O how glad I wak'd
3707: To find this but a dream!  Thus *Eve* her Night
3709: ¶Best Image of my self and dearer half,
3710: The trouble of thy thoughts this night in sleep
3711: Affects me equally; nor can I like
3712: This uncouth dream, of evil sprung I fear;
3713: Yet evil whence? in thee can harbour none,
3714: Created pure.  But know that in the Soule
3715: Are many lesser Faculties that serve
3716: Reason as chief; among these Fansie next
3717: Her office holds; of all external things,
3718: Which the five watchful Senses represent,
3720: Which Reason joyning or disjoyning, frames
3721: All what we affirm or what deny, and call
3722: Our knowledge or opinion; then retires
3723: Into her private Cell when Nature rests.
3724: Oft in her absence mimic Fansie wakes
3725: To imitate her; but misjoyning shapes,
3726: Wilde work produces oft, and most in dreams,
3727: Ill matching words and deeds long past or late.
3728: Som such resemblances methinks I find
3729: Of our last Eevnings talk, in this thy dream,
3730: But with addition strange; yet be not sad.
3731: Evil into the mind of God or Man
3732: May come and go, so unapprov'd, and leave
3733: No spot or blame behind: Which gives me hope
3734: That what in sleep thou didst abhorr to dream,
3735: Waking thou never wilt consent to do.
3736: Be not disheart'nd then, nor cloud those looks
3737: That wont to be more chearful and serene
3738: Then when fair Morning first smiles on the World,
3739: And let us to our fresh imployments rise
3740: Among the Groves, the Fountains, and the Flours
3741: That open now thir choicest bosom'd smells
3742: Reservd from night, and kept for thee in store.
3743: ¶So cheard he his fair Spouse, and she was cheard,
3744: But silently a gentle tear let fall
3745: From either eye, and wip'd them with her haire;
3746: Two other precious drops that ready stood,
3747: Each in thir chrystal sluce, hee ere they fell
3748: Kiss'd as the gracious signs of sweet remorse
3749: And pious awe, that feard to have offended.
3750: ¶So all was cleard, and to the Field they haste.
3751: But first from under shadie arborous roof,
3752: Soon as they forth were come to open sight
3753: Of day-spring, and the Sun, who scarce up risen
3754: With wheels yet hov'ring o're the Ocean brim,
3755: Shot paralel to the earth his dewie ray,
3756: Discovering in wide Lantskip all the East
3758: Lowly they bow'd adoring, and began
3759: Thir Orisons, each Morning duly paid
3760: In various style, for neither various style
3761: Nor holy rapture wanted they to praise
3762: Thir Maker, in fit strains pronounc't or sung
3764: Flowd from thir lips, in Prose or numerous Verse,
3765: More tuneable then needed Lute or Harp
3766: To add more sweetness, and they thus began.
3767: ¶These are thy glorious works, Parent of good,
3769: Thus wondrous fair; thy self how wondrous then!
3770: Unspeakable, who sitst above these Heavens
3771: To us invisible or dimly seen
3772: In these thy lowest works, yet these declare
3773: Thy goodness beyond thought, and Power Divine:
3774: Speak yee who best can tell, ye Sons of light,
3775: Angels, for yee behold him, and with songs
3776: And choral symphonies, Day without Night,
3777: Circle his Throne rejoycing, yee in Heav'n,
3778: On Earth joyn all yee Creatures to extoll
3779: Him first, him last, him midst, and without end.
3780: Fairest of Starrs, last in the train of Night,
3781: If better thou belong not to the dawn,
3782: Sure pledge of day, that crownst the smiling Morn
3783: With thy bright Circlet, praise him in thy Spheare
3784: While day arises, that sweet hour of Prime.
3785: Thou Sun, of this great World both Eye and Soule,
3786: Acknowledge him thy Greater, sound his praise
3787: In thy eternal course, both when thou climb'st,
3788: And when high Noon hast gaind, & when thou fallst.
3789: Moon, that now meetst the orient Sun, now fli'st
3790: With the fixt Starrs, fixt in thir Orb that flies,
3791: And yee five other wandring Fires that move
3792: In mystic Dance not without Song, resound
3793: His praise, who out of Darkness call'd up Light.
3794: Aire, and ye Elements the eldest birth
3795: Of Natures Womb, that in quaternion run
3797: And nourish all things, let your ceasless change
3798: Varie to our great Maker still new praise.
3799: Ye Mists and Exhalations that now rise
3800: From Hill or steaming Lake, duskie or grey,
3801: Till the Sun paint your fleecie skirts with Gold,
3802: In honour to the Worlds great Author rise,
3803: Whether to deck with Clouds the uncolourd skie,
3804: Or wet the thirstie Earth with falling showers,
3805: Rising or falling still advance his praise.
3806: His praise ye Winds, that from four Quarters blow,
3807: Breath soft or loud; and wave your tops, ye Pines,
3808: With every Plant, in sign of Worship wave.
3809: Fountains and yee, that warble, as ye flow,
3810: Melodious murmurs, warbling tune his praise.
3811: Joyn voices all ye living Souls, ye Birds,
3812: That singing up to Heaven Gate ascend,
3813: Bear on your wings and in your notes his praise;
3814: Yee that in Waters glide, and yee that walk
3815: The Earth, and stately tread, or lowly creep;
3816: Witness if I be silent, Morn or Eeven,
3817: To Hill, or Valley, Fountain, or fresh shade
3818: Made vocal by my Song, and taught his praise.
3819: Hail universal Lord, be bounteous still
3820: To give us onely good; and if the night
3821: Have gathered aught of evil or conceald,
3822: Disperse it, as now light dispels the dark.
3823: ¶So pray'd they innocent, and to thir thoughts
3824: Firm peace recoverd soon and wonted calm.
3825: On to thir mornings rural work they haste
3826: Among sweet dewes and flours; where any row
3827: Of Fruit-trees overwoodie reachd too farr
3828: Thir pamperd boughes, and needed hands to check
3829: Fruitless imbraces: or they led the Vine
3830: To wed her Elm; she spous'd about him twines
3831: Her mariageable arms, and with her brings
3832: Her dowr th' adopted Clusters, to adorn
3833: His barren leaves.  Them thus imploid beheld
3834: With pittie Heav'ns high King, and to him call'd
3837: His marriage with the seaventimes-wedded Maid.
3838: ¶*Raphael*, said hee, thou hear'st what stir on Earth
3839: *Satan* from Hell scap't through the darksom Gulf
3840: Hath raisd in Paradise, and how disturbd
3841: This night the human pair, how he designes
3842: In them at once to ruin all mankind.
3843: Go therefore, half this day as friend with friend
3844: Converse with *Adam*, in what Bowre or shade
3845: Thou find'st him from the heat of Noon retir'd,
3846: To respit his day-labour with repast,
3847: Or with repose; and such discourse bring on,
3848: As may advise him of his happie state,
3849: Happiness in his power left free to will,
3850: Left to his own free Will, his Will though free,
3851: Yet mutable; whence warne him to beware
3852: He swerve not too secure: tell him withall
3853: His danger, and from whom, what enemie
3854: Late falln himself from Heav'n, is plotting now
3855: The fall of others from like state of bliss;
3856: By violence, no, for that shall be withstood,
3857: But by deceit and lies; this let him know,
3860: ¶So spake th' Eternal Father, and fulfilld
3861: All Justice: nor delaid the winged Saint
3862: After his charge receivd, but from among
3863: Thousand Celestial Ardors, where he stood
3864: Vaild with his gorgeous wings, up springing light
3865: Flew through the midst of Heav'n; th' angelic Quires
3866: On each hand parting, to his speed gave way
3867: Through all th' Empyreal road; till at the Gate
3868: Of Heav'n arriv'd, the gate self-opend wide
3869: On golden Hinges turning, as by work
3870: Divine the sov'ran Architect had fram'd.
3871: From hence, no cloud, or, to obstruct his sight,
3872: Starr interpos'd, however small he sees,
3873: Not unconform to other shining Globes,
3874: Earth and the Gard'n of God, with Cedars crownd
3875: Above all Hills.  As when by night the Glass
3877: Imagind Lands and Regions in the Moon:
3880: A cloudy spot.  Down thither prone in flight
3881: He speeds, and through the vast Ethereal Skie
3882: Sailes between worlds & worlds, with steddie wing
3883: Now on the polar windes, then with quick Fann
3884: Winnows the buxom Air; till within soare
3885: Of Towring Eagles, to all the Fowles he seems
3886: A *Phoenix*, gaz'd by all, as that sole Bird
3887: When to enshrine his reliques in the Sun's
3888: Bright Temple, to *Aegyptian Theb's* he flies.
3889: At once on th' Eastern cliff of Paradise
3890: He lights, and to his proper shape returns
3891: A Seraph wingd; six wings he wore, to shade
3892: His lineaments Divine; the pair that clad
3893: Each shoulder broad, came mantling o're his brest
3894: With regal Ornament; the middle pair
3895: Girt like a Starrie Zone his waste, and round
3896: Skirted his loines and thighes with downie Gold
3897: And colours dipt in Heav'n; the third his feet
3898: Shaddowd from either heele with featherd maile
3899: Skie-tinctur'd grain.  Like *Maia's* son he stood,
3900: And shook his Plumes, that Heav'nly fragrance filld
3901: The circuit wide.  Strait knew him all the bands
3902: Of Angels under watch; and to his state,
3903: And to his message high in honour rise;
3904: For on som message high they guessd him bound.
3905: Thir glittering Tents he passd, and now is come
3906: Into the blissful field, through Groves of Myrrhe,
3907: And flouring Odours, Cassia, Nard, and Balme;
3908: A Wilderness of sweets; for Nature here
3909: Wantond as in her prime, and plaid at will
3910: Her Virgin Fancies, pouring forth more sweet,
3911: Wilde above rule or art; enormous bliss.
3912: Him through the spicie Forrest onward com
3913: *Adam* discernd, as in the dore he sat
3914: Of his coole Bowre, while now the mounted Sun
3915: Shot down direct his fervid Raies, to warme
3916: Earths inmost womb, more warmth then *Adam* need;
3917: And *Eve* within, due at her hour prepar'd
3918: For dinner savourie fruits, of taste to please
3919: True appetite, and not disrelish thirst
3920: Of nectarous draughts between, from milkie stream,
3921: Berrie or Grape: to whom thus *Adam* call'd.
3922: ¶Haste hither *Eve*, and worth thy sight behold
3923: Eastward among those Trees, what glorious shape
3924: Comes this way moving; seems another Morn
3925: Ris'n on mid-noon; som great behest from Heav'n
3926: To us perhaps he brings, and will voutsafe
3927: This day to be our Guest.  But goe with speed,
3928: And what thy stores contain, bring forth and poure
3929: Abundance, fit to honour and receive
3930: Our Heav'nly stranger; well we may afford
3931: Our givers thir own gifts, and large bestow
3932: From large bestowd, where Nature multiplies
3933: Her fertil growth, and by disburd'ning grows
3934: More fruitful, which instructs us not to spare.
3936: Of God inspir'd, small store will serve, where store,
3937: All seasons, ripe for use hangs on the stalk;
3938: Save what by frugal storing firmness gains
3939: To nourish, and superfluous moist consumes:
3940: But I will haste and from each bough and break,
3941: Each Plant & juciest Gourd will pluck such choice
3942: To entertain our Angel guest, as hee
3943: Beholding shall confess that here on Earth
3944: God hath dispenst his bounties as in Heav'n.
3945: ¶So saying, with dispatchful looks in haste
3946: She turns, on hospitable thoughts intent
3947: What choice to chuse for delicacie best,
3948: What order, so contriv'd as not to mix
3949: Tastes, not well joynd, inelegant, but bring
3950: Taste after taste upheld with kindliest change,
3951: Bestirs her then, and from each tender stalk
3953: In *India* East or West, or middle shoare
3954: In *Pontus* or the *Punic* Coast, or where
3955: *Alcinous* reign'd, fruit of all kindes, in coate,
3956: Rough, or smooth rin'd, or bearded husk, or shell
3957: She gathers, Tribute large, and on the board
3958: Heaps with unsparing hand; for drink the Grape
3959: She crushes, inoffensive moust, and meathes
3960: From many a berrie, and from sweet kernels prest
3961: She tempers dulcet creams, nor these to hold
3962: Wants her fit vessels pure, then strews the ground
3963: With Rose and Odours from the shrub unfum'd.
3964: Mean while our Primitive great Sire, to meet
3965: His god-like Guest, walks forth, without more train
3966: Accompani'd then with his own compleat
3967: Perfections, in himself was all his state,
3968: More solemn then the tedious pomp that waits
3969: On Princes, when thir rich Retinue long
3970: Of Horses led, and Grooms besmeard with Gold
3971: Dazles the croud, and sets them all agape.
3972: Neerer his presence *Adam* though not awd,
3973: Yet with submiss approach and reverence meek,
3974: As to a superior Nature, bowing low,
3975: ¶Thus said.  Native of Heav'n, for other place
3976: None can then Heav'n such glorious shape contain;
3977: Since by descending from the Thrones above,
3978: Those happie places thou hast deignd a while
3979: To want, and honour these, voutsafe with us
3980: Two onely, who yet by sov'ran gift possess
3981: This spacious ground, in yonder shadie Bowre
3982: To rest, and what the Garden choicest bears
3983: To sit and taste, till this meridian heat
3984: Be over, and the Sun more coole decline.
3985: ¶Whom thus the Angelic Vertue answerd milde.
3986: *Adam*, I therefore came, nor art thou such
3987: Created, or such place hast here to dwell,
3988: As may not oft invite, though Spirits of Heav'n
3989: To visit thee; lead on then where thy Bowre
3990: Oreshades; for these mid-hours, till Eevning rise
3991: I have at will.  So to the Silvan Lodge
3992: They came, that like *Pomona's* Arbour smil'd
3993: With flourets deck't and fragrant smells; but *Eve*
3994: Undeckt, save with her self more lovely fair
3995: Then Wood-Nymph, or the fairest Goddess feign'd
3996: Of three that in Mount *Ida* naked strove,
3997: Stood to entertain her guest from Heav'n; no vaile
3998: Shee needed, Vertue-proof, no thought infirme
3999: Alterd her cheek.  On whom the Angel *Haile*
4002: ¶Haile Mother of Mankind, whose fruitful Womb
4003: Shall fill the World more numerous with thy Sons
4004: Then with these various fruits the Trees of God
4005: Have heap'd this Table.  Rais'd of grassie terf
4006: Thir Table was, and mossie seats had round,
4007: And on her ample Square from side to side
4009: Danc'd hand in hand.  A while discourse they hold;
4010: No fear lest Dinner coole; when thus began
4011: Our Authour.  Heav'nly stranger, please to taste
4012: These bounties which our Nourisher, from whom
4013: All perfet good unmeasur'd out, descends,
4014: To us for food and for delight hath caus'd
4015: The Earth to yeild; unsavourie food perhaps
4016: To spiritual Natures; only this I know,
4017: That one Celestial Father gives to all.
4018: ¶To whom the Angel.  Therefore what he gives
4019: (Whose praise be ever sung) to man in part
4020: Spiritual, may of purest Spirits be found
4021: No ingrateful food: and food alike those pure
4023: As doth your Rational; and both contain
4025: Of sense, whereby they hear, see, smell, touch, taste,
4028: For know, whatever was created, needs
4029: To be sustaind and fed; of Elements
4030: The grosser feeds the purer, earth the sea,
4031: Earth and the Sea feed Air, the Air those Fires
4032: Ethereal, and as lowest first the Moon;
4033: Whence in her visage round those spots, unpurg'd
4034: Vapours not yet into her substance turnd.
4035: Nor doth the Moon no nourishment exhale
4036: From her moist Continent to higher Orbes.
4037: The Sun that light imparts to all, receives
4039: In humid exhalations, and at Even
4040: Sups with the Ocean: though in Heav'n the Trees
4041: Of life ambrosial frutage bear, and vines
4042: Yeild Nectar, though from off the boughs each Morn
4043: We brush mellifluous Dewes, and find the ground
4044: Cover'd with pearly grain: yet God hath here
4045: Varied his bounty so with new delights,
4046: As may compare with Heaven; and to taste
4047: Think not I shall be nice.  So down they sat,
4048: And to thir viands fell, nor seemingly
4049: The Angel, nor in mist, the common gloss
4050: Of Theologians, but with keen dispatch
4051: Of real hunger, and concoctive heate
4053: Through Spirits with ease; nor wonder; if by fire
4054: Of sooty coal the Empiric Alchimist
4055: Can turn, or holds it possible to turn
4056: Metals of drossiest Ore to perfet Gold
4057: As from the Mine.  Mean while at Table *Eve*
4058: Ministerd naked, and thir flowing cups
4059: With pleasant liquors crown'd: O innocence
4061: Then had the Sons of God excuse to have bin
4062: Enamour'd at that sight; but in those hearts
4064: Was understood, the injur'd Lovers Hell.
4065: ¶Thus when with meats & drinks they had suffic'd,
4066: Not burd'nd Nature, sudden mind arose
4067: In *Adam*, not to let th' occasion pass
4068: Given him by this great Conference to know
4069: Of things above his World, and of thir being
4070: Who dwell in Heav'n, whose excellence he saw
4071: Transcend his own so farr, whose radiant forms
4072: Divine effulgence, whose high Power so far
4073: Exceeded human, and his wary speech
4074: Thus to th' Empyreal Minister he fram'd.
4075: ¶Inhabitant with God, now know I well
4076: Thy favour, in this honour done to man,
4077: Under whose lowly roof thou hast voutsaf't
4078: To enter, and these earthly fruits to taste,
4079: Food not of Angels, yet accepted so,
4080: As that more willingly thou couldst not seem
4081: At Heav'ns high feasts to have fed: yet what compare?
4083: O *Adam*, one Almightie is, from whom
4084: All things proceed, and up to him return,
4085: If not deprav'd from good, created all
4086: Such to perfection, one first matter all,
4087: Indu'd with various forms, various degrees
4088: Of substance, and in things that live, of life;
4089: But more refin'd, more spiritous, and pure,
4090: As neerer to him plac't or neerer tending
4091: Each in thir several active Sphears assignd,
4092: Till body up to spirit work, in bounds
4093: Proportiond to each kind.  So from the root
4094: Springs lighter the green stalk, from thence the leaves
4095: More aerie, last the bright consummate floure
4096: Spirits odorous breathes: flours and thir fruit
4097: Mans nourishment, by gradual scale sublim'd
4098: To vital Spirits aspire, to animal,
4099: To intellectual, give both life and sense,
4100: Fansie and understanding, whence the soule
4101: Reason receives, and reason is her being,
4103: Is oftest yours, the latter most is ours,
4104: Differing but in degree, of kind the same.
4105: Wonder not then, what God for you saw good
4106: If I refuse not, but convert, as you,
4107: To proper substance; time may come when men
4108: With Angels may participate, and find
4109: No inconvenient Diet, nor too light Fare:
4110: And from these corporal nutriments perhaps
4111: Your bodies may at last turn all to Spirit
4112: Improv'd by tract of time, and wingd ascend
4113: Ethereal, as wee, or may at choice
4114: Here or in Heav'nly Paradises dwell;
4115: If ye be found obedient, and retain
4117: Whose progenie you are.  Mean while enjoy
4118: Your fill what happiness this happie state
4120: ¶To whom the Patriarch of mankind repli'd.
4122: Well hast thou taught the way that might direct
4123: Our knowledge, and the scale of Nature set
4126: By steps we may ascend to God.  But say,
4127: What meant that caution joind, *If ye be found
4128: obedient?* can wee want obedience then
4129: To him, or possibly his love desert
4130: Who formd us from the dust, and plac'd us here
4131: Full to the utmost measure of what bliss
4132: Human desires can seek or apprehend?
4133: ¶To whom the Angel.  Son of Heav'n and Earth,
4134: Attend: That thou art happie, owe to God;
4135: That thou continu'st such, owe to thy self,
4136: That is, to thy obedience; therein stand.
4137: This was that caution giv'n thee; be advis'd.
4138: God made thee perfet, not immutable;
4139: And good he made thee, but to persevere
4140: He left it in thy power, ordaind thy will
4141: By nature free, not over-rul'd by Fate
4144: Not our necessitated, such with him
4145: Findes no acceptance, nor can find, for how
4146: Can hearts, not free, be tri'd whether they serve
4147: Willing or no, who will but what they must
4148: By Destinie, and can no other choose?
4149: My self and all th' Angelic Host that stand
4150: In sight of God enthron'd, our happie state
4151: Hold, as you yours, while our obedience holds;
4152: On other surety none; freely we serve.
4153: Because wee freely love, as in our will
4154: To love or not; in this we stand or fall:
4155: And som are fall'n, to disobedience fall'n,
4156: And so from Heav'n to deepest Hell; O fall
4157: From what high state of bliss into what woe!
4158: ¶To whom our great Progenitor.  Thy words
4159: Attentive, and with more delighted eare
4160: Divine instructer, I have heard, then when
4161: Cherubic Songs by night from neighbouring Hills
4162: Aereal Music send: nor knew I not
4163: To be both will and deed created free;
4164: Yet that we never shall forget to love
4165: Our maker, and obey him whose command
4166: Single, is yet so just, my constant thoughts
4167: Assur'd me and still assure: though what thou tellst
4168: Hath past in Heav'n, som doubt within me move,
4169: But more desire to hear, if thou consent,
4170: The full relation, which must needs be strange,
4171: Worthy of Sacred silence to be heard;
4172: And we have yet large day, for scarce the Sun
4173: Hath finisht half his journey, and scarce begins
4174: His other half in the great Zone of Heav'n.
4176: After short pause assenting, thus began.
4177: ¶High matter thou injoinst me, O prime of men,
4178: Sad task and hard, for how shall I relate
4179: To human sense th' invisible exploits
4180: Of warring Spirits; how without remorse
4181: The ruin of so many glorious once
4182: And perfet while they stood; how last unfould
4183: The secrets of another world, perhaps
4184: Not lawful to reveal? yet for thy good
4185: This is dispenc't, and what surmounts the reach
4186: Of human sense, I shall delineate so,
4187: By lik'ning spiritual to corporal forms,
4188: As may express them best, though what if Earth
4189: Be but the shaddow of Heav'n, and things therein
4190: Each to other like, more then on earth is thought?
4191: ¶As yet this world was not, and *Chaos* wilde
4192: Reignd where these Heav'ns now rowl, where Earth now rests
4193: Upon her Center pois'd, when on a day
4195: To motion, measures all things durable
4196: By present, past, and future) on such day
4197: As Heav'ns great Year brings forth, th' Empyreal Host
4198: Of Angels by Imperial summons call'd,
4200: Forthwith from all the ends of Heav'n appeerd
4201: Under thir Hierarchs in orders bright
4202: Ten thousand thousand Ensignes high advanc'd,
4203: Standards, and Gonfalons twixt Van and Reare
4204: Streame in the Aire, and for distinction serve
4205: Of Hierarchies, of Orders, and Degrees;
4206: Or in thir glittering Tissues bear imblaz'd
4207: Holy Memorials, acts of Zeale and Love
4208: Recorded eminent.  Thus when in Orbes
4210: Orb within Orb, the Father infinite,
4211: By whom in bliss imbosom'd sat the Son,
4212: Amidst as from a flaming Mount, whoseop
4213: Brightness had made invisible, thus spake.
4214: ¶Hear all ye Angels, Progenie of Light,
4216: Hear my Decree, which unrevok't shall stand.
4217: This day I have begot whom I declare
4218: My onely Son, and on this holy Hill
4219: Him have anointed, whom ye now behold
4220: At my right hand; your Head I him appoint;
4221: And by my Self have sworn to him shall bow
4222: All knees in Heav'n, and shall confess him Lord:
4223: Under his great Vice-gerent Reign abide
4225: For ever happie: him who disobeyes
4226: Mee disobeyes, breaks union, and that day
4227: Cast out from God and blessed vision, falls
4228: Into utter darkness, deep ingulft, his place
4230: ¶So spake th' Omnipotent, and with his words
4231: All seemd well pleas'd, all seem'd, but were not all.
4232: That day, as other solem dayes, they spent
4233: In song and dance about the sacred Hill,
4234: Mystical dance, which yonder starrie Spheare
4235: Of Planets and of fixt in all her Wheeles
4238: Then most, when most irregular they seem:
4239: And in thir motions harmonie Divine
4240: So smooths her charming tones, that Gods own ear
4242: (For we have also our Eevning and our Morn,
4243: We ours for change delectable, not need)
4244: Forthwith from dance to sweet repast they turn
4245: Desirous, all in Circles as they stood,
4246: Tables are set, and on a sudden pil'd
4247: With Angels Food, and rubied Nectar flows:
4248: In Pearl, in Diamond, and massie Gold,
4249: Fruit of delicious Vines, the growth of Heav'n.
4250: They eat, they drink, and with refection sweet
4251: Are fill'd, before th' all bounteous King, who showrd
4252: With copious hand, rejoycing in thir joy.
4253: Now when ambrosial Night with Clouds exhal'd
4254: From that high mount of God, whence light & shade
4255: Spring both, the face of brightest Heav'n had changd
4256: To grateful Twilight (for Night comes not there
4257: In darker veile) and roseat Dews dispos'd
4258: All but the unsleeping eyes of God to rest,
4259: Wide over all the Plain, and wider farr
4260: Then all this globous Earth in Plain outspred,
4261: (Such are the Courts of God) Th' Angelic throng
4262: Disperst in Bands and Files thir Camp extend
4263: By living Streams among the Trees of Life,
4266: Fannd with coole Winds, save those who in thir course
4267: Melodious Hymns about the sovran Throne
4268: Alternate all night long: but not so wak'd
4269: *Satan*, so call him now, his former name
4270: Is heard no more Heav'n; he of the first,
4271: If not the first Arch-Angel, great in Power,
4272: In favour and praeeminence, yet fraught
4273: With envie against the Son of God, that day
4274: Honourd by his great Father, and proclaimd
4276: Through pride that sight, and thought himself impaird.
4278: Soon as midnight brought on the duskie houre
4279: Friendliest to sleep and silence, he resolv'd
4280: With all his Legions to dislodge, and leave
4283: Awak'ning, thus to him in secret spake.
4284: ¶Sleepst thou Companion dear, what sleep can close
4285: Thy eye-lids? and remembrest what Decree
4286: Of yesterday, so late hath past the lips
4287: Of Heav'ns Almightie.  Thou to me thy thoughts
4288: Wast wont, I mine to thee was wont to impart;
4289: Both waking we were one; how then can now
4290: Thy sleep dissent? new Laws thou seest impos'd;
4291: New Laws from him who reigns, new minds may raise
4292: In us who serve, new Counsels, to debate
4293: What doubtful may ensue, more in this place
4294: To utter is not safe.  Assemble thou
4295: Of all those Myriads which we lead the chief;
4296: Tell them that by command, ere yet dim Night
4297: Her shadowie Cloud withdraws, I am to haste,
4298: And all who under me thir Banners wave,
4299: Homeward with flying march where we possess
4300: The Quarters of the North, there to prepare
4301: Fit entertainment to receive our King
4302: The great *Messiah*, and his new commands,
4303: Who speedily through all the Hierarchies
4304: Intends to pass triumphant, and give Laws.
4305: ¶So spake the false Arch-Angel, and infus'd
4306: Bad influence into th' unwarie brest
4307: Of his Associate; hee together calls,
4308: Or several one by one, the Regent Powers,
4309: Under him Regent, tells, as he was taught,
4310: That the most High commanding, now ere Night,
4311: Now ere dim Night had disincumberd Heav'n,
4312: The great Hierarchal Standard was to move;
4313: Tells the suggested cause, and casts between
4314: Ambiguous words and jealousies, to sound
4315: Or taint integritie; but all obey'd
4316: The wonted signal, and superior voice
4317: Of thir great Potentate; for great indeed
4318: His name, and high was his degree in Heav'n;
4319: His count'nance, as the Morning Starr that guides
4320: The starrie flock, allur'd them, and with lyes
4321: Drew after him the third part of Heav'ns Host:
4322: Mean while th' Eternal eye, whose sight discernes
4323: Abstrusest thoughts, from forth his holy Mount
4324: And from within the golden Lamps that burne
4325: Nightly before him, saw without thir light
4326: Rebellion rising, saw in whom, how spred
4327: Among the sons of Morn, what multitudes
4328: Were banded to oppose his high Decree;
4329: And smiling to his onely Son thus said.
4330: ¶Son, thou in whom my glory I behold
4331: In full resplendence, Heir of all my might,
4332: Neerly it now concernes us to be sure
4333: Of our Omnipotence, and with what Arms
4334: We mean to hold what anciently we claim
4335: Of Deitie or Empire, such a foe
4336: Is rising, who intends to erect his Throne
4337: Equal to ours, throughout the spacious North;
4338: Nor so content, hath in his thought to trie
4339: In battel, what our Power is, or our right.
4340: Let us advise, and to this hazard draw
4341: With speed what force is left, and all imploy
4342: In our defence, lest unawares we lose
4343: This our high place, our Sanctuarie, our Hill.
4344: ¶To whom the Son with calm aspect and cleer
4346: Made answer.  Mightie Father, thou thy foes
4347: Justly hast in derision, and secure
4348: Laugh'st at thir vain designes and tumults vain,
4349: Matter to mee of Glory, whom thir hate
4350: Illustrates, when they see all Regal Power
4351: Giv'n me to quell thir pride, and in event
4352: Know whether I be dextrous to subdue
4353: Thy Rebels, or be found the worst in Heav'n.
4354: ¶So spake the Son, but *Satan* with his Powers
4355: Farr was advanc't on winged speed, an Host
4356: Innumerable as the Starrs of Night,
4357: Or Starrs of Morning, Dew-drops, which the Sun
4358: Impearls on every leaf and every flouer.
4359: Regions they pass'd, the mightie Regencies
4360: Of Seraphim and Potentates and Thrones
4361: In thir triple Degrees, Regions to which
4362: All thy Dominion, *Adam*, is no more
4363: Then what this Garden is to all the Earth,
4364: And all the Sea, from one entire globose
4365: Stretcht into Longitude; which having pass'd
4366: At length into the limits of the North
4367: They came, and *Satan* to his Royal seat
4368: High on a Hill, far blazing, as a Mount
4369: Rais'd on a Mount, with Pyramids and Towrs
4370: From Diamond Quarries hew'n, & Rocks of Gold,
4372: That Structure in the Dialect of men
4373: Interpreted) which not long after, hee
4375: In imitation of that Mount whereon
4376: *Messiah* was declar'd in sight of Heav'n,
4377: The Mountain of the Congregation call'd;
4378: For thither he assembl'd all his Train,
4380: About the great reception of thir King,
4381: Thither to come, and with calumnious Art
4382: Of counterfeted truth thus held thir ears.
4384: If these magnific Titles yet remain
4385: Not meerly titular, since by Decree
4386: Another now hath to himself ingross't
4387: All Power, and us eclipst under the name
4388: Of King anointed, for whom all this haste
4389: Of midnight march, and hurried meeting here,
4390: This onely to consult how we may best
4391: With what may be devis'd of honours new
4392: Receive him coming to receive from us
4394: Too much to one, but double how endur'd,
4395: To one and to his image now proclaim'd?
4396: But what if better counsels might erect
4397: Our minds and teach us to cast off this Yoke?
4398: Will ye submit your necks, and chuse to bend
4399: The supple knee? ye will not, if I trust
4400: To know ye right, or if ye know your selves
4401: Natives and Sons of Heav'n possest before
4402: By none, and if not equal all, yet free,
4403: Equally free; for Orders and Degrees
4404: Jarr not with liberty, but well consist.
4405: Who can in reason then or right assume
4406: Monarchie over such as live by right
4407: His equals, if in power and splendor less,
4408: In freedome equal? or can introduce
4409: Law and Edict on us, who without law
4410: Erre not, much less for this to be our Lord,
4411: And look for adoration to th' abuse
4412: Of those Imperial Titles which assert
4413: Our being ordain'd to govern, not to serve?
4414: ¶Thus farr his bold discourse without controule
4415: Had audience, when among the Seraphim
4416: *Abdiel*, then whom none with more zeale ador'd
4417: The Deitie, and divine commands obei'd,
4418: Stood up, and in a flame of zeale severe
4419: The current of his fury thus oppos'd.
4421: Words which no eare ever to hear in Heav'n
4422: Expected, least of all from thee, ingrate
4423: In place thy self so high above thy Peeres.
4424: Canst thou with impious obloquie condemne
4425: The just Decree of God, pronounc't and sworn,
4426: That to his only Son by right endu'd
4427: With Regal Scepter, every Soule in Heav'n
4428: Shall bend the knee, and in that honour due
4429: Confess him rightful King? unjust thou saist
4430: Flatly unjust, to binde with Laws the free,
4431: And equal over equals to let Reigne,
4432: One over all with unsucceeded power.
4433: Shalt thou give Law to God, shalt thou dispute
4434: With him the points of libertie, who made
4435: Thee what thou art, & formd the Pow'rs of Heav'n
4436: Such as he pleasd, and circumscrib'd thir being?
4437: Yet by experience taught we know how good,
4438: And of our good, and of our dignitie
4439: How provident he is, how farr from thought
4440: To make us less, bent rather to exalt
4441: Our happie state under one Head more neer
4442: United.  But to grant it thee unjust,
4443: That equal over equals Monarch Reigne:
4444: Thy self though great & glorious dost thou count,
4445: Or all Angelic Nature joind in one,
4446: Equal to him begotten Son, by whom
4447: As by his Word the mighty Father made
4448: All things, ev'n thee, and all the Spirits of Heav'n
4449: By him created in thir bright degrees,
4450: Crownd them with Glory, & to thir Glory nam'd
4452: Essential Powers, nor by his Reign obscur'd,
4453: But more illustrious made, since he the Head
4454: One of our number thus reduc't becomes,
4455: His Laws our Laws, all honour to him done
4456: Returns our own.  Cease then this impious rage,
4457: And tempt not these; but hast'n to appease
4458: Th' incensed Father, and th' incensed Son,
4459: While Pardon may be found in time besought.
4460: ¶So spake the fervent Angel, but his zeale
4461: None seconded, as out of season judg'd,
4462: Or singular and rash, whereat rejoic'd
4463: Th' Apostat, and more haughty thus repli'd.
4464: That we were formd then saist thou? & the work
4465: Of secondarie hands, by task transferd
4466: From Father to his Son? strange point and new!
4467: Doctrin which we would know whence learnt: who saw
4468: When this creation was? rememberst thou
4469: Thy making, while the Maker gave thee being?
4470: We know no time when we were not as now;
4471: Know none before us, self-begot, self-rais'd
4472: By our own quick'ning power, when fatal course
4473: Had circl'd his full Orbe, the birth mature
4474: Of this our native Heav'n, Ethereal Sons.
4475: Our puissance is our own, our own right hand
4476: Shall teach us highest deeds, by proof to try
4477: Who is our equal: then thou shalt behold
4479: Address, and to begirt th' Almighty Throne
4481: These tidings carrie to th' anointed King;
4482: And fly, ere evil intercept thy flight.
4483: ¶He said, and as the sound of waters deep
4484: Hoarce murmur echo'd to his words applause
4485: Through the infinite Host, nor less for that
4486: The flaming Seraph fearless, though alone
4487: Encompass'd round with foes, thus answerd bold.
4488: ¶O alienate from God, O spirit accurst,
4489: Forsak'n of all good; I see thy fall
4490: Determind, and thy hapless crew involv'd
4491: In this perfidious fraud, contagion spred
4492: Both of thy crime and punishment: henceforth
4493: No more be troubl'd how to quit the yoke
4495: Will not be now voutsaf't, other Decrees
4496: Against thee are gon forth without recall;
4497: That Golden Scepter which thou didst reject
4498: Is now an Iron Rod to bruise and breake
4499: Thy disobedience.  Well thou didst advise,
4500: Yet not for thy advise or threats I fly
4501: These wicked Tents devoted, least the wrauth
4503: Distinguish not: for soon expect to feel
4504: His Thunder on thy head, devouring fire.
4505: Then who created thee lamenting learne,
4506: When who can uncreate thee thou shalt know.
4508: Among the faithless, faithful only hee;
4511: His Loyaltie he kept, his Love, his Zeale;
4512: Nor number, nor example with him wrought
4513: To swerve from truth, or change his constant mind
4514: Though single.  From amidst them forth he passd,
4515: Long way through hostile scorn, which he susteind
4516: Superior, nor of violence fear'd aught;
4517: And with retorted scorn his back he turn'd
4518: On those proud Towrs to swift destruction doom'd.
4521: Through Heav'ns wide Champain held his way, till Morn,
4522: Wak't by the circling Hours, with rosie hand
4523: Unbarr'd the gates of Light.  There is a Cave
4524: Within the Mount of God, fast by his Throne,
4525: Where light and darkness in perpetual round
4526: Lodge and dislodge by turns, which makes through Heav'n
4527: Grateful vicissitude, like Day and Night;
4528: Light issues forth, and at the other dore
4529: Obsequious darkness enters, till her houre
4530: To veile the Heav'n, though darkness there might well
4531: Seem twilight here; and now went forth the Morn
4532: Such as in highest Heav'n, arrayd in Gold
4533: Empyreal, from before her vanisht Night,
4534: Shot through with orient Beams: when all the Plain
4535: Coverd with thick embatteld Squadrons bright,
4536: Chariots and flaming Armes, and fierie Steeds
4537: Reflecting blaze on blaze, first met his view:
4538: Warr he perceav'd, warr in procinct, and found
4539: Already known what he for news had thought
4540: To have reported: gladly then he mixt
4541: Among those friendly Powers who him receav'd
4542: With joy and acclamations loud, that one
4543: That of so many Myriads fall'n, yet one
4544: Returnd not lost: On to the sacred hill
4545: They led him high applauded, and present
4546: Before the seat supream; from whence a voice
4547: From midst a Golden Cloud thus milde was heard.
4548: ¶Servant of God, well done, well hast thou fought
4549: The better fight, who single hast maintaind
4551: Of Truth, in word mightier then they in Armes;
4552: And for the testimonie of Truth hast born
4553: Universal reproach, far worse to beare
4554: Then violence: for this was all thy care
4555: To stand approv'd in sight of God, though Worlds
4556: Judg'd thee perverse: the easier conquest now
4557: Remains thee, aided by this host of friends,
4558: Back on thy foes more glorious to return
4559: Then scornd thou didst depart, and to subdue
4560: By force, who reason for thir Law refuse,
4561: Right reason for thir Law, and for thir King
4562: *Messiah*, who by right of merit Reigns.
4564: And thou in Military prowess next
4565: *Gabriel*, lead forth to Battel these my Sons
4566: Invincible, lead forth my armed Saints
4567: By Thousands and by Millions rang'd for fight;
4568: Equal in number to that Godless crew
4569: Rebellious, them with Fire and hostile Arms
4570: Fearless assault, and to the brow of Heav'n
4571: Pursuing drive them out from God and bliss,
4572: Into thir place of punishment, the Gulf
4574: His fiery *Chaos* to receave thir fall.
4575: ¶So spake the Sovran voice, and Clouds began
4576: To darken all the Hill, and smoak to rowl
4577: In duskie wreathes, reluctant flames, the signe
4578: Of wrauth awak't: nor with less dread the loud
4579: Ethereal Trumpet from on high gan blow:
4580: At which command the Powers Militant,
4581: That stood for Heav'n, in mighty Quadrate joyn'd
4583: In silence thir bright Legions, to the sound
4586: Under thir God-like Leaders, in the Cause
4587: Of God and his *Messiah*.  On they move
4589: Nor streit'ning Vale, nor Wood, nor Stream divides
4590: Thir perfet ranks; for high above the ground
4591: Thir march was, and the passive Air upbore
4592: Thir nimble tread; as when the total kind
4593: Of Birds in orderly array on wing
4595: Thir names of thee; so over many a tract
4596: Of Heav'n they march'd, and many a Province wide
4597: Tenfold the length of this terrene: at last
4598: Farr in th' Horizon to the North appeer'd
4599: From skirt to skirt a fierie Region, stretcht
4600: In battailous aspect, and neerer view
4602: Of rigid Spears, and Helmets throng'd, and Shields
4604: The banded Powers of *Satan* hasting on
4605: With furious expedition; for they weend
4606: That self same day by fight, or by surprize
4607: To win the Mount of God, and on his Throne
4608: To set the envier of his State, the proud
4609: Aspirer, but thir thoughts prov'd fond and vain
4610: In the mid way: though strange to us it seemd
4611: At first, that Angel should with Angel warr,
4612: And in fierce hosting meet, who wont to meet
4613: So oft in Festivals of joy and love
4614: Unanimous, as sons of one great Sire
4615: Hymning th' Eternal Father: but the shout
4616: Of Battel now began, and rushing sound
4617: Of onset ended soon each milder thought.
4618: High in the midst exalted as a God
4619: Th' Apostat in his Sun-bright Chariot sate
4621: With Flaming Cherubim, and golden Shields;
4622: Then lighted from his gorgeous Throne, for now
4623: 'Twixt Host and Host but narrow space was left,
4624: A dreadful interval, and Front to Front
4626: Of hideous length: before the cloudie Van,
4627: On the rough edge of battel ere it joyn'd,
4628: *Satan* with vast and haughtie strides advanc't,
4629: Came towring, armd in Adamant and Gold;
4630: *Abdiel* that sight endur'd not, where he stood
4631: Among the mightiest, bent on highest deeds,
4632: And thus his own undaunted heart explores.
4633: ¶O Heav'n! that such resemblance of the Highest
4634: Should yet remain, where faith and realtie
4635: Remain not; wherfore should not strength & might
4636: There fail where Vertue fails, or weakest prove
4637: Where boldest; though to sight unconquerable?
4638: His puissance, trusting in th' Almightie's aide,
4639: I mean to try, whose Reason I have tri'd
4640: Unsound and false; nor is it aught but just,
4641: That he who in debate of Truth hath won,
4642: Should win in Arms, in both disputes alike
4643: Victor; though brutish that contest and foule,
4644: When Reason hath to deal with force, yet so
4645: Most reason is that Reason overcome.
4646: ¶So pondering, and from his armed Peers
4647: Forth stepping opposite, half way he met
4648: His daring foe, at this prevention more
4649: Incens't, and thus securely him defi'd.
4650: ¶Proud, art thou met? thy hope was to have reacht
4651: The highth of thy aspiring unoppos'd,
4652: The Throne of God unguarded, and his side
4653: Abandond at the terror of thy Power
4654: Or potent tongue; fool, not to think how vain
4655: Against th' Omnipotent to rise in Arms;
4656: Who out of smallest things could without end
4657: Have rais'd incessant Armies to defeat
4658: Thy folly; or with solitarie hand
4659: Reaching beyond all limit, at one blow
4660: Unaided could have finisht thee, and whelmd
4661: Thy Legions under darkness; but thou seest
4662: All are not of thy Train; there be who Faith
4663: Prefer, and Pietie to God, though then
4664: To thee not visible, when I alone
4665: Seemd in thy World erroneous to dissent
4666: From all: my Sect thou seest, now learn too late
4667: How few somtimes may know, when thousands err.
4668: ¶Whom the grand foe with scornful eye askance
4669: Thus answerd.  Ill for thee, but in wisht houre
4670: Of my revenge, first sought for thou returnst
4671: From flight, seditious Angel, to receave
4672: Thy merited reward, the first assay
4673: Of this right hand provok't, since first that tongue
4675: A third part of the Gods, in Synod met
4676: Thir Deities to assert, who while they feel
4677: Vigour Divine within them, can allow
4678: Omnipotence to none.  But well thou comst
4679: Before thy fellows, ambitious to win
4680: From me som Plume, that thy success may show
4681: Destruction to the rest: this pause between
4682: (Unanswerd least thou boast) to let thee know;
4683: At first I thought that Libertie and Heav'n
4684: To heav'nly Soules had bin all one; but now
4685: I see that most through sloth had rather serve,
4686: Ministring Spirits, traind up in Feast and Song;
4687: Such hast thou arm'd, the Minstrelsie of Heav'n,
4689: As both thir deeds compar'd this day shall prove.
4690: ¶To whom in brief thus *Abdiel* stern repli'd.
4691: Apostat, still thou errst, nor end wilt find
4692: Of erring, from the path of truth remote:
4693: Unjustly thou deprav'st it with the name
4694: Of *Servitude* to serve whom God ordains,
4695: Or Nature; God and Nature bid the same,
4696: When he who rules is worthiest, and excells
4697: Them whom he governs.  This is servitude,
4698: To serve th' unwise, or him who hath rebelld
4699: Against his worthier, as thine now serve thee,
4700: Thy self not free, but to thy self enthrall'd;
4701: Yet leudly dar'st our ministring upbraid.
4702: Reign thou in Hell thy Kingdom, let mee serve
4703: In Heav'n God ever blessed, and his Divine
4704: Behests obey, worthiest to be obey'd,
4705: Yet Chains in Hell, not Realms expect: mean while
4706: From mee returnd, as erst thou saidst, from flight,
4707: This greeting on thy impious Crest receive.
4708: ¶So saying, a noble stroke he lifted high,
4709: Which hung not, but so swift with tempest fell
4710: On the proud Crest of *Satan*, that no sight,
4711: Nor motion of swift thought, less could his Shield
4712: Such ruin intercept: ten paces huge
4713: He back recoild; the tenth on bended knee
4714: His massie Spear upstaid; as if on Earth
4715: Winds under ground or waters forcing way
4716: Sidelong, had push't a Mountain from his seat
4717: Half sunk with all his Pines.  Amazement seis'd
4718: The Rebel Thrones, but greater rage to see
4719: Thus foil'd thir mightiest, ours joy filld, and shout,
4720: Presage of Victorie and fierce desire
4722: Th' Arch-Angel trumpet; through the vast of Heav'n
4723: It sounded, and the faithful Armies rung
4724: *Hosanna* to the Highest: nor stood at gaze
4725: The adverse Legions, nor less hideous joyn'd
4726: The horrid shock: now storming furie rose,
4727: And clamour such as heard in Heav'n till now
4728: Was never, Arms on Armour clashing bray'd
4729: Horrible discord, and the madding Wheeles
4730: Of brazen Chariots rag'd; dire was the noise
4731: Of conflict; over head the dismal hiss
4732: Of fiery Darts in flaming volies flew,
4733: And flying vaulted either Host with fire.
4735: Both Battels maine, with ruinous assault
4737: Resounded, and had Earth bin then, all Earth
4738: Had to her Center shook.  What wonder? when
4739: Millions of fierce encountring Angels fought
4740: On either side, the least of whom could weild
4741: These Elements, and arm him with the force
4742: Of all thir Regions: how much more of Power
4743: Armie against Armie numberless to raise
4745: Though not destroy, thir happie Native seat;
4746: Had not th' Eternal King Omnipotent
4747: From his strong hold of Heav'n high over-rul'd
4748: And limited thir might; though numberd such
4749: As each divided Legion might have seemd
4750: A numerous Host, in strength each armed hand
4751: A Legion; led in fight, yet Leader seemd
4752: Each Warriour single as in Chief, expert
4753: When to advance, or stand, or turn the sway
4754: Of Battel, open when, and when to close
4755: The ridges of grim Warr; no thought of flight,
4756: None of retreat, no unbecoming deed
4757: That argu'd fear; each on himself reli'd,
4758: As onely in his arm the moment lay
4759: Of victorie; deeds of eternal fame
4760: Were don, but infinite: for wide was spred
4761: That Warr and various; somtimes on firm ground
4762: A standing fight, then soaring on main wing
4763: Tormented all the Air; all Air seemd then
4764: Conflicting Fire: long time in eeven scale
4765: The Battel hung; till *Satan*, who that day
4766: Prodigious power had shewn, and met in Armes
4767: No equal, raunging through the dire attack
4768: Of fighting Seraphim confus'd, at length
4769: Saw where the Sword of *Michael* smote, and fell'd
4770: Squadrons at once, with huge two-handed sway
4771: Brandisht aloft the horrid edge came down
4772: Wide wasting; such destruction to withstand
4773: He hasted, and oppos'd the rockie Orb
4774: Of tenfold Adamant, his ample Shield
4775: A vast circumference: At his approach
4776: The great Arch-Angel from his warlike toile
4777: Surceas'd, and glad as hoping here to end
4778: Intestine War in Heav'n, the arch foe subdu'd
4779: Or Captive drag'd in Chains, with hostile frown
4780: And visage all enflam'd first thus began.
4781: ¶Author of evil, unknown till thy revolt,
4782: Unnam'd in Heav'n, now plenteous, as thou seest
4783: These Acts of hateful strife, hateful to all,
4784: Though heaviest by just measure on thy self
4785: And thy adherents: how hast thou disturb'd
4786: Heav'ns blessed peace, and into Nature brought
4788: Of thy Rebellion? how hast thou instill'd
4789: Thy malice into thousands, once upright
4790: And faithful, now prov'd false.  But think not here
4791: To trouble Holy Rest; Heav'n casts thee out
4792: From all her Confines.  Heav'n the seat of bliss
4793: Brooks not the works of violence and Warr.
4794: Hence then, and evil go with thee along
4795: Thy ofspring, to the place of evil, Hell,
4796: Thou and thy wicked crew; there mingle broiles,
4797: Ere this avenging Sword begin thy doome,
4798: Or som more sudden vengeance wing'd from God
4800: ¶So spake the Prince of Angels; to whom thus
4801: The Adversarie.  Nor think thou with wind
4802: Of airie threats to aw whom yet with deeds
4803: Thou canst not.  Hast thou turnd the least of these
4804: To flight, or if to fall, but that they rise
4805: Unvanquisht, easier to transact with mee
4806: That thou shouldst hope, imperious, & with threats
4807: To chase me hence? erre not that so shall end
4808: The strife which thou call'st evil, but wee style
4809: The strife of Glorie: which we mean to win,
4810: Or turn this Heav'n it self into the Hell
4811: Thou fablest, here however to dwell free,
4812: If not to reign: mean while thy utmost force,
4813: And join him nam'd *Almightie* to thy aid,
4814: I flie not, but have sought thee farr and nigh.
4815: ¶They ended parle, and both addrest for fight
4816: Unspeakable; for who, though with the tongue
4817: Of Angels, can relate, or to what things
4818: Liken on Earth conspicuous, that may lift
4820: Of Godlike Power: for likest Gods they seemd,
4821: Stood they or mov'd, in stature, motion, arms
4822: Fit to decide the Empire of great Heav'n.
4823: Now wav'd thir fierie Swords, and in the Aire
4824: Made horrid Circles; two broad Suns thir Shields
4826: In horror; from each hand with speed retir'd
4827: Where erst was thickest fight, th' Angelic throng,
4828: And left large field, unsafe within the wind
4829: Of such commotion, such as to set forth
4830: Great things by small, If Natures concord broke,
4831: Among the Constellations warr were sprung,
4832: Two Planets rushing from aspect maligne
4833: Of fiercest opposition in mid Skie,
4834: Should combat, and thir jarring Sphears confound.
4835: Together both with next to Almightie Arme,
4836: Uplifted imminent one stroke they aim'd
4837: That might determine, and not need repeate,
4838: As not of power, at once; nor odds appeerd
4839: In might or swift prevention; but the sword
4840: Of *Michael* from the Armorie of God
4841: Was giv'n him temperd so, that neither keen
4842: Nor solid might resist that edge: it met
4843: The sword of *Satan* with steep force to smite
4844: Descending, and in half cut sheere, nor staid,
4845: But with swift wheele reverse, deep entring shar'd
4846: All his right side; then *Satan* first knew pain,
4847: And writh'd him to and fro convolv'd; so sore
4848: The griding sword with discontinuous wound
4849: Pass'd through him, but th' Ethereal substance clos'd
4850: Not long divisible, and from the gash
4851: A stream of Nectarous humor issuing flow'd
4852: Sanguin, such as Celestial Spirits may bleed,
4853: And all his Armour staind ere while so bright.
4854: Forthwith on all sides to his aide was run
4855: By Angels many and strong, who interpos'd
4856: Defence, while others bore him on thir Shields
4857: Back to his Chariot; where it stood retir'd
4858: From off the files of warr; there they him laid
4859: Gnashing for anguish and despite and shame
4860: To find himself not matchless, and his pride
4861: Humbl'd by such rebuke, so farr beneath
4862: His confidence to equal God in power.
4863: Yet soon he heal'd; for Spirits that live throughout
4864: Vital in every part, not as frail man
4865: In Entrailes, Heart or Head, Liver or Reines,
4867: Nor in thir liquid texture mortal wound
4868: Receive, no more then can the fluid Aire:
4869: All Heart they live, all Head, all Eye, all Eare,
4870: All Intellect, all Sense, and as they please,
4871: They Limb themselves, and colour, shape or size
4872: Assume, as likes them best, condense or rare.
4873: ¶Mean while in other parts like deeds deservd
4874: Memorial, where the might of *Gabriel* fought,
4875: And with fierce Ensignes pierc'd the deep array
4876: Of *Moloc* furious King, who him defi'd,
4877: And at his Chariot wheeles to drag him bound
4878: Threatn'd, nor from the Holie One of Heav'n
4879: Refrein'd his tongue blasphemous; but anon
4880: Down clov'n to the waste, with shatterd Armes
4881: And uncouth paine fled bellowing.  On each wing
4883: Though huge, and in a Rock of Diamond Armd,
4885: Two potent Thrones, that to be less then Gods
4886: Disdain'd, but meaner thoughts learnd in thir flight,
4887: Mangl'd with gastly wounds through Plate and Maile.
4889: The Atheist crew, but with redoubl'd blow
4892: I might relate of thousands, and thir names
4893: Eternize here on Earth; but those elect
4894: Angels contented with thir fame in Heav'n
4895: Seek not the praise of men: the other sort
4896: In might though wondrous and in Acts of Warr,
4897: Nor of Renown less eager, yet by doome
4898: Canceld from Heav'n and sacred memorie,
4899: Nameless in dark oblivion let them dwell.
4900: For strength from Truth divided and from Just,
4902: And ignominie, yet to glorie aspires
4903: Vain glorious, and through infamie seeks fame:
4904: Therfore Eternal silence be thir doome.
4905: ¶And now thir mightiest quelld, the battel swerv'd,
4906: With many an inrode gor'd; deformed rout
4907: Enter'd, and foul disorder; all the ground
4908: With shiverd armour strow'n, and on a heap
4910: And fierie foaming Steeds; what stood, recoyld
4911: Orewearied, through the faint Satanic Host
4912: Defensive scarse, or with pale fear surpris'd,
4913: Then first with fear surpris'd and sense of paine
4914: Fled ignominious, to such evil brought
4915: By sinne of disobedience, till that hour
4916: Not liable to fear or flight or paine.
4918: In Cubic Phalanx firm advanc't entire,
4921: Gave them above thir foes, not to have sinnd,
4922: Not to have disobei'd; in fight they stood
4924: By wound, though from thir place by violence mov'd.
4925: ¶Now Night her course began, and over Heav'n
4927: And silence on the odious dinn of Warr:
4928: Under her Cloudie covert both retir'd,
4929: Victor and Vanquisht: on the foughten field
4931: Encamping, plac'd in Guard thir Watches round,
4932: Cherubic waving fires: on th' other part
4934: Far in the dark dislodg'd, and void of rest,
4935: His Potentates to Councel call'd by night;
4936: And in the midst thus undismai'd began.
4937: ¶O now in danger tri'd, now known in Armes
4938: Not to be overpowerd, Companions deare,
4939: Found worthy not of Libertie alone,
4940: Too mean pretense, but what we more affect,
4942: Who have sustaind one day in doubtful fight,
4943: (And if one day, why not Eternal dayes?)
4944: What Heavens Lord had powerfullest to send
4945: Against us from about his Throne, and judg'd
4946: Sufficient to subdue us to his will,
4947: But proves not so: then fallible, it seems,
4948: Of future we may deem him, though till now
4949: Omniscient thought.  True is, less firmly arm'd,
4950: Some disadvantage we endur'd and paine,
4951: Till now not known, but known as soon contemnd,
4952: Since now we find this our Empyreal forme
4954: Imperishable, and though peirc'd with wound,
4955: Soon closing, and by native vigour heal'd.
4956: Of evil then so small as easie think
4957: The remedie; perhaps more valid Armes,
4958: Weapons more violent, when next we meet,
4959: May serve to better us, and worse our foes,
4960: Or equal what between us made the odds,
4961: In Nature none: if other hidden cause
4962: Left them Superiour, while we can preserve
4963: Unhurt our mindes, and understanding sound,
4964: Due search and consultation will disclose.
4965: ¶He sat; and in th' assembly next upstood
4967: As one he stood escap't from cruel fight,
4968: Sore toild, his riv'n Armes to havoc hewn,
4969: And cloudie in aspect thus answering spake.
4970: Deliverer from new Lords, leader to free
4971: Enjoyment of our right as Gods; yet hard
4972: For Gods, and too unequal work we find
4973: Against unequal armes to fight in paine,
4974: Against unpaind, impassive; from which evil
4975: Ruin must needs ensue; for what availes
4976: Valour or strength, though matchless, quelld with pain
4977: Which all subdues, and makes remiss the hands
4978: Of Mightiest.  Sense of pleasure we may well
4979: Spare out of life perhaps, and not repine,
4980: But live content, which is the calmest life:
4981: But pain is perfet miserie, the worst
4983: All patience.  He who therefore can invent
4984: With what more forcible we may offend
4985: Our yet unwounded Enemies, or arme
4986: Our selves with like defence, to mee deserves
4987: No less then for deliverance what we owe.
4989: Not uninvented that, which thou aright
4990: Beleivst so main to our success, I bring;
4991: Which of us who beholds the bright surface
4992: Of this Ethereous mould whereon we stand,
4993: This continent of spacious Heav'n, adornd
4994: With Plant, Fruit, Flour Ambrosial, Gemms & Gold,
4996: These things, as not to mind from whence they grow
4997: Deep under ground, materials dark and crude,
4998: Of spiritous and fierie spume, till toucht
4999: With Heav'ns ray, and temperd they shoot forth
5000: So beauteous, op'ning to the ambient light.
5001: These in thir dark Nativitie the Deep
5002: Shall yeild us, pregnant with infernal flame,
5003: Which into hallow Engins long and round
5004: Thick-rammd, at th' other bore with touch of fire
5005: Dilated and infuriate shall send forth
5006: From far with thundring noise among our foes
5007: Such implements of mischief as shall dash
5008: To pieces, and orewhelm whatever stands
5009: Adverse, that they shall fear we have disarmd
5010: The Thunderer of his only dreaded bolt.
5011: Nor long shall be our labour, yet ere dawne,
5012: Effect shall end our wish.  Mean while revive;
5013: Abandon fear; to strength and counsel joind
5014: Think nothing hard, much less to be despaird.
5015: He ended, and his words thir drooping chere
5016: Enlightn'd, and thir languisht hope reviv'd.
5017: Th' invention all admir'd, and each, how hee
5018: To be th' inventer miss'd, so easie it seemd
5019: Once found, which yet unfound most would have thought
5020: Impossible: yet haply of thy Race
5021: In future dayes, if Malice should abound,
5022: Some one intent on mischief, or inspir'd
5024: Like instrument to plague the Sons of men
5025: For sin, on warr and mutual slaughter bent.
5026: Forthwith from Councel to the work they flew,
5028: Were ready, in a moment up they turnd
5029: Wide the Celestial soile, and saw beneath
5030: Th' originals of Nature in thir crude
5032: They found, they mingl'd, and with suttle Art,
5034: To blackest grain, and into store conveyd:
5035: Part hidd'n veins diggd up (nor hath this Earth
5036: Entrails unlike) of Mineral and Stone,
5037: Whereof to found thir Engins and thir Balls
5038: Of missive ruin; part incentive reed
5039: Provide, pernicious with one touch to fire.
5040: So all ere day spring, under conscious Night
5041: Secret they finish'd, and in order set,
5043: Now when fair Morn Orient in Heav'n appeerd
5044: Up rose the Victor Angels, and to Arms
5045: The matin Trumpet Sung: in Arms they stood
5047: Soon banded; others from the dawning Hills
5048: Lookd round, and Scouts each Coast light-armed scoure,
5049: Each quarter, to descrie the distant foe,
5050: Where lodg'd, or whither fled, or if for fight,
5051: In motion or in alt: him soon they met
5052: Under spred Ensignes moving nigh, in slow
5053: But firm Battalion; back with speediest Sail
5055: Came flying, and in mid Aire aloud thus cri'd.
5056: ¶Arme, Warriours, Arme for fight, the foe at hand,
5057: Whom fled we thought, will save us long pursuit
5058: This day, fear not his flight; so thick a Cloud
5059: He comes, and settl'd in his face I see
5060: Sad resolution and secure: let each
5061: His Adamantine coat gird well, and each
5062: Fit well his Helme, gripe fast his orbed Shield,
5063: Born eevn or high, for this day will pour down,
5064: If I conjecture aught, no drizling showr,
5065: But ratling storm of Arrows barbd with fire.
5066: So warnd he them aware themselves, and soon
5067: In order, quit of all impediment;
5068: Instant without disturb they took Allarm,
5069: And onward move Embattelld; when behold
5070: Not distant far with heavie pace the Foe
5071: Approaching gross and huge; in hollow Cube
5073: On every side with shaddowing Squadrons Deep,
5074: To hide the fraud.  At interview both stood
5075: A while, but suddenly at head appeerd
5076: *Satan*: And thus was heard Commanding loud.
5077: ¶Vangard, to Right and Left the Front unfould;
5078: That all may see who hate us, how we seek
5079: Peace and composure, and with open brest
5080: Stand readie to receive them, if they like
5081: Our overture, and turn not back perverse;
5082: But that I doubt, however witness Heaven,
5083: Heav'n witness thou anon, while we discharge
5084: Freely our part: yee who appointed stand
5085: Do as you have in charge, and briefly touch
5086: What we propound, and loud that all may hear.
5087: ¶So scoffing in ambiguous words, he scarce
5088: Had ended; when to Right and Left the Front
5089: Divided, and to either Flank retir'd.
5090: Which to our eyes discoverd new and strange,
5091: A triple-mounted row of Pillars laid
5092: On Wheels (for like to Pillars most they seem'd
5093: Or hollow'd bodies made of Oak or Firr
5094: With branches lopt, in Wood or Mountain fell'd)
5095: Brass, Iron, Stonie mould, had not thir mouthes
5096: With hideous orifice gap't on us wide,
5097: Portending hollow truce; at each behind
5098: A Seraph stood, and in his hand a Reed
5099: Stood waving tipt with fire; while we suspense,
5100: Collected stood within our thoughts amus'd,
5101: Not long, for sudden all at once thir Reeds
5102: Put forth, and to a narrow vent appli'd
5103: With nicest touch.  Immediate in a flame,
5104: But soon obscur'd with smoak, all Heav'n appeerd,
5105: From those deep-throated Engins belcht, whose roar
5106: Emboweld with outragious noise the Air,
5107: And all her entrails tore, disgorging foule
5108: Thir devillish glut, chaind Thunderbolts and Hail
5109: Of Iron Globes, which on the Victor Host
5110: Level'd, with such impetuous furie smote,
5111: That whom they hit, none on thir feet might stand,
5112: Though standing else as Rocks, but down they fell
5113: By thousands, Angel on Arch-Angel rowl'd;
5114: The sooner for thir Arms, unarm'd they might
5115: Have easily as Spirits evaded swift
5116: By quick contraction or remove; but now
5117: Foule dissipation follow'd and forc't rout;
5118: Nor serv'd it to relax thir serried files.
5119: What should they do? if on they rusht, repulse
5121: Doubl'd, would render them yet more despis'd,
5122: And to thir foes a laughter; for in view
5123: Stood rankt of Seraphim another row
5124: In posture to displode thir second tire
5125: Of Thunder: back defeated to return
5126: They worse abhorr'd.  *Satan* beheld thir plight,
5127: And to his Mates thus in derision call'd.
5128: ¶O Friends, why come not on these Victors proud?
5129: Ere while they fierce were coming, and when wee,
5130: To entertain them fair with open Front
5131: And Brest, (what could we more?) propounded terms
5132: Of composition, strait they chang'd thir minds,
5133: Flew off, and into strange vagaries fell,
5134: As they would dance, yet for a dance they seemd
5136: For joy of offerd peace: but I suppose
5137: If our proposals once again were heard
5138: We should compel them to a quick result.
5139: ¶To whom thus *Belial* in like gamesom mood.
5140: Leader, the terms we sent were terms of weight,
5141: Of hard contents, and full of force urg'd home,
5142: Such as we might perceive amus'd them all,
5143: And stumbl'd many, who receives them right,
5144: Had need from head to foot well understand;
5145: Not understood, this gift they have besides,
5146: They shew us when our foes walk not upright.
5147: ¶So they among themselves in pleasant veine
5148: Stood scoffing, highthn'd in thir thoughts beyond
5149: All doubt of Victorie, eternal might
5150: To match with thir inventions they presum'd
5151: So easie, and of his Thunder made a scorn,
5152: And all his Host derided, while they stood
5153: A while in trouble; but they stood not long,
5154: Rage prompted them at length, & found them arms
5155: Against such hellish mischief fit to oppose.
5157: Which God hath in his mighty Angels plac'd)
5158: Thir Arms away they threw, and to the Hills
5159: (For Earth hath this variety from Heav'n
5160: Of pleasure situate in Hill and Dale)
5161: Light as the Lightning glimps they ran, they flew,
5162: From thir foundations loosning to and fro
5163: They pluckt the seated Hills with all thir load,
5164: Rocks, Waters, Woods, and by the shaggie tops
5165: Up lifting bore them in thir hands: Amaze,
5166: Be sure, and terrour seis'd the rebel Host,
5167: When coming towards them so dread they saw
5168: The bottom of the Mountains upward turn'd,
5169: Till on those cursed Engins triple-row
5170: They saw them whelmd, and all thir confidence
5171: Under the weight of Mountains buried deep,
5172: Themselves invaded next, and on thir heads
5173: Main Promontories flung, which in the Air
5174: Came shadowing, and opprest whole Legions arm'd,
5175: Thir armor help'd thir harm, crush't in and brus'd
5176: Into thir substance pent, which wrought them pain
5177: Implacable, and many a dolorous groan,
5178: Long strugling underneath, ere they could wind
5179: Out of such prison, though Spirits of purest light,
5180: Purest at first, now gross by sinning grown.
5181: The rest in imitation to like Armes
5182: Betook them, and the neighbouring Hills uptore;
5183: So Hills amid the Air encounterd Hills
5184: Hurl'd to and fro with jaculation dire,
5185: That under ground they fought in dismal shade;
5186: Infernal noise; Warr seem'd a civil Game
5187: To this uproar; horrid confusion heapt
5188: Upon confusion rose: and now all Heav'n
5189: Had gone to wrack, with ruin overspred,
5190: Had not th' Almightie Father where he sits
5191: Shrin'd in his Sanctuarie of Heav'n secure,
5192: Consulting on the sum of things, foreseen
5193: This tumult, and permitted all, advis'd:
5194: That his great purpose he might so fulfill,
5195: To honour his Anointed Son aveng'd
5196: Upon his enemies, and to declare
5197: All power on him transferr'd: whence to his Son
5198: Th' Assessor of his Throne he thus began.
5200: Son in whose face invisible is beheld
5201: Visibly, what by Deitie I am,
5202: And in whose hand what by Decree I doe,
5203: Second Omnipotence, two dayes are past,
5204: Two dayes, as we compute the dayes of Heav'n,
5205: Since *Michael* and his Powers went forth to tame
5206: These disobedient; sore hath been thir fight,
5207: As likeliest was, when two such Foes met arm'd;
5208: For to themselves I left them, and thou knowst,
5209: Equal in their Creation they were form'd,
5210: Save what sin hath impaird, which yet hath wrought
5211: Insensibly, for I suspend thir doom;
5212: Whence in perpetual fight they needs must last
5213: Endless, and no solution will be found:
5214: Warr wearied hath perform'd what Warr can do,
5215: And to disorder'd rage let loose the reines,
5216: With Mountains as with Weapons arm'd, which makes
5217: Wild work in Heav'n, and dangerous to the maine.
5218: Two dayes are therefore past, the third is thine;
5219: For thee I have ordain'd it, and thus farr
5220: Have sufferd, that the Glorie may be thine
5221: Of ending this great Warr, since none but Thou
5222: Can end it.  Into thee such Vertue and Grace
5223: Immense I have transfus'd, that all may know
5224: In Heav'n and Hell thy Power above compare,
5225: And this perverse Commotion governd thus,
5226: To manifest thee worthiest to be Heir
