5227: Of all things, to be Heir and to be King
5228: By Sacred Unction, thy deserved right.
5229: Go then thou Mightiest in thy Fathers might,
5230: Ascend my Chariot, guide the rapid Wheeles
5231: That shake Heav'ns basis, bring forth all my Warr,
5232: My Bow and Thunder, my Almightie Arms
5233: Gird on, and Sword upon thy puissant Thigh;
5234: Pursue these sons of Darkness, drive them out
5235: From all Heav'ns bounds into the utter Deep:
5236: There let them learn, as likes them, to despise
5238: ¶He said, and on his Son with Rayes direct
5239: Shon full, he all his Father full exprest
5241: And thus the filial Godhead answering spake.
5242: ¶O Father, O Supream of heav'nly Thrones,
5243: First, Highest, Holiest, Best, thou alwayes seekst
5244: To glorifie thy Son, I alwayes thee,
5245: As is most just; this I my Glorie account,
5246: My exaltation, and my whole delight,
5247: That thou in me well pleas'd, declarst thy will
5248: Fulfill'd, which to fulfil is all my bliss.
5249: Scepter and Power, thy giving, I assume,
5250: And gladlier shall resign, when in the end
5251: Thou shalt be All in All, and I in thee
5252: For ever, and in mee all whom thou lov'st:
5253: But whom thou hat'st, I hate, and can put on
5254: Thy terrors, as I put thy mildness on,
5255: Image of thee in all things; and shall soon,
5256: Armd with thy might, rid heav'n of these rebell'd,
5257: To thir prepar'd ill Mansion driven down
5258: To chains of Darkness, and th' undying Worm,
5259: That from thy just obedience could revolt,
5260: Whom to obey is happiness entire.
5261: Then shall thy Saints unmixt, and from th' impure
5262: Farr separate, circling thy holy Mount
5264: Hymns of high praise, and I among them chief.
5265: So said, he o're his Scepter bowing, rose
5266: From the right hand of Glorie where he sate,
5267: And the third sacred Morn began to shine
5268: Dawning through Heav'n: forth rush'd with whirlwind sound
5270: Flashing thick flames, Wheele within Wheele undrawn,
5271: It self instinct with Spirit, but convoyd
5272: By four Cherubic shapes, four Faces each
5273: Had wondrous, as with Starrs thir bodies all
5274: And Wings were set with Eyes, with Eyes the Wheels
5275: Of Beril, and careering Fires between;
5276: Over thir heads a chrystal Firmament,
5277: Whereon a Saphir Throne, inlaid with pure
5278: Amber, and colours of the showrie Arch.
5279: Hee in Celestial Panoplie all armd
5281: Ascended, at his right hand Victorie
5282: Sate Eagle-wing'd, beside him hung his Bow
5283: And Quiver with three-bolted Thunder stor'd,
5284: And from about him fierce Effusion rowld
5285: Of smoak and bickering flame, and sparkles dire;
5286: Attended with ten thousand thousand Saints,
5287: He onward came, farr off his coming shon,
5288: And twentie thousand (I thir number heard)
5289: Chariots of God, half on each hand were seen:
5290: Hee on the wings of Cherub rode sublime
5291: On the Crystallin Skie, in Saphir Thron'd.
5292: Illustrious farr and wide, but by his own
5293: First seen, them unexpected joy surpriz'd,
5294: When the great Ensign of *Messiah* blaz'd
5295: Aloft by Angels born, his Sign in Heav'n:
5297: His Armie, circumfus'd on either Wing,
5298: Under thir Head imbodied all in one.
5299: Before him Power Divine his way prepar'd;
5300: At his command the uprooted Hills retir'd
5301: Each to his place, they heard his voice and went
5302: Obsequious, Heav'n his wonted face renewd,
5303: And with fresh Flourets Hill and Valley smil'd.
5304: This saw his hapless Foes, but stood obdur'd,
5305: And to rebellious fight rallied thir Powers
5307: In heav'nly Spirits could such perverseness dwell?
5308: But to convince the proud what Signs availe,
5309: Or Wonders move th' obdurate to relent?
5310: They hard'nd more by what might most reclame,
5311: Grieving to see his Glorie, at the sight
5312: Took envie, and aspiring to his highth,
5313: Stood reimbattell'd fierce, by force or fraud
5314: Weening to prosper, and at length prevaile
5315: Against God and *Messiah*, or to fall
5316: In universal ruin last, and now
5317: To final Battel drew, disdaining flight,
5318: Or faint retreat; when the great Son of God
5319: To all his Host on either hand thus spake.
5320: ¶Stand still in bright array ye Saints, here stand
5321: Ye Angels arm'd, this day from Battel rest;
5322: Faithful hath been your Warfare, and of God
5323: Accepted, fearless in his righteous Cause,
5324: And as ye have receivd, so have ye don
5325: Invincibly; but of this cursed crew
5326: The punishment to other hand belongs,
5327: Vengeance is his, or whose he sole appoints;
5328: Number to this dayes work is not ordain'd
5329: Nor multitude, stand onely and behold
5330: Gods indignation on these Godless pourd
5331: By mee; not you but mee they have despis'd,
5332: Yet envied; against mee is all thir rage,
5333: Because the Father, t' whom in Heav'n supream
5334: Kingdom and Power and Glorie appertains,
5335: Hath honourd me according to his will.
5336: Therefore to mee thir doom he hath assig'n'd;
5337: That they may have thir wish, to trie with mee
5338: In Battel which the stronger proves, they all,
5339: Or I alone against them, since by strength
5340: They measure all, of other excellence
5341: Not emulous, nor care who them excells;
5342: Nor other strife with them do I voutsafe.
5343: ¶So spake the Son, and into terrour chang'd
5344: His count'nance too severe to be beheld
5345: And full of wrauth bent on his Enemies.
5346: At once the Four spred out thir Starrie wings
5347: With dreadful shade contiguous, and the Orbes
5348: Of his fierce Chariot rowld, as with the sound
5349: Of torrent Floods, or of a numerous Host.
5350: Hee on his impious Foes right onward drove,
5351: Gloomie as Night; under his burning Wheeles
5353: All but the Throne it self of God.  Full soon
5354: Among them he arriv'd; in his right hand
5355: Grasping ten thousand Thunders, which he sent
5356: Before him, such as in thir Soules infix'd
5357: Plagues; they astonisht all resistance lost,
5358: All courage; down thir idle weapons drop'd;
5359: O're Shields and Helmes, and helmed heads he rode
5360: Of Thrones and mighty Seraphim prostrate,
5361: That wish'd the Mountains now might be again
5362: Thrown on them as a shelter from his ire.
5363: Nor less on either side tempestuous fell
5364: His arrows, from the fourfold-visag'd Foure,
5365: Distinct with eyes, and from the living Wheels,
5366: Distinct alike with multitude of eyes,
5367: One Spirit in them rul'd, and every eye
5368: Glar'd lightning, and shot forth pernicious fire
5369: Among th' accurst, that witherd all thir strength,
5370: And of thir wonted vigour left them draind,
5372: Yet half his strength he put not forth, but check'd
5373: His Thunder in mid Volie, for he meant
5374: Not to destroy, but root them out of Heav'n:
5375: The overthrown he rais'd, and as a Heard
5376: Of Goats or timerous flock together throngd
5377: Drove them before him Thunder-struck, pursu'd
5378: With terrors and with furies to the bounds
5379: And Chrystall wall of Heav'n, which op'ning wide,
5380: Rowld inward, and a spacious Gap disclos'd
5381: Into the wastful Deep; the monstrous sight
5382: Strook them with horror backward, but far worse
5383: Urg'd them behind; headlong themselvs they threw
5384: Down from the verge of Heav'n, Eternal wrauth
5385: Burnt after them to the bottomless pit.
5386: ¶Hell heard th' unsufferable noise, Hell saw
5387: Heav'n ruining from Heav'n and would have fled
5388: Affrighted; but strict Fate had cast too deep
5389: Her dark foundations, and too fast had bound.
5390: Nine dayes they fell; confounded *Chaos* roard,
5391: And felt tenfold confusion in thir fall
5392: Through his wilde Anarchie, so huge a rout
5393: Incumberd him with ruin: Hell at last
5394: Yawning receavd them whole, and on them clos'd,
5395: Hell thir fit habitation fraught with fire
5396: Unquenchable, the house of woe and paine.
5397: Disburd'nd Heav'n rejoic'd, and soon repaird
5398: Her mural breach, returning whence it rowld.
5399: Sole Victor from th' expulsion of his Foes
5401: To meet him all his Saints, who silent stood
5402: Eye witnesses of his Almightie Acts,
5403: With Jubilie advanc'd; and as they went,
5404: Shaded with branching Palme, each order bright,
5405: Sung Triumph, and him sung Victorious King,
5406: Son, Heire, and Lord, to him Dominion giv'n,
5407: Worthiest to Reign: he celebrated rode
5408: Triumphant through mid Heav'n, into the Courts
5409: And Temple of his mightie Father Thron'd
5410: On high; who into Glorie him receav'd,
5411: Where now he sits at the right hand of bliss.
5412: ¶Thus measuring things in Heav'n by things on Earth
5413: At thy request, and that thou maist beware
5414: By what is past, to thee I have reveal'd
5415: What might have else to human Race bin hid;
5416: The discord which befel, and Warr in Heav'n
5417: Among th' Angelic Powers, and the deep fall
5418: Of those too high aspiring, who rebelld
5419: With *Satan*, hee who envies now thy state,
5420: Who now is plotting how he may seduce
5421: Thee also from obedience, that with him
5422: Bereavd of happiness thou maist partake
5424: Which would be all his solace and revenge,
5425: As a despite don against the most High,
5426: Thee once to gaine Companion of his woe.
5427: But list'n not to his Temptations, warne
5428: Thy weaker; let it profit thee to have heard
5430: Of disobedience; firm they might have stood,
5431: Yet fell; remember, and fear to transgress.
5434: If rightly thou art call'd, whose Voice divine
5435: Following, above th' *Olympian* Hill I soare,
5437: The meaning, not the Name I call: for thou
5438: Nor of the Muses nine, nor on the top
5439: Of old *Olympus* dwell'st, but Heav'nlie borne,
5440: Before the Hills appeerd, or Fountain flow'd,
5441: Thou with Eternal wisdom didst converse,
5442: Wisdom thy Sister, and with her didst play
5443: In presence of th' Almightie Father, pleas'd
5444: With thy Celestial Song.  Up led by thee
5445: Into the Heav'n of Heav'ns I have presum'd,
5446: An Earthlie Guest, and drawn Empyreal Aire,
5447: Thy tempring; with like safetie guided down
5448: Return me to my Native Element:
5449: Least from this flying Steed unrein'd, (as once
5451: Dismounted, on th' *Aleian* Field I fall
5452: Erroneous, there to wander and forlorne.
5453: Half yet remaines unsung, but narrower bound
5455: Standing on Earth, not rapt above the Pole,
5456: More safe I Sing with mortal voice, unchang'd
5457: To hoarce or mute, though fall'n on evil dayes,
5458: On evil dayes though fall'n, and evil tongues;
5459: In darkness, and with dangers compast rouud,
5460: And solitude; yet not alone, while thou
5461: Visit'st my slumbers Nightly, or when Morn
5462: Purples the East: still govern thou my Song,
5463: *Urania*, and fit audience find, though few.
5464: But drive farr off the barbarous dissonance
5465: Of *Bacchus* and his Revellers, the Race
5466: Of that wilde Rout that tore the *Thracian* Bard
5467: In *Rhodope*, where Woods and Rocks had Eares
5468: To rapture, till the savage clamor dround
5469: Both Harp and Voice; nor could the Muse defend
5470: Her Son.  So fail not thou, who thee implores:
5471: For thou art Heav'nlie, shee an empty dreame.
5475: Apostasie, by what befell in Heaven
5476: To those Apostates, least the like befall
5477: In Paradise to *Adam* or his Race,
5478: Charg'd not to touch the interdicted Tree,
5479: If they transgress, and slight that sole command,
5480: So easily obeyd amid the choice
5481: Of all tasts else to please thir appetite,
5482: Though wandring.  He with his consorted *Eve*
5483: The storie heard attentive, and was fill'd
5484: With admiration, and deep Muse to heare
5485: Of things so high and strange, things to thir thought
5486: So unimaginable as hate in Heav'n,
5487: And Warr so neer the Peace of God in bliss
5488: With such confusion: but the evil soon
5489: Driv'n back redounded as a flood on those
5490: From whom it sprung, impossible to mix
5492: The doubts that in his heart arose: and now
5493: Led on, yet sinless, with desire to know
5494: What neerer might concern him, how this World
5495: Of Heav'n and Earth conspicuous first began,
5496: When, and whereof created, for what cause,
5497: What within *Eden* or without was done
5498: Before his memorie, as one whose drouth
5499: Yet scarce allay'd still eyes the current streame,
5500: Whose liquid murmur heard new thirst excites,
5501: Proceeded thus to ask his Heav'nly Guest.
5502: ¶Great things, and full of wonder in our eares,
5503: Farr differing from this World, thou hast reveal'd
5505: Down from the Empyrean to forewarne
5506: Us timely of what might else have bin our loss,
5507: Unknown, which human knowledg could not reach:
5508: For which to the infinitly Good we owe
5510: Receave with solemne purpose to observe
5511: Immutably his sovran will, the end
5512: Of what we are.  But since thou hast voutsaf't
5513: Gently for our instruction to impart
5514: Things above Earthly thought, which yet concernd
5515: Our knowing, as to highest wisdom seemd,
5516: Deign to descend now lower, and relate
5517: What may no less perhaps availe us known,
5518: How first began this Heav'n which we behold
5519: Distant so high, with moving Fires adornd
5520: Innumerable, and this which yeelds or fills
5521: All space, the ambient Aire wide interfus'd
5522: Imbracing round this florid Earth, what cause
5523: Mov'd the Creator in his holy Rest
5524: Through all Eternitie so late to build
5525: In *Chaos*, and the work begun, how soon
5526: Absolv'd, if unforbid thou maist unfould
5527: What wee, not to explore the secrets aske
5528: Of his Eternal Empire, but the more
5529: To magnifie his works, the more we know.
5530: And the great Light of Day yet wants to run
5531: Much of his Race though steep, suspens in Heav'n
5532: Held by thy voice, thy potent voice he heares,
5533: And longer will delay to heare thee tell
5534: His Generation, and the rising Birth
5535: Of Nature from the unapparent Deep:
5536: Or if the Starr of Eevning and the Moon
5537: Haste to thy audience, Night with her will bring
5538: Silence, and Sleep listning to thee will watch,
5539: Or we can bid his absence, till thy Song
5540: End, and dismiss thee ere the Morning shine.
5542: ¶And thus the Godlike Angel answerd milde.
5543: This also thy request with caution askt
5544: Obtaine: though to recount Almightie works
5545: What words or tongue of Seraph can suffice,
5546: Or heart of man suffice to comprehend?
5547: Yet what thou canst attain, which best may serve
5548: To glorifie the Maker, and inferr
5549: Thee also happier, shall not be withheld
5550: Thy hearing, such Commission from above
5551: I have receav'd, to answer thy desire
5552: Of knowledge within bounds; beyond abstain
5553: To ask, nor let thine own inventions hope
5554: Things not reveal'd, which th' invisible King,
5555: Onely Omniscient, hath supprest in Night,
5556: To none communicable in Earth or Heaven:
5557: Anough is left besides to search and know.
5558: But Knowledge is as food, and needs no less
5559: Her Temperance over Appetite, to know
5560: In measure what the mind may well contain,
5561: Oppresses else with Surfet, and soon turns
5562: Wisdom to Folly, as Nourishment to Winde.
5564: (So call him, brighter once amidst the Host
5565: Of Angels, then that Starr the Starrs among)
5566: Fell with his flaming Legions through the Deep
5567: Into his place, and the great Son returnd
5568: Victorious with his Saints, th' Omnipotent
5569: Eternal Father from his Throne beheld
5570: Thir multitude, and to his Son thus spake.
5571: ¶At least our envious Foe hath fail'd, who thought
5572: All like himself rebellious, by whose aid
5573: This inaccessible high strength, the seat
5575: He trusted to have seis'd, and into fraud
5576: Drew many, whom thir place knows here no more;
5577: Yet farr the greater part have kept, I see,
5578: Thir station, Heav'n yet populous retaines
5579: Number sufficient to possess her Realmes
5580: Though wide, and this high Temple to frequent
5581: With Ministeries due and solemn Rites:
5582: But least his heart exalt him in the harme
5583: Already done, to have dispeopl'd Heav'n,
5584: My damage fondly deem'd, I can repaire
5585: That detriment, if such it be to lose
5586: Self-lost, and in a moment will create
5587: Another World, out of one man a Race
5588: Of men innumerable, there to dwell,
5589: Not here, till by degrees of merit rais'd
5590: They open to themselves at length the way
5591: Up hither, under long obedience tri'd,
5592: And Earth be chang'd to Heavn, & Heav'n to Earth,
5593: One Kingdom, Joy and Union without end.
5594: Mean while inhabit laxe, ye Powers of Heav'n,
5595: And thou my Word, begotten Son, by thee
5596: This I perform, speak thou, and be it don:
5597: My overshadowing Spirit and might with thee
5598: I send along, ride forth, and bid the Deep
5599: Within appointed bounds be Heav'n and Earth,
5600: Boundless the Deep, because I am who fill
5602: Though I uncircumscrib'd my self retire,
5603: And put not forth my goodness, which is free
5604: To act or not, Necessitie and Chance
5605: Approach not mee, and what I will is Fate.
5606: ¶So spake th' Almightie, and to what he spake
5607: His Word, the Filial Godhead, gave effect.
5608: Immediate are the Acts of God, more swift
5609: Then time or motion, but to human ears
5610: Cannot without process of speech be told,
5611: So told as earthly notion can receave.
5612: Great triumph and rejoycing was in Heav'n
5613: When such was heard declar'd the Almightie's will;
5614: Glorie they sung to the most High, good will
5615: To future men, and in thir dwellings peace:
5616: Glorie to him whose just avenging ire
5617: Had driven out th' ungodly from his sight
5618: And th' habitations of the just; to him
5619: Glorie and praise, whose wisdom had ordain'd
5620: Good out of evil to create, in stead
5621: Of Spirits maligne a better Race to bring
5622: Into thir vacant room, and thence diffuse
5623: His good to Worlds and Ages infinite.
5624: So sang the Hierarchies: Mean while the Son
5625: On his great Expedition now appeer'd,
5626: Girt with Omnipotence, with Radiance crown'd
5627: Of Majestie Divine, Sapience and Love
5628: Immense, and all his Father in him shon.
5629: About his Chariot numberless were pour'd
5630: Cherub and Seraph, Potentates and Thrones,
5631: And Vertues, winged Spirits, and Chariots wing'd,
5632: From the Armoury of God, where stand of old
5633: Myriads between two brazen Mountains lodg'd
5634: Against a solemn day, harnest at hand,
5635: Celestial Equipage; and now came forth
5636: Spontaneous, for within them Spirit livd,
5637: Attendant on thir Lord: Heav'n op'nd wide
5638: Her ever during Gates, Harmonious sound
5639: On golden Hinges moving, to let forth
5640: The King of Glorie in his powerful Word
5641: And Spirit coming to create new Worlds.
5642: On heav'nly ground they stood, and from the shore
5643: They view'd the vast immeasurable Abyss
5644: Outrageous as a Sea, dark, wasteful, wilde,
5645: Up from the bottom turn'd by furious windes
5646: And surging waves, as Mountains to assault
5647: Heav'ns highth, and with the Center mix the Pole.
5648: ¶Silence, ye troubl'd waves, and thou Deep, peace,
5649: Said then th' Omnific Word, your discord end:
5650: ¶Nor staid, but on the Wings of Cherubim
5652: Farr into *Chaos*, and the World unborn;
5653: For *Chaos* heard his voice: him all his Traine
5654: Follow'd in bright procession to behold
5655: Creation, and the wonders of his might.
5656: Then staid the fervid Wheeles, and in his hand
5657: He took the golden Compasses, prepar'd
5658: In Gods Eternal store, to circumscribe
5659: This Universe, and all created things:
5660: One foot he center'd, and the other turn'd
5661: Round through the vast profunditie obscure,
5662: And said, thus farr extend, thus farr thy bounds,
5663: This be thy just Circumference, O World.
5664: Thus God the Heav'n created, thus the Earth,
5665: Matter unform'd and void: Darkness profound
5666: Cover'd th' Abyss: but on the watrie calme
5667: His brooding wings the Spirit of God outspred,
5668: And vital vertue infus'd, and vital warmth
5669: Throughout the fluid Mass, but downward purg'd
5670: The black tartareous cold infernal dregs
5671: Adverse to life: then founded, then conglob'd
5672: Like things to like, the rest to several place
5673: Disparted, and between spun out the Air,
5674: And Earth self-ballanc't on her Center hung.
5675: ¶Let ther be Light, said God, and forthwith Light
5676: Ethereal, first of things, quintessence pure
5677: Sprung from the Deep, and from her Native East
5678: To journie through the airie gloom began,
5679: Sphear'd in a radiant Cloud, for yet the Sun
5680: Was not; shee in a cloudie Tabernacle
5681: Sojourn'd the while.  God saw the Light was good;
5682: And light from darkness by the Hemisphere
5683: Divided: Light the Day, and Darkness Night
5684: He nam'd.  Thus was the first Day Eev'n and Morn:
5686: By the Celestial Quires, when Orient Light
5687: Exhaling first from Darkness they beheld;
5688: Birth-day of Heav'n and Earth; with joy and shout
5689: The hollow Universal Orb they fill'd,
5690: And touch't thir Golden Harps, & hymning prais'd
5691: God and his works, Creatour him they sung,
5692: Both when first Eevning was, and when first Morn.
5693: ¶Again, God said, let ther be Firmament
5694: Amid the Waters, and let it divide
5695: The Waters from the Waters: and God made
5696: The Firmament, expanse of liquid, pure,
5698: In circuit to the uttermost convex
5699: Of this great Round: partition firm and sure,
5700: The Waters underneath from those above
5701: Dividing: for as Earth, so hee the World
5702: Built on circumfluous Waters calme, in wide
5703: Crystallin Ocean, and the loud misrule
5704: Of *Chaos* farr remov'd, least fierce extreames
5705: Contiguous might distemper the whole frame:
5706: And Heav'n he nam'd the Firmament: So Eev'n
5707: And Morning *Chorus* sung the second Day.
5708: ¶The Earth was form'd, but in the Womb as yet
5710: Appeer'd not: over all the face of Earth
5711: Main Ocean flow'd, not idle, but with warme
5712: Prolific humour soft'ning all her Globe,
5713: Fermented the great Mother to conceave,
5714: Satiate with genial moisture, when God said
5715: Be gather'd now ye Waters under Heav'n
5716: Into one place, and let dry Land appeer.
5718: Emergent, and thir broad bare backs upheave
5719: Into the Clouds, thir tops ascend the Skie:
5720: So high as heav'd the tumid Hills, so low
5721: Down sunk a hollow bottom broad and deep,
5722: Capacious bed of Waters: thither they
5724: As drops on dust conglobing from the drie;
5725: Part rise in crystal Wall, or ridge direct,
5726: For haste; such flight the great command impress'd
5727: On the swift flouds: as Armies at the call
5728: Of Trumpet (for of Armies thou hast heard)
5729: Troop to thir Standard, so the watrie throng,
5730: Wave rowling after Wave, where way they found,
5731: If steep, with torrent rapture, if through Plaine,
5732: Soft-ebbing; nor withstood them Rock or Hill,
5733: But they, or under ground, or circuit wide
5734: With Serpent errour wandring, found thir way,
5735: And on the washie Oose deep Channels wore;
5736: Easie, e're God had bid the ground be drie,
5737: All but within those banks, where Rivers now
5738: Stream, and perpetual draw thir humid traine.
5739: The dry Land, Earth, and the great receptacle
5740: Of congregated Waters he call'd Seas:
5741: And saw that it was good, and said, Let th' Earth
5742: Put forth the verdant Grass, Herb yeilding Seed,
5743: And Fruit Tree yeilding Fruit after her kind;
5744: Whose Seed is in her self upon the Earth.
5745: He scarce had said, when the bare Earth, till then
5747: Brought forth the tender Grass, whose verdure clad
5748: Her Universal Face with pleasant green,
5749: Then Herbs of every leaf, that sudden flour'd
5750: Op'ning thir various colours, and made gay
5751: Her bosom smelling sweet: and these scarce blown,
5752: Forth flourish't thick the clustring Vine, forth crept
5753: The smelling Gourd, up stood the cornie Reed
5754: Embattell'd in her field: add the humble Shrub,
5755: And Bush with frizl'd hair implicit: last
5756: Rose as in Dance the stately Trees, and spred
5757: Thir branches hung with copious Fruit; or gemm'd
5758: Thir Blossoms: with high Woods the Hills were crownd,
5759: With tufts the vallies & each fountain side,
5760: With borders long the Rivers.  That Earth now
5761: Seemd like to Heav'n, a seat where Gods might dwell,
5762: Or wander with delight, and love to haunt
5763: Her sacred shades: though God had yet not rain'd
5764: Upon the Earth, and man to till the ground
5765: None was, but from the Earth a dewie Mist
5766: Went up and waterd all the ground, and each
5767: Plant of the field, which e're it was in the Earth
5768: God made, and every Herb, before it grew
5769: On the green stemm; God saw that it was good:
5770: So Eev'n and Morn recorded the Third Day.
5771: ¶Again th' Almightie spake: Let there be Lights
5772: High in th' expanse of Heaven to divide
5773: The Day from Night; and let them be for Signes,
5774: For Seasons, and for Dayes, and circling Years,
5775: And let them be for Lights as I ordaine
5776: Thir Office in the Firmament of Heav'n
5777: To give Light on the Earth; and it was so.
5778: And God made two great Lights, great for thir use
5779: To Man, the greater to have rule by Day,
5780: The less by Night alterne: and made the Starrs,
5781: And set them in the Firmament of Heav'n
5782: To illuminate the Earth, and rule the Day
5783: In thir vicissitude, and rule the Night,
5784: And Light from Darkness to divide.  God saw,
5785: Surveying his great Work, that it was good:
5786: For of Celestial Bodies first the Sun
5787: A mightie Spheare he fram'd, unlightsom first,
5788: Though of Ethereal Mould: then form'd the Moon
5789: Globose, and everie magnitude of Starrs,
5790: And sowd with Starrs the Heav'n thick as a field:
5791: Of Light by farr the greater part he took,
5792: Transplanted from her cloudie Shrine, and plac'd
5793: In the Suns Orb, made porous to receive
5794: And drink the liquid Light, firm to retaine
5795: Her gather'd beams, great Palace now of Light.
5796: Hither as to thir Fountain other Starrs
5797: Repairing, in thir gold'n Urns draw Light,
5798: And hence the Morning Planet guilds his horns;
5799: By tincture or reflection they augment
5800: Thir small peculiar, though from human sight
5801: So farr remote, with diminution seen.
5802: First in his East the glorious Lamp was seen,
5803: Regent of Day, and all th' Horizon round
5804: Invested with bright Rayes, jocond to run
5805: His Longitude through Heav'ns high rode: the gray
5806: Dawn, and the *Pleiades* before him danc'd
5807: Shedding sweet influence: less bright the Moon,
5808: But opposite in leveld West was set
5809: His mirror, with full face borrowing her Light
5810: From him, for other light she needed none
5811: In that aspect, and still that distance keepes
5812: Till night, then in the East her turn she shines,
5813: Revolvd on Heav'ns great Axle, and her Reign
5814: With thousand lesser Lights dividual holds,
5815: With thousand thousand Starres, that then appeer'd
5816: Spangling the Hemisphere: then first adornd
5817: With thir bright Luminaries that Set and Rose,
5818: Glad Eevning & glad Morn crownd the fourth day.
5819: ¶And God said, let the Waters generate
5820: Reptil with Spawn abundant, living Soule:
5821: And let Fowle flie above the Earth, with wings
5822: Displayd on the op'n Firmament of Heav'n.
5823: And God created the great Whales, and each
5824: Soul living, each that crept, which plenteously
5825: The waters generated by thir kindes,
5826: And every Bird of wing after his kinde;
5827: And saw that it was good, and bless'd them, saying,
5828: Be fruitful, multiply, and in the Seas
5829: And Lakes and running Streams the waters fill;
5830: And let the Fowle be multiply'd on the Earth.
5831: Forthwith the Sounds and Seas, each Creek & Bay
5832: With Frie innumerable swarme, and Shoales
5833: Of Fish that with thir Finns and shining Scales
5834: Glide under the green Wave, in Sculles that oft
5835: Bank the mid Sea: part single or with mate
5836: Graze the Sea weed thir pasture, & through Groves
5837: Of Coral stray, or sporting with quick glance
5838: Show to the Sun thir wav'd coats dropt with Gold,
5839: Or in thir Pearlie shells at ease, attend
5840: Moist nutriment, or under Rocks thir food
5841: In jointed Armour watch: on smooth the Seale,
5842: And bended Dolphins play: part huge of bulk
5843: Wallowing unweildie, enormous in thir Gate
5845: Hugest of living Creatures, on the Deep
5846: Stretcht like a Promontorie sleeps or swimmes,
5847: And seems a moving Land, and at his Gilles
5848: Draws in, and at his Trunck spouts out a Sea.
5849: Mean while the tepid Caves, and Fens and shoares
5850: Thir Brood as numerous hatch, from the Egg that soon
5851: Bursting with kindly rupture forth disclos'd
5852: Thir callow young, but featherd soon and fledge
5853: They summ'd thir Penns, and soaring th' air sublime
5854: With clang despis'd the ground, under a cloud
5855: In prospect; there the Eagle and the Stork
5856: On Cliffs and Cedar tops thir Eyries build:
5857: Part loosly wing the Region, part more wise
5858: In common, rang'd in figure wedge thir way,
5859: Intelligent of seasons, and set forth
5860: Thir Aierie Caravan high over Sea's
5861: Flying, and over Lands with mutual wing
5862: Easing thir flight; so stears the prudent Crane
5863: Her annual Voiage, born on Windes; the Aire
5864: Floats, as they pass, fann'd with unnumber'd plumes:
5865: From Branch to Branch the smaller Birds with song
5866: Solac'd the Woods, and spred thir painted wings
5867: Till Ev'n, nor then the solemn Nightingal
5868: Ceas'd warbling, but all night tun'd her soft layes:
5869: Others on Silver Lakes and Rivers Bath'd
5870: Thir downie Brest; the Swan with Arched neck
5871: Between her white wings mantling proudly, Rowes
5872: Her state with Oarie feet: yet oft they quit
5873: The Dank, and rising on stiff Pennons, towre
5874: The mid Aereal Skie: Others on ground
5875: Walk'd firm; the crested Cock whose clarion sounds
5876: The silent hours, and th' other whose gay Traine
5877: Adorns him, colour'd with the Florid hue
5878: Of Rainbows and Starrie Eyes.  The Waters thus
5879: With Fish replenisht, and the Aire with Fowle,
5880: Ev'ning and Morn solemniz'd the Fift day.
5881: ¶The Sixt, and of Creation last arose
5882: With Eevning Harps and Mattin, when God said,
5883: Let th' Earth bring forth Fowle living in her kinde,
5884: Cattel and Creeping things, and Beast of the Earth,
5885: Each in their kinde.  The Earth obey'd, and strait
5886: Op'ning her fertil Woomb teem'd at a Birth
5888: Limb'd and full grown: out of the ground up-rose
5889: As from his Laire the wilde Beast where he wonns
5890: In Forrest wilde, in Thicket, Brake, or Den;
5891: Among the Trees in Pairs they rose, they walk'd:
5892: The Cattel in the Fields and Meddowes green:
5893: Those rare and solitarie, these in flocks
5894: Pasturing at once, and in broad Herds upsprung:
5895: The grassie Clods now Calv'd, now half appeer'd
5896: The Tawnie Lion, pawing to get free
5897: His hinder parts, then springs as broke from Bonds,
5898: And Rampant shakes his Brinded main; the Ounce,
5899: The Libbard, and the Tyger, as the Moale
5900: Rising, the crumbl'd Earth above them threw
5901: In Hillocks; the swift Stag from under ground
5902: Bore up his branching head: scarse from his mould
5904: His vastness: Fleec't the Flocks and bleating rose,
5905: As Plants: ambiguous between Sea and Land
5906: The River Horse and scalie Crocodile.
5907: At once came forth whatever creeps the ground,
5908: Insect or Worme; those wav'd thir limber fans
5909: For wings, and smallest Lineaments exact
5910: In all the Liveries dect of Summers pride
5911: With spots of Gold and Purple, azure and green:
5912: These as a line thir long dimension drew,
5913: Streaking the ground with sinuous trace; not all
5914: Minims of Nature; some of Serpent kinde
5915: Wondrous in length and corpulence involv'd
5916: Thir Snakie foulds, and added wings.  First crept
5918: Of future, in small room large heart enclos'd,
5920: Hereafter, join'd in her popular Tribes
5922: The Femal Bee that feeds her Husband Drone
5923: Deliciously, and builds her waxen Cells
5924: With Honey stor'd: the rest are numberless,
5925: And thou thir Natures know'st, and gav'st them Names,
5926: Needlest to thee repeaed; nor unknown
5927: The Serpent suttl'st Beast of all the field,
5928: Of huge extent somtimes, with brazen Eyes
5929: And hairie Main terrific, though to thee
5930: Not noxious, but obedient at thy call.
5931: Now Heav'n in all her Glorie shon, and rowld
5932: Her motions, as the great first-Movers hand
5933: First wheeld thir course; Earth in her rich attire
5934: Consummate lovly smil'd; Aire, Water, Earth,
5935: By Fowl, Fish, Beast, was flown, was swum, was walkt
5936: Frequent; and of the Sixt day yet remain'd;
5937: There wanted yet the Master work, the end
5938: Of all yet don; a Creature who not prone
5939: And Brute as other Creatures, but endu'd
5940: With Sanctitie of Reason, might erect
5941: His Stature, and upright with Front serene
5942: Govern the rest, self-knowing, and from thence
5944: But grateful to acknowledge whence his good
5945: Descends, thither with heart and voice and eyes
5947: And worship God Supream, who made him chief
5948: Of all his works: therefore the Omnipotent
5949: Eternal Father (For where is not hee
5950: Present) thus to his Son audibly spake.
5951: ¶Let us make now Man in our image, Man
5952: In our similitude, and let them rule
5953: Over the Fish and Fowle of Sea and Aire,
5954: Beast of the Field, and over all the Earth,
5955: And every creeping thing that creeps the ground.
5956: This said, he formd thee, *Adam*, thee O Man
5957: Dust of the ground, and in thy nostrils breath'd
5958: The breath of Life; in his own Image hee
5959: Created thee, in the Image of God
5960: Express, and thou becam'st a living Soul.
5961: Male he created thee, but thy consort
5962: Femal for Race; then bless'd Mankinde, and said,
5963: Be fruitful, multiplie, and fill the Earth,
5964: Subdue it, and throughout Dominion hold
5965: Over Fish of the Sea, and Fowle of the Aire,
5966: And every living thing that moves on the Earth.
5967: Wherever thus created, for no place
5968: Is yet distinct by name, thence, as thou know'st
5969: He brought thee into this delicious Grove,
5970: This Garden, planted with the Trees of God,
5971: Delectable both to behold and taste;
5972: And freely all thir pleasant fruit for food
5973: Gave thee, all sorts are here that all th' Earth yeelds,
5974: Varietie without end; but of the Tree
5975: Which tasted works knowledge of Good and Evil,
5976: Thou mai'st not; in the day thou eat'st, thou di'st;
5977: Death is the penaltie impos'd, beware,
5978: And govern well thy appetite, least sin
5979: Surprise thee, and her black attendant Death.
5980: Here finish'd hee, and all that he had made
5981: View'd, and behold all was entirely good;
5982: So Ev'n and Morn accomplish'd the Sixt day:
5983: Yet not till the Creator from his work
5985: Up to the Heav'n of Heav'ns his high abode,
5986: Thence to behold this new created World
5987: Th' addition of his Empire, how it shew'd
5988: In prospect from his Throne, how good, how faire,
5989: Answering his great Idea.  Up he rode
5990: Followd with acclamation and the sound
5991: Symphonious of ten thousand Harpes that tun'd
5992: Angelic harmonies: the Earth, the Aire
5994: The Heav'ns and all the Constellations rung,
5995: The Planets in thir stations list'ning stood,
5996: While the bright Pomp ascended jubilant.
5997: Open, ye everlasting Gates, they sung,
5998: Open, ye Heav'ns, your living dores; let in
5999: The great Creator from his work returnd
6000: Magnificent, his Six days work, a World;
6001: Open, and henceforth oft; for God will deigne
6002: To visit oft the dwellings of just Men
6004: Thither will send his winged Messengers
6005: On errands of supernal Grace.  So sung
6006: The glorious Train ascending: He through Heav'n,
6007: That open'd wide her blazing Portals, led
6008: To Gods Eternal house direct the way,
6009: A broad and ample rode, whose dust is Gold
6010: And pavement Starrs, as Starrs to thee appeer,
6011: Seen in the Galaxie, that Milkie way
6012: Which nightly as a circling Zone thou seest
6013: Pouderd with Starrs.  And now on Earth the Seaventh
6014: Eev'ning arose in *Eden*, for the Sun
6015: Was set, and twilight from the East came on,
6016: Forerunning Night; when at the holy mount
6017: Of Heav'ns high-seated top, th' Impereal Throne
6018: Of Godhead, fixt for ever firm and sure,
6019: The Filial Power arriv'd, and sate him down
6020: With his great Father (for he also went
6022: Hath Omnipresence) and the work ordain'd,
6023: Author and end of all things, and from work
6024: Now resting, bless'd and hallowd the Seav'nth day,
6025: As resting on that day from all his work,
6026: But not in silence holy kept; the Harp
6027: Had work and rested not, the solemn Pipe,
6028: And Dulcimer, all Organs of sweet stop,
6029: All sounds on Fret by String or Golden Wire
6030: Temper'd soft Tunings, intermixt with Voice
6031: Choral or Unison: of incense Clouds
6032: Fuming from Golden Censers hid the Mount.
6033: Creation and the Six dayes acts they sung,
6035: Thy power; what thought can measure thee or tongue
6036: Relate thee; greater now in thy return
6037: Then from the Giant Angels; thee that day
6038: Thy Thunders magnifi'd; but to create
6039: Is greater then created to destroy.
6040: Who can impair thee, mighty King, or bound
6041: Thy Empire? easily the proud attempt
6042: Of Spirits apostat and thir Counsels vaine
6043: Thou hast repeld, while impiously they thought
6044: Thee to diminish, and from thee withdraw
6045: The number of thy worshippers.  Who seekes
6046: To lessen thee, against his purpose serves
6047: To manifest the more thy might: his evil
6048: Thou usest, and from thence creat'st more good.
6049: Witness this new-made World, another Heav'n
6050: From Heaven Gate not farr, founded in view
6051: On the cleer *Hyaline*, the Glassie Sea;
6052: Of amplitude almost immense, with Starr's
6053: Numerous, and every Starr perhaps a World
6054: Of destind habitation; but thou know'st
6055: Thir seasons: among these the seat of men,
6056: Earth with her nether Ocean circumfus'd,
6057: Thir pleasant dwelling place.  Thrice happie men,
6058: And sons of men, whom God hath thus advanc't,
6059: Created in his Image, there to dwell
6060: And worship him, and in reward to rule
6061: Over his Works, on Earth, in Sea, or Air,
6062: And multiply a Race of Worshippers
6063: Holy and just: thrice happie if they know
6065: ¶So sung they, and the Empyrean rung,
6067: And thy request think now fulfill'd, that ask'd
6068: How first this World and face of things began,
6069: And what before thy memorie was don
6071: Informd by thee might know; if else thou seekst
6072: Aught, not surpassing human measure, say.
6074: What thanks sufficient, or what recompence
6075: Equal have I to render thee, Divine
6076: Hystorian, who thus largely hast allayd
6077: The thirst I had of knowledge, and voutsaf't
6079: Things else by me unsearchable, now heard
6080: With wonder, but delight, and, as is due,
6081: With glorie attributed to the high
6082: Creator; some thing yet of doubt remaines,
6083: Which onely thy solution can resolve.
6084: When I behold this goodly Frame, this World
6085: Of Heav'n and Earth consisting, and compute,
6086: Thir magnitudes, this Earth a spot, a graine,
6087: An Atom, with the Firmament compar'd
6088: And all her numberd Starrs, that seem to rowle
6090: Thir distance argues and thir swift return
6092: Round this opacous Earth, this punctual spot,
6093: One day and night; in all thir vast survey
6094: Useless besides, reasoning I oft admire,
6095: How Nature wise and frugal could commit
6097: So many nobler Bodies to create,
6098: Greater so manifold to this one use,
6099: For aught appeers, and on thir Orbs impose
6100: Such restless revolution day by day
6102: That better might with farr less compass move,
6103: Serv'd by more noble then her self, attaines
6104: Her end without least motion, and receaves,
6105: As Tribute such a sumless journey brought
6106: Of incorporeal speed, her warmth and light;
6107: Speed, to describe whose swiftness Number failes.
6108: ¶So spake our Sire, and by his count'nance seemd
6109: Entring on studious thoughts abstruse, which *Eve*
6110: Perceaving where she sat retir'd in sight,
6111: With lowliness Majestic from her seat,
6112: And Grace that won who saw to wish her stay,
6113: Rose, and went forth among her Fruits and Flours,
6114: To visit how they prosper'd, bud and bloom,
6115: Her Nurserie; they at her coming sprung
6116: And toucht by her fair tendance gladlier grew.
6117: Yet went she not, as not with such discourse
6118: Delighted, or not capable her eare
6119: Of what was high: such pleasure she reserv'd,
6121: Her Husband the Relater she preferr'd
6122: Before the Angel, and of him to ask
6123: Chose rather; hee, she knew would intermix
6124: Grateful digressions, and solve high dispute
6125: With conjugal Caresses, from his Lip
6126: Not Words alone pleas'd her.  O when meet now
6127: Such pairs, in Love and mutual Honour joyn'd?
6128: With Goddess-like demeanour forth she went;
6129: Not unattended, for on her as Queen
6130: A pomp of winning Graces waited still,
6131: And from about her shot Darts of desire
6132: Into all Eyes to wish her still in sight.
6135: ¶To ask or search I blame thee not, for Heav'n
6136: Is as the Book of God before thee set,
6137: Wherein to read his wondrous Works, and learne
6138: His Seasons, Hours, or Days, or Months, or Yeares:
6139: This to attain, whether Heav'n move or Earth,
6140: Imports not, if thou reck'n right, the rest
6141: From Man or Angel the great Architect
6142: Did wisely to conceal, and not divulge
6143: His secrets to be scann'd by them who ought
6144: Rather admire; or if they list to try
6145: Conjecture, he his Fabric of the Heav'ns
6146: Hath left to thir disputes, perhaps to move
6147: His laughter at thir quaint Opinions wide
6148: Hereafter, when they come to model Heav'n
6149: And calculate the Starrs, how they will weild
6150: The mightie frame, how build, unbuild, contrive
6151: To save appeerances, how gird the Sphear
6152: With Centric and Eccentric scribl'd o're,
6153: Cycle and Epicycle, Orb in Orb:
6154: Alreadie by thy reasoning this I guess,
6155: Who art to lead thy ofspring, and supposest
6156: That Bodies bright and greater should not serve
6157: The less not bright, nor Heav'n such journies run,
6158: Earth sitting still, when she alone receaves
6159: The benefit: consider first, that Great
6160: Or Bright inferrs not Excellence: the Earth
6161: Though, in comparison of Heav'n, so small,
6162: Nor glistering, may of solid good containe
6163: More plenty then the Sun that barren shines,
6164: Whose vertue on it self workes no effect,
6165: But in the fruitful Earth; there first receavd
6166: His beams, unactive else, thir vigor find.
6167: Yet not to Earth are those bright Luminaries
6168: Officious, but to thee Earths habitant.
6169: And for the Heav'ns wide Circuit, let it speak
6170: The Makers high magnificence, who built
6171: So spacious, and his Line stretcht out so farr;
6172: That Man may know he dwells not in his own;
6173: An Edifice too large for him to fill,
6174: Lodg'd in a small partition, and the rest
6175: Ordain'd for uses to his Lord best known.
6176: The swiftness of those Circles attribute,
6178: That to corporeal substances could adde
6179: Speed almost Spiritual; mee thou thinkst not slow,
6180: Who since the Morning hour set out from Heav'n
6181: Where God resides, and ere mid-day arriv'd
6183: By Numbers that have name.  But this I urge,
6184: Admitting Motion in the Heav'ns, to shew
6185: Invalid that which thee to doubt it mov'd;
6186: Not that I so affirm, though so it seem
6187: To thee who hast thy dwelling here on Earth.
6188: God to remove his wayes from human sense,
6189: Plac'd Heav'n from Earth so farr, that earthly sight,
6190: If it presume, might erre in things too high,
6191: And no advantage gaine.  What if the Sun
6192: Be Center to the World, and other Starrs
6193: By his attractive vertue and thir own
6194: Incited, dance about him various rounds?
6195: Thir wandring course now high, now low, then hid,
6197: In six thou seest, and what if sev'nth to these
6198: The Planet Earth, so stedfast though she seem,
6200: Which else to several Sphears thou must ascribe,
6202: Or save the Sun his labour, and that swift
6204: Invisible else above all Starrs, the Wheele
6205: Of Day and Night; which needs not thy beleefe,
6206: If Earth industrious of her self fetch Day
6207: Travelling East, and with her part averse
6208: From the Suns beam meet Night, her other part
6209: Still luminous by his ray.  What if that light
6210: Sent from her through the wide transpicuous aire,
6211: To the terrestrial Moon be as a Starr
6212: Enlightning her by Day, as she by Night
6213: This Earth? reciprocal, if Land be there,
6214: Feilds and Inhabitants: Her spots thou seest
6215: As Clouds, and Clouds may rain, and Rain produce
6216: Fruits in her soft'nd Soile, for some to eate
6217: Allotted there; and other Suns perhaps
6218: With thir attendant Moons thou wilt descrie
6220: Which two great Sexes animate the World,
6221: Stor'd in each Orb perhaps with some that live.
6222: For such vast room in Nature unpossest
6223: By living Soule, desert and desolate,
6224: Onely to shine, yet scarce to contribute
6225: Each Orb a glimps of Light, conveyd so farr
6226: Down to this habitable, which returnes
6227: Light back to them, is obvious to dispute.
6228: But whether thus these things, or whether not,
6229: Whether the Sun predominant in Heav'n
6230: Rise on the Earth, or Earth rise on the Sun,
6231: Hee from the East his flaming rode begin,
6232: Or Shee from West her silent course advance
6233: With inoffensive pace that spinning sleeps
6234: On her soft Axle, while she paces Eev'n,
6235: And bears thee soft with the smooth Air along,
6236: Sollicit not thy thoughts with matters hid,
6237: Leave them to God above, him serve and feare;
6238: Of other Creatures, as him pleases best,
6239: Wherever plac't, let him dispose: joy thou
6240: In what he gives to thee, this Paradise
6241: And thy faire *Eve*; Heav'n is for thee too high
6242: To know what passes there; be lowlie wise:
6243: Think onely what concernes thee and thy being;
6244: Dream not of other Worlds, what Creatures there
6245: Live, in what state, condition or degree,
6246: Contented that thus farr hath been reveal'd
6247: Not of Earth onely but of highest Heav'n.
6248: ¶To whom thus *Adam* cleerd of doubt, repli'd.
6249: How fully hast thou satisfi'd mee, pure
6251: And freed from intricacies, taught to live,
6252: The easiest way, nor with perplexing thoughts
6253: To interrupt the sweet of Life, from which
6254: God hath bid dwell farr off all anxious cares,
6255: And not molest us, unless we our selves
6256: Seek them with wandring thoughts, and notions vaine.
6257: But apt the Mind or Fancie is to roave
6258: Uncheckt, and of her roaving is no end;
6259: Till warn'd, or by experience taught, she learne,
6260: That not to know at large of things remote
6261: From use, obscure and suttle, but to know
6262: That which before us lies in daily life,
6263: Is the prime Wisdom, what is more, is fume,
6265: And renders us in things that most concerne
6266: Unpractis'd, unprepar'd, and still to seek.
6267: Therefore from this high pitch let us descend
6268: A lower flight, and speak of things at hand
6269: Useful, whence haply mention may arise
6270: Of somthing not unseasonable to ask
6271: By sufferance, and thy wonted favour deign'd.
6272: Thee I have heard relating what was don
6273: Ere my remembrance: now hear mee relate
6274: My Storie, which perhaps thou hast not heard;
6275: And Day is yet not spent; till then thou seest
6276: How suttly to detaine thee I devise,
6277: Inviting thee to hear while I relate,
6278: Fond, were it not in hope of thy reply:
6279: For while I sit with thee, I seem in Heav'n,
6280: And sweeter thy discourse is to my eare
6281: Then Fruits of Palm-tree pleasantest to thirst
6282: And hunger both, from labour, at the houre
6283: Of sweet repast; they satiate, and soon fill,
6284: Though pleasant, but thy words with Grace Divine
6285: Imbu'd, bring to thir sweetness no satietie.
6287: Nor are thy lips ungraceful, Sire of men,
6288: Nor tongue ineloquent; for God on thee
6289: Abundantly his gifts hath also pour'd,
6290: Inward and outward both, his image faire:
6291: Speaking or mute all comliness and grace
6292: Attends thee, and each word, each motion formes.
6293: Nor less think wee in Heav'n of thee on Earth
6294: Then of our fellow servant, and inquire
6295: Gladly into the wayes of God with Man:
6296: For God we see hath honour'd thee, and set
6297: On Man his equal Love: say therefore on;
6298: For I that Day was absent, as befell,
6299: Bound on a voyage uncouth and obscure,
6300: Farr on excursion toward the Gates of Hell;
6301: Squar'd in full Legion (such command we had)
6302: To see that none thence issu'd forth a spie,
6303: Or enemie, while God was in his work,
6304: Least hee incenst at such eruption bold,
6305: Destruction with Creation might have mixt.
6306: Not that they durst without his leave attempt,
6307: But us he sends upon his high behests
6308: For state, as Sovran King, and to enure
6309: Our prompt obedience.  Fast we found, fast shut
6310: The dismal Gates, and barricado'd strong;
6311: But long ere our approaching heard within
6312: Noise, other then the sound of Dance or Song,
6313: Torment, and lowd lament, and furious rage.
6314: Glad we return'd up to the coasts of Light
6315: Ere Sabbath Eev'ning: so we had in charge.
6316: But thy relation now; for I attend,
6317: Pleas'd with thy words no less then thou with mine.
6318: ¶So spake the Godlike Power, and thus our Sire.
6319: For Man to tell how human Life began
6320: Is hard; for who himself beginning knew?
6321: Desire with thee still longer to converse
6322: Induc'd me.  As new wak't from soundest sleep
6323: Soft on the flourie herb I found me laid
6324: In Balmie Sweat, which with his Beames the Sun
6325: Soon dri'd, and on the reaking moisture fed.
6326: Strait toward Heav'n my wondring Eyes I turnd,
6327: And gaz'd a while the ample Skie, till rais'd
6328: By quick instinctive motion up I sprung,
6330: Stood on my feet; about me round I saw
6331: Hill, Dale, and shadie Woods, and sunnie Plaines,
6332: And liquid Lapse of murmuring Streams; by these,
6333: Creatures that livd, and movd, and walk'd, or flew,
6334: Birds on the branches warbling; all things smil'd,
6335: With fragrance and with joy my heart oreflow'd.
6336: My self I then perus'd, and Limb by Limb
6337: Survey'd, and sometimes went, and sometimes ran
6338: With supple joints, as lively vigour led:
6339: But who I was, or where, or from what cause,
6340: Knew not; to speak I tri'd, and forthwith spake,
6341: My Tongue obey'd and readily could name
6342: What e're I saw.  Thou Sun, said I, faire Light,
6343: And thou enlight'nd Earth, so fresh and gay,
6344: Ye Hills and Dales, ye Rivers, Woods, and Plaines,
6345: And ye that live and move, fair Creatures, tell,
6346: Tell, if ye saw, how came I thus, how here?
6347: Not of my self; by some great Maker then,
6348: In goodness and in power praeeminent;
6349: Tell me, how may I know him, how adore,
6350: From whom I have that thus I move and live,
6351: And feel that I am happier then I know.
6352: While thus I call'd, and stray'd I knew not whither,
6353: From where I first drew Aire, and first beheld
6354: This happie Light, when answer none return'd,
6355: On a green shadie Bank profuse of Flours
6356: Pensive I sate me down; there gentle sleep
6357: First found me, and with soft oppression seis'd
6358: My droused sense, untroubl'd, though I thought
6359: I then was passing to my former state
6361: When suddenly stood at my Head a dream,
6363: My Fancy to believe I yet had being,
6364: And livd: One came, methought, of shape Divine,
6365: And said, thy Mansion wants thee, *Adam*, rise,
6366: First Man, of Men innumerable ordain'd
6367: First Father, call'd by thee I come thy Guide
6368: To the Garden of bliss, thy seat prepar'd.
6369: So saying, by the hand he took me rais'd,
6370: And over Fields and Waters, as in Aire
6371: Smooth sliding without step, last led me up
6372: A woodie Mountain; whose high top was plaine,
6373: A Circuit wide, enclos'd, with goodliest Trees
6374: Planted, with Walks, and Bowers, that what I saw
6375: Of Earth before scarse pleasant seemd.  Each Tree
6376: Load'n with fairest Fruit, that hung to the Eye
6377: Tempting, stirr'd in me sudden appetite
6378: To pluck and eate; whereat I wak'd, and found
6379: Before mine Eyes all real, as the dream
6380: Had lively shadowd: Here had new begun
6381: My wandring, had not hee who was my Guide
6382: Up hither, from among the Trees appeer'd,
6383: Presence Divine.  Rejoycing, but with aw
6384: In adoration at his feet I fell
6385: Submiss: he rear'd me, & Whom thou soughtst I am,
6386: Said mildely, Author of all this thou seest
6387: Above, or round about thee or beneath.
6388: This Paradise I give thee, count it thine
6389: To Till and keep, and of the Fruit to eate:
6390: Of every Tree that in the Garden growes
6391: Eate freely with glad heart; fear here no dearth:
6392: But of the Tree whose operation brings
6393: Knowledg of good and ill, which I have set
6394: The Pledge of thy Obedience and thy Faith,
6395: Amid the Garden by the Tree of Life,
6396: Remember what I warne thee, shun to taste,
6397: And shun the bitter consequence: for know,
6398: The day thou eat'st thereof, my sole command
6400: From that day mortal, and this happie State
6401: Shalt loose, expell'd from hence into a World
6402: Of woe and sorrow.  Sternly he pronounc'd
6404: Yet dreadful in mine eare, though in my choice
6405: Not to incur; but soon his cleer aspect
6406: Return'd and gratious purpose thus renew'd.
6407: Not onely these fair bounds, but all the Earth
6408: To thee and to thy Race I give; as Lords
6409: Possess it, and all things that therein live,
6410: Or live in Sea, or Aire, Beast, Fish, and Fowle.
6411: In signe whereof each Bird and Beast behold
6412: After thir kindes; I bring them to receave
6413: From thee thir Names, and pay thee fealtie
6414: With low subjection; understand the same
6415: Of Fish within thir watry residence,
6416: Not hither summond, since they cannot change
6417: Thir Element to draw the thinner Aire.
6418: As thus he spake, each Bird and Beast behold
6419: Approaching two and two, These cowring low
6420: With blandishment, each Bird stoop'd on his wing.
6421: I nam'd them, as they pass'd, and understood
6422: Thir Nature, with such knowledg God endu'd
6423: My sudden apprehension: but in these
6424: I found not what me thought I wanted still;
6425: And to the Heav'nly vision thus presum'd.
6426: ¶O by what Name, for thou above all these,
6427: Above mankinde, or aught then mankinde higher,
6428: Surpassest farr my naming, how may I
6429: Adore thee, Author of this Universe,
6430: And all this good to man, for whose well being
6431: So amply, and with hands so liberal
6432: Thou hast provided all things: but with mee
6433: I see not who partakes.  In solitude
6434: What happiness, who can enjoy alone,
6435: Or all enjoying, what contentment find?
6436: Thus I presumptuous; and the vision bright,
6437: As with a smile more bright'nd, thus repli'd.
6438: ¶What call'st thou solitude, is not the Earth
6439: With various living creatures, and the Aire
6440: Replenisht, and all these at thy command
6441: To come and play before thee, know'st thou not
6442: Thir language and thir wayes, they also know,
6443: And reason not contemptibly; with these
6444: Find pastime, and beare rule; thy Realm is large.
6445: So spake the Universal Lord, and seem'd
6446: So ordering.  I with leave of speech implor'd,
6448: ¶Let not my words offend thee, Heav'nly Power,
6449: My Maker, be propitious while I speak.
6450: Hast thou not made me here thy substitute,
6451: And these inferiour farr beneath me set?
6453: Can sort, what harmonie or true delight?
6454: Which must be mutual, in proportion due
6455: Giv'n and receiv'd; but in disparitie
6456: The one intense, the other still remiss
6457: Cannot well suite with either, but soon prove
6458: Tedious alike: Of fellowship I speak
6459: Such as I seek, fit to participate
6460: All rational delight, wherein the brute
6461: Cannot be human consort; they rejoyce
6462: Each with thir kinde, Lion with Lioness;
6463: So fitly them in pairs thou hast combin'd;
6464: Much less can Bird with Beast, or Fish with Fowle
6465: So well converse, nor with the Ox the Ape;
6466: Wors then can Man with Beast, and least of all.
6468: A nice and suttle happiness I see
6469: Thou to thy self proposest, in the choice
6470: Of thy Associates, *Adam*, and wilt taste
6471: No pleasure, though in pleasure, solitarie.
6472: What thinkst thou then of mee, and this my State,
6473: Seem I to thee sufficiently possest
6474: Of happiness, or not? who am alone
6475: From all Eternitie, for none I know
6476: Second to mee or like, equal much less.
6477: How have I then with whom to hold converse
6478: Save with the Creatures which I made, and those
6480: Beneath what other Creatures are to thee?
6481: ¶He ceas'd, I lowly answer'd.  To attaine
6482: The highth and depth of thy Eternal wayes
6483: All human thoughts come short, Supream of things;
6484: Thou in thy self art perfet, and in thee
6485: Is no deficience found; not so is Man,
6486: But in degree, the cause of his desire
6487: By conversation with his like to help,
6488: Or solace his defects.  No need that thou
6490: And through all numbers absolute, though One;
6491: But Man by number is to manifest
6493: Like of his like, his Image multipli'd,
6496: Thou in thy secresie although alone,
6497: Best with thy self accompanied, seek'st not
6499: Canst raise thy Creature to what highth thou wilt
6501: I by conversing cannot these erect
6502: From prone, nor in thir wayes complacence find.
6503: Thus I embold'nd spake, and freedom us'd
6504: Permissive, and acceptance found, which gain'd
6505: This answer from the gratious voice Divine.
6506: ¶Thus farr to try thee, *Adam*, I was pleas'd,
6507: And finde thee knowing not of Beasts alone,
6508: Which thou hast rightly nam'd, but of thy self,
6509: Expressing well the spirit within thee free,
6510: My Image, not imparted to the Brute,
6511: Whose fellowship therefore unmeet for thee
6512: Good reason was thou freely shouldst dislike,
6513: And be so minded still; I, ere thou spak'st,
6514: Knew it not good for Man to be alone,
6515: And no such companie as then thou saw'st
6516: Intended thee, for trial onely brought,
6517: To see how thou could'st judge of fit and meet:
6518: What next I bring shall please thee, be assur'd,
6519: Thy likeness, thy fit help, thy other self,
6520: Thy wish, exactly to thy hearts desire.
6521: ¶Hee ended, or I heard no more, for now
6522: My earthly by his Heav'nly overpowerd,
6523: Which it had long stood under, streind to the highth
6525: As with an object that excels the sense,
6526: Dazl'd and spent, sunk down, and sought repair
6527: Of sleep, which instantly fell on me, call'd
6528: By Nature as in aide, and clos'd mine eyes.
6529: Mine eyes he clos'd, but op'n left the Cell
6530: Of Fancie my internal sight, by which
6531: Abstract as in a transe methought I saw,
6532: Though sleeping, where I lay, and saw the shape
6533: Still glorious before whom awake I stood;
6534: Who stooping op'nd my left side, and took
6535: From thence a Rib, with cordial spirits warme,
6536: And Life-blood streaming fresh; wide was the wound,
6537: But suddenly with flesh fill'd up & heal'd:
6538: The Rib he formd and fashond with his hands;
6539: Under his forming hands a Creature grew,
6540: Manlike, but different sex, so lovly faire,
6541: That what seemd fair in all the World, seemd now
6542: Mean, or in her summd up, in her containd
6543: And in her looks, which from that time infus'd
6544: Sweetness into my heart, unfelt before,
6545: And into all things from her Aire inspir'd
6546: The spirit of love and amorous delight.
6547: She disappeerd, and left me dark, I wak'd
6548: To find her, or for ever to deplore
6549: Her loss, and other pleasures all abjure:
6550: When out of hope, behold her, not farr off,
6551: Such as I saw her in my dream, adornd
6552: With what all Earth or Heaven could bestow
6553: To make her amiable: On she came,
6554: Led by her Heav'nly Maker, though unseen,
6555: And guided by his voice, nor uninformd
6556: Of nuptial Sanctitie and marriage Rites:
6557: Grace was in all her steps, Heav'n in her Eye,
6558: In every gesture dignitie and love.
6559: I overjoyd could not forbear aloud.
6560: ¶This turn hath made amends; thou hast fulfill'd
6561: Thy words, Creator bounteous and benigne,
6562: Giver of all things faire, but fairest this
6563: Of all thy gifts, nor enviest.  I now see
6564: Bone of my Bone, Flesh of my Flesh, my Self
6565: Before me; Woman is her Name, of Man
6566: Extracted; for this cause he shall forgoe
6567: Father and Mother, and to his Wife adhere;
6568: And they shall be one Flesh, one Heart, one Soule.
6569: ¶She heard me thus, and though divinely brought,
6571: Her vertue and the conscience of her worth,
6572: That would be woo'd, and not unsought be won,
6573: Not obvious, not obtrusive, but retir'd,
6574: The more desirable, or to say all,
6575: Nature her self, though pure of sinful thought,
6576: Wrought in her so, that seeing me, she turn'd;
6577: I follow'd her, she what was Honour knew,
6579: My pleaded reason.  To the Nuptial Bowre
6580: I led her blushing like the Morn: all Heav'n,
6581: And happie Constellations on that houre
6582: Shed thir selectest influence; the Earth
6583: Gave sign of gratulation, and each Hill;
6584: Joyous the Birds; fresh Gales and gentle Aires
6585: Whisper'd it to the Woods, and from thir wings
6586: Flung Rose, flung Odours from the spicie Shrub,
6587: Disporting, till the amorous Bird of Night
6588: Sung Spousal, and bid haste the Eevning Starr
6589: On his Hill top, to light the bridal Lamp.
6590: Thus I have told thee all my State, and brought
6591: My Storie to the sum of earthly bliss
6592: Which I enjoy, and must confess to find
6593: In all things else delight indeed, but such
6594: As us'd or not, works in the mind no change,
6596: I mean of Taste, Sight, Smell, Herbs, Fruits, & Flours,
6597: Walks, and the melodie of Birds; but here
6599: Transported touch; here passion first I felt,
6600: Commotion strange, in all enjoyments else
6601: Superiour and unmov'd, here onely weake
6602: Against the charm of Beauties powerful glance.
6603: Or Nature faild in mee, and left some part
6604: Not proof enough such Object to sustain,
6605: Or from my side subducting, took perhaps
6606: More then enough; at least on her bestow'd
6607: Too much of Ornament, in outward shew
6609: For well I understand in the prime end
6610: Of Nature her th' inferiour, in the mind
6611: And inward Faculties, which most excell,
6612: In outward also her resembling less
6613: His Image who made both, and less expressing
6614: The character of that Dominion giv'n
6615: O're other Creatures; yet when I approach
6616: Her loveliness, so absolute she seems
6617: And in her self compleat, so well to know
6618: Her own, that what she wills to do or say,
6620: All higher knowledge in her presence falls
6621: Degraded, Wisdom in discourse with her
6622: Looses discount'nanc't, and like folly shewes;
6623: Authoritie and Reason on her waite,
6624: As one intended first, not after made
6626: Greatness of mind and nobleness thir seat
6627: Build in her loveliest, and create an awe
6628: About her, as a guard Angelic plac't.
6629: To whom the Angel with contracted brow.
6630: ¶Accuse not Nature, she hath don her part;
6631: Do thou but thine, and be not diffident
6632: Of Wisdom, she deserts thee not, if thou
6633: Dismiss not her, when most thou needst her nigh,
6635: Less excellent, as thou thy self perceav'st.
6636: For what admir'st thou, what transports thee so,
6637: An outside? fair no doubt, and worthy well
6638: Thy cherishing, thy honouring, and thy love,
6639: Not thy subjection: weigh with her thy self;
6640: Then value: Oft times nothing profits more
6641: Then self-esteem, grounded on just and right
6642: Well manag'd; of that skill the more thou know'st,
6643: The more she will acknowledge thee her Head,
6644: And to realities yeild all her shows;
6645: Made so adorn for thy delight the more,
6646: So awful, that with honour thou maist love
6647: Thy mate, who sees when thou art seen least wise.
6648: But if the sense of touch whereby mankind
6649: Is propagated seem such dear delight
6650: Beyond all other, think the same voutsaf't
6651: To Cattel and each Beast; which would not be
6652: To them made common & divulg'd, if aught
6653: Therein enjoy'd were worthy to subdue
6654: The Soule of Man, or passion in him move.
6655: What higher in her societie thou findst
6657: In loving thou dost well, in passion not,
6658: Wherein true Love consists not; love refines
6659: The thoughts, and heart enlarges, hath his seat
6660: In Reason, and is judicious, is the scale
6661: By which to heav'nly Love thou maist ascend,
6662: Not sunk in carnal pleasure, for which cause
6663: Among the Beasts no Mate for thee was found.
6665: Neither her out-side formd so fair, nor aught
6666: In procreation common to all kindes
6667: (Though higher of the genial Bed by far,
6668: And with mysterious reverence I deem)
6669: So much delights me, as those graceful acts,
6670: Those thousand decencies that daily flow
6671: From all her words and actions, mixt with Love
6672: And sweet compliance, which declare unfeign'd
6673: Union of Mind, or in us both one Soule;
6674: Harmonie to behold in wedded pair
6675: More grateful then harmonious sound to the eare.
6676: Yet these subject not; I to thee disclose
6677: What inward thence I feel, not therefore foild,
6678: Who meet with various objects, from the sense
6680: Approve the best, and follow what I approve.
6681: To love thou blam'st me not, for love thou saist
6682: Leads up to Heav'n, is both the way and guide;
6683: Bear with me then, if lawful what I ask;
6684: Love not the heav'nly Spirits, and how thir Love
6685: Express they, by looks onely, or do they mix
6687: ¶To whom the Angel with a smile that glow'd
6688: Celestial rosie red, Loves proper hue,
6689: Answer'd.  Let it suffice thee that thou know'st
6690: Us happie, and without Love no happiness.
6691: Whatever pure thou in the body enjoy'st
6692: (And pure thou wert created) we enjoy
6693: In eminence, and obstacle find none
6694: Of membrane, joynt, or limb, exclusive barrs:
6695: Easier then Air with Air, if Spirits embrace,
6696: Total they mix, Union of Pure with Pure
6698: As Flesh to mix with Flesh, or Soul with Soul.
6699: But I can now no more; the parting Sun
6700: Beyond the Earths green Cape and verdant Isles
6702: Be strong, live happie, and love, but first of all
6703: Him whom to love is to obey, and keep
6704: His great command; take heed least Passion sway
6705: Thy Judgement to do aught, which else free Will
6706: Would not admit; thine and of all thy Sons
6707: The weal or woe in thee is plac't; beware.
6708: I in thy persevering shall rejoyce,
6709: And all the Blest: stand fast; to stand or fall
6710: Free in thine own Arbitrement it lies.
6711: Perfet within, no outward aid require;
6712: And all temptation to transgress repel.
6714: Follow'd with benediction.  Since to part,
6716: Sent from whose sovran goodness I adore.
6717: Gentle to me and affable hath been
6718: Thy condescension, and shall be honour'd ever
6719: With grateful Memorie: thou to mankind
6720: Be good and friendly still, and oft return.
6721: ¶So parted they, the Angel up to Heav'n
6722: From the thick shade, and *Adam* to his Bowre.
6724: ¶No more of talk where God or Angel Guest
6725: With Man, as with his Friend, familiar us'd
6726: To sit indulgent, and with him partake
6727: Rural repast, permitting him the while
6728: Venial discourse unblam'd: I now must change
6729: Those Notes to Tragic; foul distrust, and breach
6730: Disloyal on the part of Man, revolt
6731: And disobedience: On the part of Heav'n
6733: Anger and just rebuke, and judgement giv'n,
6734: That brought into this World a world of woe,
6735: Sinne and her shadow Death, and Miserie
6736: Deaths Harbinger: Sad task, yet argument
6737: Not less but more Heroic then the wrauth
6738: Of stern *Achilles* on his Foe pursu'd
6739: Thrice Fugitive about *Troy* Wall; or rage
6741: Or *Neptun's* ire or *Juno's*, that so long
6743: If answerable style I can obtaine
6744: Of my Celestial Patroness, who deignes
6746: And dictates to me slumbring, or inspires
6748: Since first this subject for Heroic Song
6749: Pleas'd me long choosing, and beginning late;
6750: Not sedulous by Nature to indite
6752: Heroic deem'd, chief maistrie to dissect
6753: With long and tedious havoc fabl'd Knights
6754: In Battels feign'd; the better fortitude
6756: Unsung; or to describe Races and Games,
6759: Bases and tinsel Trappings, gorgious Knights
6760: At Joust and Torneament; then marshal'd Feast
6761: Serv'd up in Hall with Sewers, and Seneshals;
6762: The skill of Artifice or Office mean,
6763: Not that which justly gives Heroic name
6764: To Person or to Poem.  Mee of these
6765: Nor skilld nor studious, higher Argument
6766: Remaines, sufficient of it self to raise
6767: That name, unless an age too late, or cold
6768: Climat, or Years damp my intended wing
6769: Deprest, and much they may, if all be mine,
6770: Not Hers who brings it nightly to my Ear.
6771: ¶The Sun was sunk, and after him the Starr
6772: Of *Hesperus*, whose Office is to bring
6773: Twilight upon the Earth, short Arbiter
6774: Twixt Day and Night, and now from end to end
6775: Nights Hemisphere had veild the Horizon round:
6776: When *Satan* who late fled before the threats
6778: In meditated fraud and malice, bent
6779: On mans destruction, maugre what might hap
6780: Of heavier on himself, fearless return'd.
6781: By Night he fled, and at Midnight return'd
6782: From compassing the Earth, cautious of day,
6783: Since *Uriel* Regent of the Sun descri'd
6784: His entrance, and forewarnd the Cherubim
6785: That kept thir watch; thence full of anguish driv'n,
6786: The space of seven continu'd Nights he rode
6787: With darkness, thrice the Equinoctial Line
6788: He circl'd, four times cross'd the Carr of Night
6789: From Pole to Pole, traversing each Colure;
6790: On the eighth return'd, and on the Coast averse
6791: From entrance or Cherubic Watch, by stealth
6792: Found unsuspected way.  There was a place,
6793: Now not, though Sin, not Time, first wraught the change,
6794: Where *Tigris* at the foot of Paradise
6795: Into a Gulf shot under ground, till part
6796: Rose up a Fountain by the Tree of Life;
6797: In with the River sunk, and with it rose
6798: Satan involv'd in rising Mist, then sought
6799: Where to lie hid; Sea he had searcht and Land
6802: Downward as farr Antartic; and in length
6803: West from *Orantes* to the Ocean barr'd
6804: At *Darien*, thence to the Land where flowes
6805: *Ganges* and *Indus:* thus the Orb he roam'd
6806: With narrow search; and with inspection deep
6807: Consider'd every Creature, which of all
6808: Most opportune might serve his Wiles, and found
6809: The Serpent suttlest Beast of all the Field.
6811: Of thoughts revolv'd, his final sentence chose
6812: Fit Vessel, fittest Imp of fraud, in whom
6813: To enter, and his dark suggestions hide
6814: From sharpest sight: for in the wilie Snake,
6815: Whatever sleights none would suspicious mark,
6816: As from his wit and native suttletie
6817: Proceeding, which in other Beasts observ'd
6818: Doubt might beget of Diabolic pow'r
6819: Active within beyond the sense of brute.
6820: Thus he resolv'd, but first from inward griefe
6821: His bursting passion into plaints thus pour'd:
6822: ¶O Earth, how like to Heav'n, if not preferrd
6823: More justly, Seat worthier of Gods, as built
6824: With second thoughts, reforming what was old!
6825: For what God after better worse would build?
6826: Terrestrial Heav'n, danc't round by other Heav'ns
6827: That shine, yet bear thir bright officious Lamps,
6828: Light above Light, for thee alone, as seems,
6829: In thee concentring all thir precious beams
6830: Of sacred influence: As God in Heav'n
6831: Is Center, yet extends to all, so thou
6832: Centring receav'st from all those Orbs; in thee,
6833: Not in themselves, all thir known vertue appeers
6834: Productive in Herb, Plant, and nobler birth
6835: Of Creatures animate with gradual life
6836: Of Growth, Sense, Reason, all summ'd up in Man.
6837: With what delight could I have walkt thee round
6838: If I could joy in aught, sweet interchange
6839: Of Hill and Vallie, Rivers, Woods and Plaines,
6840: Now Land, now Sea, & Shores with Forrest crownd,
6841: Rocks, Dens, and Caves; but I in none of these
6842: Find place or refuge; and the more I see
6843: Pleasures about me, so much more I feel
6844: Torment within me, as from the hateful siege
6845: Of contraries; all good to me becomes
6846: Bane, and in Heav'n much worse would be my state.
6847: But neither here seek I, no nor in Heav'n
6848: To dwell, unless by maistring Heav'ns Supreame;
6849: Nor hope to be my self less miserable
6850: By what I seek, but others to make such
6851: As I though thereby worse to me redound:
6852: For onely in destroying I finde ease
6853: To my relentless thoughts; and him destroyd,
6854: Or won to what may work his utter loss,
6855: For whom all this was made, all this will soon
6856: Follow, as to him linkt in weal or woe,
6857: In wo then; that destruction wide may range:
6858: To mee shall be the glorie sole among
6859: The infernal Powers, in one day to have marr'd
6860: What he *Almightie* styl'd, six Nights and Days
6861: Continu'd making, and who knows how long
6862: Before had bin contriving, though perhaps
6863: Not longer then since I in one Night freed
6865: Th' Angelic Name, and thinner left the throng
6866: Of his adorers: hee to be aveng'd,
6867: And to repaire his numbers thus impair'd,
6868: Whether such vertue spent of old now faild
6869: More Angels to Create, if they at least
6870: Are his Created or to spite us more,
6871: Determin'd to advance into our room
6872: A Creature form'd of Earth, and him endow,
6874: With Heav'nly spoils, our spoils: What he decreed
6875: He effected; Man he made, and for him built
6876: Magnificent this World, and Earth his seat,
6877: Him Lord pronounc'd, and, O indignitie!
6878: Subjected to his service Angel wings,
6879: And flaming Ministers to watch and tend
6880: Thir earthlie Charge: Of these the vigilance
6881: I dread, and to elude, thus wrapt in mist
6882: Of midnight vapor glide obscure, and prie
6883: In every Bush and Brake, where hap may finde
6884: The Serpent sleeping, in whose mazie foulds
6885: To hide me, and the dark intent I bring.
6886: O foul descent! that I who erst contended
6887: With Gods to sit the highest, am now constraind
6888: Into a Beast, and mixt with bestial slime,
6889: This essence to incarnate and imbrute,
6890: That to the hight of Deitie aspir'd;
6891: But what will not Ambition and Revenge
6892: Descend to? who aspires must down as low
6893: As high he soard, obnoxious first or last
6894: To basest things.  Revenge, at first though sweet,
6895: Bitter ere long back on it self recoiles;
6896: Let it; I reck not, so it light well aim'd,
6897: Since higher I fall short, on him who next
6898: Provokes my envie, this new Favorite
6899: Of Heav'n, this Man of Clay, Son of despite,
6900: Whom us the more to spite his Maker rais'd
6901: From dust: spite then with spite is best repaid.
6902: ¶So saying, through each Thicket Danck or Drie,
6903: Like a black mist low creeping, he held on
6904: His midnight search, where soonest he might finde
6905: The Serpent: him fast sleeping soon he found
6906: In Labyrinth of many a round self-rowl'd,
6907: His head the midst, well stor'd with suttle wiles:
6908: Not yet in horrid Shade or dismal Den,
6909: Not nocent yet, but on the grassie Herbe
6910: Fearless unfeard he slept: in at his Mouth
6911: The Devil enterd, and his brutal sense,
6912: In heart or head, possessing soon inspir'd
6913: With act intelligential; but his sleep
6914: Disturbd not, waiting close th' approach of Morn.
6915: Now whenas sacred Light began to dawne
6916: In *Eden* on the humid Flours, that breathd
6917: Thir morning Incense, when all things that breath,
6918: From th' Earths great Altar send up silent praise
6919: To the Creator, and his Nostrils fill
6920: With gratefull Smell, forth came the human pair
6921: And joynd thir vocal Worship to the Quire
6922: Of Creatures wanting voice, that done, partake
6923: The season, prime for sweetest Sents and Aires:
6924: Then commune how that day they best may ply
6925: Thir growing work: for much thir work outgrew
6926: The hands dispatch of two Gardning so wide.
6927: And *Eve* first to her Husband thus began.
6928: ¶*Adam*, well may we labour still to dress
6929: This Garden, still to tend Plant, Herb and Flour.
6930: Our pleasant task enjoyn'd, but till more hands
6931: Aid us, the work under our labour grows,
6932: Luxurious by restraint; what we by day
6933: Lop overgrown, or prune, or prop, or bind,
6934: One night or two with wanton growth derides
6935: Tending to wilde.  Thou therefore now advise
6936: Or hear what to my mind first thoughts present,
6937: Let us divide our labours, thou where choice
6938: Leads thee, or where most needs, whether to wind
6939: The Woodbine round this Arbour, or direct
6940: The clasping Ivie where to climb, while I
6941: In yonder Spring of Roses intermixt
6942: With Myrtle, find what to redress till Noon:
6943: For while so near each other thus all day
6944: Our task we choose, what wonder if no near
6945: Looks intervene and smiles, or object new
6946: Casual discourse draw on, which intermits
6947: Our dayes work brought to little, though begun
6948: Early, and th' hour of Supper comes unearn'd.
6950: Sole *Eve*, Associate sole, to me beyond
6951: Compare above all living Creatures deare,
6952: Well hast thou motion'd, wel thy thoughts imployd
6953: How we might best fulfill the work which here
6954: God hath assign'd us, nor of me shalt pass
6955: Unprais'd: for nothing lovelier can be found
6956: In woman, then to studie houshold good,
6957: And good workes in her Husband to promote.
6958: Yet not so strictly hath our Lord impos'd
6959: Labour, as to debarr us when we need
6960: Refreshment, whether food, or talk between,
6961: Food of the mind, or this sweet intercourse
6962: Of looks and smiles, for smiles from Reason flow,
6963: To brute deni'd, and are of Love the food,
6964: Love not the lowest end of human life.
6965: For not to irksom toile, but to delight
6966: He made us, and delight to Reason joyn'd.
6967: These paths and Bowers doubt not but our joynt
