6968: Will keep from Wilderness with ease, as wide
6969: As we need walk, till younger hands ere long
6970: Assist us: But if much converse perhaps
6971: Thee satiate, to short absence I could yeild.
6972: For solitude somtimes is best societie,
6973: And short retirement urges sweet returne.
6974: But other doubt possesses me, least harm
6975: Befall thee sever'd from me; for thou knowst
6976: What hath bin warn'd us, what malicious Foe
6977: Envying our happiness, and of his own
6978: Despairing, seeks to work us woe and shame
6979: By sly assault; and somwhere nigh at hand
6980: Watches, no doubt, with greedy hope to find
6981: His wish and best advantage, us asunder,
6982: Hopeless to circumvent us joynd, where each
6983: To other speedie aide might lend at need;
6984: Whether his first design be to withdraw
6985: Our fealtie from God, or to disturb
6986: Conjugal Love, then which perhaps no bliss
6987: Enjoy'd by us excites his envie more;
6988: Or this, or worse, leave not the faithful side
6989: That gave thee being, stil shades thee and protects.
6990: The Wife, where danger or dishonour lurks,
6991: Safest and seemliest by her Husband staies,
6992: Who guards her, or with her the worst endures.
6994: As one who loves, and some unkindness meets,
6995: With sweet austeer composure thus reply'd.
6996: ¶Ofspring of Heav'n and Earth, and all Earths Lord,
6997: That such an enemie we have, who seeks
6998: Our ruin, both by thee informd I learne,
6999: And from the parting Angel over-heard
7000: As in a shadie nook I stood behind,
7001: Just then returnd at shut of Evening Flours.
7002: But that thou shouldst my firmness therefore doubt
7003: To God or thee, because we have a foe
7004: May tempt it, I expected not to hear.
7005: His violence thou fearst not, being such,
7006: As wee, not capable of death or paine,
7007: Can either not receave, or can repell.
7008: His fraud is then thy fear, which plain inferrs
7009: Thy equal fear that my firm Faith and Love
7010: Can by his fraud be shak'n or seduc't;
7011: Thoughts, which how found they harbour in thy Brest,
7012: *Adam*, misthought of her to thee so dear?
7014: Daughter of God and Man, immortal *Eve*,
7015: For such thou art, from sin and blame entire:
7016: Not diffident of thee do I dissuade
7017: Thy absence from my sight, but to avoid
7018: Th' attempt it self, intended by our Foe.
7019: For hee who tempts, though in vain, at least asperses
7020: The tempted with dishonour foul, suppos'd
7021: Not incorruptible of Faith, not prooff
7022: Against temptation: thou thy self with scorne
7023: And anger wouldst resent the offer'd wrong,
7024: Though ineffectual found: misdeem not then,
7025: If such affront I labour to avert
7026: From thee alone, which on us both at once
7027: The Enemie, though bold, will hardly dare,
7028: Or daring, first on mee th' assault shall light.
7029: Nor thou his malice and false guile contemn;
7030: Suttle he needs must be, who could seduce
7031: Angels, nor think superfluous others aid.
7032: I from the influence of thy looks receave
7033: Access in every Vertue, in thy sight
7034: More wise, more watchful, stronger, if need were
7035: Of outward strength; while shame, thou looking on,
7036: Shame to be overcome or over-reacht
7037: Would utmost vigor raise, and rais'd unite.
7038: Why shouldst not thou like sense within thee feel
7039: When I am present, and thy trial choose
7040: With me, best witness of thy Vertue tri'd.
7042: And Matrimonial Love, but *Eve*, who thought
7043: Less attributed to her Faith sincere,
7044: Thus her reply with accent sweet renewd.
7045: ¶If this be our condition, thus to dwell
7046: In narrow circuit strait'nd by a Foe,
7047: Suttle or violent, we not endu'd
7048: Single with like defence, wherever met,
7049: How are we happie, still in fear of harm?
7050: But harm precedes not sin: onely our Foe
7051: Tempting affronts us with his foul esteem
7052: Of our integritie: his foul esteeme
7053: Sticks no dishonor on our Front, but turns
7054: Foul on himself; then wherfore shund or feard
7055: By us? who rather double honour gaine
7056: From his surmise prov'd false, finde peace within,
7057: Favour from Heav'n, our witness from th' event.
7058: And what is Faith, Love, Vertue unassaid
7060: Let us not then suspect our happie State
7061: Left so imperfet by the Maker wise,
7062: As not secure to single or combin'd.
7063: Fraile is our happiness, if this be so,
7066: O Woman, best are all things as the will
7067: Of God ordaind them, his creating hand
7069: Of all that he Created, much less Man,
7070: Or ought that might his happie State secure,
7071: Secure from outward force; within himself
7072: The danger lies, yet lies within his power:
7073: Against his will he can receave no harme.
7074: But God left free the Will, for what obeyes
7075: Reason, is free, and Reason he made right,
7076: But bid her well beware, and still erect,
7077: Least by some faire appeering good surpris'd
7078: She dictate false, and missinforme the Will
7079: To do what God expresly hath forbid.
7080: Not then mistrust, but tender love enjoynes,
7081: That I should mind thee oft, and mind thou me.
7082: Firm we subsist, yet possible to swerve,
7083: Since Reason not impossibly may meet
7084: Some specious object by the Foe subornd,
7086: Not keeping strictest watch, as she was warnd.
7087: Seek not temptation then, which to avoide
7088: Were better, and most likelie if from mee
7089: Thou sever not; Trial will come unsought.
7090: Wouldst thou approve thy constancie, approve
7091: First thy obedience; th' other who can know,
7092: Not seeing thee attempted, who attest?
7093: But if thou think, trial unsought may finde
7094: Us both securer then thus warnd thou seemst,
7095: Go; for thy stay, not free, absents thee more;
7096: Go in thy native innocence, relie
7097: On what thou hast of vertue, summon all,
7098: For God towards thee hath done his part, do thine.
7099: ¶So spake the Patriarch of Mankinde, but *Eve*
7100: Persisted, yet submiss, though last, repli'd.
7101: ¶With thy permission then, and thus forewarnd
7102: Chiefly by what thy own last reasoning words
7103: Touchd onely, that our trial, when least sought,
7104: May finde us both perhaps farr less prepar'd,
7105: The willinger I goe, nor much expect
7106: A Foe so proud will first the weaker seek;
7107: So bent, the more shall shame him his repulse.
7108: Thus saying, from her Husbands hand her hand
7109: Soft she withdrew, and like a Wood-Nymph light
7111: Betook her to the Groves, but *Delia's* self
7112: In gate surpass'd and Goddess-like deport,
7113: Though not as shee with Bow and Quiver armd,
7114: But with such Gardning Tools as Are yet rude,
7115: Guiltless of fire had formd, or Angels brought,
7117: Likest she seemd, *Pomona* when she fled
7120: Her long with ardent look his *Eye* pursu'd
7121: Delighted, but desiring more her stay.
7122: Oft he to her his charge of quick returne,
7123: Repeated, shee to him as oft engag'd
7124: To be returnd by Noon amid the Bowre,
7125: And all things in best order to invite
7127: O much deceav'd, much failing, hapless *Eve*,
7128: Of thy presum'd return! event perverse!
7129: Thou never from that houre in Paradise
7130: Foundst either sweet repast, or found repose;
7131: Such ambush hid among sweet Flours and Shades
7133: To intercept thy way, or send thee back
7134: Despoild of Innocence, of Faith, of Bliss.
7135: For now, and since first break of dawne the Fiend,
7136: Meer Serpent in appearance, forth was come,
7137: And on his Quest, where likeliest he might finde
7138: The onely two of Mankinde, but in them
7139: The whole included Race, his purposd prey.
7140: In Bowre and Field he sought, where any tuft
7141: Of Grove or Garden-Plot more pleasant lay,
7142: Thir tendance or Plantation for delight,
7143: By Fountain or by shadie Rivulet
7144: He sought them both, but wish'd his hap might find
7145: *Eve* separate, he wish'd, but not with hope
7146: Of what so seldom chanc'd, when to his wish,
7147: Beyond his hope, *Eve* separate he spies,
7148: Veild in a Cloud of Fragrance, where she stood,
7149: Half spi'd, so thick the Roses bushing round
7150: About her glowd, oft stooping to support
7151: Each Flour of slender stalk, whose head though gay
7152: Carnation, Purple, Azure, or spect with Gold,
7153: Hung drooping unsustaind, them she upstaies
7154: Gently with Mirtle band, mindless the while,
7155: Her self, though fairest unsupported Flour,
7156: From her best prop so farr, and storn so nigh.
7157: Neererhe drew, and many a walk travers'd
7158: Of stateliest Covert, Cedar, Pine, or Palme,
7159: Then voluble and bold, now hid, now seen
7161: Imborderd on each Bank, the hand of *Eve*:
7162: Spot more delicious then those Gardens feign'd
7165: Or that, not Mystic, where the Sapient King
7166: Held dalliance with his faire *Egyptian* Spouse.
7167: Much hee the Place admir'd, the Person more.
7168: As one who long in populous City pent,
7169: Where Houses thick and Sewers annoy the Aire,
7170: Forth issuing on a Summers Morn, to breathe
7171: Among the pleasant Villages and Farmes
7172: Adjoynd, from each thing met conceaves delight,
7173: The smell of Grain, or tedded Grass, or Kine,
7174: Or Dairie, each rural sight, each rural sound;
7175: If chance with Nymphlike step fair Virgin pass,
7176: What pleasing seemd, for her now pleases more,
7177: She most, and in her look summs all Delight.
7178: Such Pleasure took the Serpent to behold
7179: This Flourie Plat, the sweet recess of *Eve*
7180: Thus earlie, thus alone; her Heav'nly forme
7181: Angelic, but more soft, and Feminine,
7182: Her graceful Innocence, her every Aire
7183: Of gesture or lest action overawd
7184: His Malice, and with rapine sweet bereav'd
7185: His fierceness of the fierce intent it brought:
7186: That space the Evil one abstracted stood
7187: From his own evil, and for the time remaind
7189: Of guile, of hate, of envie, of revenge;
7190: But the hot Hell that alwayes in him burnes,
7191: Though in mid Heav'n, soon ended his delight,
7192: And tortures him now more, the more he sees
7193: Of pleasure not for him ordain'd: then soon
7194: Fierce hate he recollects, and all his thoughts
7196: ¶Thoughts, whither have he led me, with what sweet
7198: What hither brought us, hate, not love, nor hope
7199: Of Paradise for Hell, hope here to taste
7200: Of pleasure, but all pleasure to destroy,
7201: Save what is in destroying, other joy
7202: To me is lost.  Then let me not let pass
7203: Occasion which now smiles, behold alone
7204: The Woman, opportune to all attempts,
7205: Her Husband, for I view far round, not nigh,
7206: Whose higher intellectual more I shun,
7207: And strength, of courage hautie, and of limb
7208: Heroic built, though of terrestrial mould,
7209: Foe not informidable, exempt from wound,
7210: I not; so much hath Hell debas'd, and paine
7211: Infeebl'd me, to what I was in Heav'n.
7212: Shee fair, divinely fair, fit Love for Gods,
7213: Not terrible, though terrour be in Love
7214: And beautie, not approacht by stronger hate,
7215: Hate stronger, under shew of Love well feign'd,
7216: The way which to her ruin now I tend.
7217: ¶So spake the Enemie of Mankind, enclos'd
7218: In Serpent, Inmate bad, and toward *Eve*
7219: Address'd his way, not with indented wave,
7220: Prone on the ground, as since, but on his reare,
7221: Circular base of rising foulds, that tour'd
7222: Fould above fould a surging Maze, his Head
7223: Crested aloft, and Carbuncle his Eyes;
7224: With burnisht Neck of verdant Gold, erect
7225: Amidst his circling Spires, that on the grass
7226: Floted redundant: pleasing was his shape,
7227: And lovely, never since of Serpent kind
7228: Lovelier, not those that in *Illyria* chang'd
7232: Hee with *Olympias*, this with her who bore
7233: *Scipio* the highth of *Rome*.  With tract oblique
7234: At first, as one who sought access, but feard
7235: To interrupt, side-long he works his way.
7236: As when a Ship by skilful Stearsman wrought
7237: Nigh Rivers mouth or Foreland, where the Wind
7238: Veres oft, as oft so steers, and shifts her Saile;
7239: So varied hee, and of his tortuous Traine
7240: Curld many a wanton wreath in sight of *Eve*,
7241: To lure her Eye; shee busied heard the sound
7242: Of rusling Leaves, but minded not, as us'd
7243: To such disport before her through the Field,
7244: From every Beast, more duteous at her call,
7245: Then at *Circean* call the Herd disguis'd.
7246: Hee boulder now, uncall'd before her stood;
7247: But as in gaze admiring: Oft he bowd
7248: His turret Crest, and sleek enamel'd Neck,
7249: Fawning, and lick'd the ground whereon she trod.
7250: His gentle dumb expression turnd at length
7251: The Eye of *Eve* to mark his play; he glad
7252: Of her attention gaind, with Serpent Tongue
7253: Organic, or impulse of vocal Air,
7256: Thou canst, who art sole Wonder, much less arm
7257: Thy looks, the Heav'n of mildness, with disdain,
7258: Displeas'd that I approach thee thus, and gaze
7259: Insatiate, I thus single; nor have feard
7260: Thy awful brow, more awful thus retir'd.
7261: Fairest resemblance of thy Maker faire,
7262: Thee all living things gaze on, all things thine
7263: By gift, and thy Celestial Beautie adore
7264: With ravishment beheld, there best beheld
7266: In this enclosure wild, these Beasts among,
7267: Beholders rude, and shallow to discerne
7268: Half what in thee is fair, one man except,
7269: Who sees thee? (and what is one?) who shouldst be seen
7270: A Goddess among Gods, ador'd and serv'd
7271: By Angels numberless, thy daily Train.
7272: ¶So gloz'd the Tempter, and his Proem tun'd;
7273: Into the Heart of *Eve* his words made way,
7274: Though at the voice much marveling; at length
7275: Not unamaz'd she thus in answer spake.
7276: What may this mean?  Language of Man pronounc't
7277: By Tongue of Brute, and human sense exprest?
7278: The first at lest of these I thought deni'd
7279: To Beasts, whom God on their Creation-Day
7280: Created mute to all articulat sound;
7281: The latter I demurre, for in thir looks
7282: Much reason, and in thir actions oft appeers.
7283: Thee, Serpent, suttlest beast of all the field
7284: I knew, but not with human voice endu'd;
7285: Redouble then this miracle, and say,
7286: How cam'st thou speakable of mute, and how
7287: To me so friendly grown above the rest
7288: Of brutal kind, that daily are in sight?
7289: Say, for such wonder claims attention due.
7290: ¶To whom the guileful Tempter thus reply'd.
7291: Empress of this fair World, resplendent *Eve*,
7292: Easie to mee it is to tell thee all
7293: What thou commandst, and right thou shouldst be obeyd:
7294: I was at first as other Beasts that graze
7295: The trodden Herb, of abject thoughts and low,
7296: As was my food, nor aught but food discern'd
7297: Or Sex, and apprehended nothing high:
7298: Till on a day roaving the field, I chanc'd
7299: A goodly Tree farr distant to behold
7300: Loaden with fruit of fairest colours mixt,
7301: Ruddie and Gold: I nearer drew to gaze;
7302: When from the boughes a savorie odour blow'n,
7303: Grateful to appetite, more pleas'd my sense
7304: Then smell of sweetest Fenel, or the Teats
7305: Of Ewe or Goat dropping with Milk at Eevn,
7306: Unsuckt of Lamb or Kid, that tend thir play.
7307: To satisfie the sharp desire I had
7308: Of tasting those fair Apples, I resolv'd
7309: Not to deferr; hunger and thirst at once,
7310: Powerful perswaders, quick'nd at the scent
7311: Of that alluring fruit, urg'd me so keene.
7312: About the Mossie Trunk I wound me soon,
7313: For high from ground the branches would require
7314: Thy utmost reach or *Adams*: Round the Tree
7315: All other Beasts that saw, with like desire
7316: Longing and envying stood, but could not reach.
7317: Amid the Tree now got, where plentie hung
7318: Tempting so nigh, to pluck and eat my fill
7319: I spar'd not, for such pleasure till that hour
7320: At Feed or Fountain never had I found.
7321: Sated at length, ere long I might perceave
7322: Strange alteration in me, to degree
7323: Of Reason in my inward Powers, and Speech
7324: Wanted not long, though to this shape retaind.
7325: Thenceforth to Speculations high or deep
7326: I turnd my thoughts, and with capacious mind
7327: Considerd all things visible in Heav'n,
7328: Or Earth, or Middle, all things fair and good;
7329: But all that fair and good in thy Divine
7330: Semblance, and in thy Beauties heav'nly Ray
7331: United I beheld; no Fair to thine
7333: Mee thus, though importune perhaps, to come
7334: And gaze, and worship thee of right declar'd
7336: ¶So talk'd the spirited sly Snake; and *Eve*
7337: Yet more amaz'd unwarie thus reply'd.
7339: The vertue of that Fruit, in thee first prov'd:
7340: But say, where grows the Tree, from hence how far?
7341: For many are the Trees of God that grow
7342: In Paradise, and various, yet unknown
7343: To us, in such abundance lies our choice,
7344: As leaves a greater store of Fruit untoucht,
7346: Grow up to thir provision, and more hands
7347: Help to disburden Nature of her Bearth.
7348: ¶To whom the wilie Adder, blithe and glad.
7349: Empress, the way is readie, and not long,
7350: Beyond a row of Myrtles, on a Flat,
7351: Fast by a Fountain, one small Thicket past
7352: Of blowing Myrrh and Balme; if thou accept
7353: My conduct, I can bring thee thither soon.
7354: ¶Lead then, said *Eve*.  Hee leading swiftly rowld
7355: In tangles, and make intricate seem strait,
7356: To mischief swift.  Hope elevates, and joy
7357: Bright'ns his Crest, as when a wandring Fire
7358: Compact of unctuous vapor, which the Night
7359: Condenses, and the cold invirons round,
7360: Kindl'd through agitation to a Flame,
7361: Which oft, they say, some evil Spirit attends,
7362: Hovering and blazing with delusive Light,
7363: Misleads th' amaz'd Night-wanderer from his way
7364: To Boggs and Mires, & oft through Pond or Poole,
7365: There swallow'd up and lost, from succour farr.
7366: So glister'd the dire Snake and into fraud
7367: Led *Eve* our credulous Mother, to the Tree
7368: Of prohibition, root of all our woe;
7369: Which when she saw, thus to her guide she spake.
7370: ¶Serpent, we might have spar'd our coming hither,
7371: Fruitless to me, though Fruit be here to excess,
7372: The credit of whose vertue rest with thee,
7373: Wondrous indeed, if cause of such effects.
7374: But of this Tree we may not taste nor touch;
7375: God so commanded, and left that Command
7376: Sole Daughter of his voice; the rest, we live
7377: Law to our selves, our Reason is our Law.
7379: Indeed? hath God then said that of the Fruit
7380: Of all these Garden Trees ye shall not eate,
7381: Yet Lords declar'd of all in Earth or Aire?
7382: ¶To whom thus *Eve* yet sinless.  Of the Fruit
7383: Of each Tree in the Garden we may eate,
7384: But of the Fruit of this fair Tree amidst
7385: The Garden, God hath said, Ye shall not eate
7386: Thereof, nor shall ye touch it, least ye die.
7387: ¶She scarse had said, though brief, when now more bold
7388: The Tempter, but with shew of Zeale and Love
7389: To Man, and indignation at his wrong,
7390: New part puts on, and as to passion mov'd,
7391: Fluctuats disturbd, yet comely, and in act
7392: Rais'd, as of som great matter to begin.
7393: As when of old som Orator renound
7395: Flourishd, since mute, to som great cause addrest,
7396: Stood in himself collected, while each part,
7397: Motion, each act won audience ere the tongue,
7398: Somtimes in highth began, as no delay
7399: Of Preface brooking through his Zeal of Right.
7400: So standing, moving, or to highth upgrown
7401: The Tempter all impassiond thus began.
7403: Mother of Science, Now I feel thy Power
7404: Within me cleere, not onely to discerne
7405: Things in thir Causes, but to trace the wayes
7406: Of highest Agents, deemd however wise.
7407: Queen of this Universe, doe not believe
7408: Those rigid threats of Death; ye shall not Die:
7409: How should ye? by the Fruit? it gives you Life
7410: To Knowledge?  By the Threatner, look on mee,
7411: Mee who have touch'd and tasted, yet both live,
7412: And life more perfet have attaind then Fate
7413: Meant mee, by ventring higher then my Lot.
7414: Shall that be shut to Man, which to the Beast
7415: Is open? or will God incense his ire
7416: For such a pretty Trespass, and not praise
7417: Rather your dauntless vertue, whom the pain
7418: Of Death denounc't, whatever thing Death be,
7419: Deterrd not from atchieving what might leade
7420: To happier life, knowledge of Good and Evil;
7421: Of good, how just? of evil, if what is evil
7422: Be real, why not known, since easier shunnd?
7423: God therefore cannot hurt ye, and be just;
7424: Not just, not God; not feard then, nor obeid:
7425: Your feare it self of Death removes the feare.
7426: Why then was this forbid?  Why but to awe,
7427: Why but to keep ye low and ignorant,
7428: His worshippers; he knows that in the day
7429: Ye Eate thereof, your Eyes that seem so cleere,
7430: Yet are but dim, shall perfetly be then
7431: Op'nd and cleerd, and ye shall be as Gods,
7432: Knowing both Good and Evil as they know.
7433: That ye should be as Gods, since I as Man,
7434: Internal Man, is but proportion meet,
7435: I of brute human, yee of human Gods.
7436: So ye shalt die perhaps, by putting off
7437: Human, to put on Gods, death to be wisht,
7438: Though threat'nd, which no worse then this can bring
7439: And what are Gods that Man may not become
7441: The Gods are first, and that advantage use
7442: On our belief, that all from them proceeds,
7443: I question it, for this fair Earth I see,
7444: Warm'd by the Sun, producing every kind,
7445: Them nothing: If they all things, who enclos'd
7446: Knowledge of Good and Evil in this Tree,
7447: That whoso eats thereof, forthwith attains
7448: Wisdom without their leave? and wherein lies
7449: Th' offence, that Man should thus attain to know?
7450: What can your knowledge hurt him, or this Tree
7451: Impart against his will if all be his?
7452: Or is it envie, and can envie dwell
7453: In heav'nly brests? these, these and many more
7454: Causes import your need of this fair Fruit.
7455: Goddess humane, reach then, and freely taste.
7456: ¶He ended, and his words replete with guile
7457: Into her heart too easie entrance won:
7458: Fixt on the Fruit she gaz'd, which to behold
7459: Might tempt alone, and in her ears the sound
7460: Yet rung of his perswasive words, impregn'd
7461: With Reason, to her seeming, and with Truth;
7462: Meanwhile the hour of Noon drew on, and wak'd
7463: An eager appetite, rais'd by the smell
7464: So savorie of that Fruit, which with desire,
7465: Inclinable now grown to touch or taste,
7466: Sollicited her longing eye; yet first
7467: Pausing a while, thus to her self she mus'd.
7468: ¶Great are thy Vertues, doubtless, best of Fruits,
7469: Though kept from Man, & worthy to be admir'd,
7470: Whose taste, too long forborn, at first assay
7471: Gave elocution to the mute, and taught
7472: The Tongue not made for Speech to speak thy praise:
7473: Thy praise hee also who forbids thy use,
7474: Conceales not from us, naming thee the Tree
7475: Of Knowledge, knowledge both of good and evil;
7476: Forbids us then to taste, but his forbidding
7477: Commends thee more, while it inferrs the good
7478: By thee communicated, and our want:
7479: For good unknown, sure is not had, or had
7480: And yet unknown, is as not had at all.
7481: In plain then, what forbids he but to know,
7482: Forbids us good, forbids us to be wise?
7483: Such prohibitions binde not.  But if Death
7484: Bind us with after-bands, what profits then
7485: Our inward freedom?  In the day we eate
7486: Of this fair Fruit, our doom is, we shall die.
7487: How dies the Serpent? hee hath eat'n and lives,
7488: And knows, and speaks, and reasons, and discernes,
7489: Irrational till then.  For us alone
7490: Was death invented? or to us deni'd
7491: This intellectual food, for beasts reserv'd?
7492: For Beasts it seems: yet that one Beast which first
7493: Hath tasted, envies not, but brings with joy
7494: The good befall'n him, Author unsuspect,
7495: Friendly to man, farr from deceit or guile.
7496: What fear I then, rather what know to feare
7497: Under this ignorance of Good and Evil,
7498: Of God or Death, of Law or Penaltie?
7499: Here grows the Cure of all, this Fruit Divine,
7500: Fair to the Eye, inviting to the Taste,
7501: Of vertue to make wise: what hinders then
7502: To reach, and feed at once both Bodie and Mind?
7503: ¶So saying, her rash hand in evil hour
7504: Forth reaching to the Fruit, she pluck'd, she eat:
7505: Earth felt the wound, and Nature from her seat
7506: Sighing through all her Works gave signs of woe,
7507: That all was lost.  Back to the Thicket slunk
7508: The guiltie Serpent, and well might, for *Eve*
7509: Intent now wholly on her taste, naught else
7510: Regarded, such delight till then, as seemd,
7511: In Fruit she never tasted, whether true
7512: Or fansied so, through expectation high
7513: Of knowledg, nor was God-head from her thought.
7515: And knew not eating Death: Satiate at length,
7516: And hight'nd as with Wine, jocond and boon,
7517: Thus to her self she pleasingly began.
7518: ¶O Sovran, vertuous, precious of all Trees
7521: And thy fair Fruit let hang, as to no end
7522: Created; but henceforth my early care,
7523: Not without Song, each Morning, and due praise
7524: Shall tend thee, and the fertil burden ease
7525: Of thy full branches offer'd free to all;
7526: Till dieted by thee I grow mature
7527: In knowledge, as the Gods who all things know;
7528: Though others envie what they cannot give;
7529: For had the gift bin theirs, it had not here
7530: Thus grown.  Experience, next to thee I owe,
7531: Best guide; not following thee, I had remaind
7532: In ignorance, thou op'nst Wisdoms way,
7533: And giv'st access, though secret she retire.
7534: And I perhaps am secret; Heav'n is high,
7535: High and remote to see from thence distinct
7536: Each thing on Earth; and other care perhaps
7537: May have diverted from continual watch
7538: Our great Forbidder, safe with all his Spies
7539: About him.  But to *Adam* in what sort
7540: Shall I appeer? shall I to him make known
7541: As yet my change, and give him to partake
7542: Full happiness with mee, or rather not,
7543: But keep the odds of Knowledge in my power
7544: Without Copartner? so to add what wants
7545: In Femal Sex, the more to draw his Love,
7546: And render me more equal, and perhaps
7548: Superior; for inferior who is free?
7549: This may be well: but what if God have seen,
7550: And Death ensue? then I shall be no more,
7552: Shall live with her enjoying, I extinct;
7553: A death to think.  Confirm'd then I resolve,
7554: *Adam* shall share with me in bliss or woe:
7555: So dear I love him, that with him all deaths
7556: I could endure; without him live no life.
7557: ¶So saying, from the Tree her step she turnd,
7558: But first low Reverence don, as to the power
7559: That dwelt within, whose presence had infus'd
7560: Into the plant sciential sap, deriv'd
7561: From Nectar, drink of Gods.  *Adam* the while
7562: Waiting desirous her return, had wove
7563: Of choicest Flours a Garland to adorne
7564: Her Tresses, and her rural labours crown
7565: As Reapers oft are wont thir Harvest Queen.
7566: Great joy he promis'd to his thoughts, and new
7567: Solace in her return, so long delay'd;
7568: Yet oft his heart, divine of somthing ill,
7569: Misgave him; hee the faultring measure felt;
7570: And forth to meet her went, the way she took
7571: That Morn when first they parted; by the Tree
7572: Of Knowledge he must pass, there he her met,
7573: Scarse from the Tree returning; in her hand
7574: A bough of fairest fruit that downie smil'd,
7575: New gatherd, and ambrosial smell diffus'd.
7576: To him she hasted, in her face excuse
7577: Came Prologue, and Apologie to prompt,
7578: Which with bland words at will she thus addrest.
7579: ¶Hast thou not wonderd, *Adam*, at my stay?
7580: Thee I have misst, and thought it long, depriv'd
7581: Thy presence, agonie of love till now
7582: Not felt, nor shall be twice, for never more
7583: Mean I to trie, what rash untri'd I sought,
7584: The paine of absence from thy sight.  But strange
7585: Hath bin the cause, and wonderful to heare:
7586: This Tree is not as we are told, a Tree
7587: Of danger tasted, nor to evil unknown
7588: Op'ning the way, but of Divine effect
7589: To open Eyes, and make them Gods who taste;
7590: And hath bin tasted such; the Serpent wise,
7591: Or not restraind as wee, or not obeying,
7592: Hath eat'n of the fruit, and is become,
7593: Not dead, as we are threatn'd, but thenceforth
7594: Endu'd with human voice and human sense,
7595: Reasoning to admiration, and with mee
7596: Perswasively hath so prevaild, that I
7597: Have also tasted, and have also found
7598: Th' effects to correspond, opener mine Eyes,
7599: Dimm erst, dilated Spirits, ampler Heart,
7600: And growing up to Godhead; which for thee
7601: Chiefly I sought, without thee can despise.
7602: For bliss, as thou hast part, to me is bliss,
7603: Tedious, unshar'd with thee, and odious soon.
7604: Thou therefore also taste, that equal Lot
7605: May joyne us, equal Joy, as equal Love;
7606: Least thou not tasting, different degree
7607: Disjoyne us, and I then too late renounce
7608: Deitie for thee, when Fate will not permit.
7609: ¶Thus *Eve* with Countnance blithe her storie told;
7610: But in her Cheek distemper flushing glowd.
7611: On th' other side, *Adam*, soon as he heard
7612: The fatal Trespass don by *Eve*, amaz'd,
7613: Astonied stood and Blank, while horror chill
7614: Ran through his veins, and all his joynts relax'd;
7615: From his slack hand the Garland wreath'd for *Eve*
7616: Down drop'd, and all the faded Roses shed:
7617: Speechless he stood and pale, till thus at length
7618: First to himself he inward silence broke.
7619: ¶O fairest of Creation, last and best
7620: Of all Gods Works, Creature in whom excell'd
7621: Whatever can to fight or thought be found,
7622: Holy, divine, good, amiable, or sweet!
7623: How art thou lost, how on a sudden lost,
7624: Defac't, deflourd, and now to Death devote?
7625: Rather how hast thou yeelded to transgress
7626: The strict forbiddance, how to violate
7627: The sacred Fruit forbidd'n! som cursed fraud
7628: Of Enemie hath beguil'd thee, yet unknown,
7629: And mee with thee hath ruind, for with thee
7630: Certain my resolution is to Die;
7631: How can I live without thee, how forgoe
7632: Thy sweet Converse and Love so dearly joyn'd,
7633: To live again in these wilde Woods forlorn?
7634: Should God create another *Eve*, and I
7635: Another Rib afford, yet loss of thee
7636: Would never from my heart; no no, I feel
7637: The Link of Nature draw me: Flesh of Flesh,
7638: Bone of my Bone thou art, and from thy State
7639: Mine never shall be parted, bliss or woe.
7640: ¶So having said, as one from sad dismay
7643: Thus in calme mood his Words to *Eve* he turnd.
7645: And peril great provok't, who thus hast dar'd
7646: Had it bin onely coveting to Eye
7647: That sacred Fruit, sacred to abstinence,
7648: Much more to taste it under banne to touch.
7649: But past who can recall, or don undoe?
7650: Not God omnipotent, for Fate, yet so
7651: Perhaps thou shalt not Die, perhaps the Fact
7652: Is not so hainous now, foretasted Fruit,
7653: Profan'd first by the Serpent, by him first
7654: Made common and unhallowd: ere one tastes;
7655: Nor yet on him found deadly; he yet lives,
7656: Lives, as thou saidst, and gaines to live as Man
7657: Higher degree of Life, inducement strong
7658: To us, as likely tasting to attaine
7660: But to be Gods, or Angels Demi-gods.
7661: Nor can I think that God, Creator wise,
7662: Though threatning, will in earnest so destroy
7663: Us his prime Creatures, dignifi'd so high,
7664: Set over all his Works, which in our Fall,
7665: For us created, needs with us must faile,
7666: Dependent made; so God shall uncreate,
7667: Be frustrate, do, undo, and labour loose,
7668: Not well conceav'd of God, who though his Power
7669: Creation could repeate, yet would be loath
7670: Us to abolish, least the Adversary
7671: Triumph and say; Fickle their State whom God
7672: Most Favors, who can please him long?  Mee first
7673: He ruind, now Mankind; whom will he next?
7674: Matter of scorne, not to be given the Foe.
7675: However I with thee have fixt my Lot,
7676: Certain to undergoe like doom, if Death
7677: Consort with thee, Death is to mee as Life;
7678: So forcible within my heart I feel
7679: The Bond of Nature draw me to my owne,
7680: My own in thee, for what thou art is mine;
7681: Our State cannot be severd, we are one,
7682: One Flesh; to loose thee were to loose my self.
7684: O glorious trial of exceeding Love,
7686: Ingaging me to emulate, but short
7687: Of thy perfection, how shall I attaine,
7688: *Adam*, from whose deare side I boast me sprung,
7689: And gladly of our Union heare thee speak,
7690: One Heart, one Soul in both; whereof good prooff
7691: This day affords, declaring thee resolvd,
7692: Rather then Death or aught then Death more dread
7693: Shall separate us, linkt in Love so deare,
7694: To undergoe with mee one Guilt, one Crime,
7695: If any be, of tasting this fair Fruit,
7696: Whose vertue, for of good still good proceeds,
7697: Direct, or by occasion hath presented
7698: This happie trial of thy Love, which else
7699: So eminently never had bin known.
7700: Were it I thought Death menac't would ensue
7701: This my attempt, I would sustain alone
7702: The worst, and not perswade thee, rather die
7703: Deserted, then oblige thee with a fact
7704: Pernicious to thy Peace, chiefly assur'd
7705: Remarkably so late of thy so true,
7706: So faithful Love unequald; but I feel
7707: Farr otherwise th' event, not Death, but Life
7708: Augmented, op'nd Eyes, new Hopes, new Joyes,
7709: Taste so Divine, that what of sweet before
7710: Hath toucht my sense, flat seems to this, and harsh.
7712: And fear of Death deliver to the Windes.
7713: ¶So saying, she embrac'd him, and for joy
7714: Tenderly wept, much won that he his Love
7715: Had so enobl'd, as of choice to incurr
7716: Divine displeasure for her sake, or Death.
7718: Such recompence best merits) from the bough
7719: She gave him of that fair enticing Fruit
7720: With liberal hand: he scrupl'd not to eat
7721: Against his better knowledge, not deceav'd,
7722: But fondly overcome with Femal charm.
7723: Earth trembl'd from her entrails, as again
7724: In pangs, and Nature gave a second groan,
7725: Skie lowr'd, and muttering Thunder, som sad drops
7726: Wept at compleating of the mortal Sin
7728: Eating his fill, nor *Eve* to iterate
7729: Her former trespass fear'd, the more to soothe
7730: Him with her lov'd societie, that now
7731: As with new Wine intoxicated both
7732: They swim in mirth, and fansie that they feel
7734: Wherewith to scorn the Earth: but that false Fruit
7737: Began to cast lascivious Eyes, she him
7738: As wantonly repaid; in Lust they burne:
7740: ¶*Eve*, now I see thou art exact of taste,
7741: And elegant, of Sapience no small part,
7742: Since to each meaning savour we apply,
7743: And Palate call judicious; I the praise
7744: Yeild thee, so well this day thou hast purvey'd.
7745: Much pleasure we have lost, while we abstain'd
7746: From this delightful Fruit, nor known till now
7747: True relish, tasting; if such pleasure be
7748: In things to us forbidden, it might be wish'd,
7749: For this one Tree had bin forbidden ten.
7750: But come, so well refresh't, now let us play,
7751: As meet is, after such delicious Fare;
7752: For never did thy Beautie since the day
7753: I saw thee first and wedded thee, adorn'd
7754: With all perfections, so enflame my sense
7755: With ardor to enjoy thee, fairer now
7756: Then ever, bountie of this vertuous Tree.
7757: ¶So said he, and forbore not glance or toy
7759: Of *Eve*, whose Eye darted contagious Fire.
7760: Her hand he seis'd, and to a shadie bank,
7761: Thick overhead with verdant roof imbowr'd
7762: He led her nothing loath; Flours were the Couch,
7764: And Hyacinth, Earths freshest softest lap.
7765: There they thir fill of Love and Loves disport
7766: Took largely, of thir mutual guilt the Seale,
7767: The solace of thir sin, till dewie sleep
7768: Oppress'd them, wearied with thir amorous play.
7769: Soon as the force of that fallacious Fruit,
7771: About thir spirits had plaid, and inmost powers
7772: Made erre, was now exhal'd, and grosser sleep
7773: Bred of unkindly fumes, with conscious dreams
7774: Encumberd, now had left them, up they rose
7775: As from unrest, and each the other viewing,
7776: Soon found thir Eyes how op'nd, and thir minds
7777: How dark'nd; innocence, that as a veile
7778: Had shadow'd them from knowing ill, was gon,
7780: And honour from about them, naked left
7781: To guiltie shame hee cover'd, but his Robe
7782: Uncover'd more.  So rose the *Danite* strong
7785: Shorn of his strength, They destitute and bare
7786: Of all thir vertue: silent, and in face
7787: Confounded long they sate, as struck'n mute,
7788: Till *Adam*, though not less then *Eve* abasht,
7789: At length gave utterance to these words constraind.
7790: ¶O *Eve*, in evil hour thou didst give care
7791: To that false Worm, of whomsoever taught
7792: To counterfet Mans voice, true in our Fall,
7793: False in our promis'd Rising; since our Eyes
7794: Op'nd we find indeed, and find we know
7795: Both Good and Evil, Good lost and Evil got,
7796: Bad Fruit of Knowledge, if this be to know,
7797: Which leaves us naked thus, of Honour void,
7798: Of Innocence, of Faith, of Puritie,
7799: Our wonted Ornaments now soild and staind,
7800: And in our Faces evident the signes
7801: Of foul concupiscence; whence evil store;
7802: Even shame, the last of evils; of the first
7803: Be sure then.  How shall I behold the face
7804: Henceforth of God or Angel, earst with joy
7805: And rapture so oft beheld? those heav'nly shapes
7806: Will dazle now this earthly, with thir blaze
7807: Insufferably bright.  O might I here
7808: In solitude live savage, in some glad
7810: To Starr or Sun-light, spread thir umbrage broad,
7811: And brown as Evening: Cover me ye Pines,
7813: Hide me, where I may never see them more.
7814: But let us now, as in bad plight, devise
7815: What best may for the present serve to hide
7816: The Parts of each from other, that seem most
7817: To shame obnoxious, and unseemliest seen,
7818: Some Tree whose broad smooth Leaves together sowd,
7819: And girded on our loyns, may cover round
7820: Those middle parts, that this new commer, Shame,
7821: There sit not, and reproach us as unclean.
7822: ¶So counsel'd hee, and both together went
7823: Into the thickest Wood, there soon they chose
7824: The Figtree, not that kind for Fruit renown'd,
7825: But such as at this day to *Indians* known
7827: Braunching so broad and long, that in the ground
7828: The bended Twigs take root, and Daughters grow
7829: About the Mother Tree, a Pillard shade
7830: High overarch't, and echoing Walks between;
7831: There oft the *Indian* Herdsman shunning heate
7832: Shelters in coole, and tends his pasturing Herds
7833: At Loopholes cut through thickest shade: Those Leaves
7835: And with what skill they had, together sowd,
7836: To gird thir waste, vain Covering if to hide
7837: Thir guilt and dreaded shame; O how unlike
7838: To that first naked Glorie.  Such of late
7840: With featherd Cincture, naked else and wilde
7841: Among the Trees on Iles and woodie Shores.
7842: Thus fenc't, and as they thought, thir shame in part
7843: Coverd, but not at rest or ease of Mind,
7844: They sate them down to weep, nor onely Teares
7845: Raind at thir Eyes, but high Winds worse within
7846: Began to rise, high Passions, Anger, Hate,
7847: Mistrust, Suspicion, Discord, and shook sore
7848: Thir inward State of Mind, calme Region once
7849: And full of Peace, now tost and turbulent:
7850: For Understanding rul'd not, and the Will
7851: Heard not her lore, both in subjection now
7852: To sensual Appetite, who from beneathe
7854: Superior sway: From thus distemperd brest,
7855: *Adam*, estrang'd in look and alterd stile,
7857: ¶Would thou hadst heark'nd to my words, & stai'd
7858: With me, as I besought thee, when that strange
7859: Desire of wandring this unhappie Morn,
7860: I know not whence possessd thee; we had then
7861: Remaind still happie, not as now, despoild
7862: Of all our good, sham'd, naked, miserable.
7863: Let none henceforth seek needless cause to approve
7864: The Faith they owe; when earnestly they seek
7865: Such proof, conclude, they then begin to faile.
7866: ¶To whom soon mov'd with touch of blame thus *Eve*.
7867: What words have past thy Lips, *Adam* severe,
7868: Imput'st thou that to my default, or will
7869: Of wandering, as thou call'st it, which who knows
7870: But might as ill have happ'nd thou being by,
7871: Or to thy self perhaps: hadst thou bin there,
7872: Or bere th' attempt, thou couldst not have discernd
7873: Fraud in the Serpent, speaking as he spake;
7874: No ground of enmitie between us known,
7875: Why hee should mean me ill, or seek to harme.
7876: Was I to have never parted from thy side?
7877: As good have grown there still a liveless Rib.
7878: Being as I am, why didst not thou the Head
7879: Command me absolutely not to go,
7880: Going into such danger as thou saidst?
7881: Too facil then thou didst not much gainsay,
7882: Nay, didst permit, approve, and fair dismiss.
7883: Hadst thou bin firm and fixt in thy dissent,
7884: Neither had I transgress'd, nor thou with mee.
7886: Is this the Love, is the recompence
7887: Of mine to thee, ingrateful *Eve*, exprest
7888: Immutable when thou wert lost, not I,
7889: Who might have liv'd and joyd immortal bliss,
7890: Yet willingly chose rather Death with thee:
7891: And am I now upbraided, as the cause
7892: Of thy transgressing? not enough severe,
7893: It seems, in thy restraint: what could I more?
7894: I warn'd thee, I admonish'd thee, foretold
7895: The danger, and the lurking Enemie
7896: That lay in wait; beyond this had bin force,
7897: And force upon free Will hath here no place.
7898: But confidence then bore thee on, secure
7899: Either to meet no danger, or to finde
7900: Matter of glorious trial; and perhaps
7901: I also err'd in overmuch admiring
7902: What seemd in thee so perfet, that I thought
7903: No evil durst attempt thee, but I rue
7904: That errour now, which is become my crime,
7905: And thou th' accuser.  Thus it shall befall
7906: Him who to worth in Women overtrusting
7907: Lets her Will rule; restraint she will not brook,
7908: And left to her self, if evil thence ensue,
7909: Shee first his weak indulgence will accuse.
7911: The fruitless hours, but neither self-condemning
7912: And of thir vain contest appeer'd no end.
7915: Of *Satan* done in Paradise, and how
7916: Hee in the Serpent had perverted *Eve*,
7917: Her Husband shee, to taste the fatall fruit,
7918: Was known in Heav'n; for what can scape the Eye
7919: Of God All-seeing, or deceave his Heart
7920: Omniscient, who in all things wise and just,
7921: Hinder'd not *Satan* to attempt the minde
7922: Of Man, with strength entire, and free Will arm'd,
7923: Complete to have discover'd and repulst
7924: Whatever wiles of Foe or seeming Friend.
7925: For still they knew, and ought to have still remember'd
7926: The high Injunction not to taste that Fruit,
7927: Whoever tempted; which they not obeying,
7928: Incurr'd, what could they less, the penaltie,
7929: And manifold in sin, deserv'd to fall.
7930: Up into Heav'n from Paradise in hast
7931: Th' Angelic Guards ascended, mute and sad
7932: For Man, for of his state by this they knew,
7933: Much wondring how the suttle Fiend had stoln
7934: Entrance unseen.  Soon as th' unwelcome news
7935: From Earth arriv'd at Heaven Gate, displeas'd
7936: All were who heard, dim sadness did not spare
7937: That time Celestial visages, yet mixt
7938: With pitie, violated not thir bliss.
7940: Th' ethereal People ran, to hear and know
7941: How all befell: they towards the Throne Supream
7942: Accountable made haste to make appear
7943: With righteous plea, thir utmost vigilance,
7944: And easily approv'd; when the most High
7945: Eternal Father from his secret Cloud,
7946: Amidst in Thunder utter'd thus his voice.
7948: From unsuccessful charge, be not dismaid,
7949: Nor troubl'd at these tidings from the Earth,
7950: Which your sincerest care could not prevent,
7951: Foretold so lately what would come to pass,
7952: When first this Tempter cross'd the Gulf from Hell.
7953: I told ye then he should prevail and speed
7954: On his bad Errand, Man should be seduc't
7955: And flatter'd out of all, believing lies
7956: Against his Maker; no Decree of mine
7958: Or touch with lightest moment of impulse
7959: His free Will, to her own inclining left
7960: In eevn scale.  But fall'n he is, and now
7961: What rests, but that the mortal Sentence pass
7962: On his transgression, Death denounc't that day,
7963: Which he presumes already vain and void,
7964: Because not yet inflicted, as he fear'd,
7965: By some immediate stroak; but soon shall find
7966: Forbearance no acquittance ere day end.
7967: Justice shall not return as bountie scorn'd.
7968: But whom send I to judge them? whom but thee
7969: Vicegerent Son, to thee I have transferr'd
7970: All Judgement, whether in Heav'n, or Earth; or Hell.
7971: Easie it may be seen that I intend
7972: Mercie collegue with Justice, sending thee
7973: Mans Friend, his Mediator, his design'd
7975: And destin'd Man himself to judge Man fall'n.
7976: ¶So spake the Father, and unfoulding bright
7977: Toward the right hand his Glorie, on the Son
7978: Blaz'd forth unclouded Deitie; he full
7980: Express'd, and thus divinely answer'd milde.
7982: Mine both in Heav'n and Earth to do thy will
7983: Supream, that thou in mee thy Son belov'd
7984: Mayst ever rest well pleas'd.  I go to judge
7985: On Earth these thy transgressors, but thou knowst,
7986: Whoever judg'd, the worst on mee must light,
7987: When time shall be, for so I undertook
7988: Before thee; and not repenting, this obtaine
7989: Of right, that I may mitigate thir doom
7990: On me deriv'd, yet I shall temper so
7991: Justice with Mercie, as may illustrate most
7992: Them fully satisfied, and thee appease.
7993: Attendance none shall need, nor Train, where none
7994: Are to behold the Judgement, but the judg'd,
7995: Those two; the third best absent is condemn'd,
7996: Convict by flight, and Rebel to all Law
7997: Conviction to the Serpent none belongs.
7998: ¶Thus saying, from his radiant Seat he rose
7999: Of high collateral glorie: him Thrones and Powers,
8001: Accompanied to Heaven Gate, from whence
8002: *Eden* and all the Coast in prospect lay.
8003: Down he descended strait; the speed of Gods
8004: Time counts not, though with swiftest minutes wing'd.
8005: Now was the Sun in Western cadence low
8006: From Noon, and gentle Aires due at thir hour
8007: To fan the Earth now wak'd, and usher in
8008: The Eevning coole when he from wrauth more coole
8009: Came the mild Judge and Intercessor both
8010: To sentence Man: the voice of God they heard
8011: Now walking in the Garden, by soft windes
8012: Brought to thir Ears, while day declin'd, they heard
8013: And from his presence hid themselves among
8014: The thickest Trees, both Man and Wife, till God
8016: ¶Where art thou *Adam*, wont with joy to meet
8017: My coming seen far off?  I miss thee here,
8018: Not pleas'd, thus entertaind with solitude,
8019: Where obvious dutie erewhile appear'd unsaught:
8020: Or come I less conspicuous, or what change
8021: Absents thee, or what chance detains?  Come forth.
8022: He came, and with him *Eve*, more loth, though first
8023: To offend, discount'nanc't both, and discompos'd;
8024: Love was not in thir looks, either to God
8025: Or to each other, but apparent guilt,
8026: And shame, and perturbation, and despaire,
8027: Anger, and obstinacie, and hate, and guile.
8028: Whence *Adam* faultring long, thus answer'd brief.
8029: ¶I heard thee in the Garden, and of thy voice
8030: Affraid, being naked, hid my self.  To whom
8031: The gracious Judge without revile repli'd.
8032: ¶My voice thou oft hast heard, and hast not fear'd,
8033: But still rejoyc't, how is it now become
8034: So dreadful to thee? that thou art naked, who
8035: Hath told thee? hast thou eaten of the Tree
8036: Whereof I gave thee charge thou shouldst not eat?
8038: O Heav'n! in evil strait this day I stand
8039: Before my Judge, either to undergoe
8040: My self the total Crime, or to accuse
8041: My other self, the partner of my life;
8042: Whose failing, while her Faith to me remaines,
8043: I should conceal, and not expose to blame
8044: By my complaint; but strict necessitie
8046: Least on my head both sin and punishment,
8048: Devolv'd; though should I hold my peace, yet thou
8049: Wouldst easily detect what I conceale.
8050: This Woman whom thou mad'st to be my help,
8051: And gav'st me as thy perfet gift, so good,
8052: So fit, so acceptable, so Divine,
8053: That from her hand I could suspect no ill,
8054: And what she did, whatever in it self,
8055: Her doing seem'd to justifie the deed;
8056: Shee gave me of the Tree, and I did eate.
8057: ¶To whom the sovran Presence thus repli'd.
8058: Was shee thy God, that her thou didst obey
8059: Before his voice, or was shee made thy guide,
8060: Superior, or but equal, that to her
8061: Thou did'st resigne thy Manhood, and the Place
8062: Wherein God set thee above her made of thee,
8063: And for thee, whose perfection farr excell'd
8064: Hers in all real dignitie: Adornd
8065: She was indeed, and lovely to attract
8066: Thy Love, not thy Subjection, and her Gifts
8067: Were such as under Government well seem'd,
8068: Unseemly to beare rule, which was thy part
8069: And person, had'st thou known thy self aright.
8070: ¶So having said, he thus to *Eve* in few:
8071: Say Woman, what is this which thou hast done?
8072: ¶To whom sad *Eve* with shame nigh overwhelm'd,
8073: Confessing soon, yet not before her Judge
8074: Bold or loquacious, thus abasht repli'd.
8075: ¶The Serpent me beguil'd and I did eate.
8076: ¶Which when the Lord God heard, without delay
8077: To Judgement he proceeded on th' accus'd
8078: Serpent though brute, unable to transferre
8079: The Guilt on him who made him instrument
8080: Of mischief, and polluted from the end
8081: Of his Creation; justly then accurst,
8082: As vitiated in Nature: more to know
8083: Concern'd not Man (since he no further knew)
8084: Nor alter'd his offence; yet God at last
8085: To Satan first in sin his doom apply'd,
8086: Though in mysterious terms, judg'd as then best:
8087: And on the Serpent thus his curse let fall.
8088: ¶Because thou hast done this, thou art accurst
8089: Above all Cattel, each Beast of the Field;
8090: Upon thy Belly groveling thou shalt goe,
8091: And dust shalt eat all the days of thy Life.
8092: Between Thee and the Woman I will put
8093: Enmitie, and between thine and her Seed;
8094: Her Seed shall bruise thy head, thou bruise his heel.
8097: Saw Satan fall like Lightning down from Heav'n,
8098: Prince of the Aire; then rising from his Grave
8100: In open shew, and with ascention bright
8101: Captivity led captive through the Aire,
8102: The Realme it self of Satan long usurpt,
8103: Whom he shall tread at last under our feet;
8104: Eevn hee who now foretold his fatal bruise,
8105: And to the Woman thus his Sentence turn'd.
8107: By thy Conception; Children thou shalt bring
8108: In sorrow forth, and to thy Husbands will
8109: Thine shall submit, hee over thee shall rule.
8111: Because thou hast heark'nd to the voice of thy Wife,
8112: And eaten of the Tree concerning which
8113: I charg'd thee, saying: Thou shalt not eate thereof,
8114: Curs'd is the ground for thy sake, thou in sorrow
8115: Shalt eate thereof all the days of thy Life;
8116: Thornes also and Thistles it shall bring thee forth
8117: Unbid, and thou shalt eate th' Herb of th' Field,
8118: In the sweat of thy Face shalt thou eate Bread,
8119: Till thou return unto the ground, for thou
8120: Out of the ground wast taken, know thy Birth,
8121: For dust thou art, and shalt to dust returne.
8122: ¶So judg'd he Man, both Judge and Saviour sent,
8123: And th' instant stroke of Death denounc't that day
8124: Remov'd farr off; then pittying how they stood
8125: Before him naked to the aire, that now
8126: Must suffer change, disdain'd not to begin
8127: Thenceforth the forme of servant to assume,
8128: As when he wash'd his servants feet, so now
8129: As Father of his Familie he clad
8130: Thir nakedness with Skins of Beasts, or slain,
8131: Or as the Snake with youthful Coate repaid;
8132: And thought not much to cloath his Enemies:
8133: Nor hee thir outward onely with the Skins
8134: Of Beasts, but inward nakedness, much more
8135: Opprobrious, with his Robe of righteousness,
8136: Araying cover'd from his Fathers sight.
8137: To him with swift ascent he up returnd,
8139: In glory as of old, to him appeas'd
8140: All, though all-knowing, what had past with Man
8142: Meanwhile ere thus was sin'd and judg'd on Earth,
8143: Within the Gates of Hell sate Sin and Death,
8144: In counterview within the Gates, that now
8145: Stood open wide, belching outrageous flame
8146: Farr into *Chaos*, since the Fiend pass'd through,
8147: Sin opening, who thus now to Death began.
8148: ¶O Son, why sit we here each other viewing
8149: Idlely, while Satan our great Author thrives
8150: In other Worlds, and happier Seat provides
8151: For us his ofspring deare?  It cannot be
8152: But that success attends him; if mishap,
8153: Ere this he had return'd, with fury driv'n
8154: By his Avenger, since no place like this
8155: Can fit his punishment, or their revenge.
8156: Methinks I feel new strength within me rise,
8157: Wings growing, and Dominion giv'n me large
8158: Beyond this Deep; whatever drawes me on,
8159: Or sympathie, or som connatural force
8160: Powerful at greatest distance to unite
8161: With secret amity things of like kinde
8162: By secretest conveyance.  Thou my Shade
8164: For Death from Sin no power can separate.
8165: But least the difficultie of passing back
8166: Stay his returne perhaps over this Gulfe
8168: Adventrous work, yet to thy power and mine
8169: Not unagreeable, to found a path
8170: Over this Maine from Hell to that new World
8171: Where Satan now prevailes, a Monument
8172: Of merit high to all th' infernal Host,
8173: Easing thir passage hence, for intercourse,
8174: Or transmigration, as thir lot shall lead.
8175: Nor can I miss the way, so strongly drawn
8176: By this new felt attraction and instinct.
8177: ¶Whom thus the meager Shadow answerd soon.
8178: Goe whither Fate and inclination strong
8179: Leads thee, I shall not lag behinde, nor erre
8180: The way, thou leading, such a sent I draw
8181: Of carnage, prey innumerable, and taste
8182: The savour of Death from all things there that live:
8183: Nor shall I to the work thou enterprisest
8184: Be wanting, but afford thee equal aid.
8185: ¶So saying, with delight he snuff'd the smell
8186: Of mortal change on Earth.  As when a flock
8187: Of ravenous Fowl, though many a League remote,
8188: Against the day of Battel, to a Field,
8189: Where Armies lie encampt, come flying, lur'd
8190: With sent of living Carcasses design'd
8191: For death, the following day, in bloodie fight.
8192: So sented the grim Feature, and upturn'd
8193: His Nostril wide into the murkie Air,
8194: Sagacious of his Quarrey from so farr.
8195: Then Both from out Hell Gates into the waste
8196: Wide Anarchie of *Chaos* damp and dark
8197: Flew divers, & with Power (thir Power was great)
8198: Hovering upon the Waters; what they met
8199: Solid or slimie, as in raging Sea
8200: Tost up and down, together crowded drove
8201: From each side shoaling towards the mouth of Hell.
8202: As when two Polar Winds blowing adverse
8204: Mountains of Ice, that stop th' imagin'd way
8207: Death with his Mace petrific, cold and dry,
8208: As with a Trident smote, and fix't as firm
8209: As *Delos* floating once; the rest his look
8210: Bound with *Gorgonian* rigor not to move,
8211: And with *Asphaltic* slime; broad as the Gate,
8212: Deep to the Roots of Hell the gather'd beach
8213: They fasten'd, and the Mole immense wraught on
8214: Over the foaming deep high Archt, a Bridge
8215: Of length prodigious joyning to the Wall
8216: Immoveable of this now fenceless world
8217: Forfeit to Death; from hence a passage broad,
8218: Smooth, easie, inoffensive down to Hell.
8219: So, if great things to small may be compar'd,
8222: Came to the Sea, and over *Hellespont*
8224: And scourg'd with many a stroak th' indignant waves.
8225: Now had they brought the work by wondrous Art
8226: Pontifical, a ridge of pendent Rock
8227: Over the vext Abyss, following the track
8228: Of *Satan*, to the selfsame place where hee
8229: First lighted from his Wing, and landed safe
8230: From out of *Chaos* to the outside bare
8231: Of this round World: with Pinns of Adamant
8232: And Chains they made all fast, too fast they made
8233: And durable; and now in little space
8234: The Confines met of Empyrean Heav'n
8235: And of this World, and on the left hand Hell
8236: With long reach interpos'd; three sev'ral wayes
8237: In sight, to each of these three places led.
8238: And now thir way to Earth they had descri'd,
8239: To Paradise first tending, when behold
8240: *Satan* in likeness of an Angel bright
8242: His *Zenith*, while the Sun in *Aries* rose:
8243: Disguis'd he came, but those his Children dear
8244: Thir Parent soon discern'd, though in disguise.
8246: Into the Wood fast by, and changing shape
8247: To observe the sequel, saw his guileful act
8249: Upon her Husband, saw thir shame that sought
8250: Vain covertures; but when he saw descend
8251: The Son of God to judge them, terrifi'd
8252: Hee fled, not hoping to escape, but shun
8253: The present, fearing guiltie what his wrauth
8254: Might suddenly inflict; that past, return'd
8255: By Night, and listning where the hapless Paire
8256: Sate in thir sad discourse, and various plaint,
8257: Thence gatherd his own doom, which understood
8258: Not instant, but of future time.  With joy
8259: And tidings fraught, to Hell he now return'd,
8260: And at the brink of *Chaos*, neer the foot
8261: Of this new wondrous Pontifice, unhop't
8262: Met who to meet him came, his Ofspring dear.
8263: Great joy was at thir meeting, and at sight
8264: Of that stupendious Bridge his joy encreas'd.
8265: Long hee admiring stood, till Sin, his faire
8266: Inchanting Daughter, thus the silence broke.
8267: ¶O Parent, these are thy magnific deeds,
8268: Thy Trophies, which thou view'st as not thine own,
8269: Thou art thir Author and prime Architect:
8270: For I no sooner in my Heart divin'd,
8271: My Heart, which by a secret harmonie
8272: Still moves with thine, joyn'd in connexion sweet,
8273: That thou on Earth hadst prosper'd, which thy looks
8274: Now also evidence, but straight I felt
8275: Though distant from thee Worlds between, yet felt
8276: That I must after thee with this thy Son;
8277: Such fatal consequence unites us three:
8278: Hell could no longer hold us in her bounds,
8280: Detain from following thy illustrious track.
8281: Thou hast atchiev'd our libertie, confin'd
8282: Within Hell Gates till now, thou us impow'rd
8283: To fortifie thus farr, and overlay
8284: With this portentous Bridge the dark Abyss.
8285: Thine now is all this World, thy vertue hath won
8286: What thy hands builded not, thy Wisdom gain'd
8287: With odds what Warr hath lost, and fully aveng'd
8288: Our foile in Heav'n; here thou shalt Monarch reign,
8289: There didst not; there let him still Victor sway,
8290: As Battel hath adjudg'd, from this new World
8291: Retiring, by his own doom alienated,
8292: And henceforth Monarchie with thee divide
8293: Of all things, parted by th' Empyreal bounds,
8294: His Quadrature, from thy Orbicular World,
8295: Or trie thee now more dang'rous to his Throne.
8296: ¶Whom thus the Prince of Darkness answerd glad.
8297: Fair Daughter, and thou Son and Grandchild both,
8298: High proof ye now have giv'n to be the Race
8299: Of *Satan* (for I glorie in the name,
8301: Amply have merited of me, of all
8302: Th' Infernal Empire, that so neer Heav'ns dore
8303: Triumphal with triumphal act have met,
8304: Mine with this glorious Work, & made one Realm
8305: Hell and this World, one Realm, one Continent
8306: Of easie thorough-fare.  Therefore while I
8307: Descend through Darkness, on your Rode with ease
8308: To my associate Powers, them to acquaint
8309: With these successes, and with them rejoyce,
8310: You two this way, among those numerous Orbs
8311: All yours, right down to Paradise descend;
8312: There dwell & Reign in bliss, thence on the Earth
8313: Dominion exercise and in the Aire,
8314: Chiefly on Man, sole Lord of all declar'd,
8315: Him first make sure your thrall, and lastly kill.
8316: My Substitutes I send ye, and Create
8317: Plenipotent on Earth, of matchless might
8318: Issuing from mee: on your joynt vigor now
8319: My hold of this new Kingdom all depends,
8320: Through Sin to Death expos'd by my exploit.
8321: If your joynt power prevaile, th' affaires of Hell
8322: No detriment need feare, goe and be strong.
8323: ¶So saying he dismiss'd them, they with speed
8324: Thir course through thickest Constellations held
8325: Spreading thir bane; the blasted Starrs lookt wan,
8327: Then sufferd.  Th' other way *Satan* went down
8328: The Causey to Hell Gate; on either side
8330: And with rebounding surge the barrs assaild,
8331: That scorn'd his indignation: through the Gate,
8333: And all about found desolate; for those
8334: Appointed to sit there, had left thir charge,
8335: Flown to the upper World; the rest were all
8336: Farr to the inland retir'd, about the walls
8339: Of that bright Starr to *Satan* paragond.
8340: There kept thir Watch the Legions, while the Grand
8341: In Council sate, sollicitous what chance
8342: Might intercept thir Emperour sent, so hee
8343: Departing gave command, and they observ'd.
8344: As when the *Tartar* from his *Russian* Foe
8346: Retires, or *Bactrian* Sophi from the hornes
8347: Of *Turkish* Crescent, leaves all waste beyond
8348: The Realme of *Aladule*, in his retreate
8349: To *Tauris* or *Casbeen*.  So these the late
8350: Heav'n-banisht Host, left desert utmost Hell
8351: Many a dark League, reduc't in careful Watch
8352: Round thir Metropolis, and now expecting
8353: Each hour their great adventurer from the search
8354: Of Forrein Worlds: he through the midst unmarkt,
8356: Of lowest order, past; and from the dore
8358: Ascended his high Throne, which under state
8359: Of richest texture spred, at th' upper end
8360: Was plac't in regal lustre.  Down a while
8361: He sate, and round about him saw unseen:
8362: At last as from a Cloud his fulgent head
8363: And shape Starr bright appeer'd, or brighter, clad
8364: With what permissive glory since his fall
8365: Was left him, or false glitter: All amaz'd
8366: At that so sudden blaze the *Stygian* throng
8367: Bent thir aspect, and whom they wish'd beheld,
8368: Thir mighty Chief returnd: loud was th' acclaime:
8369: Forth rush'd in haste the great consulting Peers,
8370: Rais'd from thir dark *Divan*, and with like joy
8371: Congratulant approach'd him, who with hand
8372: Silence, and with these words attention won.
8374: For in possession such, not onely of right,
8375: I call ye and declare ye now, returnd
8376: Successful beyond hope, to lead ye forth
8377: Triumphant out of this infernal Pit
8378: Abominable, accurst, the house of woe,
8379: And Dungeon of our Tyrant: Now possess,
8380: As Lords, a spacious World, to our native Heaven
8381: Little inferiour, by my adventure hard
8382: With peril great atchiev'd.  Long were to tell
8383: What I have don, what sufferd, with what paine
8384: Voyag'd the unreal, vast, unbounded deep
8386: By Sin and Death a broad way now is pav'd
8387: To expedite your glorious march; but I
8388: Toild out my uncouth passage, forc't to ride
8389: Th' untractable Abysse, plung'd in the womb
8391: That jealous of thir secrets fiercely oppos'd
8392: My journey strange, with clamorous uproare
8393: Protesting Fate supreame; thence how I found
8394: The new created World, which fame in Heav'n
8395: Long had foretold, a Fabrick wonderful
8397: Plac't in a Paradise, by our exile
8398: Made happie: Him by fraud I have seduc'd
8399: From his Creator, and the more to increase
8400: Your wonder, with an Apple; he thereat
8401: Offended, worth your laughter, hath giv'n up
8402: Both his beloved Man and all his World,
8403: To Sin and Death a prey, and so to us,
8404: Without our hazard, labour or allarme,
8405: To range in, and to dwell, and over Man
8406: To rule, as over all he should have rul'd.
8407: True is, mee also he hath judg'd, or rather
8408: Mee not, but the brute Serpent in whose shape
8409: Man I deceav'd: that which to mee belongs,
8410: Is enmity, which he will put between
8411: Mee and Mankinde; I am to bruise his heel;
8412: His Seed, when is not set, shall bruise my head:
8413: A World who would not purchase with a bruise,
8414: Or much more grievous pain?  Ye have th' account
8415: Of my performance: What remaines, ye Gods,
8416: But up and enter now into full bliss.
8417: ¶So having said, a while he stood, expecting
8418: Thir universal shout and high applause
8419: To fill his eare, when contrary he hears
8420: On all sides, from innumerable tongues
8421: A dismal universal hiss, the sound
8422: Of public scorn; he wonderd, but not long
8423: Had leasure, wondring at himself now more;
8424: His Visage drawn he felt to sharp and spare,
8425: His Armes clung to his Ribs, his Leggs entwining
8426: Each other, till supplanted down he fell
8427: A monstrous Serpent on his Belly prone,
8428: Reluctant, but in vaine, a greater power
8429: Now rul'd him, punisht in the shape he sin'd,
8430: According to his doom: he would have spoke,
8431: But hiss for hiss returnd with forked tongue
8432: To forked tongue, for now were all transform'd
8433: Alike, to Serpents all as accessories
8434: To his bold Riot: dreadful was the din
8435: Of hissing through the Hall, thick swarming now
8436: With complicated monsters, head and taile,
8439: And *Dipsas* (Not so thick swarm'd once the Soil
8440: Bedropt with blood of Gorgon, or the Isle
8441: *Ophiusa*) but still greatest hee the midst,
8442: Now Dragon grown, larger then whom the Sun
8443: Ingenderd in the *Pythian* Vale on slime,
8444: Huge *Python*, and his Power no less he seem'd
8445: Above the rest still to retain; they all
8446: Him follow'd issuing forth to th' open Field,
8447: Where all yet left of that revolted Rout
8448: Heav'n-fall'n, in station stood or just array,
8449: Sublime with expectation when to see
8450: In Triumph issuing forth thir glorious Chief;
8451: They saw, but other sight instead, a crowd
8452: Of ugly Serpents; horror on them fell,
8453: And horrid sympathie; for what they saw,
8454: They felt themselvs now changing; down thir arms,
8455: Down fell both Spear and Shield, down they as fast,
8456: And the dire hiss renew'd, and the dire form
8457: Catcht by Contagion, like in punishment,
8458: As in thir crime.  Thus was th' applause they meant,
8459: Turnd to exploding hiss, triumph to shame
8460: Cast on themselves from thir own mouths.  There stood
8461: A Grove hard by, sprung up with this thir change,
8462: His will who reigns above, to aggravate
8463: Thir penance, laden with fair Fruit, like that
8464: Which grew in Paradise, the bait of *Eve*
8465: Us'd by the Tempter: on that prospect strange
8466: Thir earnest eyes they fix'd, imagining
8467: For one forbidden Tree a multitude
8468: Now ris'n, to work them furder woe or shame;
8469: Yet parcht with scalding thurst and hunger fierce,
8470: Though to delude them sent, could not abstain,
8471: But on they rould in heaps, and up the Trees
8472: Climbing, sat thicker then the snakie locks
8474: The Frutage fair to sight, like that which grew
8475: Neer that bituminous Lake where *Sodom* flam'd;
8476: This more delusive, not the touch, but taste
8477: Deceav'd; they fondly thinking to allay
8478: Thir appetite with gust, instead of Fruit
8479: Chewd bitter Ashes, which th' offended taste
8480: With spattering noise rejected: oft they assayd,
8481: Hunger and thirst constraining, drugd as oft,
8482: With hatefullest disrelish writh'd thir jaws
8483: With foot and cinders fill'd; so oft they fell
8484: Into the same illusion, not as Man
8485: Whom they triumph'd once lapst.  Thus were they plagu'd
8486: And worn with Famin, long and ceasless hiss,
8487: Till thir lost shape, permitted, they resum'd,
8488: Yearly enjoynd, some say, to undergo
8489: This annual humbling certain number'd days,
8490: To dash thir pride, and joy for Man seduc't.
8492: Among the Heathen of thir purchase got,
8493: And Fabl'd how the Serpent, whom they calld
8495: Encroaching *Eve* perhaps, had first the rule
8498: Mean while in Paradise the hellish pair
8499: Too soon arriv'd, *Sin* there in power before,
8500: Once actual, now in body, and to dwell
8502: Close following pace for pace, not mounted yet
8503: On his pale Horse: to whom *Sin* thus began.
8505: What thinkst thou of our Empire now, though earnd
8506: With travail difficult, not better farr
8507: Then stil at Hels dark threshold to have sate watch,
8508: Unnam'd, undreaded, and thy self half starv'd?
8509: ¶Whom thus the Sin-born Monster answerd soon.
8510: To mee, who with eternal Famin pine,
8511: Alike is Hell, or Paradise, or Heaven,
8512: There best, where most with ravin I may meet;
8513: Which here, though plenteous, all too little seems
8514: To stuff this Maw, this vast unhide-bound Corps.
8515: ¶To whom th' incestuous Mother thus repli'd.
8516: Thou therefore on these Herbs, and Fruits, & Flours
8517: Feed first, on each Beast next, and Fish, and Fowle,
8518: No homely morsels, and whatever thing
8519: The Sithe of Time mowes down, devour unspar'd,
8520: Till I in Man residing through the Race,
8521: His thoughts, his looks, words, actions all infect,
8522: And season him thy last and sweetest prey.
8523: ¶This said, they both betook them several wayes,
8524: Both to destroy, or unimmortal make
8525: All kinds, and for destruction to mature
8526: Sooner or later; which th' Almightie seeing,
8527: From his transcendent Seat the Saints among,
8528: To those bright Orders utterd thus his voice.
8529: ¶See with what heat these Dogs of Hell advance
8530: To waste and havoc yonder World, which I
8531: So fair and good created, and had still
8532: Kept in that state, had not the folly of Man
8533: Let in these wastful Furies, who impute
8534: Folly to mee, so doth the Prince of Hell
8535: And his Adherents, that with so much ease
8536: I suffer them to enter and possess
8537: A place so heav'nly, and conniving seem
8539: That laugh, as if transported with some fit
8540: Of Passion, I to them had quitted all,
8541: At random yeilded up to their misrule;
8542: And know not that I call'd and drew them thither
8543: My Hell-hounds, to lick up the draff and filth
8544: Which mans polluting Sin with taint hath shed
8545: On what was pure, till cramm'd and gorg'd, nigh burst
8546: With suckt and glutted offal, at one fling
8547: Of thy victorious Arm, well-pleasing Son,
8548: Both *Sin*, and *Death*, and yawning *Grave* at last
8549: Through *Chaos* hurld, obstruct the mouth of Hell
8550: For ever, and seal up his ravenous Jawes.
8551: Then Heav'n and Earth renewd shall be made pure
8552: To sanctitie that shall receive no staine:
8553: Till then the Curse pronounc't on both precedes.
8554: ¶Hee ended, and the heav'nly Audience loud
8555: Sung *Halleluia*, as the sound of Seas,
8556: Through multitude that sung: Just are thy ways,
8557: Righteous are thy Decrees on all thy Works;
8558: Who can extenuate thee?  Next, to the Son,
8559: Destin'd restorer of Mankind, by whom
8560: New Heav'n and Earth shall to the Ages rise,
8561: Or down from Heav'n descend.  Such was thir song,
8562: While the Creator calling forth by name
8563: His mightie Angels gave them several charge,
8564: As sorted best with present things.  The Sun
8565: Had first his precept so to move, so shine,
8566: As might affect the Earth with cold and heat
8567: Scarce tollerable, and from the North to call
8568: Decrepit Winter, from the South to bring
8569: Solstitial summers heat.  To the blanc Moone
8570: Her office they prescrib'd, to th' other five
8573: Of noxious efficacie, and when to joyne
8574: In Synod unbenigne, and taught the fixt
8575: Thir influence malignant when to showre,
8576: Which of them rising with the Sun, or falling,
8577: Should prove tempestuous: To the Winds they set
8578: Thir corners, when with bluster to confound
8579: Sea, Aire, and Shoar, the Thunder when to rowle
8580: With terror through the dark Aereal Hall.
8581: Some say he bid his Angels turne ascanse
8582: The Poles of Earth twice ten degrees and more
8583: From the Suns Axle; they with labour push'd
8584: Oblique the Centric Globe: Som say the Sun
8585: Was bid turn Reines from th' Equinoctial Rode
8586: Like distant breadth to *Taurus* with the Seav'n
8588: Up to the *Tropic* Crab; thence down amaine
8590: As deep as *Capricorne*, to bring in change
8591: Of Seasons to each Clime; else had the Spring
8592: Perpetual smil'd on Earth with vernant Flours,
8593: Equal in Days and Nights, except to those
8594: Beyond the Polar Circles; to them Day
8595: Had unbenighted shon, while the low Sun
8596: To recompence his distance, in thir sight
8597: Had rounded still th' *Horizon*, and not known
8598: Or East or West, which had forbid the Snow
8599: From cold *Estotiland*, and South as farr
8601: The Sun, as from *Thyestean* Banquet, turn'd
8602: His course intended; else how had the World
8603: Inhabited, though sinless, more then now,
8604: Avoided pinching cold and scorching heate?
8605: These changes in the Heav'ns, though slow, produc'd
8606: Like change on Sea and Land, sideral blast,
8607: Vapour, and Mist, and Exhalation hot,
8608: Corrupt and Pestilent: Now from the North
8610: Bursting thir brazen Dungeon, armd with ice
8611: And snow and haile and stormie gust and flaw,
8613: And *Thrascias* rend the Woods and Seas upturn;
8614: With adverse blast up-turns them from the South
8616: From *Serraliona*; thwart of these as fierce
8617: Forth rush the *Levant* and the *Ponent* Windes
8620: Outrage from liveless things; but Discord first
8621: Daughter of Sin, among th' irrational,
8623: Beast now with Beast gan war, & Fowle with Fowle,
8624: And Fish with Fish; to graze the Herb all leaving,
8625: Devourd each other; nor stood much in awe
8626: Of Man, but fled him, or with count'nance grim
8627: Glar'd on him passing: these were from without
8629: Alreadie in part, though hid in gloomiest shade,
8630: To sorrow abandond, but worse felt within,
8631: And in a troubl'd Sea of passion tost,
8632: Thus to disburd'n sought with sad complaint.
8633: ¶O miserable of happie! is this the end
8634: Of this new glorious World, and mee so late
8635: The Glory of that Glory, who now becom
8636: Accurst of blessed, hide me from the face
8637: Of God, whom to behold was then my highth
8638: Of happiness: yet well, if here would end
8639: The miserie, I deserv'd it, and would beare
8640: My own deservings; but this will not serve;
8641: All that I eate or drink, or shall beget,
8642: Is propagated curse.  O voice once heard
8644: Now death to heare! for what can I encrease
8645: Or multiplie, but curses on my head?
8646: Who of all Ages to succeed, but feeling
8647: The evil on him brought by me, will curse
8648: My Head, Ill fare our Ancestor impure,
8649: For this we may thank *Adam*; but his thanks
8650: Shall be the execration; so besides
8651: Mine own that bide upon me, all from mee
8652: Shall with a fierce reflux on mee redound,
8653: On mee as on thir natural center light
8654: Heavie, though in thir place.  O fleeting joyes
8655: Of Paradise, deare bought with lasting woes!
8656: Did I request thee, Maker, from my Clay
8657: To mould me Man, did I sollicite thee
8658: From darkness to promote me, or here place
8659: In this delicious Garden? as my Will
8660: Concurd not to my being, it were but right
8661: And equal to reduce me to my dust,
8662: Desirous to resigne, and render back
8663: All I receav'd, unable to performe
8664: Thy terms too hard, by which I was to hold
8665: The good I sought not.  To the loss of that,
8666: Sufficient penaltie, why hast thou added
8667: The sense of endless woes? inexplicable
8668: Thy Justice seems; yet to say truth, too late,
8669: I thus contest; then should have been refusd
8670: Those terms whatever, when they were propos'd:
8671: Thou didst accept them; wilt thou enjoy the good,
8672: Then cavil the conditions? and though God
8673: Made thee without thy leave, what if thy Son
8675: Wherefore didst thou beget me? I sought it not:
8676: Wouldst thou admit for his contempt of thee
8677: That proud excuse? yet him not thy election,
8679: God made thee of choice his own, and of his own
8680: To serve him, thy reward was of his grace,
8681: Thy punishment then justly is at his Will.
8682: Be it so, for I submit, his doom is fair,
8683: That dust I am, and shall to dust returne:
8684: O welcom hour whenever! why delayes
8685: His hand to execute what his Decree
8686: Fixd on this day? why do I overlive,
8687: Why am I mockt with death, and length'nd out
8688: To deathless pain? how gladly would I meet
8689: Mortalitie my sentence, and be Earth
8690: Insensible, how glad would lay me down
8691: As in my Mothers lap? there I should rest
8692: And sleep secure; his dreadful voice no more
8693: Would Thunder in my ears, no fear of worse
8694: To mee and to my ofspring would torment me
8695: With cruel expectation.  Yet one doubt
8696: Pursues me still, least all I cannot die,
8697: Least that pure breath of Life, the Spirit of Man
8698: Which God inspir'd, cannot together perish
8699: With this corporeal Clod; then in the Grave,
8700: Or in some other dismal place, who knows
8701: But I shall die a living Death?  O thought
8702: Horrid, if true! yet why? it was but breath
8703: Of Life that sinn'd; what dies but what had life
8704: And sin? the Bodie properly hath neither.
8705: All of me then shall die: let this appease
8706: The doubt, since humane reach no further knows.
8707: For though the Lord of all be infinite,
8708: Is his wrauth also? be it, man is not so,
8709: But mortal doom'd.  How can he exercise
8710: Wrath without end on Man whom Death must end?
8711: Can he make deathless Death? that were to make
8712: Strange contradiction, which to God himself
8714: Of weakness, not of Power.  Will he, draw out,
8715: For angers sake, finite to infinite
8716: In punisht man, to satisfie his rigour
8717: Satisfi'd never; that were to extend
8718: His Sentence beyond dust and Natures Law,
8719: By which all Causes else according still
8720: To the reception of thir matter act,
8721: Not to th' extent of thir own Spheare.  But say
8722: That Death be not one stroak, as I suppos'd,
8724: From this day onward, which I feel begun
8725: Both in me, and without me, and so last
8726: To perpetuitie; Ay me, that fear
8727: Comes thundring back with dreadful revolution
