8728: On my defensless head; both Death and I
8729: Am found Eternal, and incorporate both,
8730: Nor I on my part single, in mee all
8732: That I must leave ye, Sons; O were I able
8733: To waste it all my self, and leave ye none!
8734: So disinherited how would ye bless
8735: Me now your Curse!  Ah, why should all mankind
8736: For one mans fault thus guiltless be condemn'd,
8737: If guiltless?  But from mee what can proceed,
8738: But all corrupt, both Mind and Will deprav'd,
8739: Not to do onely, but to will the same
8740: With me? how can they acquitted stand
8741: In sight of God?  Him after all Disputes
8742: Forc't I absolve: all my evasions vain
8743: And reasonings, though through Mazes, lead me still
8744: But to my own conviction: first and last
8745: On mee, mee onely, as the sourse and spring
8746: Of all corruption, all the blame lights due;
8747: So might the wrauth, Fond wish! couldst thou support
8748: That burden heavier then the Earth to bear,
8749: Then all the world much heavier, though divided
8750: With that bad Woman?  Thus what thou desir'st,
8751: And what thou fearst, alike destroyes all hope
8752: Of refuge, and concludes thee miserable
8753: Beyond all past example and future,
8754: To *Satan* onely like both crime and doom.
8755: O Conscience, into what Abyss of fears
8756: And horrors hast thou driv'n me; out of which
8757: I find no way, from deep to deeper plung'd!
8759: Through the still Night, now now, as ere man fell,
8760: Wholsom and cool, and mild, but with black Air
8761: Accompanied, with damps and dreadful gloom,
8762: Which to his evil Conscience represented
8763: All things with double terror: On the ground
8764: Outstretcht he lay, on the cold ground, and oft
8765: Curs'd his Creation, Death as oft accus'd
8767: The day of his offence.  Why comes not Death,
8768: Said hee, with one thrice acceptable stroke
8769: To end me?  Shall Truth fail to keep her word,
8770: Justice Divine not hast'n to be just?
8771: But Death comes not at call, Justice Divine
8772: Mends not her slowest pace for prayers or cries.
8773: O Woods, O Fountains, Hillocks, Dales and Bowrs,
8774: With other echo farr I taught your Shades
8775: To answer, and resound farr other Song.
8776: Whom thus afflicted when sad *Eve* beheld,
8777: Desolate where she sate, approaching nigh,
8778: Soft words to his fierce passion she assay'd:
8779: But her with stern regard he thus repell'd.
8780: ¶Out of my sight, thou Serpent, that name best
8781: Befits thee with him leagu'd, thy self as false
8782: And hateful; nothing wants, but that thy shape,
8783: Like his, and colour Serpentine may shew
8784: Thy inward fraud, to warn all Creatures from thee
8785: Henceforth; least that too heav'nly form, pretended
8786: To hellish falshood, snare them.  But for thee
8787: I had persisted happie, had not thy pride
8788: And wandring vanitie, when lest was safe,
8790: Not to be trusted, longing to be seen
8791: Though by the Devil himself, him overweening
8792: To over-reach, but with the Serpent meeting
8793: Fool'd and beguil'd, by him thou, I by thee,
8794: To trust thee from my side, imagin'd wise,
8795: Constant, mature, proof against all assaults,
8796: And understood not all was but a shew
8797: Rather then solid vertu, all but a Rib
8798: Crooked by nature, bent, as now appears,
8799: More to the part sinister from me drawn,
8800: Well if thrown out, as supernumerarie
8801: To my just number found.  O why did God,
8802: Creator wise, that peopl'd highest Heav'n
8803: With Spirits Masculine, create at last
8804: This noveltie on Earth, this fair defect
8805: Of Nature, and not fill the World at once
8806: With Men as Angels without Feminine,
8807: Or find some other way to generate
8808: Mankind? this mischief had not then befall'n,
8809: And more that shall befall, innumerable
8810: Disturbances on Earth through Femal snares,
8811: And straight conjunction with this Sex: for either
8812: He never shall find out fit Mate, but such
8813: As some misfortune brings him, or mistake,
8814: Or whom he wishes most shall seldom gain
8815: Through her perverseness, but shall see her gaind
8816: By a farr worse, or if she love, withheld
8817: By Parents, or his happiest choice too late
8818: Shall meet, alreadie linkt and Wedlock-bound
8819: To a fell Adversarie, his hate or shame:
8821: To humane life, and houshold peace confound.
8822: ¶He added not, and from her turn'd, but *Eve*
8823: Not so repulst, with Tears that ceas'd not flowing,
8824: And tresses all disorderd, at his feet
8825: Fell humble, and imbracing them, besaught
8826: His peace, and thus proceeded in her plaint.
8828: What love sincere, and reverence in my heart
8829: I beare thee, and unweeting have offended,
8831: I beg, and clasp thy knees; bereave me not,
8832: Whereon I live, thy gentle looks, thy aid,
8833: Thy counsel in this uttermost distress,
8834: My onely strength and stay: forlorn of thee,
8835: Whither shall I betake me, where subsist?
8836: While yet we live, scarse one short hour perhaps,
8837: Between us two let there be peace, both joyning,
8838: As joyn'd in injuries, one enmitie
8839: Against a Foe by doom express assign'd us,
8840: That cruel Serpent: On me exercise not
8841: Thy hatred for this miserie befall'n,
8842: On me already lost, mee then thy self
8843: More miserable; both have sin'd, but thou
8844: Against God onely, I against God and thee,
8845: And to the place of judgement will return,
8846: There with my cries importune Heaven, that all
8847: The sentence from thy head remov'd may light
8848: On me, sole cause to thee of all this woe,
8849: Mee mee onely just object of his ire.
8850: ¶She ended weeping, and her lowlie plight,
8851: Immoveable till peace obtain'd from fault
8854: Towards her, his life so late and sole delight,
8855: Now at his feet submissive in distress,
8856: Creature so faire his reconcilement seeking,
8857: His counsel whom she had displeas'd, his aide;
8858: As one disarm'd, his anger all he lost,
8859: And thus with peaceful words uprais'd her soon.
8861: So now of what thou knowst not, who desir'st
8862: The punishment all on thy self; alas,
8863: Beare thine own first, ill able to sustaine
8864: His full wrauth whose thou feelst as yet lest part,
8865: And my displeasure bearst so ill.  If Prayers
8866: Could alter high Decrees, I to that place
8867: Would speed before thee, and be louder heard,
8868: That on my head all might be visited,
8869: Thy frailtie and infirmer Sex forgiv'n,
8870: To me committed and by me expos'd.
8871: But rise, let us no more contend, nor blame
8872: Each other, blam'd enough elsewhere, but strive
8873: In offices of Love, how we may light'n
8874: Each others burden in our share of woe;
8875: Since this days Death denounc't, if ought I see,
8876: Will prove no sudden, but a slow-pac't evill,
8877: A long days dying to augment our paine,
8878: And to our Seed (O hapless Seed!) deriv'd.
8881: How little weight my words with thee can finde,
8882: Found so erroneous, thence by just event
8884: Restor'd by thee, vile as I am, to place
8885: Of new acceptance, hopeful to regaine
8886: Thy Love, the sole contentment of my heart,
8887: Living or dying from thee I will not hide
8888: What thoughts in my unquiet brest are ris'n,
8889: Tending to som relief of our extremes,
8890: Or end, though sharp and sad, yet tolerable,
8891: As in our evils, and of easier choice.
8892: If care of our descent perplex us most,
8893: Which must be born to certain woe, devourd
8894: By Death at last, and miserable it is
8895: To be to others cause of misery,
8896: Our own begotten, and of our Loines to bring
8897: Into this cursed World a woful Race,
8898: That after wretched Life must be at last
8899: Food for so foule a Monster, in thy power
8900: It lies, yet ere Conception to prevent
8901: The Race unblest, to being yet unbegot.
8903: So Death shall be deceav'd his glut, and with us two
8904: Be forc'd to satisfie his Rav'nous Maw.
8905: But if thou judge it hard and difficult,
8907: From Loves due Rites, Nuptial embraces sweet,
8908: And with desire to languish without hope,
8910: With like desire, which would be miserie
8911: And torment less then none of what we dread,
8912: Then both our selves and Seed at once to free
8913: From what we fear for both, let us make short,
8914: Let us seek Death, or hee not found, supply
8915: With our own hands his Office on our selves;
8916: Why stand we longer shivering under feares,
8917: That shew no end but Death, and have the power,
8918: Of many wayes to die the shortest choosing,
8921: Broke off the rest; so much of Death her thoughts
8922: Had entertaind, as di'd her Cheeks with pale.
8923: But *Adam* with such counsel nothing sway'd,
8924: To better hopes his more attentive minde
8925: Labouring had rais'd, and thus to *Eve* repli'd.
8926: ¶*Eve*, thy contempt of life and pleasure seems
8927: To argue in thee somthing more sublime
8928: And excellent then what thy minde contemnes;
8930: That excellence thought in thee, and implies,
8931: Not thy contempt, but anguish and regret
8932: For loss of life and pleasure overlov'd.
8933: Or if thou covet death, as utmost end
8934: Of miserie, so thinking to evade
8935: The penaltie pronounc't, doubt not but God
8936: Hath wiselier arm'd his vengeful ire then so
8937: To be forestall'd; much more I fear least Death
8938: So snatcht will not exempt us from the paine
8939: We are by doom to pay; rather such acts
8940: Of contumacie will provoke the highest
8941: To make death in us live: Then let us seek
8943: I have in view, calling to minde with heed
8944: Part of our Sentence, that thy Seed shall bruise
8945: The Serpents head; piteous amends, unless
8946: Be meant, whom I conjecture, our grand Foe
8947: *Satan*, who in the Serpent hath contriv'd
8948: Against us this deceit: to crush his head
8949: Would be revenge indeed; which will be lost
8950: By death brought on our selves, or childless days
8951: Resolv'd, as thou proposest; so our Foe
8952: Shall scape his punishment ordain'd, and wee
8953: Instead shall double ours upon our heads.
8954: No more be mention'd then of violence
8955: Against our selves, and wilful barrenness,
8956: That cuts us off from hope, and savours onely
8957: Rancor and pride, impatience and despite,
8958: Reluctance against God and his just yoke
8959: Laid on our Necks.  Remember with what mild
8960: And gracious temper he both heard and judg'd
8961: Without wrauth or reviling; wee expected
8963: Was meant by Death that day, when lo, to thee
8964: Pains onely in Child-bearing were foretold,
8965: And bringing forth, soon recompenc't with joy,
8966: Fruit of thy Womb: On mee the Curse aslope
8967: Glanc'd on the ground, with labour I must earne
8968: My bread; what harm?  Idleness had bin worse;
8969: My labour will sustain me; and least Cold
8970: Or Heat should injure us, his timely care
8971: Hath unbesaught provided, and his hands
8972: Cloath'd us unworthie, pitying while he judg'd;
8973: How much more, if we pray him, will his ear
8974: Be open, and his heart to pitie incline,
8975: And teach us further by what means to shun
8976: Th' inclement Seasons, Rain, Ice, Hail and Snow,
8977: Which now the Skie with various Face begins
8978: To shew us in this Mountain, while the Winds
8979: Blow moist and keen, shattering the graceful locks
8980: Of these fair spreading Trees; which bids us seek
8981: Som better shroud, som better warmth to cherish
8982: Our Limbs benumm'd, ere this diurnal Starr
8983: Leave cold the Night, how we his gather'd beams
8984: Reflected, may with matter sere foment,
8985: Or by collision of two bodies grinde
8986: The Air attrite to Fire, as late the Clouds
8987: Justling or pusht with Winds rude in thir shock
8988: Tine the slant Lightning, whose thwart flame driv'n down
8989: Kindles the gummie bark of Firr or Pine,
8990: And sends a comfortable heat from farr,
8991: Which might supplie the Sun: such Fire to use,
8992: And what may else be remedie or cure
8993: To evils which our own misdeeds have wrought,
8994: Hee will instruct us praying, and of Grace
8995: Beseeching him, so as we need not fear
8996: To pass commodiously this life, sustain'd
8997: By him with many comforts, till we end
8998: In dust, our final rest and native home.
8999: What better can we do, then to the place
9000: Repairing where he judg'd us, prostrate fall
9001: Before him reverent, and there confess
9002: Humbly our faults, and pardon beg, with tears
9003: Watering the ground, and with our sighs the Air
9004: Frequenting, sent from hearts contrite, in sign
9005: Of sorrow unfeign'd, and humiliation meek.
9006: Undoubtedly he will relent and turn
9007: From his displeasure; in whose look serene,
9008: When angry most he seem'd and most severe,
9009: What else but favor, grace, and mercie shon?
9011: Felt less remorse: they forthwith to the place
9012: Repairing where he judg'd them prostrate fell
9013: Before him reverent, and both confess'd
9014: Humbly thir faults, and pardon beg'd, with tears
9015: Watering the ground, and with thir sighs the Air
9016: Frequenting, sent from hearts contrite, in sign
9017: Of sorrow unfeign'd, and humiliation meek.
9019: ¶Thus they in lowliest plight repentant stood
9020: Praying, for from the Mercie-seat above
9022: The stonie from thir hearts, and made new flesh
9023: Regenerat grow instead, that sighs now breath'd
9024: Unutterable, which the Spirit of prayer
9025: Inspir'd, and wing'd for Heav'n with speedier flight
9026: Then loudest Oratorie: yet thir port
9027: Not of mean suiters, nor important less
9028: Seem'd thir Petition, then when th' ancient Pair
9029: In Fables old, less ancient yet then these,
9031: The Race of Mankind drownd, before the Shrine
9032: Of *Themis* stood devout.  To Heav'n thir prayers
9033: Flew up, nor missed the way, by envious windes
9034: Blow'n vagabond or frustrate: in they passd
9035: Dimentionless through Heav'nly dores; then clad
9036: With incense, where the Golden Altar fum'd,
9037: By thir great Intercessor, came in sight
9038: Before the Fathers Throne: Them the glad Son
9040: ¶See Father, what first fruits on Earth are sprung
9041: From thy implanted Grace in Man, these Sighs
9042: And Prayers, which in this Golden Censer, mixt
9043: With Incense, I thy Priest before thee bring,
9044: Fruits of more pleasing savour from thy seed
9045: Sow'n with contrition in his heart, then those
9046: Which his own hand manuring all the Trees
9047: Of Paradise could have produc't, ere fall'n
9048: From innocence.  Now therefore bend thine eare
9049: To supplication, heare his sighs though mute;
9050: Unskilful with what words to pray, let mee
9051: Interpret for him, mee his Advocate
9052: And propitiation, all his works on mee
9053: Good or not good ingraft, my Merit those
9054: Shall perfet, and for these my Death shall pay.
9055: Accept me, and in mee from these receave
9056: The smell of peace toward Mankinde, let him live
9057: Before thee reconcil'd, at least his days
9058: Numberd, though sad, till Death, his doom (which I
9059: To mitigate thus plead, not to reverse)
9060: To better life shall yeeld him, where with mee
9061: All my redeemd may dwell in joy and bliss,
9062: Made one with me as I with thee am one.
9063: ¶To whom the Father, without Cloud, serene.
9064: All thy request for Man, accepted Son,
9065: Obtain, all thy request was my Decree:
9066: But longer in that Paradise to dwell,
9067: The Law I gave to Nature him forbids:
9068: Those pure immortal Elements that know
9069: No gross, no unharmoneous mixture foule,
9070: Eject him tainted now, and purge him off
9071: As a distemper, gross to aire as gross,
9072: And mortal food, as may dispose him best
9073: For dissolution wrought by Sin, that first
9074: Distemperd all things, and of incorrupt
9075: Corrupted.  I at first with two fair gifts
9078: This other serv'd but to eternize woe;
9079: Till I provided Death; so Death becomes
9080: His final remedie, and after Life
9081: Tri'd in sharp tribulation, and refin'd
9082: By Faith and faithful works, to second Life,
9083: Wak't in the renovation of the just,
9084: Resignes him up with Heav'n and Earth renewd.
9085: But let us call to Synod all the Blest
9086: Through Heav'ns wide bounds; from them I will not hide
9087: My judgments, how with Mankind I proceed,
9088: As how with peccant Angels late they saw;
9089: And in thir state, though firm, stood more confirmd.
9090: ¶He ended, and the Son gave signal high
9091: To the bright Minister that watchd, hee blew
9092: His Trumpet, heard in *Oreb* since perhaps
9093: When God descended, and perhaps once more
9094: To sound at general Doom.  Th' Angelic blast
9095: Filld all the Regions: from thir blissful Bowrs
9097: By the waters of Life, where ere they sate
9098: In fellowships of joy: the Sons of Light
9099: Hasted, resorting to the Summons high,
9100: And took thir Seats; till from his Throne supream
9101: Th' Almighty thus pronounced his sovran Will.
9102: ¶O Sons, like one of us Man is become
9103: To know both Good and Evil, since his taste
9104: Of that defended Fruit; but let him boast
9105: His knowledge of Good lost, and Evil got,
9106: Happier, had it suffic'd him to have known
9107: Good by it self, and Evil not at all.
9108: He sorrows now, repents, and prayes contrite,
9109: My motions in him, longer then they move,
9110: His heart I know, how variable and vain
9111: Self-left.  Least therefore his now bolder hand
9112: Reach also of the Tree of Life, and eat,
9113: And live for ever, dream at least to live
9114: Forever, to remove him I decree,
9115: And send him from the Garden forth to Till
9116: The Ground whence he was taken, fitter soile.
9117: ¶*Michael*, this my behest have thou in charge,
9118: Take to thee from among the Cherubim
9119: Thy choice of flaming Warriours, least the Fiend
9120: Or in behalf of Man, or to invade
9121: Vacant possession som new trouble raise:
9122: Hast thee, and from the Paradise of God
9123: Without remorse drive out the sinful Pair,
9124: From hallowd ground th' unholie, and denounce
9125: To them and to thir Progenie from thence
9126: Perpetual banishment.  Yet least they faint
9127: At the sad Sentence rigorously urg'd,
9128: For I behold them soft'nd and with tears
9129: Bewailing thir excess, all terror hide.
9130: If patiently thy bidding they obey,
9132: To *Adam* what shall come in future dayes,
9133: As I shall thee enlighten, intermix
9134: My Cov'nant in the Womans seed renewd;
9135: So send them forth, though sorrowing, yet in peace:
9136: And on the East side of the Garden place,
9137: Where entrance up from *Eden* easiest climbes,
9138: Cherubic watch, and of a Sword the flame
9139: Wide waving, all approach farr off to fright,
9140: And guard all passage to the Tree of Life:
9142: To Spirits foule, and all my Trees thir prey,
9143: With whose stol'n Fruit Man once more to delude.
9144: ¶He ceas'd; and th' Archangelic Power prepar'd
9145: For swift descent, with him the Cohort bright
9146: Of watchful Cherubim; four faces each
9147: Had, like a double *Janus*, all thir shape
9148: Spangl'd with eyes more numerous then those
9149: Of *Argus*, and more wakeful then to drouze,
9150: Charm'd with *Arcadian* Pipe, the Pastoral Reed
9151: Of *Hermes*, or his opiate Rod.  Meanwhile
9152: To resalute the World with sacred Light
9153: *Leucothea* wak'd, and with fresh dews imbalmd
9154: The Earth, when *Adam* and first Matron *Eve*
9155: Had ended now thir Orisons, and found,
9156: Strength added from above, new hope to spring
9157: Out of despaire, joy, but with fear yet linkt;
9158: Which thus to *Eve* his welcome words renewd.
9159: ¶*Eve*, easily may Faith admit, that all
9160: The good which we enjoy, from Heav'n descends
9161: But that from us ought should ascend to Heav'n
9162: So prevalent as to concerne the mind
9163: Of God high blest, or to incline his will,
9164: Hard to belief may seem; yet this will Prayer,
9165: Or one short sigh of humane breath, up-borne
9166: Ev'n to the Seat of God.  For since I saught
9167: By Prayer th' offended Deitie to appease,
9168: Kneel'd and before him humbl'd all my heart,
9169: Methought I saw him placable and mild,
9170: Bending his eare; perswasion in me grew
9171: That I was heard with favour; peace returnd
9172: Home to my brest, and to my memorie
9173: His promise, that thy Seed shall bruise our Foe;
9174: Which then not minded in dismay, yet now
9175: Assures me that the bitterness of death
9176: Is past, and we shall live.  Whence Haile to thee,
9177: *Eve* rightly call'd, Mother of all Mankind,
9178: Mother of all things living, since by thee
9179: Man is to live, and all things live for Man.
9180: ¶To whom thus *Eve* with sad demeanour meek.
9181: Ill worthie I such title should belong
9182: To me transgressour, who for thee ordaind
9183: A help, became thy snare; to mee reproach
9184: Rather belongs, distrust and all dispraise:
9185: But infinite in pardon was my Judge,
9186: That I who first brought Death on all, am grac't
9187: The sourse of life; next favourable thou,
9188: Who highly thus to entitle me voutsaf't,
9189: Farr other name deserving.  But the Field
9190: To labour calls us now with sweat impos'd,
9191: Though after sleepless Night; for see the Morn,
9192: All unconcern'd with our unrest, begins
9193: Her rosie progress smiling; let us forth,
9194: I never from thy side henceforth to stray,
9195: Wherere our days work lies, though now enjoind
9196: Laborious, till day droop; while here we dwell,
9197: What can be toilsom in these pleasant Walkes?
9198: Here let us live, though in fall'n state, content.
9199: ¶So spake, so wish'd much-humbl'd *Eve*, but Fate
9200: Subscrib'd not; Nature first gave Signs, imprest
9201: On Bird, Beast, Aire, Aire suddenly eclips'd
9202: After short blush of Morn; nigh in her sight
9203: The Bird of *Jove*, stoopt from his aerie tour,
9204: Two Birds of gayest plume before him drove:
9205: Down from a Hill the Beast that reigns in Woods,
9206: First Hunter then, pursu'd a gentle brace,
9207: Goodliest of all the Forrest, Hart and Hinde;
9208: Direct to th' Eastern Gate was bent thir flight.
9209: *Adam* observ'd, and with his Eye the chase
9210: Pursuing, not unmov'd to *Eve* thus spake.
9211: ¶O *Eve*, some furder change awaits us nigh,
9212: Which Heav'n by these mute signs in Nature shews
9213: Forerunners of his purpose, or to warn
9214: Us haply too secure of our discharge
9215: From penaltie, because from death releast
9216: Some days; how long, and what till then our life,
9217: Who knows, or more then this, that we are dust,
9218: And thither must return and be no more.
9219: Why else this double object in our sight
9220: Of flight pursu'd in th' Air and ore the ground
9221: One way the self-same hour? why in the East
9222: Darkness ere Dayes mid-course, and Morning light
9223: More orient in yon Western Cloud that draws
9224: O're the blew Firmament a radiant white,
9225: And slow descends, with somthing heav'nly fraught.
9226: ¶He err'd not, for by this the heav'nly Bands
9227: Down from a Skie of Jasper lighted now
9228: In Paradise, and on a Hill made alt,
9229: A glorious Apparition, had not doubt
9230: And carnal fear that day dimm'd *Adams* eye.
9231: Not that more glorious, when the Angels met
9233: The field Pavilion'd with his Guardians bright;
9234: Nor that which on the flaming Mount appeerd
9235: In *Dothan*, cover'd with a Camp of Fire,
9236: Against the *Syrian* King, who to surprize
9237: One man, Assassin-like had levied Warr,
9239: In thir bright stand, there left his Powers to seise
9240: Possession of the Garden; hee alone,
9241: To finde where *Adam* shelterd, took his way,
9243: While the great Visitant approachd, thus spake.
9244: ¶*Eve*, now expect great tidings, which perhaps
9245: Of us will soon determin, or impose
9246: New Laws to be observ'd; for I descrie
9247: From yonder blazing Cloud that veils the Hill
9248: One of the heav'nly Host, and by his Gate
9249: None of the meanest, some great Potentate
9250: Or of the Thrones above, such Majestie
9251: Invests him coming; yet not terrible,
9252: That I should fear, nor sociably mild,
9253: As *Raphael*, that I should much confide,
9254: But solemn and sublime, whom not to offend,
9255: With reverence I must meet, and thou retire.
9256: He ended; and th' Arch-Angel soon drew nigh,
9257: Not in his shape Celestial, but as Man
9258: Clad to meet Man; over his lucid Armes
9259: A militarie Vest of purple flowd
9261: Of *Sarra*, worn by Kings and Hero's old
9262: In time of Truce; *Iris* had dipt the wooff;
9263: His starrie Helme unbuckl'd shew'd him prime
9264: In Manhood where Youth ended; by his side
9265: As in a glistering *Zodiac* hung the Sword,
9266: Satans dire dread, and in his hand the Spear.
9267: *Adam* bowd low, hee Kingly from his State
9268: Inclin'd not, but his coming thus declar'd.
9269: ¶*Adam*, Heav'ns high behest no Preface needs:
9270: Sufficient that thy Prayers are heard, and Death,
9271: Then due by sentence when thou didst transgress,
9272: Defeated of his seisure many dayes
9273: Giv'n thee of Grace, wherein thou may'st repent,
9274: And one bad act with many deeds well done
9275: Mayst cover: well may then thy Lord appeas'd
9276: Redeem thee quite from Deaths rapacious claimes;
9277: But longer in this Paradise to dwell
9278: Permits not; to remove thee I am come,
9279: And send thee from the Garden forth to till
9280: The ground whence thou wast tak'n, fitter Soile.
9281: ¶He added not, for *Adam* at the newes
9282: Heart-strook with chilling gripe of sorrow stood,
9283: That all his senses bound; *Eve*, who unseen
9284: Yet all had heard, with audible lament
9285: Discover'd soon the place of her retire.
9286: ¶O unexpected stroke, worse then of Death!
9287: Must I thus leave thee Paradise? thus leave
9288: Thee Native Soile, these happie Walks and Shades,
9289: Fit haunt of Gods? where I had hope to spend,
9290: Quiet though sad, the respit of that day
9291: That must be mortal to us both.  O flours,
9292: That never will in other Climate grow,
9293: My early visitation, and my last
9294: At Eev'n, which I bred up with tender hand
9295: From the first op'ning bud, and gave ye Names,
9296: Who now shall reare ye to the Sun, or ranke
9297: Your Tribes, and water from th' ambrosial Fount?
9298: Thee lastly nuptial Bowre, by mee adornd
9299: With what to sight or smell was sweet; from thee
9300: How shall I part, and whither wander down
9301: Into a lower World, to this obscure
9302: And wilde, how shall we breath in other Aire
9303: Less pure, accustomd to immortal Fruits?
9306: What justly thou hast lost; nor set thy heart,
9307: Thus over fond, on that which is not thine;
9308: Thy going is not lonely, with thee goes
9309: Thy Husband, him to follow thou art bound;
9310: Where he abides, think there thy native soile.
9311: ¶*Adam* by this from the cold sudden damp
9312: Recovering, and his scatterd spirits returnd,
9313: To *Michael* thus his humble words addressd.
9314: ¶Celestial, whether among the Thrones, or nam'd
9315: Of them the Highest, for such of shape may seem
9316: Prince above Princes, gently hast thou tould
9317: Thy message, which might else in telling wound,
9318: And in performing end us; what besides
9319: Of sorrow and dejection and despair
9320: Our frailtie can sustain, thy tidings bring,
9321: Departure from this happy place, our sweet
9323: Familiar to our eyes, all places else
9325: Nor knowing us nor known: and if by prayer
9326: Incessant I could hope to change the will
9327: Of him who all things can, I would not cease
9328: To wearie him with my assiduous cries:
9329: But prayer against his absolute Decree
9330: No more availes then breath against the winde,
9331: Blown stifling back on him that breaths it forth:
9332: Therefore to his great bidding I submit.
9333: This most afflicts me, that departing hence,
9334: As from his face I shall be hid, deprivd
9335: His blessed count'nance; here I could frequent,
9336: With worship, place by place where he voutsaf'd
9337: Presence Divine, and to my Sons relate;
9338: On this Mount he appeerd, under this Tree
9339: Stood visible, among these Pines his voice
9340: I heard, here with him at this Fountain talk'd:
9341: So many grateful Altars I would reare
9342: Of grassie Terfe, and pile up every Stone
9343: Of lustre from the brook, in memorie,
9344: Or monument to Ages, and thereon
9345: Offer sweet smelling Gumms & Fruits and Flours:
9346: In yonder nether World where shall I seek
9347: His bright appearances, or footstep trace?
9348: For though I fled him angrie, yet recall'd
9349: To life prolongd and promisd Race, I now
9350: Gladly behold though but his utmost skirts
9351: Of glory, and farr off his steps adore.
9353: *Adam*, thou know'st Heav'n his, and all the Earth
9354: Not this Rock onely; his Omnipresence fills
9355: Land, Sea, and Aire, and every kinde that lives,
9356: Fomented by his virtual power and warmd:
9357: All th' Earth he gave thee to possess and rule,
9358: No despicable gift; surmise not then
9359: His presence to these narrow bounds confin'd
9360: Of Paradise or *Eden*: this had been
9361: Perhaps thy Capital Seate, from whence had spred
9362: All generations, and had hither come
9363: From all the ends of th' Earth, to celebrate
9364: And reverence thee thir great Progenitor.
9365: But this praeeminence thou hast lost, brought down
9366: To dwell on eeven ground now with thy Sons:
9367: Yet doubt not but in Vallie and in Plaine
9368: God is as here, and will be found alike
9369: Present, and of his presence many a signe
9370: Still following thee, still compassing thee round
9371: With goodness and paternal Love, his Face
9372: Express, and of his steps the track Divine.
9373: Which that thou mayst beleeve, and be confirmd,
9374: Ere thou from hence depart, know I am sent
9375: To shew thee what shall come in future dayes
9376: To thee and to thy Ofspring; good with bad
9377: Expect to hear, supernal Grace contending
9378: With sinfulness of Men; thereby to learn
9379: True patience, and to temper joy with fear
9381: By moderation either state to beare,
9382: Prosperous or adverse: so shalt thou lead
9383: Safest thy life, and best prepar'd endure
9384: Thy mortal passage when it comes.  Ascend
9385: This Hill; let *Eve* (for I have drencht her eyes)
9386: Here sleep below while thou to foresight wak'st,
9387: As once thou slepst, while Shee to life was formd.
9389: Ascend, I follow thee, safe Guide, the path
9390: Thou lead'st me, and to the hand of Heav'n submit,
9391: However chast'ning, to the evil turne
9392: My obvious breast, arming to overcom
9393: By suffering, and earne rest from labour won,
9394: If so I may attain.  So both ascend
9395: In the Visions of God:  It was a Hill
9396: Of Paradise the highest, from whose top
9397: The Hemisphere of Earth in cleerest Ken
9398: Stretcht out to amplest reach of prospect lay.
9399: Not higher that Hill nor wider looking round,
9400: Whereon for different cause the Tempter set
9402: To shew him all Earths Kingdomes and thir Glory.
9403: His Eye might there command wherever stood
9404: City of old or modern Fame, the Seat
9405: Of mightiest Empire, from the destind Walls
9410: Down to the golden *Chersones*, or where
9414: *Turchestan*-born; nor could his eye not ken
9415: Th' Empire of *Negus* to his utmost Port
9420: Or thence from *Niger* Flood to *Atlas* Mount
9423: On *Europe* thence, and where *Rome* was to sway
9424: The World: in Spirit perhaps he also saw
9429: Call *El Dorado:* but to nobler sights
9431: Which that false Fruit that promis'd clearer sight
9432: Had bred; then purg'd with Euphrasie and Rue
9433: The visual Nerve, for he had much to see;
9434: And from the Well of Life three drops instill'd.
9435: So deep the power of these Ingredients pierc'd,
9436: Eevn to the inmost seat of mental sight,
9437: That *Adam* now enforc't to close his eyes,
9438: Sunk down and all his Spirits became intranst:
9439: But him the gentle Angel by the hand
9440: Soon rais'd, and his attention thus recall'd.
9441: ¶*Adam*, now ope thine eyes, and first behold
9442: Th' effects which thy original crime hath wrought
9443: In some to spring from thee, who never touch'd
9444: Th' excepted Tree, nor with the Snake conspir'd,
9445: Nor sinn'd thy sin, yet from that sin derive
9446: Corruption to bring forth more violent deeds.
9447: ¶His eyes he op'nd, and beheld a field,
9448: Part arable and tilth, whereon were Sheaves
9449: New reapt, the other part sheep-walks and foulds;
9450: Ith' midst an Altar as the Land-mark stood
9451: Rustic, of grassie sord; thither anon
9452: A sweatie Reaper from his Tillage brought
9453: First Fruits, the green Eare, and the yellow Sheaf,
9454: Uncull'd, as came to hand; a Shepherd next
9455: More meek came with the Firstlings of his Flock
9456: Choicest and best; then sacrificing, laid
9457: The Inwards and thir Fat, with Incense strew'd,
9458: On the cleft Wood, and all due Rites perform'd.
9459: His Offring soon propitious Fire from Heav'n
9460: Consum'd with nimble glance, and grateful steame;
9461: The others not, for his was not sincere;
9462: Whereat hee inlie rag'd, and as they talk'd,
9463: Smote him into the Midriff with a stone
9464: That beat out life; he fell, and deadly pale
9465: Groand out his Soul with gushing bloud effus'd.
9466: Much at that sight was *Adam* in his heart
9467: Dismai'd, and thus in haste to th' Angel cri'd.
9468: ¶O Teacher, some great mischief hath befall'n
9469: To that meek man, who well had sacrific'd;
9470: Is Pietie thus and pure Devotion paid?
9471: ¶T' whom *Michael* thus, hee also mov'd, repli'd.
9472: These two are Brethren, *Adam*, and to come
9473: Out of thy loyns; th' unjust the just hath slain,
9474: For envie that his Brothers Offering found
9475: From Heav'n acceptance; but the bloodie Fact
9476: Will be aveng'd, and th' others Faith approv'd
9477: Loose no reward, though here thou see him die,
9478: Rowling in dust and gore.  To which our Sire.
9479: ¶Alas, both for the deed and for the cause!
9480: But have I now seen Death?  Is this the way
9481: I must return to native dust?  O sight
9482: Of terrour, foul and ugly to behold,
9483: Horrid to think, how horrible to feel!
9484: ¶To whom thus *Michael*.  Death thou hast seen
9485: In his first shape on man; but many shapes
9486: Of Death, and many are the wayes that lead
9487: To his grim Cave, all dismal; yet to sense
9488: More terrible at th' entrance then within.
9489: Some, as thou saw'st, by violent stroke shall die,
9490: By Fire, Flood, Famin, by Intemperance more
9491: In Meats and Drinks, which on the Earth shal bring
9492: Diseases dire, of which a monstrous crew
9493: Before thee shall appear; that thou mayst know
9495: Shall bring on men.  Immediately a place
9496: Before his eyes appeard, sad, noysom, dark,
9497: A Lazar-house it seemd, wherein were laid
9498: Numbers of all diseas'd, all maladies
9499: Of gastly Spasm, or racking torture, qualmes
9500: Of heart-sick Agonie, all feavorous kinds,
9502: Intestin Stone and Ulcer, Colic pangs,
9503: Dropsies, and Asthma's, and Joint-racking Rheums.
9504: Dire was the tossing, deep the groans, despair
9505: Tended the sick busiest from Couch to Couch;
9506: And over them triumphant Death his Dart
9507: Shook, but delaid to strike, though oft invok't
9508: With vows, as thir chief good, and final hope.
9509: Sight so deform what heart of Rock could long
9510: Drie-ey'd behold?  *Adam* could not, but wept,
9511: Though not of Woman born; compassion quell'd
9512: His best of Man, and gave him up to tears
9513: A space, till firmer thoughts restraind excess,
9514: And scarce recovering words his plaint renew'd.
9516: Degraded, to what wretched state reserv'd?
9517: Better end heer unborn.  Why is life giv'n
9518: To be thus wrested from us? rather why
9519: Obtruded on us thus? who if we knew
9520: What we receive, would either not accept
9521: Life offer'd, or soon beg to lay it down,
9522: Glad to be so dismist in peace.  Can thus
9523: Th' Image of God in man created once
9524: So goodly and erect, though faultie since,
9525: To such unsightly sufferings be debas't
9526: Under inhuman pains?  Why should not Man,
9528: In part, from such deformities be free,
9529: And for his Makers Image sake exempt?
9531: Forsook them, when themselves they villifi'd
9532: To serve ungovern'd appetite, and took
9533: His Image whom they serv'd, a brutish vice,
9534: Inductive mainly to the sin of *Eve*.
9535: Therefore so abject is thir punishment,
9536: Disfiguring not Gods likeness, but thir own,
9537: Or if his likeness, by themselves defac't
9538: While they pervert pure Natures healthful rules
9539: To loathsom sickness, worthily, since they
9540: Gods Image did not reverence in themselves.
9541: ¶I yeild it just, said *Adam*, and submit.
9542: But is there yet no other way, besides
9543: These painful passages, how we may come
9544: To Death, and mix with our connatural dust?
9545: ¶There is, said *Michael*, if thou well observe
9546: The rule of not too much, by temperance taught
9547: In what thou eatst and drinkst, seeking from thence
9549: Till many years over thy head return:
9550: So maist thou live, till like ripe Fruit thou drop
9551: Into thy Mothers lap, or be with ease
9552: Gatherd, not harshly pluckt, for death mature:
9553: This is old age; but then thou must outlive
9554: Thy youth, thy strength, thy beauty, which will change
9555: To witherd weak & gray; thy Senses then
9556: Obtuse, all taste of pleasure must forgoe,
9557: To what thou hast, and for the Aire of youth
9558: Hopeful and cheerful, in thy blood will reigne
9559: A melancholly damp of cold and dry
9560: To waigh thy spirits down, and last consume
9561: The Balme of Life.  To whom our Ancestor.
9562: ¶Henceforth I flie not Death, nor would prolong
9563: Life much, bent rather how I may be quit
9564: Fairest and easiest of this combrous charge,
9565: Which I must keep till my appointed day
9566: Of rendring up.  *Michael* to him repli'd.
9567: ¶Nor love thy Life, nor hate; but what thou livst
9568: Live well, how long or short permit to Heav'n:
9569: And now prepare thee for another sight.
9570: ¶He lookd and saw a spacious Plaine, whereon
9571: Were Tents of various hue; by some were herds
9572: Of Cattel grazing: others, whence the sound
9573: Of Instruments that made melodious chime
9574: Was heard, of Harp and Organ; and who moovd
9575: Thir stops and chords was seen: his volant touch
9576: Instinct through all proportions low and high
9577: Fled and pursu'd transverse the resonant fugue.
9578: In other part stood one who at the Forge
9579: Labouring, two massie clods of Iron and Brass
9580: Had melted (whether found where casual fire
9581: Had wasted woods on Mountain or in Vale,
9582: Down to the veins of Earth, thence gliding hot
9583: To som Caves mouth, or whether washt by stream
9584: From underground) the liquid Ore he dreind
9585: Into fit moulds prepar'd; from which he formd
9586: First his own Tooles; then, what might else be wrought
9587: Fulfil or grav'n in mettle.  After these,
9588: But on the hether side a different sort
9589: From the high neighbouring Hills, which was thir Seat,
9590: Down to the Plain descended: by thir guise
9591: Just men they seemd, and all thir study bent
9592: To worship God aright, and know his works
9593: Not hid, nor those things lost which might preserve
9594: Freedom and Peace to men: they on the Plain
9595: Long had not walkt, when from the Tents behold
9596: A Beavie of fair Women, richly gay
9597: In Gems and wanton dress; to the Harp they sung
9598: Soft amorous Ditties, and in dance came on:
9599: The Men though grave, ey'd them, and let thir eyes
9600: Rove without rein, till in the amorous Net
9601: Fast caught, they lik'd, and each his liking chose;
9602: And now of love they treat till th' Eevning Star
9603: Loves Harbinger appeerd; then all in heat
9604: They light the Nuptial Torch, and bid invoke
9605: Hymen, then first to marriage Rites invok't;
9606: With Feast and Musick all the Tents resound.
9607: Such happy interview and fair event
9608: Of love & youth not lost, Songs, Garlands, Flours,
9609: And charming Symphonies attach'd the heart
9610: Of *Adam*, soon enclin'd to admit delight,
9611: The bent of Nature; which he thus express'd.
9612: ¶True opener of mine eyes, prime Angel blest,
9613: Much better seems this Vision, and more hope
9614: Of peaceful dayes portends, then those two past;
9615: Those were of hate and death, or pain much worse,
9616: Here Nature seems fulfilld in all her ends.
9617: ¶To whom thus *Michael*.  Judg not what is best
9618: By pleasure, though to Nature seeming meet,
9619: Created, as thou art, to nobler end
9621: Those Tents thou sawst so pleasant, were the Tents
9622: Of wickedness, wherein shall dwell his Race
9623: Who slew his Brother; studious they appere
9624: Of Arts that polish Life, Inventers rare,
9625: Unmindful of thir Maker, though his Spirit
9626: Taught them, but they his gifts acknowledg'd none.
9627: Yet they a beauteous ofspring shall beget;
9628: For that fair femal Troop thou sawst, that seemd
9629: Of Goddesses, so blithe, so smooth, so gay,
9630: Yet empty of all good wherein consists
9631: Womans domestic honour and chief praise;
9632: Bred onely and completed to the taste
9633: Of lustful apperence, to sing, to dance,
9634: To dress, and troule the Tongue, and roule the Eye.
9635: To these that sober Race of Men, whose lives
9636: Religious titl'd them the Sons of God,
9637: Shall yeild up all thir vertue, all thir fame
9638: Ignobly, to the trains and to the smiles
9639: Of these fair Atheists, and now swim in joy,
9640: (Erelong to swim at larg) and laugh; for which
9641: The world erelong a world of tears must weepe.
9642: ¶To whom thus *Adam* of short joy bereft.
9643: O pittie and shame, that they who to live well
9644: Enterd so faire, should turn aside to tread
9645: Paths indirect, or in the mid way faint!
9646: But still I see the tenor of Mans woe
9647: Holds on the same, from Woman to begin.
9649: Said th' Angel, who should better hold his place
9650: By wisdome, and superiour gifts receavd.
9651: But now prepare thee for another Scene.
9652: ¶He lookd and saw wide Territorie spred
9653: Before him, Towns, and rural works between,
9654: Cities of Men with lofty Gates and Towrs,
9655: Concours in Arms, fierce Faces threatning Warr,
9656: Giants of mightie Bone, and bould emprise;
9657: Part wield thir Arms, part courb the foaming Steed,
9658: Single or in Array of Battel rang'd
9659: Both Horse and Foot, nor idely mustring stood;
9660: One way a Band select from forage drives
9661: A herd of Beeves, faire Oxen and faire Kine
9662: From a fat Meddow ground; or fleecy Flock,
9663: Ewes and thir bleating Lambs over the Plaine,
9664: Thir Bootie; scarce with Life the Shepherds flye,
9665: But call in aide, which tacks a bloody Fray;
9666: With cruel Tournament the Squadrons joine;
9667: Where Cattel pastur'd late, now scatterd lies
9668: With Carcasses and Arms th' ensanguind Field
9669: Deserted: Others to a Citie strong
9670: Lay Siege, encampt; by Batterie, Scale, and Mine,
9671: Assaulting; others from the Wall defend
9672: With Dart and Jav'lin, Stones and sulfurous Fire;
9673: On each hand slaughter and gigantic deeds.
9674: In other part the scepter'd Haralds call
9675: To Council in the Citie Gates: anon
9676: Grey-headed men and grave, with Warriours mixt,
9677: Assemble, and Harangues are heard, but soon
9678: In factious opposition, till at last
9679: Of middle Age one rising, eminent
9680: In wise deport, spake much of Right and Wrong,
9681: Of Justice, of Religion, Truth and Peace,
9682: And Judgement from above: him old and young
9683: Exploded, and had seiz'd with violent hands,
9684: Had not a Cloud descending snatch'd him thence
9685: Unseen amid the throng: so violence
9687: Through all the Plain, and refuge none was found.
9688: *Adam* was all in tears, and to his guide
9689: Lamenting turnd full sad; O what are these,
9690: Deaths Ministers, not Men, who thus deal Death
9692: Ten thousand fould the sin of him who slew
9693: His Brother; for of whom such massacher
9694: Make they but of thir Brethren, men of men?
9695: But who was that Just Man, whom had not Heav'n
9696: Rescu'd, had in his Righteousness bin lost?
9697: ¶To whom thus *Michael*; These are the product
9698: Of those ill-mated Marriages thou saw'st;
9699: Where good with bad were matcht, who of themselves
9700: Abhor to joyn; and by imprudence mixt,
9701: Produce prodigious Births of bodie or mind.
9702: Such were these Giants, men of high renown;
9703: For in those dayes Might onely shall be admir'd,
9704: And Valour and Heroic Vertu call'd;
9705: To overcome in Battel, and subdue
9706: Nations, and bring home spoils with infinite
9707: Man-slaughter, shall be held the highest pitch
9708: Of human Glorie, and for Glorie done
9709: Of triumph, to be styl'd great Conquerours,
9710: Patrons of Mankind, Gods, and Sons of Gods,
9711: Destroyers rightlier call'd and Plagues of men.
9712: Thus Fame shall be achiev'd, renown on Earth,
9713: And what most merits fame in silence hid.
9714: But hee the seventh from thee, whom thou beheldst
9715: The onely righteous in a World perverse,
9716: And therefore hated, therefore so beset
9717: With Foes for daring single to be just,
9718: And utter odious Truth, that God would come
9719: To judge them with his Saints: Him the most High
9720: Rapt in a balmie Cloud with winged Steeds
9721: Did, as thou sawst, receave, to walk with God
9722: High in Salvation and the Climes of bliss,
9723: Exempt from Death; to shew thee what reward
9724: Awaits the good, the rest what punishment;
9725: Which now direct thine eyes and soon behold.
9726: ¶He look'd, & saw the face of things quite chang'd;
9727: The brazen Throat of Warr had ceast to roar,
9728: All now was turn'd to jollitie and game,
9729: To luxurie and riot, feast and dance,
9731: Rape or Adulterie, where passing faire
9732: Allurd them; thence from Cups to civil Broiles.
9733: At length a Reverend Sire among them came,
9734: And of thir doings great dislike declar'd,
9735: And testifi'd against thir wayes; hee oft
9737: Triumphs or Festivals, and to them preachd
9738: Conversion and Repentance, as to Souls
9740: But all in vain: which when he saw, he ceas'd
9741: Contending, and remov'd his Tents farr off;
9742: Then from the Mountain hewing Timber tall,
9743: Began to build a Vessel of huge bulk,
9744: Measur'd by Cubit, length, & breadth, and highth,
9745: Smeard round with Pitch, and in the side a dore
9746: Contriv'd, and of provisions laid in large
9747: For Man and Beast: when loe a wonder strange!
9748: Of everie Beast, and Bird, and Insect small
9749: Came seavens, and pairs, and enterd in, as taught
9750: Thir order; last the Sire, and his three Sons
9751: With thir four Wives, and God made fast the dore.
9752: Meanwhile the Southwind rose, & with black wings
9753: Wide hovering, all the Clouds together drove
9754: From under Heav'n; the Hills to their supplie
9755: Vapour, and Exhalation dusk and moist,
9756: Sent up amain; and now the thick'nd Skie
9757: Like a dark Ceeling stood; down rush'd the Rain
9758: Impetuous, and continu'd till the Earth
9759: No more was seen; the floating Vessel swum
9760: Uplifted; and secure with beaked prow
9761: Rode tilting o're the Waves, all dwellings else
9762: Flood overwhelmd, and them with all thir pomp
9763: Deep under water rould; Sea cover'd Sea,
9764: Sea without shoar; and in thir Palaces
9765: Where luxurie late reign'd, Sea-monsters whelp'd
9766: And stabl'd; of Mankind, so numerous late,
9767: All left, in one small bottom swum imbark't.
9768: How didst thou grieve then, *Adam*, to behold
9769: The end of all thy Ofspring, end so sad,
9771: Of tears and sorrow a Floud thee also drown'd,
9772: And sunk thee as thy Sons; till gently reard
9773: By th' Angel, on thy feet thou stoodst at last,
9774: Though comfortless, as when a Father mourns
9775: His Childern, all in view destroyd at once;
9776: And scarce to th' Angel utterdst thus thy plaint.
9777: ¶O Visions ill foreseen! better had I
9778: Liv'd ignorant of future, so had borne
9779: My part of evil onely, each dayes lot
9780: Anough to bear; those now, that were dispenst
9781: The burd'n of many Ages, on me light
9782: At once, by my foreknowledge gaining Birth
9783: Abortive, to torment me ere thir being,
9784: With thought that they must be.  Let no man seek
9785: Henceforth to be foretold what shall befall
9786: Him or his Childern, evil he may be sure,
9787: Which neither his foreknowing can prevent,
9788: And hee the future evil shall no less
9789: In apprehension then in substance feel
9790: Grievous to bear: but that care now is past,
9791: Man is not whom to warne: those few escap't
9792: Famin and anguish will at last consume
9793: Wandring that watrie Desert: I had hope
9794: When violence was ceas't, and Warr on Earth,
9795: All would have then gon well, peace would have crownd
9796: With length of happy days the race of man;
9797: But I was farr deceav'd; for now I see
9798: Peace to corrupt no less then Warr to waste.
9799: How comes it thus? unfould, Celestial Guide,
9800: And whether here the Race of man will end.
9801: To whom thus *Michael*.  Those whom last thou sawst
9802: In triumph and luxurious wealth, are they
9803: First seen in acts of prowess eminent
9804: And great exploits, but of true vertu void;
9805: Who having spilt much blood, and don much waste
9807: Fame in the World, high titles, and rich prey,
9808: Shall change thir course to pleasure, ease, and sloth,
9809: Surfet, and lust, till wantonness and pride
9810: Raise out of friendship hostil deeds in Peace.
9811: The conquerd also, and enslav'd by Warr
9812: Shall with thir freedom lost all vertu loose
9813: And feare of God, from whom thir pietie feign'd
9814: In sharp contest of Battel found no aide
9815: Against invaders; therefore coold in zeale
9816: Thenceforth shall practice how to live secure,
9817: Worldlie or dissolute, on what thir Lords
9818: Shall leave them to enjoy; for th' Earth shall bear
9819: More then anough, that temperance may be tri'd:
9820: So all shall turn degenerate, all deprav'd,
9821: Justice and Temperance, Truth and Faith forgot;
9822: One Man except, the onely Son of light
9823: In a dark Age, against example good,
9824: Against allurement, custom, and a World
9825: Offended; fearless of reproach and scorn,
9826: Or violence, hee of thir wicked wayes
9827: Shall them admonish, and before them set
9828: The paths of righteousness, how much more safe,
9829: And full of peace, denouncing wrauth to come
9830: On thir impenitence; and shall returne
9831: Of them derided, but of God observd
9832: The one just Man alive; by his command
9833: Shall build a wondrous Ark, as thou beheldst,
9834: To save himself and houshold from amidst
9835: A World devote to universal rack.
9836: No sooner hee with them of Man and Beast
9837: Select for life shall in the Ark be lodg'd,
9838: And shelterd round, but all the Cataracts
9839: Of Heav'n set open on the Earth shall powre
9840: Raine day and night, all fountaines of the Deep
9841: Broke up, shall heave the Ocean to usurp
9842: Beyond all bounds, till inundation rise
9843: Above the highest Hills: then shall this Mount
9844: Of Paradise by might of Waves be moovd
9845: Out of his place, pushd by the horned floud,
9846: With all his verdure spoil'd, and Trees adrift
9847: Down the great River to the op'ning Gulf,
9848: And there take root an Iland salt and bare,
9849: The haunt of Seales and Orcs, and Sea-mews clang.
9850: To teach thee that God attributes to place
9851: No sanctitie, if none be thither brought
9852: By Men who there frequent, or therein dwell.
9853: And now what further shall ensue, behold.
9854: ¶He lookd, and saw the Ark hull on the floud,
9855: Which now abated, for the Clouds were fled,
9856: Drivn by a keen North-winde, that blowing drie
9857: Wrinkl'd the face of Deluge, as decai'd;
9858: And the cleer Sun on his wide watrie Glass
9859: Gaz'd hot, and of the fresh Wave largely drew,
9860: As after thirst, which made thir flowing shrink
9861: From standing lake to tripping ebbe, that stole
9862: With soft foot towards the deep, who now had stopt
9863: His Sluces, as the Heav'n his windows shut.
9864: The Ark no more now flotes, but seems on ground
9865: Fast on the top of som high mountain fixt.
9866: And now the tops of Hills as Rocks appeer;
9867: With clamor thence the rapid Currents drive
9868: Towards the retreating Sea thir furious tyde.
9869: Forthwith from out the Arke a Raven flies,
9870: And after him, the surer messenger,
9871: A Dove sent forth once and agen to spie
9872: Green Tree or ground whereon his foot may light;
9873: The second time returning, in his Bill
9874: An Olive leafe he brings, pacific signe:
9875: Anon drie ground appeers, and from his Arke
9876: The ancient Sire descends with all his Train;
9877: Then with uplifted hands, and eyes devout,
9878: Grateful to Heav'n, over his head beholds
9879: A dewie Cloud, and in the Cloud a Bow
9880: Conspicuous with three lifted colours gay,
9881: Betok'ning peace from God, and Cov'nant new.
9882: Whereat the heart of *Adam* erst so sad
9883: Greatly rejoyc'd, and thus his joy broke forth.
9884: ¶O thou that future things canst represent
9885: As present, Heav'nly instructer, I revive
9886: At this last sight, assur'd that Man shall live
9887: With all the Creatures, and thir seed preserve.
9888: Farr less I now lament for one whole World
9889: Of wicked Sons destroyd, then I rejoyce
9890: For one Man found so perfet and so just,
9891: That God voutsafes to raise another World
9892: From him, and all his anger to forget.
9893: But say, what mean those colourd streaks in Heavn,
9894: Distended as the Brow of God appeas'd,
9895: Or serve they as a flourie verge to binde
9896: The fluid skirts of that same watrie Cloud,
9897: Least it again dissolve and showr the Earth?
9898: ¶To whom th' Archangel.  Dextrously thou aim'st;
9899: So willingly doth God remit his Ire,
9900: Though late repenting him of Man deprav'd,
9901: Griev'd at his heart, when looking down he saw
9902: The whole Earth fill'd with violence, and all flesh
9903: Corrupting each thir way; yet those remoov'd,
9904: Such grace shall one just Man find in his sight,
9905: That he relents, not to blot out mankind,
9906: And makes a Covenant never to destroy
9907: The Earth again by flood, nor let the Sea
9908: Surpass his bounds, nor Rain to drown the World
9909: With Man therein or Beast; but when he brings
9910: Over the Earth a Cloud, will therein set
9911: His triple-colour'd Bow, whereon to look
9912: And call to mind his Cov'nant: Day and Night,
9913: Seed time and Harvest, Heat and hoary Frost
9914: Shall hold thir course, till fire purge all things new,
9915: Both Heav'n and Earth, wherein the just shall dwell.
9916: Thus thou hast seen one World begin and end;
9917: And Man as from a second stock proceed.
9918: Much thou hast yet to see, but I perceave
9919: Thy mortal sight to faile; objects divine
9920: Must needs impaire and wearie human sense:
9921: Henceforth what is to com I will relate,
9922: Thou therefore give due audience, and attend.
9923: This second sours of Men, while yet but few,
9924: And while the dread of judgement past remains
9925: Fresh in thir mindes, fearing the Deitie,
9926: With some regard to what is just and right
9927: Shall lead thir lives, and multiplie apace,
9928: Labouring the soile, and reaping plenteous crop,
9929: Corn wine and oyle; and from the herd or flock,
9930: Oft sacrificing Bullock, Lamb, or Kid,
9931: With large Wine-offerings pour'd, and sacred Feast
9932: Shal spend thir dayes in joy unblam'd, and dwell
9933: Long time in peace by Families and Tribes
9934: Under paternal rule; till one shall rise
9935: Of proud ambitious heart, who not content
9938: Over his brethren, and quite dispossess
9939: Concord and law of Nature from the Earth;
9940: Hunting (and Men not Beasts shall be his game)
9941: With Warr and hostile snare such as refuse
9943: A mightie Hunter thence he shall be styl'd
9944: Before the Lord, as in despite of Heav'n,
9945: Or from Heav'n claming second Sovrantie;
9946: And from Rebellion shall derive his name,
9947: Though of Rebellion others he accuse.
9948: Hee with a crew, whom like Ambition joyns
9949: With him or under him to tyrannize,
9950: Marching from *Eden* towards the West, shall finde
9951: The Plain, wherein a black bituminous gurge
9952: Boiles out from under ground, the mouth of Hell;
9953: Of Brick, and of that stuff they cast to build
9954: A Citie & Towre, whose top may reach to Heav'n;
9955: And get themselves a name, least far disperst
9956: In foraign Lands thir memorie be lost,
9957: Regardless whether good or evil fame.
9958: But God who oft descends to visit men
9959: Unseen, and through thir habitations walks
9960: To mark thir doings, them beholding soon,
9961: Comes down to see thir Citie, ere the Tower
9962: Obstruct Heav'n Towrs, and in derision sets
9963: Upon thir Tongues a various Spirit to rase
9964: Quite out thir Native Language, and instead
9965: To sow a jangling noise of words unknown:
9966: Forthwith a hideous gabble rises loud
9967: Among the Builders; each to other calls
9968: Not understood, till hoarse, and all in rage,
9969: As mockt they storm; great laughter was in Heav'n
9970: And looking down, to see the hubbub strange
9971: And hear the din; thus was the building left
9972: Ridiculous, and the work Confusion nam'd.
9974: O execrable Son so to aspire
9975: Above his Brethren, to himself affirming
9976: Authoritie usurpt, from God not giv'n:
9977: He gave us onely over Beast, Fish, Fowl
9978: Dominion absolute; that right we hold
9979: By his donation; but Man over men
9980: He made not Lord; such title to himself
9981: Reserving, human left from human free.
9982: But this Usurper his encroachment proud
9983: Stayes not on Man; to God his Tower intends
9984: Siege and defiance: Wretched man! what food
9985: Will he convey up thither to sustain
9986: Himself and his rash Armie, where thin Aire
9987: Above the Clouds will pine his entrails gross,
9988: And famish him of Breath, if not of Bread?
9990: That Son, who on the quiet state of men
9991: Such trouble brought, affecting to subdue
9993: Since thy original lapse, true Libertie
9994: Is lost, which alwayes with right Reason dwells
9995: Twinn'd, and from her hath no dividual being:
9996: Reason in man obscur'd, or not obeyd,
9998: And upstart Passions catch the Government
9999: From Reason, and to servitude reduce
10000: Man till then free.  Therefore since hee permits
10001: Within himself unworthie Powers to reign
10002: Over free Reason, God in Judgement just
10003: Subjects him from without to violent Lords;
10005: His outward freedom: Tyrannie must be,
10006: Though to the Tyrant thereby no excuse.
10007: Yet somtimes Nations will decline so low
10008: From vertue, which is reason, that no wrong,
10009: But Justice, and some fatal curse annext
10010: Deprives them of thir outward libertie,
10011: Thir inward lost: Witness th' irreverent Son
10012: Of him who built the Ark, who for the shame
10013: Don to his Father, heard this heavie curse,
10014: *Servant of Servants*, on his vitious Race.
10015: Thus will this latter, as the former World,
10016: Still tend from bad to worse, till God at last
10018: His presence from among them, and avert
10019: His holy Eyes; resolving from thenceforth
10020: To leave them to thir own polluted wayes;
10021: And one peculiar Nation to select
10022: From all the rest, of whom to be invok'd,
10023: A Nation from one faithful man to spring:
10024: Him on this side *Euphrates* yet residing,
10025: Bred up in Idol-worship; O that men
10026: (Canst thou believe?) should be so stupid grown,
10027: While yet the Patriark liv'd, who scap'd the Flood,
10028: As to forsake the living God, and fall
10029: To-worship thir own work in Wood and Stone
10030: For Gods! yet him God the most High voutsafes
10031: To call by Vision from his Fathers house,
10032: His kindred and false Gods, into a Land
10033: Which he will shew him, and from him will raise
10034: A mightie Nation, and upon him showre
10035: His benediction so, that in his Seed
10036: All Nations shall be blest; hee straight obeys,
10037: Not knowing to what Land, yet firm believes:
10038: I see him, but thou canst not, with what Faith
10039: He leaves his Gods, his Friends, and native Soile
10041: To *Haran*, after him a cumbrous Train
10042: Of Herds and Flocks, and numerous servitude;
10043: Not wandring poor, but trusting all his wealth
10044: With God, who call'd him, in a land unknown.
10045: *Canaan* he now attains, I see his Tents
10046: Pitcht about *Sechem*, and the neighbouring Plaine
10047: Of *Moreb* there by promise he receaves
10048: Gift to his Progenie of all that Land;
10049: From *Hamath* Northward to the Desert South
10050: (Things by thir names I call, though yet unnam'd)
10051: From *Hermon* East to the great Western Sea,
10052: Mount *Hermon*, yonder Sea, each place behold
10053: In prospect, as I point them; on the shoare
10055: *Jordan*, true limit Eastward; but his Sons
10056: Shall dwell to *Senir*, that long ridge of Hills.
10057: This ponder, that all Nations of the Earth
10058: Shall in his Seed be blessed; by that Seed
10059: Is meant thy great deliverer, who shall bruise
10060: The Serpents head; whereof to thee anon
10061: Plainlier shall be reveald.  This Patriarch blest,
10062: Whom *Faithful Abraham* due time shall call,
10063: A Son, and of his Son a Grand-childe leaves,
10064: Like him in faith, in wisdom, and renown;
10065: The Grandchilde with twelve Sons increast, departs
10066: From *Canaan*, to a Land hereafter call'd
10068: See where it flows, disgorging at seaven mouthes
10069: Into the Sea: to sojourn in that Land
10070: He comes invited by a yonger Son
10071: In time of dearth, a Son whose worthy deeds
10072: Raise him to be the second in that Realme
10073: Of *Pharao*: there he dies, and leaves his Race
10074: Growing into a Nation, and now grown
10075: Suspected to a sequent King, who seeks
10076: To stop thir overgrowth, as inmate guests
10077: Too numerous; whence of guests he makes them slaves
10078: Inhospitably, and kills thir infant Males:
10079: Till by two brethren (those two brethren call
10080: *Moses* and *Aaron*) sent from God to claime
10081: His people from enthralment, they return
10082: With glory and spoile back to thir promis'd Land.
10083: But first the lawless Tyrant, who denies
10084: To know thir God, or message to regard,
10085: Must be compelld by Signes and Judgements dire;
10086: To blood unshed the Rivers must be turnd,
10087: Frogs, Lice and Flies must all his Palace fill
10088: With loath'd intrusion, and fill all the land;
10089: His Cattel must of Rot and Murren die,
10090: Botches and blaines must all his flesh imboss,
10091: And all his people; Thunder mixt with Haile,
10092: Haile mixt with fire must rend th' *Egyptian* Skie
10093: And wheel on th' Earth, devouring where it rouls;
10094: What it devours not, Herb, or Fruit, or Graine,
10095: A darksom Cloud of Locusts swarming down
10096: Must eat, and on the ground leave nothing green:
10097: Darkness must overshadow all his bounds,
10098: Palpable darkness, and blot out three dayes;
10099: Last with one midnight stroke all the first-born
10100: Of *Egypt* must lie dead.  Thus with ten wounds
10101: This River-dragon tam'd at length submits
10102: To let his sojourners depart, and oft
10103: Humbles his stubborn heart, but still as Ice
10104: More hard'nd after thaw, till in his rage
10105: Pursuing whom he late dismissd, the Sea
10106: Swallows him with his Host, but them lets pass
10107: As on drie land between two christal walls,
10108: Aw'd by the rod of *Moses* so to stand
10109: Divided, till his rescu'd gain thir shoar:
10110: Such wondrous power God to his Saint will lend,
10111: Though present in his Angel, who shall goe
10112: Before them in a Cloud, and Pillar of Fire,
10113: To guide them in thir journey, and remove
10114: Behinde them, while th' obdurat King pursues:
10115: All night he will pursue, but his approach
10116: Darkness defends between till morning Watch;
10117: Then through the Firey Pillar and the Cloud
10118: God looking forth will trouble all his Host
10119: And craze thir Chariot wheels: when by command
10120: *Moses* once more his potent Rod extends
10121: Over the Sea; the Sea his Rod obeys;
10122: On thir imbattelld ranks the Waves return,
10123: And overwhelm thir Warr: the Race elect
10124: Safe towards *Canaan* from the shoar advance
10125: Through the wilde Desert, not the readiest way,
10127: Warr terrifie them inexpert, and feare
10128: Return them back to *Egypt*, choosing rather
10129: Inglorious life with servitude; for life
10130: To noble and ignoble is more sweet
10131: Untraind in Armes, where rashness leads not on.
10132: This also shall they gain by thir delay
10133: In the wide Wilderness, there they shall found
10134: Thir government, and thir great Senate choose
10135: Through the twelve Tribes, to rule by Laws ordaind:
10136: God from the Mount of *Sinai*, whose gray top
10137: Shall tremble, he descending, will himself
10138: In Thunder Lightning and loud Trumpets sound
10139: Ordaine them Lawes; part such as appertaine
10140: To civil Justice, part religious Rites
10141: Of sacrifice, informing them, by types
10142: And shadowes, of that destind Seed to bruise
10143: The Serpent, by what meanes he shall achieve
10144: Mankinds deliverance.  But the voice of God
10145: To mortal eare is dreadful; they beseech
10146: That *Moses* might report to them his will,
10147: And terror cease; he grants them thir desire,
10148: Instructed that to God is no access
10149: Without Mediator, whose high Office now
10151: One greater, of whose day he shall foretell,
10152: And all the Prophets in thir Age the times
10153: Of great *Messiah* shall sing.  Thus Laws and Rites
10154: Establisht, such delight hath God in Men
10155: Obedient to his will, that he voutsafes
10156: Among them to set up his Tabernacle,
10157: The holy One with mortal Men to dwell:
10158: By his prescript a Sanctuary is fram'd
10159: Of Cedar, overlaid with Gold, therein
10160: An Ark, and in the Ark his Testimony,
10161: The Records of his Cov'nant, over these
10162: A Mercie-seat of Gold between the wings
10163: Of two bright Cherubim, before him burn
10164: Seaven Lamps as in a Zodiac representing
10165: The Heav'nly fires; over the Tent a Cloud
10166: Shall rest by Day, a fierie gleame by Night,
10167: Save when they journie, and at length they come,
10168: Conducted by his Angel to the Land
10169: Promisd to *Abraham* and his Seed: the rest
10170: Were long to tell, how many Battels fought,
10171: How many Kings destroyd, and Kingdoms won,
10172: Or how the Sun shall in mid Heav'n stand still
10173: A day entire, and Nights due course adjourne,
10174: Mans voice commanding, Sun in *Gibeon* stand,
10175: And thou Moon in the vale of *Aialon*,
10176: Till *Israel* overcome; so call the third
10177: From *Abraham*, Son of *Isaac*, and from him
10178: His whole descent, who thus shall *Canaan* win.
10180: Enlightner of my darkness, gracious things
10181: Thou hast reveald, those chiefly which concerne
10182: Just *Abraham* and his Seed: now first I finde
10183: Mine eyes true op'ning, and my heart much eas'd,
10184: Erwhile perplext with thoughts what would becom
10185: Of mee and all Mankind; but now I see
10186: His day, in whom all Nations shall be blest,
10187: Favour unmerited by me, who sought
10189: This yet I apprehend not, why to those
10190: Among whom God will deigne to dwell on Earth
10191: So many and so various Laws are giv'n;
10192: So many Laws argue so many sins
10193: Among them; how can God with such reside?
10194: ¶To whom thus *Michael*.  Doubt not but that sin
10195: Will reign among them, as of thee begot;
10196: And therefore was Law given them to evince
10197: Thir natural pravitie, by stirring up
10198: Sin against Law to fight; that when they see
10199: Law can discover sin, but not remove,
10200: Save by those shadowie expiations weak,
10201: The bloud of Bulls and Goats, they may conclude
10202: Some bloud more precious must be paid for Man,
10203: Just for unjust, that in such righteousness
10204: To them by Faith imputed, they may finde
10206: Of Conscience, which the Law by Ceremonies
10207: Cannot appease, nor Man the moral part
10208: Perform, and not performing cannot live.
10209: So Law appears imperfet, and but giv'n
10210: With purpose to resign them in full time
10211: Up to a better Cov'nant, disciplin'd
10212: From shadowie Types to Truth, from Flesh to Spirit,
10213: From imposition of strict Laws, to free
10214: Acceptance of large Grace, from servil fear
10215: To filial, works of Law to works of Faith.
10216: And therefore shall not *Moses*, though of God
10217: Highly belov'd, being but the Minister
10218: Of Law, his people into *Canaan* lead;
10220: His Name and Office bearing, who shall quell
10221: The adversarie Serpent, and bring back
10222: Through the worlds wilderness long wanderd man
10223: Safe to eternal Paradise of rest.
10224: Meanwhile they in thir earthly *Canaan* plac't
10225: Long time shall dwell and prosper, but when sins
10227: Provoking God to raise them enemies:
10228: From whom as oft he saves them penitent
10229: By Judges first, then under Kings; of whom
10230: The second, both for pietie renownd
10231: And puissant deeds, a promise shall receive
10233: For ever shall endure; the like shall sing
10234: All Prophecie, That of the Royal Stock
10235: Of *David* (so I name this King) shall rise
10236: A Son, the Womans Seed to thee foretold,
10237: Foretold to *Abraham*, as in whom shall trust
10238: All Nations, and to Kings foretold, of Kings
10239: The last, for of his Reign shall be no end.
10240: But first a long succession must ensue,
10241: And his next Son for Wealth and Wisdom fam'd,
10242: The clouded Ark of God till then in Tents
10243: Wandring, shall in a glorious Temple enshrine.
10244: Such follow him, as shall be registerd
10245: Part good, part bad, of bad the longer scrowle,
10246: Whose foul Idolatries, and other faults
10247: Heapt to the popular summe, will so incense
10248: God, as to leave them, and expose thir Land,
10249: Thir Citie, his Temple, and his holy Ark
10250: With all his sacred things, a scorn and prey
10251: To that proud Citie, whose high Walls thou saw'st
10253: There in captivitie he lets them dwell
10254: The space of seventie years, then brings them back,
10255: Remembring mercie, and his Cov'nant sworn
10256: To *David*, stablisht as the dayes of Heav'n.
10257: Returnd from *Babylon* by leave of Kings
10258: Thir Lords, whom God dispos'd, the house of God
10259: They first re-edifie, and for a while
10260: In mean estate live moderate, till grown
10261: In wealth and multitude, factious they grow;
10262: But first among the Priests dissension springs,
10263: Men who attend the Altar, and should most
10264: Endeavour Peace: thir strife pollution brings
10265: Upon the Temple it self: at last they seise
10266: The Scepter, and regard not *Davids* Sons,
10267: Then loose it to a stranger, that the true
10269: Barr'd of his right; yet at his Birth a Starr
10270: Unseen before in Heav'n proclaims him com,
10271: And guides the Eastern Sages, who enquire
10272: His place, to offer Incense, Myrrh, and Gold;
10273: His place of birth a solemn Angel tells
10274: To simple Shepherds, keeping watch by night;
10275: They gladly thither haste, and by a Quire
10276: Of squadrond Angels hear his Carol sung.
10277: A Virgin is his Mother, but his Sire
10278: The Power of the most High; he shall ascend
10279: The Throne hereditarie, and bound his Reign
10280: With earths wide bounds, his glory with the Heav'ns.
10282: Surcharg'd, as had like grief bin dew'd in tears,
10283: Without the vent of words, which these he breathd.
10285: Of utmost hope! now clear I understand
10286: What oft my steddiest thoughts have searcht in vain,
10287: Why our great expectation should be call'd
10288: The seed of Woman: Virgin Mother, Haile,
10289: High in the love of Heav'n, yet from my Loynes
10290: Thou shalt proceed, and from thy Womb the Son
10291: Of God most High; So God with man unites.
10292: Needs must the Serpent now his capital bruise
10293: Expect with mortal paine: say where and when
10294: Thir fight, what stroke shall bruise the Victors heel.
10295: ¶To whom thus *Michael*.  Dream not of thir fight,
10296: As of a Duel, or the local wounds
10297: Of head or heel: not therefore joynes the Son
10298: Manhood to God-head, with more strength to foil
10299: Thy enemie; nor so is overcome
10300: *Satan*, whose fall from Heav'n, a deadlier bruise,
10301: Disabl'd not to give thee thy deaths wound:
10302: Which hee, who comes thy Saviour, shall recure,
10303: Not by destroying *Satan*, but his works
10304: In thee and in thy Seed: nor can this be,
10305: But by fulfilling that which thou didst want,
10306: Obedience to the Law of God, impos'd
10307: On penaltie of death, and suffering death,
10308: The penaltie to thy transgression due,
10309: And due to theirs which out of thine will grow:
10310: So onely can high Justice rest appaid.
10311: The Law of God exact he shall fulfill
10312: Both by obedience and by love, though love
10313: Alone fulfill the Law; thy punishment
10314: He shall endure by coming in the Flesh
10315: To a reproachful life and cursed death,
10316: Proclaiming Life to all who shall believe
10317: In his redemption, and that his obedience
10318: Imputed becomes theirs by Faith, his merits
10319: To save them, not thir own, though legal works.
10320: For this he shall live hated, be blasphem'd,
10321: Seis'd on by force, judg'd, and to death condemnd
10322: A shameful and accurst, naild to the Cross
10323: By his own Nation, slaine for bringing Life;
10324: But to the Cross he nailes thy Enemies,
10325: The Law that is against thee, and the sins
10326: Of all mankinde, with him there crucifi'd,
10327: Never to hurt them more who rightly trust
10328: In this his satisfaction; so he dies,
10329: But soon revives, Death over him no power
10330: Shall long usurp; ere the third dawning light
10331: Returne, the Starres of Morn shall see him rise
10332: Out of his grave, fresh as the dawning light,
10333: Thy ransom paid, which Man from death redeems,
10334: His death for Man, as many as offerd Life
10335: Neglect not, and the benefit imbrace
10336: By Faith not void of works: this God-like act
10337: Annuls thy doom, the death thou shouldst have dy'd,
10338: In sin for ever lost from life; this act
10339: Shall bruise the head of *Satan*, crush his strength
10340: Defeating Sin and Death, his two maine armes,
10341: And fix farr deeper in his head thir stings
10342: Then temporal death shall bruise the Victors heel,
10343: Or theirs whom he redeems, a death like sleep,
10344: A gentle wafting to immortal Life.
10345: Nor after resurrection shall he stay
10346: Longer on Earth then certaine times to appeer
10347: To his Disciples, Men who in his Life
10348: Still follow'd him; to them shall leave in charge
10349: To teach all nations what of him they learn'd
10350: And his Salvation, them who shall beleeve
10351: Baptizing in the profluent streame, the signe
10352: Of washing them from guilt of sin to Life
10353: Pure, and in mind prepar'd, if so befall,
10354: For death, like that which the redeemer dy'd.
10355: All Nations they shall teach; for from that day
10356: Not onely to the Sons of *Abrahams* Loines
10357: Salvation shall be Preacht, but to the Sons
10358: Of *Abrahams* Faith wherever through the world;
10359: So in his seed all Nations shall be blest.
10360: Then to the Heav'n of Heav'ns he shall ascend
10361: With victory, triumphing through the aire
10362: Over his foes and thine; there shall surprise
10363: The Serpent, Prince of aire, and drag in Chaines
10364: Through all his realme, & there confounded leave;
10365: Then enter into glory, and resume
10366: His Seat at Gods right hand, exalted high
10367: Above all names in Heav'n; and thence shall come,
10368: When this worlds dissolution shall be ripe,
10369: With glory and power to judge both quick & dead,
10370: To judge th' unfaithful dead, but to reward
10371: His faithful, and receave them into bliss,
10372: Whether in Heav'n or Earth, for then the Earth
10373: Shall all be Paradise, far happier place
10374: Then this of *Eden*, and far happier daies.
10376: As at the Worlds great period; and our Sire
10377: Replete with joy and wonder thus repli'd.
10379: That all this good of evil shall produce,
10380: And evil turn to good; more wonderful
10381: Then that which by creation first brought forth
10382: Light out of darkness! full of doubt I stand,
10383: Whether I should repent me now of sin
10384: By mee done and occasiond, or rejoyce
10385: Much more, that much more good thereof shall spring,
10386: To God more glory, more good will to Men
10387: From God, and over wrauth grace shall abound.
10388: But say, if our deliverer up to Heav'n
10389: Must reascend, what will betide the few
10390: His faithful, left among th' unfaithful herd,
10391: The enemies of truth; who then shall guide
10392: His people, who defend? will they not deale
10393: Wors with his followers then with him they dealt?
10394: ¶Be sure they will, said th' Angel; but from Heav'n
10395: Hee to his own a Comforter will send,
10396: The promise of the Father, who shall dwell
10397: His Spirit within them, and the Law of Faith
10398: Working through love, upon thir hearts shall write,
10399: To guide them in all truth, and also arme
10400: With spiritual Armour, able to resist
10401: *Satans* assaults, and quench his fierie darts
10402: What Man can do against them, not affraid,
10403: Though to the death, against such cruelties
10405: And oft supported so as shall amaze
10406: Thir proudest persecuters: for the Spirit
10407: Powrd first on his Apostles, whom he sends
10408: To evangelize the Nations, then on all
10409: Baptiz'd, shall them with wondrous gifts endue
10410: To speak all Tongues, and do all Miracles,
10411: As did thir Lord before them.  Thus they win
10412: Great numbers of each Nation to receave
10413: With joy the tidings brought from Heav'n: at length
10414: Thir Ministry perform'd, and race well run,
10415: Thir doctrine and thir story written left,
10416: They die; but in thir room, as they forewarne,
10417: Wolves shall succeed for teachers, grievous Wolves,
10418: Who all the sacred mysteries of Heav'n
10419: To thir own vile advantages shall turne
10420: Of lucre and ambition, and the truth
10422: Left onely in those written Records pure,
10423: Though not but by the Spirit understood.
10424: Then shall they seek to avail themselves of names,
10425: Places and titles, and with these to joine
10426: Secular power, though feigning still to act
10428: The Spirit of God, promisd alike and giv'n
10429: To all Beleevers; and from that pretense,
10430: Spiritual Lawes by carnal power shall force
10431: On every conscience; Laws which none shall finde
10432: Left them inrould, or what the Spirit within
10433: Shall on the heart engrave.  What will they then
10434: But force the Spirit of Grace it self, and binde
10435: His consort Libertie; what, but unbuild
10436: His living Temples, built by Faith to stand,
